HEADLINE: Fewer New York Teen-Agers Have Their First Job

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
Only one in four of New York City's older teen-agers is in the labor force, less than half the rate in the nation as a whole and lower than that of other big cities, Federal statistics show.
Economists and social scientists differ over why so few 16- to 19-year-olds have jobs or are looking for them, though they generally cite an increasingly white-collar economy that is generating fewer opportunities for young people, the dropout rate and rising competition from immigrants and other adults.
The trend appears to largely cut across racial lines, with the work-force participation rate only slightly higher for white youths than for all young people in the city.
 
At Risk of Alienation
Experts warn that the unusually low level of young people in the labor force, a level that has dropped in recent years even as the city's economy has surged, means that many New Yorkers are not getting their first exposure to work at an appropriately early age. That may put them at risk of prolonged or even permanent alienation from the labor market, which may already be the fate of some of the half-million people the boom of the 1980's is thought to have left behind. 
With some employers worrying about New York's supply of qualified workers - and the declining number of young people - the low participation rate could also contribute to a labor shortage in the 1990's, tamping down economic growth.
''When you look at the New York City economy and the job situation of its youth,'' said the regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, who compiled the statistics on work-force participation, ''they are substantially out of synch.''
Emanuel Tobier, a professor at the Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service at New York University, said the figures were ''astoundingly low.''
''They're so low,'' he added, ''they're hard to believe.''
Why are so many estranged from the city's labor market? Experts offer an array of theories. They cite the dropout rate and what some say is the school system's failure to help students move from classroom to job; an economy that generates positions for those with skills but has fewer and fewer opportunities for people without training; the decline of retail businesses in many neighborhoods; increasing competition from immigrants, and even the city's relative lack of fast-food restaurants, a major employer of the young.
 
'Growing Puzzlement to Me'
New York City, Mr. Ehrenhalt said, has not traditionally produced many part-time jobs, the introduction to work for many young people. Even so, he acknowledged that the gap in teen-age work-force participation between the city and the nation ''has been a source of continued and growing puzzlement to me.''
Only 24.8 percent of the 400,000 New Yorkers ages 16 to 19 either had or were looking for jobs - which economists define as participation in the labor force - in 1988, the last year for which statistics were available. In comparison, the rate was 55.3 percent for the nation as a whole and 51.5 percent for the nation's cities.
The rate was 57.4 percent in Houston, 48.3 percent in Los Angeles, 44.6 percent in Washington, 39.7 percent in Detroit and 39.4 percent in Chicago.
Over the last two decades labor-force participation by the young has risen in the nation but declined in New York City. It has dropped about 10 percentage points since 1979, a decade when the city had its sharpest economic resurgence since World War II.
That has led some to conclude that ''white-collarization'' - the city's shift from a manufacturing to a service economy that is generating jobs requiring more skills - greatly diminished opportunities for the young. Even some blue-collar jobs have been upgraded.
''Before you go to a lathe, you have to go to a blueprint to know how to set it up,'' said Daniel Sandy Bayer, vice president for economic and commercial development for the New York City Partnership, a business and civic group.
 
Better Jobs, but Not for Young
Roger Waldinger, associate professor of sociology at City College, says he believes the erosion of the city's manufacturing, a trend that dates to the late 1940's, has hurt adults more than young people, since he says it employs relatively few young people.
He agreed that there had been an upgrading of jobs in the city as a resurgent economy produced more professional and managerial positions. He also said that industries that experienced substantial job growth were ones that lost ''a lot of youth employment.''
As the financial-services industry expanded, for example, it was eliminating many lower-level positions. As a result, he said, opportunities for young people had actually been reduced.
Professor Waldinger said he was interviewing a personnel officer at a bank for an article he wrote on youth employment several years ago when he observed a small example of this trend: a robot delivering the mail.
Professor Tobier of the Robert Wagner School also cited other possible factors, including the decline of small retail stores in some poor city neighborhoods that typically employed young people from the area.
 
Immigrants Hiring Immigrants
In some instances, immigrants have taken over such stores, and they tend to hire other immigrants to work in them.
''You would think now that with the tightening of the labor market they would have a better crack,'' Professor Tobier said of young New Yorkers, ''but the volume of immigration has provided alternative sources of employees.''
In addition to immigrants, young New Yorkers face competition from people who come to the city from other parts of the country to work in specialized fields, like the actors who support themselves as waiters.
In any event, Professor Tobier, echoing others, said, ''it's harder for a black or Hispanic kid from the ghetto to get a job.''
 
Low Rate for Whites, Too
With fewer opportunities for employment in their neighborhoods, more competition and a greater dependence on a public school system that some say fails to prepare many students for the more demanding jobs the economy is creating, black and Hispanic young people would seem at greater risk of missing the experience of working early in life and would seem more likely to suffer later because of it.
But statistically, the work-force participation rate for young whites, 26.1 percent, is hardly better than the overall rate for young people, though many white teen-agers are undoubtedly under less economic pressure to work and have more educational opportunities than their black and Hispanic counterparts.
The statistics are drawn from a national household survey conducted each month by the Census Bureau for the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Officials said there was too small a sample of black and Hispanic youths in the city to make reliable projections for those two groups.
Part-time jobs are counted along with full-time positions, and the responses are averaged to make the yearly figure.
New York City's labor participation rate for adults is relatively low, too -57.7 percent - but is much closer to the national average of 66 percent than is the corresponding figure for older teen-agers.
 
That Crucial Early Job
Similarly, the city's rate of youth unemployment is 18 percent, against 15 percent nationally.
In an interview, Mr. Ehrenhalt, whose first jobs included delivering newspapers and working for a dry cleaner and as a busboy and a waiter, stressed the importance of having a job early in life. ''It tells you what a boss is, what responsibility is,'' he said.
''A lot of youngsters don't get that initial first job, their introduction to the job market, in their teen-age years,'' he said at another point. ''They don't see the connection between school and what comes after school.''
To better establish that connection -and reassure potential employers -the New York City Partnership has suggested that the Board of Education issue a ''certificate of employability'' along with a diploma to high school students who complete a semester of work in addition to their courses.
 
Job Counseling in Schools
The organization, which for a decade has helped sponsor a summer jobs program that found work for 50,000 young people last year, has also helped establish employment counseling centers in 16 city high schools. Since September 1988, more than 4,000 students have been placed in full- or part-time jobs.
It is hard to imagine a school more conscious of the occupational prospects of its students than Murry Bergtraum High School in Lower Manhattan. The students there, almost all black, Asian-American and Hispanic youths, learn marketable skills like word processing and computer science along with regular high school subjects. Although Bergtraum is hardly one of the city's elite schools, about 80 percent of its students go on to college and virtually all of them end up working. The school's former principal, Dr. Barbara L. Christen, says the program fosters an attitude of employability.
Dr. Christen tells of a student who arrived one day with a purple streak in her hair, appropriate perhaps for a high school classroom but not for the office where she worked afterward. And the girl's supervisor at work told her so.
The student later discussed the episode with people at the school. ''We were talking about the values of the experience,'' Dr. Christen recalled, ''and she herself pointed out that one value was that people would clue you in about what you had to do to get ahead.''
Then there was another Bergtraum student who arrived for a job at a bank in a T-shirt and dungarees. The next day, Dr. Christen said, he wore a suit.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
GORBACHEV OFFERS CONDITIONAL TALKS WITH LITHUANIANS

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 31

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev offered to open a discussion with Lithuanian leaders tonight if they repealed their declaration of independence, and he warned the Lithuanian people that failure to comply with his request ''could have grave consequences for all of us.''
In separate appeals to the Lithuanian Parliament and the Lithuanian people, Mr. Gorbachev seemed to be signaling for the first time that the Kremlin is willing to negotiate with Lithuania, but the offer was couched in terms unacceptable to the leadership of the breakaway republic. [Texts of the statements, page 16.]
The Lithuanian President, Vytautas Landsbergis, described the appeals as ''threats'' and said Lithuania's Parliament would resume its work Monday. 
 
More Troops Are Present
Mr. Gorbachev did not specify what the ''grave consequences'' could be. He has said the Lithuanian Parliament's actions could have dire effects on the republic's economy, and although the Kremlin has repeatedly ruled out the use of force, the increased presence of troops in the republic is bound to lead many to believe that Mr. Gorbachev is threatening military action.
Given previous exchanges between the Kremlin and Lithuania, Mr. Gorbachev presumably anticipated Mr. Landsbergis's dismissal of his offer. But after a week in which Lithuanian leaders chided the Kremlin for failing to negotiate with them, the Soviet leader's strategy apparently is to cast the Lithuanians as unwilling to grasp his extended hand.
 
Seeking Common Ground
But the fact that Mr. Gorbachev answered the Lithuanian Parliament's earlier calls for dialogue could be a sign that the two sides are at least seeking common ground.
Mr. Gorbachev's statements, which were read at the beginning of the main evening news program, come a day after President Bush sent a message to the Kremlin urging a peaceful resolution to the conflict. He had stated that the United States was ''not trying to make things difficult'' for either side and reiterated Washington's support for self-determination for Lithuania.
In his appeal to the Lithuanian legislators, Mr. Gorbachev called on them to ''immediately annul the illegal acts'' they had adopted, saying that ''such a step will open a possibility for discussing the entire range of problems on the soley acceptable basis - within the framework of the Soviet Constitution.''
Then, addressing the Lithuanian people directly, Mr. Gorbachev warned that ''if the voice of reason is not heeded now, developments could have grave consequences for all of us.''
Mr. Gorbachev's tone was more ominous and his thoughts more concentrated in tonight's appeals, but the message is the same one the Kremlin has issued since the stalemate with Lithuania over its self-proclaimed independence began nearly three weeks ago: that the Lithuanian act was illegal and invalid, and that a republic could separate from the Soviet Union only by following the Soviet Constitution through a course that has yet to be prescribed by the new Soviet Parliament.
Mr. Landsbergis treated Mr. Gorbachev's proposal essentially as a non-offer, saying, ''I regret that President Gorbachev did not hear the voices of the world inviting the Soviet Union to start dialogue and negotiations with Lithuania.''
 
On Monday, Back to Work
He again tried to coax support from other countries and tried to demonstrate the ineffectiveness of Mr. Gorbachev's appeal to Lithuania to reverse its decisions by declaring that ''the day after tomorrow, the Lithuanian Parliament will resume its work and on its agenda it will consider this unexpected statement of President Gorbachev.''
Underscoring his attempt to focus responsibility for the outcome of events on the Lithuanian leaders, Mr. Gorbachev emphasized to the legislators that they were liable for ''Lithuanians and non-Lithuanians, for their security and well-being, for the destiny of democracy in the whole of our country and of stability in the world.''
In his statement, Mr. Gorbachev criticized the Lithuanian Parliament for dire decisions ''adopted in haste, without consultations and discussions, actually within one night.''
Mr. Gorbachev's appeals were made at the recommendation of the Council of Federation, a new presidential advisory board made up of the leaders of the 15 Soviet republics and other members, which met on Friday.
 
Increasing Pressure on Republic
Moscow has been steadily increasing its pressure on the renegade republic by issuing harsh decrees, rounding up army deserters who had been offered protection by the Lithuanian Parliament and stationing Soviet troops at public buildings. Initially, the troops occupied only Communist Party buildings, but on Friday night, they were dispatched to the Procurator's Office and the main printing plant in Vilnius.
So far, there has been no sign of the troops trying to interfere with work at the printing press, although there are no Sunday newspapers in the republic and the presses were not scheduled to run again until Sunday evening.
Although Moscow claims authority over both institutions, the latest deployment of troops could be a sign that Moscow is gradually trying to take over all public buildings in the republic, and Lithuanian officials say they fear Parliament may be one of the next targets.
In his statement tonight, Mr. Gorbachev stressed that the hasty separation of Lithuania from the Soviet Union would have disastrous economic consequences for the small republic. It is a point he raised repeatedly during a visit to Lithuania in January.
''The incumbent Lithuanian leaders are trying to convince you that their separatist actions will not affect the economic, scientific, technical and other ties with the other republics of the Soviet Union,'' Mr. Gorbachev said in appealing to the Lithuanian people. ''But this is not so, because all these ties can develop normally and yield fruits only in a favorable atmosphere of confidence and mutual assistance and not in the situation of confrontation, ultimatums, disrespect for one another and ethnic strife.''
 
Demonstrations of Support
He further added that people from around the Soviet Union, whose ''just indignation'' had been aroused by the Lithuanian action, had appealed to the Soviet leadership to take ''effective economic, political and administrative measures'' against the republic.
Earlier in the day, demonstrations were held in several Soviet cities to show solidarity with the people of Lithuania. In the Ukrainian capital of Kiev, about 20,000 people defied an official ban and gathered in support of Lithuania, according to Ivan Drach, head of Rukh, the Ukrainian nationalist movement.
Mr. Drach said that after initial warnings that the demonstration was illegal, police allowed the meeting to go on unharassed.
In Soviet Georgia, demonstrators called for an end to the occupation of Lithuania and its neighboring Baltic republics of Estonia and Latvia. And several hundred people gathered this afternoon in Gorky Park in Moscow to denounce the use of troops in Lithuania and to support the right of every republic to secede from the Soviet Union.

HEADLINE: Jordan 1990: New Politics, Islam's Way

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
The young woman in a dark veil had a problem: how, she asked the legislator, could she switch colleges? The legislator scribbled a supportive note to a college director he knew. The woman left. The man sighed. Only recently, said Abdel Latif Arrabiyat, a legislator from the Muslim Brotherhood, a man had asked him to adjudicate marital strife. Then, a retired soldier from the 1948 war had written asking for a raise in his pension. People, he said, did not seem to understand just what a parliamentary deputy was supposed to be able to do.
''The level of expectation is very high,'' he said. 
Expectations began to rise last November, when the first free elections in 22 years gave 32 of the 80 parliamentary seats to the Muslim Brotherhood and 10 other Islamic conservative candidates. They became the biggest and most powerful bloc in Parliament, loud in their commitment to sharia, or Islamic law, and jihad, or holy war against Israel.
 
Tremors Through Neighbors
The election and its result sent tremors through Jordan's Arab neighbors of Saudi Arabia, Iraq and Syria, unsettled variously by the siren call of freedom and the prospect of religious passion challenging secular rule. Israelis questioned the stirring of Islam so close, and many in Jordan felt their Westernized ways threatened.
But this week, as Parliament concluded its first session, the Muslim victory seemed more ambiguous, with many people disillusioned with the pace of change promised by deputies who had campaigned on the assertion that ''Islam is the solution.'' Solutions have been elusive, and, as Mr. Arrabiyat's experiences seemed to show, small detail has tripped big slogans.
''When you have a high level of expectation, whatever you do is below expectation,'' he said. ''So you find many people in Amman who say, 'What happened? We don't see anything new.' ''
Leilah Sharif, a member of the 40-seat Senate, the upper house appointed by King Hussein, said: ''They have realized the enormity of their responsibility. And they have realized that when you are under the dome of Parliament, it is not like when you are on the pulpit of the mosque.''
 
Tolerance by Monarchy
''They have achieved nothing,'' said Musa Keilani, a Jordanian diplomat and scholar who has studied the history of Islamic movements in Jordan. ''They could not impose sharia. They could not ban alcohol. They have not been able to register solid gains.''
Yet some concerns center not so much on the Brotherhood's sway in formal politics as on its street politics at a time of economic crisis and deepening disaffection among Jordanians of Palestinian descent, who form more than half the 3.5 million population, over the slow pace of United States-sponsored peace efforts.
Jordan's Hashemite monarchy, which asserts descent from the prophet Mohammed, has long shown greater tolerance toward the Brotherhood than other Arab countries.
But shortly before last November's poll, the King warned his citizens against voting for religious extremes, saying Jordan risked being thrown into Lebanon's chaos.
 
Many Did Not Vote
But the Muslim Brotherhood was able to marshal its followers at the polling stations. And many others, particularly Jordanians of Palestinian descent, many of them with a secular outlook, did not vote, staying home out of a blend of cynicism, indifference and worry that a vote in Jordan would undermine their assertion to be represented in a Palestinian state.
With a turnout of only 40 percent of the 1.4 million eligible voters, some candidates on the Islamic ticket were able to win seats from voters who may have represented only a 10th of those eligible. Since the election, Islamic candidates have lost in smaller votes for the leadership of Jordan's professional associations and syndicates.
But many suggested that the Islamic victory provided an opportunity for a wider more emotive campaign. Some Islamic deputies, notably Abdel Moneim Abu Zant, born in the West Bank town of Nablus, have stirred passions with a demand that the avowed moderacy of the Palestine Liberation Organization be abandoned in favor of holy war against Israel.
 
Support of Public Grows
On March 7, the Brotherhood issued a call for ''the liberation of Palestine from the sea to the river,'' calling it ''an Islamic duty and the responsibility of all Muslims and Arabs.'' The demand for a Palestinian state between the Mediterranean and Jordan contradicts the official policy of Jordan, the P.L.O. and most of the Arab world. But it has found an echo.
Taher el-Masri, a Jordanian of Palestinian descent and a legislator who supports more centrist policies, said he had shared platforms at public meetings with Mr. Abu Zant and ''people admire him very much.'' He continued, ''I must admit that the public is leaning to his ideas, not my ideas.''
''Abu Zant is undermining the P.L.O. because of the lack of progress on the political front,'' he said. The Muslim Brotherhood in Jordan, diplomats and Palestinian officials say, has close ties with Hamas, the Islamic movement challenging the P.L.O. in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.
''The more the peace process drags and tumbles, and the more that you find that the doors are locked in front of the peace process, the more these people have credibility among the audiences and the masses,'' said Mohammed Milhem, an independent member of the P.L.O.'s executive committee. ''It gives them more power to continue to challenge.''

HEADLINE: Cuban-American Takes Aim at Castro, on TV

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, March 31

 BODY:
Using the infant medium of television to stunning political effect, a young Fidel Castro dominated the airwaves in 1960 seeking to rally supporters to his new rule.
Seeking a similar, if less immediate result three decades later, President Castro's Cuban-American enemies are placing their hopes for his fall on television programs being beamed to Cuba from the Florida Keys.
But along with doubts that the new United States-financed television station, known as TV Marti, can overcome electronic jamming and hasten Mr. Castro's political eclipse, the start-up of the station last week exposed a deep split among Cuban exiles. 
At its heart is a wealthy and influential Miami businessman, Jorge Mas Canosa, founder and chairman of a conservative lobby, the Cuban-American National Foundation, who is credited even by his detractors with persuading Congress to support TV Marti and its five-year-old radio station.
Since Radio Marti's founding director, Ernesto F. Betancourt, resigned this month, saying Mr. Mas interfered in the running of the station, the Miami exile leader has faced assertions that he has sought to use his position as chairman of a presidential advisory board on broadcasting to advance a single-minded quest to become President of Cuba.
The one Cuban-American besides Mr. Mas on the nine-member board is a member of his foundation. Mr. Betancourt said Mr. Mas's foundation had begun to operate as a political party.
''They even drafted a constitution and economic program for the country and plans for transitional rule with Jorge Mas the prospective presidential candidate,'' Mr. Betancourt said in an interview. ''Then they realized they needed mass-media broadcast to Cuba to realize their ambitions.'' Mr. Betancourt said that earlier this year Mr. Mas requested a 55-minute documentary on Eastern Europe for the station and recently arranged for the broadcast of flattering commentary about the foundation.
Mr. Betancourt, who generally earned high marks for his tenure as director of Radio Marti, was quickly joined in his criticisms by other Cuban-Americans skeptical of Mr. Mas as well as by a flurry of editorials and letters in the Miami press arguing that the credibility of Radio and TV Marti would be best preserved by distancing them from even the suggestion of influence from Mr. Mas or his foundation.
Answering those criticisms during numerous radio and television programs and in newspaper columns, Mr. Mas, who is 50 years old, has denied exerting any influence over the station or ever trying to use broadcasts to advance his political interests.
Mr. Mas categorically denies having ever harbored presidential ambitions.
''Up until very recently, the Cuban opposition did not have someone to identify with,'' Mr. Mas said, explaining the surge in criticism of him.
''The Cuban-American National Foundation, with me as its director, has emerged as the firm head of the opposition,'' he said. With his strong leadership, to hear him explain it, have come enmity and envy.
But Mr. Mas's critics assert that he has built his foundation into an organization with over 100,000 paying members that generates large sums in contributions and extends its influence to political races at all levels but reflects, in virtually all things, the agenda of one man, Mr. Mas.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
Texts of Gorbachev's Statements to Lithuanians

 BODY:
Following are the texts of statements made yesterday by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union to the Lithuanian people and to the Lithuanian Parliament. The statements, as distributed in translation by Tass, the official Soviet press agency, were read by announcers on Radio Moscow and on the Soviet television.
 
TO LITHUANIAN PEOPLE
Dear citizens of the Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic,
 I am addressing you at a difficult time for our country. The March 11 decisions of the Lithuanian Supreme Soviet have brought us to a critical point. 
 The attempts being taken by the incumbent Lithuanian leadership to break the republic's ties with the Soviet Union and its tactics of unilateral and ultimative actions endanger the normal life and security of all people in the Republic, Lithuanians and non-Lithuanians, and are a cause of grave concern in the country.
Is it normal when amendments to the Constitution, resolving the destiny of the republic and its people and concerning the interests of the entire country, are adopted in haste, without consultations and discussions, actually within one night?
The Third Congress of U.S.S.R. People's Deputies urged the Supreme Soviet of the Republic to renounce political recklessness. The Lithuanian leadership responded to this appeal for common sense with the escalation of irresponsible and illegitimate decisions.
This counterposes Lithuania to other constituent republics and the whole of the Soviet Union and undermines the historically established ties and cooperation between our peoples.
The actions being taken in Lithuania have no logical foundation. They are being taken at a time when we have begun to resolve vital issues of the Soviet federation on a really democratic basis.
What is our position? It is the sincere adherence to the ideas of the free and original development of all peoples of our country, and respect for their legitimate rights to self- determination and sovereignty. This fully refers to the Lithuanian people, too.
Now attempts are being made to convince you that genuine sovereignty within the Soviet Union, without breaking away from it, is impossible. Simultaneously, old grudges are being purposefully kindled and the dark sides of joint life are being emphasized.
Indeed, our past includes many things that we are mutually rejecting. And this refers not only to the Lithuanian people. But no one can say that in the years of perestroika any people in our country has been deliberately elevated or purposefully humiliated.
We have for years lived in one home. Does the past time deserve only bad words? Have the Lithuanian literature and poetry, theater and cinema, music and architecture, education and sports faded and got lost in the multicolored Soviet culture?
Was it not in the mutual work and with the fraternal aid from other republics that your industry and agriculture have been developing? Did Lithuania itself not extend a helping hand to other peoples in times of trouble?
 
Supporting the Constitution
Did the Lithuanian citizens not support the U.S.S.R. Constitution, by which Lithuania abided for years honestly and strictly as a full-fledged republic?
The incumbent Lithuanian leaders are trying to convince you that their separatist actions will not affect the economic, scientific, technical and other ties with the other republics of the U.S.S.R.
But this is not so, because all these ties can develop normally and yield fruits only in a favorable atmosphere of confidence and mutual assistance and not in the situation of confrontation, ultimatums, disrespect for one another and ethnic strife.
The pointed disrespect for the U.S.S.R. Constitution, the challenge to Soviet laws and the nonimplementation of union obligations give rise to just indignation all over the country.
The President of the U.S.S.R., the U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet and the U.S.S.R. Government are receiving numerous letters and telegrams expressing utter concern and perplexity in connection with the developments in Lithuania.
People demand that the U.S.S.R. Constitution be defended and that the union be protected from the harm caused by the actions of separatists. They propose taking effective economic, political and administrative measures.
People in Byelorussia and Kaliningrad region are raising the issue of returning territories transferred to Lithuania after it joined the U.S.S.R.
In general, the situation in the Republic and around it has become dramatic. If the voice of reason is not heeded now, developments can have grave consequences for all of us. We must be united in striving to prevent this.
I have appealed to the Lithuanian Supreme Soviet, proposing that it immediately annul the illegal acts it has adopted. This will open a possibility for discussing the entire range of problems on the solely acceptable basis - within the framework of the U.S.S.R. Constitution.
I am expressing hope that my appeal will be supported by the citizens of the Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic.
 
TO LITHUANIAN PARLIAMENT
The incumbent Lithuanian leadership does not heed the voice of reason. It continues to ignore the decision of the third, extraordinary Congress of U.S.S.R. People's Deputies and is taking unilateral steps that run counter to the U.S.S.R. Constitution and that are openly challenging and insulting to the entire union.
I want to declare yet again that this road is ruinous and will only lead to a dead end.
I urge the deputies of the Lithuanian Supreme Soviet to understand this truth and their historical responsibility for the interests of the people of Lithuania - Lithuanians and non-Lithuanians, for their security and well-being, for the destiny of democracy in the whole of our country and of stability in the world.
I propose that the Lithuanian Supreme Soviet immediately annul the illegal acts it has adopted. Such a step will open a possibility for discussing the entire range of problems on the solely acceptable basis - within the framework of the U.S.S.R. constitution.

HEADLINE: Coalition Rule Seems a Safe Guess in Bulgaria

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SOFIA, Bulgaria, March 29

 BODY:
Ten weeks before this country holds its first free elections in more than four decades, the outcome is a tossup. But whichever party comes out on top, Bulgaria's next government will be formed by a coalition.
In an interview on Wednesday, Prime Minister Andrei Lukanov said that even if his Communist Party, still the most powerful political force in Bulgaria, were to win a majority, he would opt for a coalition government. 
''Whatever the results, we are convinced that we need a coalition,'' he said. ''Why? To deal with the economic crisis and economic reform and to have a period of learning, to develop a new political culture. I am convinced that we need two, maybe more years of national cooperation for that.''
Mr. Lukanov took over the Cabinet at the head of a team of reform-minded Communists on Nov. 10, following the overthrow of the neo-Stalinist leadership of Todor Zhivkov.
The Prime Minister rates as the most popular politician in Bulgaria, according to a national opinion survey taken earlier this month. His approval rating of 71 percent was exceeded only by that of Gen. Dobri Dzhurov, the Defense Minister, who is credited with having played a key role in the ouster of Mr. Zhivkov after 35 years in power. Zhelyu Zhelev, who heads the opposition, received 39 percent in the same survey.
Because he is well known and widely liked, many Bulgarians including non-Communists hope that Mr. Lukanov will remain Prime Minister even if opposition parties gain a majority on June 10. For example, Viktor Valkov, chairman of the Agrarian Party, said he would support Mr. Lukanov. The Agrarian Party, with 500,000 members roughly half the size of the Communist Party, is the second-strongest political group in Bulgaria.
But Mr. Lukanov's prospects are far from assured. The poll indicated that half the eligible voters were undecided on how they would vote, and several Western diplomats said the opposition parties gathered under the umbrella of the United Democratic Forces have gained strength in recent weeks.
Altogether the 15 opposition parties have about half a million members, and rallies sponsored by the United Democratic Forces have recently drawn as many as 200,000 Bulgarians.
Some diplomats think that with modern office equipment, the opposition coalition might even gain a majority in June. Such equipment has begun to arrive from private British, American and West German donors.
Another uncertainty is the evolution of attitudes toward the Communist Party, which is to formally change its name to the Bulgarian Socialist Party next Monday as a mark of its stated intention of transforming itself into a social democratic party.
Four factions have emerged within the party, ranging from a liberal grouping called Road to Europe to an orthodox group of members associated with the Zhivkov era.
Work is also under way on the drafting of a new constitution. A preliminary draft embodies a detailed bill of rights and envisions a powerful legislative branch. But there are apparently strong elements in the Communist Party and elsewhere that would prefer a strong executive.

HEADLINE: To a Fading U.S. Bugle, Rhineland Sings a Dirge

BYLINE: By FERDINAND PROTZMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAD KREUZNACH, West Germany

 BODY:
At 5 P.M. each day, life at the United States 8th Infantry Division headquarters comes to a brief standstill as the American flag is lowered for the night.
Soldiers and civilians stop whatever they are doing and stand at attention as Old Glory is slowly brought down at Rose Barracks and a bugle sounds Retreat. The final notes echo through the twilight, rolling across the vineyards of the Nahe River valley toward the medieval town center.
This ceremony may soon end. Since the Bush Administration proposed major troop reductions and base closings in January, it has been widely expected that the 8th Infantry Division would be one of the major units to be withdrawn from West Germany. Just the possibility of its departure is sending economic shock waves through this area's 40,000 people. 
Such tremors are being felt in many West German communities, but particularly in the state of Rhineland-Palatinate, known among some in the military as ''NATO's largest aircraft carrier'' because of the high concentration of American air bases there. #1 Out of 10 Could Close Defense Secretary Dick Cheney is already planning to close Zweibrucken Air Base, in the southwest corner of the state about 100 miles from Bad Kreuznach. Of the 800 American military installations great and small in West Germany, the commander of American forces in Europe, Gen. John R. Galvin, estimates that about 80 will be closed in the first round of reductions.
Many here complain of the annoyances and hazards of having thousands of foreign troops living and training on West German soil. But United States military spending pumps about $8 billion annually into this country's economy. Scores of companies depend on the military for business, thousands of civilians rely on it for employment, and countless German families have boosted their incomes by renting housing to soldiers and their dependents.
For those people, troop reductions will mean lower incomes, a loss of jobs and wrenching economic adjustment at a time when West Germany's Government and business sector are concentrating their resources on reunification and the enormous task of rebuilding East Germany's decrepit economy.
The Bush Administration proposed the cutbacks in response to the political changes that have swept Eastern Europe in recent months. But those developments are small comfort to people like Katherina Gruneberg, 70 years old, who works at a snack stand just up the road from Rose Barracks and spent 21 years as an employee at the base commissary.
 
'I Want Them to Stay'
''I want them to stay, not to go,'' Mrs. Gruneberg said. ''They are still a great protection for us. The American soldiers are very nice young rascals. And they account for most of the business at this stand.
''For Bad Kreuznach, it will be very bad economically, very damaging if they go,'' she continued. ''There is no big industry here, and I can't think of what they will do with the U.S. installations. They are so big only a large company could use them.''
The United States forces employ 33,000 civilians, the vast majority of them Germans. About 1,000 of them work for the 8th Infantry in Bad Kreuznach and at Dexheim, an outlying base. The gross payroll for these 1,000 civilians amounts to about $25 million a year, said Maj. Michael Maher, the 8th Division's spokesman.
Money flows from the military in other ways. The 8th Infantry spends about $2.2 million a month in Bad Kreuznach on a variety of goods and services. In 1989, it awarded construction contracts totaling $6.35 million and spent about $225,000 more on transport contracts with local bus and trucking concerns. It paid $155,000 to local hospitals for services to military staff members and their dependents.
The 8th Infantry is a mechanized division with about 21,000 officers and enlisted men. About 8,000 are stationed at the Rose Barracks headquarters, and the rest are spread over an area about the size of Rhode Island, with installations in Mainz, Wildflecken, Baumholder, Dexheim, Mannheim and Wiesbaden.
 
No Decision Yet
Major Maher said no decision had been made to move the 8th Division out, and that no such move was expected until a new agreement on limiting conventional forces in Europe is completed, perhaps late this year.
Until then, it is business as usual. ''We're busy training,'' Major Maher said.
When the troops are not training, they can part with their pay at the auto dealerships, insurance agents and fast-food restaurants that surround all big American bases in West Germany. Without the troops, these businesses would probably close.
''All of our business is with the military. If they go, that would be it,'' said Veva Hepler, an insurance sales representative for American International Underwriters, which has an office next to a car dealership just up the hill from Rose Barracks' main gate. ''I guess it was bound to happen anyway.''
If the mood is one of resignation in Bad Kreuznach, it is more like disbelief in Zweibrucken, where the 17th Air Force is based. The Air Force is the town's largest employer, providing jobs for 20 percent of the 35,000 residents.
 
Groping for New Job Skills
''My skills and knowledge are all oriented to the military,'' said a civilian clerk in the unit's administration building. ''German businesses have different requirements. They want something else, and that will make it hard for me to get another job.''
Zweibrucken city officials said that the town's unemployment rate already stands at 14 percent, well above the national average of about 8 percent. If the Zweibrucken Air Base closes, as proposed, and the 8th Infantry leaves, the state government of Rhineland-Palatinate will face serious economic problems.
The state government is considering industrial development projects that could at least ease the pain of a military departure. A ministerial working group is examining the potential problems.
''We think we will have some problems finding jobs for the military workers,'' said Jurgen Dietzen, a spokeman for the state Interior Ministry. ''We want to know what these workers can do, and if there are similar civil jobs they can do.''
One proposal is to convert one of the six American air bases in Rhineland-Palatinate into a civilian airport to ease the severe air-traffic congestion at Frankfurt International Airport. But many West Germans working at the Zweibrucken base are skeptical that the lost jobs will be replaced. In their minds, troop cuts mean unemployment.
''It's good for them because they save money,'' a mechanic working in the Zweibrucken motor pool said of the Americans. ''It's bad for me because I'll lose my job.''

HEADLINE: Ohio Valley of Tears Is Facing More

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DILLES BOTTOM, Ohio, March 30

 BODY:
Fifteen years ago more than 60,000 people worked in the coal mines and the steel, glass, pottery and paper plants that lined the banks of the Ohio River just south of Wheeling, W.Va. Today fewer than 30,000 are employed there.
In many of the valley's cities and towns, the once-booming plants are rusting testaments to the decline of America's industrial base. ''For Sale'' signs sprout everywhere, unemployment rates of 15 to 20 percent are commonplace and welfare officials say one of every five families lives in poverty.
And things may get worse, particularly for the region's miners. The clean air bill making its way through Congress includes a provision to reduce acid rain, one of the environmental fallouts that results when utility plants burn the high-sulfur coal mined here. The coal-burning plants, most of them in the Midwest, could install smokestack devices to remove the sulfur, or they could take a less costly approach and import low-sulfur coal. #4,000 Jobs Are on the Line ''Everybody knows they'll go for the cheapest approach and that means high-sulfur miners are in for some more hard times,'' said Larry Ward, the top local official of the United Mine Workers of America. ''The Congress doesn't seem to care that this bill has its own special kind of fallout and that we're going to be the victims. 
''It's a bill that's going to put 4,000 men out of work around here and probably another 10,000 or so miners elsewhere in the Midwest. And for every miner that goes, some grocer or car dealer or clothier is going to hurt, too.''
The miners who work the rich seam of high-sulfur coal that runs beneath the Ohio Valley are already among the workers hardest hit in the area. In the last 15 years, their ranks have been thinned from a high of 16,000 in the mid-1970's to 4,000 by automation and the use of alternative fuels. The miners say they do not oppose reducing acid rain or air pollution.
''Nobody has ever fought harder for clean air than us miners because we have to work where air is so dirty,'' said Ray Wright, a train motorman in the mine. ''All we ask in this new bill is fairness. There's technology out there that can make burning high-sulfur coal safe, but Congress doesn't seen to want to take the time to develop it.''
 
An Issue With Names on It
Local coal mine operators take a similar view. Robert Murray, the president of the Ohio Valley Coal Company, traveled to Washington on Wednesday to urge Congress to modify its clean air approach.
''The acid rain issue, which started out as an environmental issue, is really a human issue,'' he told one Capitol Hill hearing. ''To me, there are names on this issue.''
Senator Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginia Democrat who was once a coal miner, failed on Thursday to persuade the Senate to amend the clean air bill to offer additional unemployment benefits and retraining programs for miners thrown out of work. He pleaded with legislators to ''hear the cries of the people'' while considering the measure, which is expected to come up for a final Senate vote next week and then go on to passage by the House.
But the Byrd amendment was defeated by a vote of 50 to 49. Opponents of the amendment said it was too costly and gave miners more than other workers who would be affected by the bill.
Miners here, while appreciative of Mr. Byrd's effort, say that unemployment benefits and retraining programs would not tide them over because there is no hope of finding new work in the Ohio Valley these days.
''Retrain me for what?'' asked Roger Stillion, a miner at Powhatan Point. ''Most miners are in their 40's and 50's because no new miners have come in for years.''
 
Struggling to Stay Put
Young people now grow assuming that they will move away when they finish high school, or maybe sooner if their parents can find work elsewhere. Valley residents speak sadly of an economic diaspora that is scattering families to the winds, with some coming together only for funerals.
Most towns and villages are dotted with an unusually large number of small gas stations and little stores that sell sandwiches, the owners desperately struggling to find the money to stay put in the place they were born and raised and will always call ''home.''
''There just isn't anything for a young person to do around here,'' said Jim McGee, a retired miner who opened a fast-food restaurant at Powhatan Point to supplement his retirement income.
''And if the mines go, there won't be anything for the rest of us,'' he said. ''A hundred coal trucks go past my place every day. I get business from the drivers and, of course, so do any number of other merchants. If those trucks disappear, what then? More boarded up stores. More homes for sale. There'll be a domino effect.'' In the opinion of John Laslo, the former Mayor of Martins Ferry, who is a member of many valley economic commissions, the domino effect has been at work for some time, touching even the valley's vaunted athletic teams.
''This valley was home for Lou Groza and John Havlicek and the Niekro boys and on and on in professional sports,'' he said. ''Knute Rockne and Woody Hayes and a lot of other coaches used to recruit here. ''Well, I've got to say it. With the loss of so many of our families and young people, our teams aren't what they used to be.''

HEADLINE: On Weekend for Counting, Census Itself Is Under Scrutiny as Never Before

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
As census forms are filled out in households around the country this weekend, the nation's residents are writing an end to a decennial demographic contest that has more winners and losers than ever before.
California wants to know if it gained six Congressional seats or seven; Pennsylvania wants to know if it lost two or three. New Jersey towns want to know local population figures so they can determine how many liquor licenses to issue. Oklahoma City and Rochester want to know if they have lost their places among the top 50 metropolitan markets, meaning millions of advertising dollars would go elsewhere.
As the winners and losers have increased, so have the legal and political pressures on the Bureau of the Census, the agency that keeps the score. It has forced politicians, the bureau and professional statisticians around the country to re-examine basic questions: What demographic information should the Government gather? How should it be gathered? And to what end? 
Census figures have always been the basis of Congressional reapportionment, but not until the 1970 census was it required by the Supreme Court that the numbers be used for redrawing state legislatures' districts. By 1980, as Federal revenue sharing programs based on population grew, census figures were used to apportion large amounts of money as well as power -more than $40 billion a year in Federal money in the 1980's.
''The bureau is clearly under increasing scrutiny,'' said the Census Bureau's director, Barbara Everitt Bryant.
Representative Thomas C. Sawyer, an Ohio Democrat who is the chairman of the House subcommitee that oversees the Census Bureau, said the pressure from this scrutiny might alter the way the census counts people. ''We're undergoing a simultaneous economic, demographic and technological change that is shaping issues more directly than at any time in the past 100 years,'' he said. ''As a result, the character of the census may not change. But the methodology may change radically.''
 
More Than People Are Being Counted
 The bureau will continue to count people: the first article of the Constitution requires a count to apportion political power. But bureaucrats and political leaders have expanded that mandate to include the collection of information about race, income, employment, education, life style, housing, transportation and disability.
Warren J. Mitofsky, the executive director of the Voter Research and Surveys Association, a new consortium organized by the major television networks for polling and election data, said that the constituency for highly detailed census data had grown enormously, and that any reduction in the breadth of the count would provoke fierce opposition among those who use the information.
''In the political world, it's the whole foundation of political polling,'' Mr. Mitofsky said.
Census data is crucial in guiding poll takers and survey researchers who gather information from small samples of people and extrapolate conclusions about much larger population groups. ''When you talk about sampling, you're talking about extending a methodology out from something concrete,'' said Charles E. Metcalf, the president of Mathematical Policy Research in Princeton, N.J. To design a sample, he said, ''You have to have some basis for doing it.''
Yet some statisticians suggest that it may be possible to stand this process on its head, and use sampling techniques to get better data than that gleaned by counting people. Planners in the bureau have already written a paper suggesting that the census in 2000 be a bare-bones effort that would do little more than count people. This could be supplemented by telephone follow-up to contact people who fail to answer and an expansion of existing population surveys to learn how people live and where they come from.
Many experts in survey research are concerned about such a change in approach. Vincent Barabba, who was census director twice and is now in charge of market research for the General Motors Corporation, said surveys might indeed provide better information on a national level. But he said he doubts that there is a cost-effective substitute for obtaining reliable local data.
Nevertheless, Representative Sawyer believes change of some sort is inevitable. ''Each census has been the last census of its type,'' he said. ''There's been a rolling evolution.'' Terriann Lowenthal, Mr. Sawyer's chief aide on the Congressional committee, says the census works. ''But does it work well enough, when the stakes are so high?''
 
Methodology Raises A Basic Question
 The questions have surfaced before. But this time, some officials say, the bureau is unusually vulnerable to charges that the old way may not be the best way.
For one thing, the cost of the bureau's promised activities to perfect the accuracy of the 1990 census will exceed its current 10-year budget of $2.6 billion, Congressional auditors say. For another, it is far behind its own goals for hiring the temporary workers needed to visit the homes of those who do not fill out the form, with only about half as many hired as the bureau had hoped.
Any change in the way the Census Bureau makes it count will tie into the debate over adjusting census figures. Adjustment is a complex mathematical process that would add to the totals for groups underrepresented in the initial count and would thus change the final count.
In a reflection of the growing importance of the disputes over census methodology, the bureau's Commerce Department overseers, who have traditionally remained aloof from statistical details, have said they will decide whether to adjust the figures from the decennial count. Government officials argue that the intervention is needed, given the political ramifications of the decision and the newly pugnacious attitude of the losers.
Just five suits were filed against the bureau over the 1970 census. Fifty-two suits were filed over the 1980 census. One of those still simmers: New York City, Houston, Los Angeles, Chicago and Dade County, Fla., want the Census Bureau to adjust the count to compensate for the undercount of as many as 1 million of their poor and minority residents.
Some statisticians believe that adjustment, a major philosophical departure from the basic verities of the count, is inevitable. Others fear that it would fundamentally change the agency's way of doing business and endanger its reputation as one of the least political and most professional agencies in Government.
 
Over Two Centuries, Counts and Insight
 It all began with the Constitution, which in Article I tied each state's political representation in the House of Representatives to population figures and ordered the Government to get those figures once a decade.
At its most basic, the job of the census was heavy arithmetical lifting. At its most creative, the job let scholars create new ways of looking at the world. ''The census categories become the language we use to talk about ourselves,'' said Margo J. Anderson, a historian at the University of Wisconsin who wrote ''The American Census: A Social History.''
For instance, it was the census superintendent, Roger A. Porter, who noted in 1891 that settlement was so widespread that ''there can hardly be said to be a frontier line.'' This comment led the historian Frederick Jackson Turner to declare an end to the era of the American frontier, giving birth to a new school of historical analysis.
In 1920, the census told the American people they had crossed the divide that separates a rural nation from an urban one. In 1940, it began to record the housing conditions in the country, including how many lavatories were in each household, and whether they were inside or out. In 1980, it showed that the population of the North and Middle West had been outstripped by that of the South and West.
Since the mid-19th century, changing social and economic conditions prompted changes in the questionnaire. Now a group of Federal panels rules on requests for new questions. The goal is to keep the long form, which is sent to 17 million households, from being too burdensome or instrusive.
In the last two decades, the census has also recorded more and more minority groups who clamored for statistical recognition - and policy benefits. But the groups often felt shortchanged. The minority groups' desires for recognition in the census mingled with a distrust of motive and method was most recently shown by the leaders of the Gay and Lesbian Task Force, which wants gay couples to identify themselves as unmarried partners, a new category.
''Domestic partnership is becoming the leading-edge societal issue of the 1990's,'' said Robert Bray of the task force. ''There's a changing societal definition of what family means.''
While the question about unmarried partners was intended to identify heterosexual couples and to distinguish them from roommates or those who live together for economic reasons, homosexual groups decided the question could yield a count of homosexuals living in committed relationships.
But ''an undercount is inevitable,'' said Urvashi Vaid, the executive director of the task force. Couples living together represent only part of the gay population - and many of them may be nervous about identifying themselves out of fear of discrimination.
Over all, the people who do not cooperate tend to be poor, nonwhite, and likely to draw Federal funds to a community. But rather than making adjustments, the bureau has tried to overcome the undercount in other ways, like asking the new organizations for extensive coverage and asking clergymen to boost the census in Sunday's sermons.
''It's upside-down marketing,'' said Dr. Bryant, the director of the Census Bureau. ''Eighty or 90 percent of our effort is targeted at the 10 percent we're most likely to miss.''
 
Cooperation, a Tool That Wins the War
 The fear that census data will be misused is one attitude that deters cooperation by people at the fringes of society. Bureau officials know that many people, even those in the mainstream, are concerned that their answers will filter back to the Internal Revenue Service or the Immigration and Naturalization Service.
Widespread lack of cooperation, which would effectively kill the census, is the stuff of nightmares for bureau officials. Confidentiality of census records is both a legal requirement and a professional obsession. Access to the main data banks can be accomplished only through bureau telephones. The bureau constantly confers with law-enforcement agencies like the Immigration and Naturalization Service to avoid any coincidences between visits by census takers and raids by the immigration agency.
The lack of cooperation that is the bureau's worst nightmare became a reality in West Germany. There, where the census data was shared with other Government agencies, the 1980 decennial head count was postponed and then canceled after a grass-roots campaign against it. It was finally held, with 85 percent participation, in 1987.
In Denmark, no census count is done. The Government gets population data from a national population registry, which everyone must join. But this approach is not popular, said Harvey Choldin, an expert on censuses worldwide who works as a fellow at the Population Reference Bureau in Washington. Of more than 180 countries in the world that do censuses, most do direct counts.
Dr. Choldin believes that Americans would never accept an administrative records system. Yet the paradoxical thing is that the American people are extremely cooperative when it comes to the census. In 1980, 83 percent of the forms that went to occupied homes were mailed back.
''People see the census as a national historical event in which they are participating,'' said Jeffrey Moore, a psychologist with the bureau. ''There aren't many of those.''

CORRECTION-DATE: April 2, 1990, Monday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the United States census incorrectly identified in some copies a country in which census data was shared with other Government agencies. That was done in West Germany, not in the United States.

HEADLINE: Howard's 14th President Facing Stormy Waters

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Thirty-three years after he began college here, poor and unprepared, Franklyn Green Jenifer takes office April 1 as the 14th president of Howard University.
The 122-year-old institution, whose rich history clings like ivy to its walls, is facing gnawing budget problems and campus divisions that still are healing from last year's student unrest.
Dr. Jenifer, a robust man with steely determination and a helmet of graying hair, is alternately modest and expansive about his plans for the most distinguished black center of learning in the United States.
''I'm not the great white knight coming in to save the dying baby, Howard,'' said Dr. Jenifer, who for the last four years has been chancellor of the Massachusetts Board of Regents of Higher Education. ''I'm honored to come to Howard. Howard does me a great favor by having me come.'' 
 
A Multitude of Problems
While not dying, Howard is certainly ailing. The private institution's nearly $460 million annual budget ran a deficit throughout the mid-80's, peaking at $20 million. Faculty members speak of university buildings decaying after years of neglect and inadequate office space and equipment. They say that many of the school's 12,000 students live in crumbling dormitories, and that student housing is in short supply.
University administrators say financial problems were eased by erasing some of the school's pension contributions. But the move drove a deeper wedge of frustration between Howard's longtime president, James E. Cheek, and the school's staff, already embittered over other economic complaints.
Last March, feeling increasingly alienated from the university's leadership, some 2,000 students occupied the administration building for three days. Chief among their concerns was the appointment of the Republican National Committee chairman, Lee Atwater, to the school's board of trustees. A week after the protests, he resigned.
At the same time, the university's faculty - the country's largest concentration of blacks holding doctorates -was growing dissatisfied with the ''imperial'' leadership of Dr. Cheek. The student newspaper, the Hilltop, reflected similar sentiments when it called Dr. Cheek the ''invisible president'' shortly before he resigned last June after leading the school for 20 years.
It is into these churning waters that Dr. Jenifer, 51 years old, said he plans to plunge, not wade. Speaking in a low rumble, Dr. Jenifer tends to endow his words with an insistence often belied by his quiet manner.
 
'Our Time Is Short'
''If I am going to create the kind of change that I want, it's not going to be evolutionary,'' he said in a recent interview. ''It has to be revolutionary because our time is short.''
Evident in Dr. Jenifer's remarks about his intentions is his vision for Howard that the pursuit of excellence must be part of any endeavor. He is equally committed, he said, to broadening the opportunity for higher education for those often left out: the poor, blacks, children whose lives are reminiscent of his own childhood. In reaching for these goals, he said, he intends to reinvigorate the school and the system.
Some reporters and politicians in Massachusetts have said Dr. Jenifer sometimes trades on buzzwords - excellence and access are two most often mentioned. But Robert Schwartz, who was education adviser to Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts while Dr. Jenifer was state chancellor, said Dr. Jenifer practiced what he preached.
Educators in Massachusetts credit Dr. Jenifer with restructuring the state's financial aid system, overhauling the certification process and reorganizing the system's continuing education program. Generally, they said, Dr. Jenifer was an outspoken advocate for public higher education. As chancellor, Dr. Jenifer oversaw operations at the state's three public universities, nine state colleges and 15 community colleges, with a total enrollment of 170,000.
''By force of his own personality and his energy and his ideas, in a relatively short period of time, he built himself a base of support,'' said Mr. Schwartz. ''More importantly, he developed an agenda for change and reform and was able to move forward very rapidly.''
 
A Commitment to People
Dr. Jenifer avoids revealing his immediate plans for Howard. More generally, he said he conceives Howard's mission in terms of aggressively serving people of color.
But, among his plans is the intention to mold the school into an internationally recognized center of authority on black America and the third world, he said. As others scramble to investigate a new Europe and the emerging industrial possibilities of the Pacific Rim, Dr. Jenifer said, Howard University should look to the potentials of Africa and developing countries as future players in a global economy.
At the same time, he said, he wants Howard to turn its energies toward the poor Northwestern Washington neighborhood where the school was founded in the early years after the Emancipation Proclamation.
''I want to see more of a blur of the line of demarcation between Howard and the rest of the community,'' Dr. Jenifer said, adding that as Howard has grown as an institution, the lives of an increasing number of the city's blacks have been diminished by poverty, violence and disease. He spoke of developing tutoring and mentoring programs, using Howard's economic might to create jobs for the residents of its area, and creating research programs aimed at the pathologies that are destroying the neighborhood.
Under Dr. Cheek's guidance, Howard underwent explosive expansion. Its doctoral and master's programs grew to 77 from 25. In recent years, however, students and faculty members have complained that the school that educated Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York and Toni Morrison, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author, was faltering.
 
Hopes for Howard
Late last year, after Dr. Cheek's announcement, the search began for someone who could restore the school's reputation.
Howard's faculty favored Dr. Jenifer, who had received his undergraduate and master's degrees in microbiology from Howard. He was attractive because he had a reputation for being a forceful leader as well as an accomplished scholar, said Dr. Lawrence Johnson, chairman of Howard's marketing department.
When Franklyn Jenifer made his way to the school in 1957 with dreams of becoming a ''Howard man,'' he was 18 years old, poor and had a portfolio of weak grades and test scores. He had been separated from his father at age 5 and worked to help out at home. In his favor, he said, he had a mother and a scout leader who believed in him. Nonetheless, Howard rejected him. 'The Best Thing'
''It was the best thing that ever happened to me,'' Dr. Jenifer said recently. ''My skill level was absolutely nonexistent.''
Instead, he took a job as a messenger at the Library of Congress and worked hard to improve himself. He pushed himself to learn Russian to get a better job in the library filing periodicals, and then enrolled in a night course for pages. With a better resume, he soon had a better chance at Howard. The semester after his rejection, he was accepted.
He drove himself to earn a bachelor's and then a master's degree at Howard in 1965, and he received a doctorate in plant virology from the University of Maryland in 1970.
For the next nine years, Dr. Jenifer was a professor of biology at Rutgers University in New Jersey, holding the posts of associate provost, department chairman and chairman of the university senate.
In 1979 Dr. Jenifer was named vice chancellor for the New Jersey Department of Higher Education. In 1986 he took the post in Massachusetts.
Married and with three grown children, Dr. Jenifer said he looks forward to seeing more of his mother and brother, both of whom still live in his native Washington.
''He will be very useful at Howard,'' said Alvin F. Poussaint, associate professor of psychiatry at Harvard Medical School and a friend of Dr. Jenifer. ''His own career will serve as a reinforcing model to the students.
''What's important is that he didn't quit.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Franklyn Green Jenifer, who is to be sworn in today as the 14th president of Howard University, hopes to mold the school into an internationally recognized authority on black America and the third world. (The New York Times/George Tames)

HEADLINE: Buffalo Shuts Down Its Buses and Subways

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BUFFALO, Mar. 31

 BODY:
Buffalo's financially strapped bus and subway system was shut down tonight, despite pleas from community leaders and protests from outraged riders. 
The Niagara Frontier Transportation Authority board voted 7-to-2 to shut down the system. The vote came about five hours before the last bus was to finish its run at 1:49 A.M. Sunday.
The shutdown put more than 1,000 employees out of work, but many said unemployment was preferable to the day-to-day existence they and the transit system had been enduring.
The Erie County Legislature on Wednesday rejected a tax on public utilities to finance transit after vigorous opposition from business leaders.

HEADLINE: Lifestyle: Sunday Dinner;
For Country or Organic, Or for People-Watching

 BODY:
This is a summary of reviews of Manhattan restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have ratings. Prices are current.
 
Barrow Street Bistro
Diner's Journal (Feb. 23, 1990), 48 Barrow Street at Seventh Avenue South (691-6800) - The California grill called Melrose has recently dropped its prices about 20 percent to become a solid economy-priced spot called Barrow Street Bistro. The food at this restaurant located near Village theaters is an appealing mix of country French and California. Good starters include ricotta-filled ravioli in a fresh tomato sauce; a delicately-crusted tart of leeks and goat cheese, and crisp rosti potatoes served with salmon tartar, creme fraiche and sevruga caviar. Main courses include grilled lamb chops with green lentils cooked with balsamic vinegar and bacon; rib-eye steak with Swiss chard and gratin potatoes; grilled Norwegian salmon, and calf's liver with pearl onions and raisins. Appetizers are $4 to $8, entrees $11 to $19. Sunday dinner hours are 5 to 10 P.M. 
 
Luma
Diner's Journal (Dec. 23, 1988), 200 Ninth Avenue, south of 23d Street (633-8033) - Organic ingredients are emphasized at this Chelsea restaurant, where dishes are prepared without dairy products or eggs, and a complete no-smoking policy is the house rule. Wine is allowed, however, and the list carries some good California labels. Among the current appetizers are the house salad with edible flowers in a light vinaigrette; grilled portobello mushrooms with seared endive and radicchio, and polenta with wild mushrooms and asparagus. The main courses might include cedar-roasted salmon with barley and wheatberry risotto; guinea hen served with roasted potatoes, carrots, onions and fried sage, and millet-breaded Arctic char (described as a cross between salmon and trout), accompanied by crisped leeks. For a dessert, there is ginger-crumb pear tart. Appetizers are $7.50 to $9.50, main courses $15 to $24. Sunday dinner from 5 to 10 P.M.
 
Orso
**(Feb. 17, 1989), 322 West 46th Street (489-7212) - This popular trattoria on Restaurant Row earns top billing among theater-district dining spots. The frequently changing menu carries about a dozen starters, a selection of small pizzas and a blend of northern Italian pastas and entrees. Recent choices have been starters of shrimp, scallop and octopus salad and smoked salmon with mixed crostini and watercress. One of the pizzas is topped with grilled eggplant, smoked mozzarella, mixed herbs and garlic. Pasta might be thin cracked-pepper noodles with arugula, tomato, ricotta and garlic oil, and entrees might include grilled halibut with fried capers and roasted chicken with sausage and artichokes. Appetizers are $7 to $8, pizzas are $8.50, pastas are $13, and entrees $16 to $20. Sunday hours are noon to 11:45 P.M.
 
Ten Twenty-Two
*(Jan. 12, 1990), 1022 Lexington Avenue, at 73d Street (737-1022) - This snug and clubby East Side spot, has a softly lighted dining room, a handsome wood bar, dark wainscoting and wooden Venetian blinds. Everything on the menu sounds appealing, and several appetizers can be recommended. These include the black bean soup served with corn sticks and the grilled buttery sea scallops set over haricots verts in a ginger-spiked vinaigrette. The best choices among entrees are the most homespun - for example, roasted chicken in pan juices served with rich mashed potatoes studded with pieces of fried leeks. Marinated grilled tuna is also nicely done, paired with a salsa cruda. A Long Island version of bouillabaisse with assorted local fish, white beans and spicy rouille are recommended as well. Creme brulee and chocolate caramel crack mousse are on hand for dessert fans. Appetizers are $6 to $12, entrees $18.50 to $24. Sunday dinner from 6 to 11 P.M.
 
Yellowfingers di Nuovo
Diner's Journal (April 25, 1989), 200 East 60th Street (751-8615) - Yellowfingers di Nuovo, at the corner of Third Avenue and 60th Street, is a lively spot for people-watching and also one of the better bargains around for an informal Sunday dinner. Individual herb-scented pizzas that they call fa'vecchia are topped with everything from salt, herbs and extra-virgin olive oil to smoked salmon, creme fraiche and chives. There is also an appealing selection of grilled meats and fish, an excellent rosemary-roasted chicken salad with sweet peppers and pine nuts, and sandwiches and side dishes like grilled new potatoes and fried polenta. Appetizers are $3.50 to $7.50; pizzas, $6 to $12; grilled entrees, $7.25 to $17.50. Sunday hours are noon to midnight.
 
WHAT THE STARS MEAN
 
(None) Poor to satisfactory
* Good
** Excellent
*** Extraordinary
 
These ratings reflect the reviewer's reaction primarily to food, with ambiance and service taken into consideration. Menu listings and prices are subject to change.
