LENGTH: 1517 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Round and Round, and Yet Another Round, at Lockheed
 
First, Harold C. Simmons bought nearly 19 percent of the Lockheed Corporation's shares. Then he called in the image doctors. Out came a videotape portraying him as a steady, hard-working industrialist. And on Thursday, Lockheed executives who had denounced him as a hungry corporate raider went through their own transformation, emerging as advocates of shareholder rights. They agreed to give major shareholders three board seats and exempt the company from anti-takeover laws. Mr. Simmons has wielded the videotape in his proxy fight to replace Lockheed's board. He has won over institutional investors who are becoming less content to remain passive - especially in a company, like Lockheed, with weak earnings and a falling stock price. The company has claimed victory, Mr. Simmons has claimed the vote is too close to call, but the true outcome may not be known for weeks.
 
 
 A.T.&T. Enters Credit Card Fray 
 
The giant American Telephone and Telegraph Company teamed up with a baby bank last week to issue a new combination of calling card and credit card. A.T.& T. chose as its partner the Universal Bank, a new subsidiary of the Synovus Financial Corporation. Synovus's headquarters, in Columbus, Ga., gives it a better perspective on the nearby Chattahoochee River than on nationwide banking ventures. But another Synovus subsidiary, Total Systems Services Inc., happens to be the nation's second-largest processor of credit-card transactions, with 14 million Visa and MasterCard holders. Only Citicorp has more.
 
 
 Case of the Outspoken Analyst
 
The Janney Montgomery Scott brokerage firm wants it known that Donald J. Trump's legal threats and demands had absolutely nothing to do with the dismissal of an analyst who questioned the outlook for Mr. Trump's Taj Mahal casino. ''We did not bow to Mr. Trump,'' Norman Wilde Jr., the brokerage firm's president, said last week. He said that the analyst, Marvin B. Roffman, was dismissed for repeatedly making unauthorized comments to news organizations.
 
 
 Upcoming at Magellan
 
Fidelity Investments rushed to issue reassurances last week that its Magellan Fund could keep succeeding even without Peter Lynch, who announced his retirement on Wednesday. His stock fund consistently out-performed the market even as it grew to $13 billion, the industry's largest. His successor, Morris J. Smith, 32, has run Fidelity's well-regarded, $700 million over-the-counter fund. Mr. Smith bristled at suggestions that he might steer Magellan toward value plays, in contrast to Mr. Lynch's penchant for growth stocks. ''I own some pretty high P/E's,'' he said, referring to stocks selling for high ratios of their earnings, but then added, ''I admit I sleep better when I own stocks with a lower P/E.'' Who knows but that value investing might make more sense during the 1990's, which are unlikely to be as kind to growth stocks as the decade past. Investors seem willing to give Mr. Smith a chance. Fidelity reported that last week Magellan had only modest redemptions.
 
In Brief
 
Creditors of Eastern Airlines were said last Thursday to be considering steps that could result in the carrier's liquidation in Federal bankruptcy court. On Tuesday, Eastern told the creditors it could no longer guarantee to pay them 50 cents on the dollar.
 
*
 
James T. Sherwin, vice chairman of the GAF Corporation, was sentenced on Friday to six months in prison for securities fraud. GAF was fined $2 million.
 
 
 More Guilty Pleas in Defense
 
A major target of the long Federal investigation into Pentagon purchasing abuses pleaded guilty to bribery and tax evansion on Wednesday. William M. Galvin, once a prominent defense procurement consultant, also agreed to cooperate with the Government. Court documents said that he had arranged to bribe high-ranking Pentagon officials. They in return allegedly agreed to steer contracts to two of Mr. Galvin's clients, Mazlat Ltd. of Israel and the Loral Corporation of New York.
 
 
 Cigarettes - Just Say Non
 
Can't imagine a French cafe without a heavy haze from Gauloises and Gitanes? The French Government can, and on Wednesday announced a plan to persuade citizens that smoking is deadly, not debonair. If Parliament approves, cigarette prices would rise about 15 percent next year, and all cigarette advertising and event sponsorship would be banned starting in 1993. French health officials want to restrict alcohol advertising as well. But the French - among the world's heaviest drinkers - are unlikely to allow it. As even the French Minister of Health, Claude Evin, said, ''A little alcohol is not harmful and could be good.''
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY
 
Minimum Wage Making Waves
 
Today's 45-cent increase in the minimum wage is likely to stoke both consumer spending and inflation. A tight labor market, with low unemployment, could send reverberations from the new $3.80 minimum well up the wage scale. Only 6.5 million workers will be directly affected by the increase, but another 7 million to 13 million will see their salaries bumped up, said Lacy Hunt, chief economist at Carroll McEntee & McGinley Inc. And higher consumer spending will add one percent to economic growth during the second and third quarters, he said. When low wage earners get raises, he explained, ''Virtually all that money will be spent quickly.'' The minimum wage goes up again next year, to $4.25.
 
 
 More S.&L. Losses . . .
 
Savings and loans continue to pile up losses. Federal regulators reported last week that the industry had a record $19.2 billion deficit last year, compared with a $13.4 billion loss in 1988. The setting for this news has become painfully familiar: a hearing where Federal officials try to persuade members of Congress that the worst is past and the industry is on its way back.
 
 
 . . . And a Possible Regulator
 
By one vote, the Senate Banking Committee approved on Friday the Bush Administration's nomination of T. Timothy Ryan Jr. as chief regulator for the savings and loan industry. Several committee members protested that Mr. Ryan, a former Labor Department lawyer, lacked experience in the savings and loan business. The White House said that finding anyone to supervise the industry's bailout has been tough. ''If this was an easy job we'd have people lining up at the door to get it,'' said Marlin Fitzwater, the President's spokesman.
 
 
 In Brief
 In an annual trade report on Friday, the Bush Administration cited Japan for maintaining the most barriers among 35 countries that restrict American exports.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
 
 The Saudis Rejoin the Play
 
Back in the early 1980's, before anyone followed the Nikkei index or yen, Wall Street watched petrodollars and the price of oil. Now, with oil prices on the rebound and revenues rising, the Saudi Arabians might move markets again. The Saudis are said to have sold more than 2 million ounces of gold last Monday, sending the price down $23 an ounce to $366 (page 15). David T. Mizrahi, editor of the Mideast Report newsletter, said they needed to buy British pounds to make payments on their weapons bills. For years, the Saudis have been draining their financial reserves as slack oil revenues have failed to cover the costs of their ambitious public spending programs, he said. Now they have resumed adding to their savings, which he estimates at $70 billion or more. ''They're going to be a bigger player in the coming years,'' said William B. Quandt, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, ''but not in the position they had in 1980 and 1981.'' Their favored investment: United States Treasury securities. They also own a large block of Texaco Inc. stock.
 
 
 North America, United?
 
A North American common market? Mexico took the first step last week by agreeing to consider free-trade talks with the United States. But the Mexican fear of economic domination by the United States remains so great - the issue helped spark the Mexican Revolution - that sector-by-sector arrangements appear far more likely in the near future than sweeping agreements. President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, invariably identified in the American press as a Harvard-trained economist, has already lowered trade barriers and welcomed American investment. ''In many ways, Salinas is redrawing the boundaries'' for Mexico's economic ties to the United States, said Robert Pastor, a fellow at the Carter Center. A North American common market, Mr. Pastor added, is ''such a logical idea it's going to happen. The only real question is whether it's going to be in 10 years or 50 years.''
 
The Nikkei, Soaring and Sinking
 
Another jarring week on the Tokyo stock market: The Nikkei index jumped 1,468.33 points on Monday, a 4.83 percent gain and its second-best ever. But the market fell 1,045.71 points on Friday to finish at 29,980.45, down 1.29 percent for the week.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Betting on the 'Green' Group

 BODY:
Spinning gold from garbage is the alchemy of the 1990's. That's the clear message from money managers, who are beginning to bet heavily on the environmental services sector. ''Cleaning up our polluted planet will be the growth industry of the 90's,'' said Donavon McKerchar, portfolio manager of Oppenheimer's Global Environmental Fund, launched last month.
Several small funds focus on the environment. The $13 million New Alternatives Fund, a father-and-son operation which has been based on Long Island since 1982, invests primarily in alternative energy companies. The $2 million SFT Environmental Awareness Fund, in King of Prussia, Pa., was set up at the end of 1988. 
The Progressive Environmental Fund, part of the Schield Management Company, in Denver, will begin investing this month. Its chairman, Glenn S. Cutler, says 5 percent of the fund's marketing fee will be donated to environmental groups each year. (And, yes, the fee, at .95 percent, is one of the highest among environmental funds.) But the big players ignored the sector until last June, when Fidelity launched its Select Environmental Services Fund. The Freedom Environmental Fund, part of the John Hancock group in Boston, followed in September. The Oppenheimer fund just began investing and Alliance Capital Management is to launch the Global Environment Fund, the first closed-end environmental fund, in two months.
Why the sudden interest? Fund managers say environmental housekeeping has become the world's top priority and that each time there is another environmental scare - the Exxon oil spills, radon, asbestos, acid rain - the public calls for tougher regulations and higher public spending. ''Public opinion has given birth to this industry, and it's accelerating,'' Mr. McKerchar said.
With the environmental advocates as catalysts, public awareness is driving political action. Congress is revamping the Clean Air Act and is expected to complete the work in the next month or so. Legislators are supposed to tackle the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act this fall. There's more money, too, allocated for specific problems like Superfund sites and acid rain.
A big part of the interest in stocks of environment companies, of course, stems from the Government's willingness to foot the cleaning bill. ''Hundreds of billions of dollars are pouring into a brand-new industry,'' said Larry Greenberg, who manages the Fidelity fund.
Other countries, too, plan heavy spending. Britain must put up more than $25 billion to meet new European Community water standards, and the Netherlands is expected to spend up to 3 percent of its gross national product to clean up the Rhine.
So the funds are looking for gold in the garbage heap. They invest in companies in the business of solid- or hazardous-waste management, pollution control, paper recycling, engineering and construction, water technology and alternative energy sources.
Although the year-to-date returns for environmental funds have lagged stock funds, Michael E. Hoffman, pollution control and specialty chemicals analyst for Salomon Brothers, said ''most of the poor performance is strictly a function of profit-taking of stocks that made 50 to 60 percent runups in 1989.'' He said that, as a group, environment stocks would have ''sound earnings'' for 1990, although they would not record the big gains that they did last year.
The largest holdings of Fidelity's $85 million fund are Laidlaw Industries, a Canadian company, and Chicago-based Waste Management Inc., both leaders in solid- and hazardous-waste disposal. Mr. Greenberg, the fund's manager, says both companies are well positioned to profit from two industry trends: privatization, as more municipalities turn over their garbage business to private companies, and consolidation of the 10,000 mom-and-pop garbage collection companies, which is taking place as increased regulations make smaller companies less competitive.
David S. Beckwith, who manages the Freedom Fund, likes Zurn Industries, based in Erie, Pa., a manufacturer of equipment and instruments used in waste energy plants. He expects it to post strong gains as more plants are built and says that, as a supplier, Zurn can pursue its business ''without the attendant regulatory headaches'' that plague most environmental service companies. Another favorite: Safety Clean, a Chicago-based recycler of liquid hazardous waste.
Andrew Groshans, manager of SFT, likes the Chambers Development Corporation, a Pittsburgh-based solid-waste management company. He also likes Calgon Carbon, also in Pittsburgh, the world's largest provider of activated carbon used in water-treatment systems. Calgon recently acquired a West German company, which Mr. Groshan says gives it a strong foothold in Europe.
The New Alternatives Fund is run by two ex-lawyers who began investing $100,000 gathered from friends. Its largest holding is Wellman Inc., in Clark, N.J., the nation's largest recyclers of plastic and synthetic fibers. Another favorite: Burlington Resources, of Seattle, which has large natural gas holdings.
 
 
 
GOODBYE, PETER LYNCH
Peter Lynch, head of the Fidelity Magellan Fund and one of Wall Street's most successful money managers, resigned last week. King of the hill during a 13-year stint building the fund to a $13 billion giant, Mr. Lynch, 46 years old, said he was leaving for personal reasons and that his decision was not a forecast of where the markets are headed. Should Magellan shareholders jump ship too? ''No, but this is a good time to review how Magellan fits into your portfolio,'' said Eric M. Kobren, publisher of Fidelity Insight, an independent investment newsletter in Wellesley, Mass. The fund is now so large it is unwieldy, he said, and the next 10 years won't be as good as the last.

HEADLINE: Technology;
The Software With Good Sense

BYLINE: By GEORGE HARRAR; George Harrar, a freelance writer based in Wayland, Mass., is co-author of ''The Ultimate Entrepreneur.''

 BODY:
Water flows downhill. A person can't be in two places at once. All animals live, die and stay dead. Such common-sense statements about the world are so basic that no encyclopedia bothers to include them.
But it is exactly what an encyclopedia omits that Douglas Lenat, a research scientist at Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corporation, in Austin, Tex., wants in his knowledge base, called ''Cyc.'' Cyc is the name for an M.C.C. project at known as ''large common sense knowledge-base construction,'' which Mr. Lenat is designing to augment other computer programs by giving them common sense.
A data base is simply an assemblage of facts stored in a central computer; a knowledge base is broader, containing information about logic, relationships and descriptions of behavior. 
''We're trying to instill in Cyc what the writers of the Britannica assumed everybody already knows,''Mr. Lenat said.
The Cyc project began in 1984, the same year M.C.C. was formed as high-technology research and development cooperative. Mr. Lenat projected then that it would take 10 years to create a knowledge base of 100 million common-sense assertions.
When the Cyc project is completed its knowledge base will contain 4 billion or 5 billion bytes of information - 10,000 times larger than a typical expert system today. Expert systems - programs that attempt to mimic the decision-making and thought processes of expert human beings - are the most common type of artificial intelligence.
The work Mr. Lenat is doing does not come cheaply. Each of the seven shareholders in the Cyc project - Apple Computer Inc., Bell Communications Research Inc. (Bellcore), Control Data Corporation, Digital Equipment Corporation, Harris Corporation, Eastman Kodak Company and NCR Corporation - contribute $500,000 a year. With their investment, the participating companies gain the right to use whatever Mr. Lenat's research efforts achieve to develop and enhance their own computer products.
The problem with expert systems is that the programs operate in only one, specialized subject area, such as oil exploration. Mr. Lenat's research, if it succeeds, could give these programs greater breadth and flexibility. For instance, a computer program with a general understanding of the way the world works - and specific knowledge about a person's schedule, habits, past correspondence, job and so on - could answer that person's routine electronic mail on a variety of subjects.
Cyc's real distinction is not the amount of knowledge it includes, but the kind. Only about one-third of its memory will be devoted to standard encyclopedia-style information. The remaining two-thirds will contain rules of thumb (''People generally can't see through walls''); laws of physical objects (''A car parked at the airport will tend to stay parked there until you return from your destination''), and constraints on life (''Nothing can be older than its creator'').
In the constraints category, Mr. Lenat cites a self-evident proposition: No child can be older than its parents.
''People would never make the mistake that the child could be older than his parents,'' Mr. Lenat said. ''But the typical computer program would.''
Mr. Lenat is attempting to create a program that can be customized for particular environments or people. Cyc would be able to intelligently monitor other programs as well as the actions of the operator. For example, if a computer programmed to follow financial investments advised an individual to purchase a 20-year bond, Cyc might intercede and remind the computer user that in 10 years he may need the money to pay for his daughter's college tuition.
Mr. Lenat's sponsors are beginning to determine how to use his research. ''One idea,'' said Ed Freeman of U. S. West, a Bell operating company which participates in the Cyc project through Bellcore, ''is to develop a customer adviser assistant. It would give U. S. West personnel advice on solving customer problems on-line while they are working with customers.''
Digital is already testing Cyc to design computer systems for customers. John McDermott, head of the Digital's Artificial Intelligence Research Group, foresees advanced versions of Cyc that can assess the computing needs of Digital's customers and select components, like terminals, central processing units and memory, that would fulfill those needs.
To Mr. McDermott, Cyc's essential quality is that it brings a tremendous amount of knowledge and intelligence to a problem. If the goals of an organization are changing, a person could describe the current corporate structure to Cyc, which would retrieve from its knowledge examples of similarly organized companies that have succeeded or failed trying to attain similar goals. Cyc could replace the haphazard, time-consuming hunt through journals and periodicals.
Joseph Scullion, director of strategic planning at NCR, cannot yet point to any product that his company might derive from Cyc. ''But,'' he said, ''just being able to capture common-sense intelligence in a work station means that whatever application you run on it can be more complex. And lightly trained people can be more productive.''
For example, perhaps the owner of a small business tries to save a lawyer's research fees by doing the search himself for a legal precedent related to a personnel problem. On his work station, he might well fail to navigate the on-line data base to find the information he needs. With Cyc helping, Mr. Lenat said, ''your task is not thinking up the proper legal terms, but just explaining what your problem is. Cyc figures out how to deal with the data base.''
Mr. Lenat's approach to cultivating common sense is not universally appreciated. Rodney Brooks, a researcher who directs the Mobile Robot Group at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, said Mr. Lenant's approach is to assume that ''common sense is a result of a reasoning process.'' But, according to Mr. Brooks, ''you don't have to think it's bad to put your hand on a hot stove - you feel that it is bad.''
In Mr. Brooks's opinion, the problem with Mr. Lenat's knowledge base is that ''it will never ground out.'' He means that when a search is conducted, one item will lead to another and then another without ever making a final conclusion.
Mr. Lenat has addressed this criticism by programming rules into Cyc that will limit its searches and focus its program on answering the questions asked of it. Mr. Lenat is confident that his ''one assertion at a time'' method will create a computer program that knows as much about how the world works as the average person. In some cases, it will know more. ''Cyc knows that it knows,'' Mr. Lenat said.
''When did you learn that the chicken that is on your plate is the same as the chicken that runs around on the farm? Most people don't remember. Cyc will tell you the exact date it learned that. In this sense, it is more self-aware than we are.''
Artificial intelligence researchers have consistently failed to live up to their most boastful claims, and there is no guarantee that Mr. Lenat will either. But as U. S. West's Mr. Freeman said, ''The sorts of questions that Doug is asking are very important. Even if the Cyc project crashes and burns, the black box recorder is going to be worth the price of admission.''

* No Picasso painting could have been created bedore Picasso was born.
 
* Items sold for use by children are more regulated than items sold for use by adults.

* The basic business unit of measurement in a hospitial is the hospitial bed; in a hotel it is the room.
 
* On a very cloudy day it is a good idea for a person to carry an umbrella.

HEADLINE: Currency;
All Eyes on the Group of 7

 BODY:
Foreign exchange traders will be focusing this week on the meeting of the United States and its economic allies in the Group of Seven next Saturday in Paris. The traders will be closely following the official comments during the week of the finance ministers of the seven members - the others are Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada - to see whether the group is likely to make a coordinated effort to rescue the beleaguered yen. The yen slipped perilously close to 160 to the dollar last week before rallying a bit because of profit taking. Without some formal statement from the Group of Seven after the meeting or dollar selling by central banks in the days that follow, the yen could fall further, taking the Tokyo stock and bond markets with it.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
The U.S. Stake in Reunification

BYLINE: By JOHN L. LAFALCE; John J. LaFalce, Democrat of New York, is a member of the House Banking Committee and chairman of the House Banking Committee Task Force on the International Competitiveness of U.S. Financial Institutions.

 BODY:
The coming unification of Germany - a virtual certainty in the aftermath of last month's first free Parliamentary election in East Germany - provides the United States with a major opportunity to take commercial advantage of Central Europe's sudden opening to the West.
In the short term, East Germany itself will remain an expanding market for American goods. This is the clear impression I received in numerous talks with East Germany's new entrepreneurial class while visiting Berlin earlier this year. There are already favorable portents. Within the last week, a French-American telecommunications company announced plans to overhaul East Germany's outdated telephone network, and General Motors Corporation and Automobil-Werk Eisenach, East Germany's largest auto maker, will form a joint venture which could ultimately produce 150,000 cars annually. 
By moving into East Germany today, American companies will also improve their competitive position within the European markets of the future - beginning with Central Europe. Experts believe that once a large volume of West German capital begins flowing into the eastern part of the country, today's East Germany could become what South Korea and Taiwan have become for Southeast Asia: a dynamic engine of export-driven growth. Similar considerations apply to the European Community. A stronger American market position in East Germany today virtually guarantees America a stronger competitive position in the integrated European market after 1992.
But how do we get from here to there? Achieving a stronger American position in a unified German market will require much stronger policy direction from Washington. Broadly speaking, Congress must press the Bush Administration to make good on its oft-repeated commitment to remove a crippling array of legal obstacles that continue to weaken our competitive position throughout Central Europe and the Soviet Union. East Germany's uncertain status has not prevented our West German, French or Italian allies from providing appropriate amounts of export finance and political risk insurance to their firms. We should do no less. Both the Export-Import Bank, which just a few days ago qualified Czechoslovakia to participate in its programs, and the Overseas Private Investment Corporation should be moving into the East German market without further delay.
Congress should also insist on radical changes in our self-defeating export control policies. At last month's Coordinating Committee for Multilateral Export Controls - called Cocom - meeting in Paris, for example, the United States for the first time agreed that companies no longer need export licenses to sell high-tolerance machine tools, 32-bit microcomputers and a range of telecommunications equipment to the rapidly dissolving Eastern Bloc. Far bolder American steps are required.
The first order of business for Congress is to hold the Administration to its promise to significantly reduce the number of so-called ''off the shelf'' - easily available - items which inexplicably remain on Cocom's commodity control list and could with little difficulty be successfully marketed in East Germany. Simultaneously, the United States should accelerate multilateral efforts to reduce drastically the number of truly strategic goods we wish to remain on the Cocom list.
Thinking about future American initiatives toward East Germany raises the inevitable question of how long and under what conditions we will be able to conduct negotiations with an existing East German Government.
This is a matter over which Washington has little, if any, influence. The most plausible assumption is that Bonn will continue to treat East Germany as a separate economic entity for the foreseeable future. Far from discouraging an active American presence in the eastern part of the country, a variety of geopolitical and economic considerations suggest that, if anything, Bonn will favor an expanded American commercial presence in that part of the country.
To facilitate matters, both East Germany and the United States need to dispose of some old business. On the East German side, the new conservative coalition should accelerate efforts to settle material claims by American citizens for property expropriated by the Communist authorities 40 years ago. Similarly, East Germany needs to acknowledge forthrightly its responsibility for crimes against the Jewish community during the period of the Third Reich and make appropriate financial amends. Combined with recent steps to liberalize emigration procedures, the above East German actions should in turn enable the Administration and Congress to take the second logical step by granting most-favored-nation treatment to East Germany, as Japan, Sweden and the European Community have already done. Taking such a step at this critical time would go a long way toward putting our commercial relations with a transformed Germany on a new, more profitable footing. The stakes, to put it mildly, are huge.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
The Negotiations With Japan Get Personal

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
LIKE squabbling marriage partners, Japan and the United States have tried one idea after another to overcome their differences, falling each time into a new round of recrimination. This year it finally seemed that they had decided to get some meaningful therapy. The trouble is that each country has hired the other to do the psychoanalyzing.
Last week it was disclosed that Washington recently presented 240 suggestions to Japan on how to reduce the two countries' persistent $50 billion trade gap. But none was aimed at getting Tokyo to import specific American products. Instead, the United States wants Japan to change ingrained practices - like the dominance of huge business cartels - and adopt other means of improving access to Japanese markets.
Not to be outdone, the Japanese Government responded with 80 suggestions of its own, urging that the United States reduce its Federal budget deficit, increase its pool of savings, curtail the use of credit cards, raise gasoline taxes and spend more on education, and on research and development. These steps would theoretically improve American industrial competitiveness, leading to products that Japan might want to buy. 
The ideas on both sides are so sweeping and unrealistic that many experts think that efforts to define and eliminate so-called structural impediments to trade may be aggravating tensions instead of easing them. ''We've become like two neighbors stepping into each other's kitchens, free to criticize what we think is wrong,'' said a senior Japanese negotiator. ''That sort of exercise would test the strength of any friendship.''
It now looks as though Japan will respond to the criticisms with a modest package of revisions that are considered unlikely to have much impact on the trade balance. But the recent discussions might have a much deeper significance. They represent the first systematic attempt by the United States to decide how it should think about Japan.
The effort is long overdue and could help to clarify some of the confusion about a nation that is both America's greatest ally and its greatest rival. Few nations inspire such sharp disagreements among experts over basic assumptions. Public policy discussions echoing with empty slogans like ''the triumph of capitalism'' and the need for a ''level playing field'' have helped little now that the challenge is less one of Communism than of a system of capitalism operating under unaccustomed ground rules.
''Americans are deeply confused because Japan is an intellectual problem as great as the U.S.S.R. ever was,'' said Chalmers Johnson, professor of political science at the University of California at San Diego and an expert on Japanese industrial policy. ''Our whole approach is premised on the idea that we and Japan are becoming more like each other. I always thought that was an especially stupid idea.''
American ambivalence seems further complicated by the uncertainties of the post-cold-war era and a loss of American confidence in the ability of the United States to compete. People wonder whether Japan is an unstoppable mercantile power aspiring to global dominance and refusing to play by free-market rules, or an unswerving ally that is opening its economy to imports, assuming new responsibilities and becoming sensitive to issues of global interdependence.
In trying to change what it sees as ingrained barriers to trade, the United States also has an ulterior motive. If Washington can persuade Japan to use its huge pool of investment capital to build roads and houses in Japan, there will be that much less money for buying hotels, golf clubs and banks in the United States.
 
'A Social Revolution'
On the other hand, the exercise is peculiar because it is almost as if the United States is trying to make Japan into a country more like itself - with K Marts, big highways, big cars, big houses filled with consumer products, preferably made in America. Japan is also being asked to free up more land for housing and commercial use, spend more on public works, deregulate a retail distribution system protecting small shopkeepers that do not carry foreign products, and eliminate cartels and other anti-competitive practices by big Japanese businesses.
''It's hubris on the part of the United States to make such demands,'' said Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., the former Reagan Administration trade official who has become a critic of American policies toward Japan. ''For Japan to meet the American suggestions would require a social revolution. It's not going to happen.''
As they have in the past, the Japanese assert that the difficulty of changing their system is that the practices are embedded in cultural traditions. Michael H. Armacost, the United States Ambassador in Japan, observed recently that ''American political culture is highly individualistic,'' while Japan is a Confucian society that ''accords a higher priority to the community'' with ''a considerable autonomy and respect'' for people of high rank. This view holds that Japanese people find it easy to invest their faith in the powerful corporate conglomerates that have charged high prices at home in order to undercut competitors abroad. The rewards of that faith are the envy of all the world.
In the last year or so, a new school of thought has coalesced, sometimes called revisionism, which rejects such cultural explanations for Japanese habits and ways. The revisionists suggest that Japanese faith in powerful organizations - in producers rather than consumers - is the legacy of centuries of oppressive political relationships. These scholars see the Japanese power structure, not the culture, as the source of its practices.
In their view, for instance, the Government of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu cannot afford to eliminate cartels, collusion, price-fixing and bid-rigging among big companies - a basic aim in the current talks with the United States - because it received $200 million in political contributions in the last year from the largest Japanese corporations, which depend on these practices for their livelihood.
 
Beating 'the System'
Some revisionists have a bleak view of Japan. Professor Johnson, for example, asserts that Japan is a mercantile power like the Germany of the late 19th century: it protects its domestic market, overcharges consumers at home, subsidizes exports and engages in predatory pricing abroad that has wiped out its competitors in electronics, automobiles and other fields. He argues, for example, that construction companies that engage in bid rigging - constantly deplored by Washington - could not do so without the tacit consent of the ruling party, which, he says, gets an enormous amount of money from the building industry.
In his recent book, ''The Enigma of Japanese Power,'' Karel van Wolferen, a Dutch journalist, posits the existence of ''the System,'' which he says is the product of centuries of political oppression and thought control imposed through educational, cultural, political and bureaucratic institutions. The loving devotion of Japanese people for their corporations and educational system, he writes, has been a triumph of propaganda and social engineering ''vastly superior to those other major products of social engineering,'' Nazism and Leninism.
Many Japanese condemn Mr. van Wolferen's thesis as ethnocentric. But the observation of Japan's uniqueness is as old as the first encounters by Westerners. In the 16th century, Alessandro Valignano, a Portuguese Jesuit missionary, said of the Japanese, ''They have rites and ceremonies so different from those of all other nations that it seems that they deliberately try to be unlike any other people.''
Four hundred years later, many people still see Japan as a nation with special characteristics. ''The criticism that Japan is somehow unique has begun to shape the whole debate about us,'' lamented a Japanese diplomat. ''The fact is, Japanese intellectuals have failed to answer this criticism.''

HEADLINE: THE WORLD: A Voice From Latin America;
Some Lessons In Democracy - For the U.S.

BYLINE: By HERNANDO de SOTO; Hernando de Soto, a Peruvian businessman, is head of the Institute for Liberty and Democracy, a group that promotes change of political institutions in the third world. He is the author of ''The Other Path'' (Harper & Row), about the transition to democratic capitalism.

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru

 BODY:
IN the United States there has been much talk about increasing credits, investment and aid to Eastern Europe at the expense of money destined for Latin America. The aim is to help emerging capitalism and democracy where socialism has failed. But from a cynical Latin perspective, this South-to-East shift constitutes a transfer of resources from where capitalism has failed to where socialism has failed.
Most Latin American countries have had private property and democratic constitutions for nearly 170 years. This in addition to the tens of billions of dollars in foreign aid and hundreds of billions of dollars in loans have not raised the per capita gross domestic product over $2,000 a year. Meanwhile, totalitarian socialism, which is proclaimed to have failed, offered Eastern Europeans $5,000 a year. 
In United States policies toward Latin America and Eastern Europe the most important question seems to get little consideration: why did private property, democratic constitutions and resources from abroad fail to generate success in the South, and why are they expected to succeed in the East?
The Institute for Liberty and Democracy in Lima figured that if these three conditions have not produced prosperity, it may be that both the Latin elites and United States experts spent too much time studying backward societies, pronouncing them immovable, even lovable, cultural relics rather than studying why countries like the United States are successful. So we studied the institutions of developed countries and compared them with our own. This research found that the successful union of democracy and the market in developed countries has been accomplished through various institutions, extending far beyond elections and the elimination of central planning.
For example, Peru is considered a democracy because it elects a president and a parliament. In the five years after an election, though, the executive branch has been known to make 134,000 rules and decrees with no accountability to the congress or the public. After elections, no ongoing relationships exist between those who make decisions and those who live under them.
 
U.S. vs. Latin Democracy
In the United States democracy, elections are only the beginning. Rule-making is also democratic. To start, Americans have access to most government information. Draft rules must be published. Citizens can comment on them in writing and in hearings, and officials must respond. If the officials do not, the people can overturn the rule, using administrative courts. Civil servants do cost-benefit analyses on proposed regulations and Congressmen receive and react to constituents' letters. At the state level, referendums are used to circumvent government when, in spite of all these mechanisms, it fails to respond.
Latin American regulations and legislation are not the product of democracy, but of bargaining between a few special interests and officials. Their bargains lead to law that restricts access to markets, distorting prices and perpetuating poverty. This protects a small class of crony capitalists, denies opportunity to others and deepens inequality. This arrangement requires armies of bureaucrats and policemen for enforcement and foments underground economies for the peaceful poor, violent resistance from the rest, and migration to the United States by those who can travel.
The institutions underlying the success of the American market system and the genuine participation of Americans in their own governance were constructed over 200 years. So unnoticed has this process been that Americans have taken it for granted, losing the ability to recognize and teach the importance of these institutions and failing to incorporate them into their foreign policies.
The route to democratic capitalism is complicated and unglamorous. Take the crucial matters of tariff decisions and property rights.
In Peru, decisions on import duties are a prerogative of the president made far away from the public. As a consequence, tariff and trade decisions can distort the free market, and are a primary source of crony capitalism. In the United States, proposals to modify tariffs must be authorized by Congress, published by the Government, independently analyzed and discussed at hearings. Most must be able to survive judicial challenge. Compared with Peru's, American trade decisions are a marvel of efficiency, coherence and stability.
As for property, just because it is not government-owned does not make it efficient. In Peru, for example, private property abounds, but it is not legally secure. In the United States, property rights are grounded in unambiguous titles and registration. Transfer is easy, by sale or lease, and the full use of it is permitted, for example, as collateral for bank loans.
Getting a title on a home in Peru, however, requires up to 48 months of hard work and far more than the yearly minimum wage for bribes and registration fees. As a result, little private property is registered. In the few cases in which it is, after 10 years its value is up to nine times greater than that of unregistered property. Moreover, registered titles provide access to mortgage-backed finance, which in the United States accounts for most credit that new businesses receive.
It is evident then that for private property to work, sophisticated registry systems must be set up. Such a system must be capable of starting from scratch and operating on a scale so much greater than what is required even in the United States that it cannot be imported. We know because in Peru the Institute for Liberty and Democracy has just set up such a system.
Designing the transition from Latin American mercantilism or European Communism to market-oriented democracies is not as easy as writing a check. This is evident if one considers that only 20 out of 170 countries in the world have built the institutions and successfully made the transition.
Until there is a serious effort to meet the requirements of developing true democracy and equitable capitalism, and commit adequate resources to it, a shift in the flow of funds from Latin America to Eastern Europe will make little difference in the long run to either. Paradoxically, it may force Latins to invest scarce resources in improving our institutions, while East Europeans stall their political and economic development as they use their most valuable talents to get a bigger slice of the American funds, just as Latin Americans have done for the best part of this century.
Of course, if the American focus is on the short-run fulfillment of basic human needs Latin Americans might remind Washington that per capita income in Eastern Europe is more than twice that in Latin America. Whose basic human needs are greater?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Boning Up For the Next Battle Over Deregulation

BYLINE: By ERIC WEINER

 BODY:
AIRLINE deregulation has produced, besides much else, a steady stream of studies. More than a dozen institutes and Government agencies have churned out piles of papers since Congress decided 12 years ago to allow the airlines to fly when and where they want and to charge whatever passengers were willing to pay.
Depending on the study, deregulation is anything from a rousing success that has saved consumers billions of dollars to a dismal failure that has led to higher fares, poorer service and an erosion of saftey margins. There are more flights but fewer airlines; passenger complaints are up, but so are the number of passengers; fares are at once higher and lower. 
The latest study, released Wednesday by the Economic Policy Institute, a Washington organization associated with liberal thinking, found that air fares, when adjusted for inflation and fuel prices, are higher than they would have been had the Government continued to regulate the industry.
The study contradicts a review by the Department of Transportation released in February, which concluded that deregulation has led to more choices for consumers and fares that are, on average, 15 percent lower.
Congress is considering several proposals to re-regulate the industry, but the Bush Administration is opposed to any such moves. Secretary of Transportation Samuel K. Skinner is expected to arm himself with his department's voluminous study to fend off new restrictions. The study by the Economic Policy Institute will provide ammunition to the other side.
In the early days of airline deregulation, new carriers sprang on the scene with fares cheaper than bus tickets. But of the dozens of upstarts, only two have survived - Midway Airlines and America West.
Today, the top eight airlines control more than 90 percent of the market, down from 15 airlines in 1984. Meanwhile, the prospect is further consolidation: weaker carriers like Pan American World Airways, Trans World Airways and Eastern might not survive.
The barriers to entry are formidable. Major airlines have a virtual lock on gate space at four of the nation's busiest airports: Washington National, O'Hare in Chicago, and Kennedy and La Guardia in New York. The large airlines' reservation systems and frequent-flier programs have also deterred new entrants.
''A new carrier has to find a true niche and make sure it's not stomping on the toes of its competitors,'' said Lee Howard, executive vice president of Airline Economics, a consulting firm in Washington.
The study released last week said deregulation had been credited for trends that were already established in 1978. Fares and fuel prices had been falling for the previous decade. Because of lower-cost fuel, more efficient jets and other advances in productivity, fares would have fallen with or without deregulation, the study concluded. Using the same measures, the study found the cost of flying today is, on average, 2.6 percent a mile higher.
In places, fares seem to have gone berserk. In Kansas City, travel agents have been complaining that more people are driving the 257 miles to St. Louis now that Braniff Airlines has gone bankrupt and no longer serves the city. A full-fare, one-way coach ticket on T.W.A. costs $250. A cab ride costs $231.
Champions of deregulation note that in the 12 years the number of passengers has nearly doubled. Critics contend that, while discount fares account for some of that growth, more Americans are inclined to fly anyway as the baby-boom generation grows older and wealthier. ''These things had nothing to do with deregulation,'' said Paul Stephen Dempsey, author of the study and a former lawyer for the Civil Aeronautics Board who once supported deregulation.
The most visible change brought by deregulation was the hub-and-spoke system. Airlines funnel planes into a central airport and then disperse them in spokes to dozens of cities. The airlines argue that they can serve smaller cities; for instance, a passenger in Colorado Springs has access to hundreds of flights simply by changing planes in Denver, where United and Continental Airlines have hubs. But even the Transportation Department report found that because the system has also allowed near-monopolies in some cities, the fares at hub airports are higher.
What about the worst fear about deregulation: that safety would suffer? The accident rate is lower than it was in 1978, but Mr. Dempsey and others say the skies are safer despite deregulation, not because of it. Airplanes are older, pilots younger and the amount spent on maintenance per plane lower. More automated planes and better flight training have compensated for these problems, Mr. Dempsey said.
Several bills before Congress would essentially re-regulate the industry. Other, perhaps more politically palatable proposals include imposing ceilings on fares in certain markets, allowing foreign airlines to fly domestic routes and limiting the number of hub airports that an airline can control.
''We ought to have the courage and wisdom to admit we made a mistake,'' wrote Mr. Dempsey. ''The time has come to roll back deregulation.'' Alfred E. Kahn, the economist who is considered the originator of deregulation, supports some forms of re-regulation but says 90 percent of passengers are better off today.
''I never promised people a perfect system,'' Mr. Kahn said.

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
Dinkins Wanted An Unusual Group To Run His City, And Here It Is

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
IF mayors are known by the company they keep, David N. Dinkins bids fair to be remembered for surrounding himself with the most diverse administration in New York City's history. But he has taken his time to do it, and now must blend the eclectic group to make it all work.
In many ways, Mr. Dinkins is the consummate insider, a 25-year veteran of the Manhattan Democratic machine who has known or worked with almost everyone who is anyone in city politics. Yet he was elected on a platform promising change and brought with him an unusual group of goads and gadflies, with a sprinkling of seasoned bureaucrats.
This Mayor made a female labor-union economist his finance commissioner; a black, openly gay psychiatrist his mental health commissioner, and a bird-watching Medicaid-fraud lawyer his environmental commissioner. He has put out-of-towners in charge of the police, jails, welfare and health departments. 
Edward I. Koch, who was Mayor for 12 years, was often criticized for appointing too few minorities and women to important jobs and for relying on a cadre of experienced politicians and bureaucrats. Mr. Dinkins, while recycling some people, is taking a different tack.
It remains to be seen if diversity alone will bring greater efficiency or responsiveness to a sprawling government of a quarter-million workers. But Mr. Dinkins apparently hopes that fresh faces will shake up sleepy agencies and invigorate public confidence.
''We in New York are proving by example that we can form a government representative of all the people,'' Mr. Dinkins said in a recent speech in Washington. ''It takes time - not as much time as some others have taken to form their administrations, I might add - but in the end we will have an administration sensitive to the needs and aspirations of all our people.''
Four months after he took office, the Mayor has at last quieted most of the criticism that his search for the best was taking too long. His two biggest remaining vacancies are at the head of the City Planning Commission and the Sanitation Department, and he said Friday that he hoped to fill these soon.
But the delays took their toll. After searches for budget, welfare and housing commissioners in which people approached by the administration either were not interested or could not agree on terms, Mr. Dinkins settled on applicants whose names had been in the hopper from the beginning.
''There's nothing wrong with being somebody who takes his time to make a decision,'' said Thomas Kessner, a history professor at Kingsborough Community College in Brooklyn and author of a biography of Fiorello H. La Guardia. ''But that is not going to get you the feeling you want, which is that you're a general with your troops behind you.''
On the other hand, Mr. Kessner said, the Mayor has so far minimized internecine squabbles or ''major catastrophes, and that's not so simple.''
While some Hispanic supporters complained that he had not appointed enough Hispanic officials, he has also won praise for naming a Cuban-born hospitals chief and the first Puerto Rican fire commissioner.
As Manhattan Borough President, Mr. Dinkins was fiercely proud of the diversity of his staff and of the experts whom he persuaded to serve on task forces or committees.
''It was really important to him that people knew these important people were willing to work for him,'' a senior adviser said. Now Mr. Dinkins proudly notes the Ph.D.'s among his appointees, invariably referring to his police commissioner as ''Dr. Lee Patrick Brown.''
Still, a motley crew has its problems. Already Mr. Dinkins has let it be known, after some events were arranged without his knowledge, that he wants advance word of news conferences to be held by his consumer affairs commissioner, Mark Green, who ran for the United States Senate in 1986 and who is widely believed to still have political aspirations - and of similar appearances by other appointees.
How well the non-New Yorkers like Mr. Brown will work out also remains to be seen. Mr. Koch said his own experence with newcomers ''has not been a good one, but that doesn't mean it's definitive of all out-of-towners.''
And not all of Mr. Dinkins's appointees are new to the scene. First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel, in charge of day-to-day operations, was sanitation commissioner under Mr. Koch, and Mr. Dinkins's corporation counsel, Victor A. Kovner, was once a partner in Mr. Koch's old law firm.
Mr. Dinkins said he believed the mix would work ''very well.''
The final judgment, of course, is for the future. Andrew Hacker, a professor of political science at Queens College, said Mr. Dinkins's newly representative government will face all the challenges already faced by the first mayors from other groups, from the Irish to the Italians to the Jews.
''Whenever new groups enter public office,'' he said, ''the question always is raised: Can they handle the job? Now, as in the past, politics is serving as a proving ground.''
 
DEPUTY MAYORS
 
Norman Steisel
First Deputy Mayor
An investment banker and former commissioner who was credited with rejuvenating the Sanitation Department, he is the Mayor's most prominent appointee from the Koch administration. He had not been close to Mr. Dinkins but is highly regarded as a manager.
 
Bill Lynch
Deputy Mayor for Intergovernmental Relations
One of the Mayor's most trusted associates, he was chief of staff to Mr. Dinkins when he was Manhattan Borough President and his campaign manager. He oversees the Mayor's dealings with the City Council and political groups.
 
Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero
Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development
Also from the Mayor's inner circle, she had been deputy Manhattan borough president under Mr. Dinkins and, since 1988, the city Financial Services Commissioner, in charge of aiding small businesses and not-for-profit corporations.
 
Barbara J. Fife
Deputy Mayor for Policy and Planning
An urban planner and a former Democratic national committeewoman and state party treasurer, she was a senior assistant to Mr. Dinkins when he was borough president and was a top adviser in the campaign.
She ran the borough president's office while he campaigned.
 
Milton Mollen
Deputy Mayor for Public Safety
A former senior appellate judge who was nearing retirement, he has a newly created post overseeing cooperation among the police, the courts and the district attorneys.
His goal, he said, is to cut down on ''finger pointing'' among crime-fighting agencies.
 
COMMISSIONERS AND TOP APPOINTEES
 
Albert F. Appleton
Environmental Protection Commissioner
A lawyer and executive assistant to the state Deputy Attorney General for Medicaid fraud control, he had long been active in the Audubon Society. Environmental groups praised his selection. A top priority: dealing with environmental emergencies like oil spills.
 
Lee P. Brown
Police Commissioner
A former public safety commissioner in Atlanta and most recently police chief of Houston, he is the first non-New Yorker to head the department in nearly a quarter-century.
The Mayor passed over the incumbent, Richard J. Condon, who had strong support.
 
Mary Schmidt Campbell
Cultural Affairs Director
A holdover from the Koch administration, she was initially recommended for the job in 1987 by Mr. Dinkins when he was Manhattan Borough President.
Previously she directed the Studio Museum in Harlem, which became a leading black cultural institution.
 
Dr. J. Emilio Carrillo
Health and Hospitals Corp. President
A former director of Hispanic health services at Cambridge (Mass.) Hospital and an instructor at Harvard Medical School and the Harvard School of Public Health, he takes over an overburdened hospital system that often serves as a family doctor to the poor.
 
Elisabeth F. Gotbaum
Parks Commissioner
An administrative assistant in both the Lindsay and Beame administrations, she was the chief fund-raiser for the Dinkins campaign and after the election ran the inaugural committee. Her challenge is to keep the parks from deteriorating while city money is short.
 
Mark Green
Consumer Affairs Commissioner
A lawyer, author and consumer advocate, he was the unsuccessful Democratic opponent of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato in 1986 and an adviser to the Dinkins campaign.
''After years of shooting arrows at government,'' he said, ''I figured it was time to catch a few.''
 
Dr. Billy E. Jones
Mental Health Commissioner
A psychiatrist with a career at public hospitals, he was medical director of Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx. Dr. Jones, who has always worked at public hospitals, said his goal was to improve mental health services for children, the homeless and AIDS patients.
 
Kenneth J. Knuckles
General Services Commissioner
A lawyer and an architect, he had been deputy borough president of the Bronx since 1987, overseeing day-to-day operations of the borough president's office and housing and development issues. He heads the city housekeeping and purchasing agency.
 
Victor A. Kovner
Corporation Counsel
A close adviser in the campaign and transition and long associated with the reform wing of the Democratic Party in Manhattan, he and Mr. Dinkins have been friends since the 1960's, when they were district leaders.
Mr. Kovner was the Mayor's first appointee.
 
Philip R. Michael
Budget Director
A former city finance commissioner, he most recently had watched the city budget as director of the state Financial Control Board. His appointment was aimed at reassuring business leaders that the city was in experienced hands as it faced uncertain fiscal times.
 
Felice L. Michetti
Housing Commissioner
As first deputy commissioner of the department for four years, she was an architect of the Koch administration's 12-year housing plan. Her appointment signaled that Mr. Dinkins would continue the plan despite criticism that it does not solely aid the poor.
 
Dr. Woodrow A. Myers Jr.
Health Commissioner
A former Indiana Health Commissioner, Dr. Myers's appointment caused the most bitter dispute of the new administration. It pitted some of Mr. Dinkins's black supporters against some of his gay supporters, who questioned Dr. Myers's policies on AIDS.
 
Carol O'Cleireacain
Finance Commissioner
A fiscal adviser to the Dinkins mayoral campaign, she was chief economist of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, the city's largest municipal workers union and a campaign supporter of Mr. Dinkins.
 
Lucius J. Riccio
Transportation Commissioner
A deputy commissioner in the Transportation Department and a former Sanitation Department official, he was a surprise choice of the Mayor, who bypassed the incumbent, Ross Sandler. Mr. Riccio impressed the Mayor during an interview for another job.
 
Carlos M. Rivera
Fire Commissioner
A 31-year veteran of the Fire Department and most recently its chief of operations, he is the first Hispanic commissioner of the department.
His goal, he said, is to improve firefighters' morale after feuds with Mayor Koch over salaries and the closing of firehouses.
 
Harvey Robins
Operations Director
A former executive of the city Human Resources Administration and most recently Deputy Schools Chancellor for financial affairs, he is credited with reducing the staff at the Board of Education. His goal, he said, is to ''wring'' the excess from city government.
 
Barbara Sabol
Human Resources Administrator
A former executive deputy commissioner of the state's Department of Social Services, she will run a huge bureaucracy in a job that Mr. Dinkins has said is tougher than his.
Regarded as a conciliator, she vowed to do more for poor children and families.
 
Eric J. Schmertz
Labor Relations Commissioner
A labor mediator and former dean of the Hofstra University Law School, he was forced out as a city labor arbitrator in 1980 by Mayor Koch in a dispute over arbitration rulings.
He has an expanded mandate from Mr. Dinkins to get involved in private-sector labor disputes.
 
Susan E. Shepard
Investigation Commissioner
A former Assistant United States Attorney in Brooklyn, she most recently was counsel of the State Commission of Investigation.
She named a special counsel to conduct an inquiry into whether Mr. Dinkins violated ethics and reporting rules in a stock transfer.
 
Allyn R. Sielaff
Correction Commissioner

HEADLINE: The 51st and 52d States;
Let Puerto Ricans Decide Their Fate, but Fairly

 BODY:
Puerto Rico is not America's Lithuania, but it is unhappy with its status as a highly dependent commonwealth. An overwhelming majority of 3.3 million islanders are agreed that they want change. But as Congress is learning, agreement stops there. What adds to the perplexity is a parallel but unrelated campaign to grant statehood to the District of Columbia. 
A Senate bill supported by the Bush Administration would offer Puerto Ricans a chance to choose, by a binding vote next year, statehood, improved commonwealth status or independence. The problem is to assure a fair choice. If one or another side has plausible reasons for charging bad faith, the referendum could prolong the argument it is meant to end.
Polls for the first time show a narrow majority of Puerto Ricans now favors statehood. As sentiment has shifted, so has the tone of a longstanding debate. Statehood supporters now join with advocates of independence in decrying colonialism. Those clamoring for enhanced commonwealth status contend that the Senate bill is frontloaded unfairly in favor of statehood.
The argument springs from a complicated history. The U.S. acquired Puerto Rico from Spain almost incidentally in 1900. In 1917, Puerto Ricans became U.S. citizens, but not until 1947 did they elect a Governor. Five years later, Congress approved an ingenious commonwealth arrangement, giving a Spanish-speaking island home rule and exemption from Federal taxes but no vote in Federal elections.
Economically, the plan made sense. Using an additional tax break known as Section 936 of the revenue code, Puerto Rico has provided generous incentives for mainland investors. But politically, the island has been virtually a ward of Congress, without the clout it would wield with two senators and six or seven representatives, plus a Presidential vote.
This sense of being second-class citizens has given potent impetus to the statehood campaign. As statehood sentiment has waxed, so has uncertainty about Puerto Rico's tax exemptions, causing investors to hold back. To end the debate once and for all, Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon, a commonwealth advocate, proposed a binding referendum.
But he now faults the Senate bill as ''terribly, dangerously unbalanced.'' It would phase in Federal taxes and phase out Section 936 over four years. Meanwhile, says the Congressional Budget Office, statehood could cost other U.S. taxpayers as much as $9.4 billion in additional Federal social spending; more than half the island's population remains below the national poverty line.
A very different view is taken by former Gov. Carlos Romero Barcelo, a statehood proponent. He persuasively cites similar preferential treatment granted other incoming states. Congress can redress the balance by rewording the commonwealth choice to give its proponents more of what they seek: an increased international role, an open port for air carriers, a voice in Federal appointments and jurisdiction over natural resources.
What is unarguable and fundamental is Puerto Rico's right to self-determination. The choice is primarily between two forms of association with the United States. Even the minority favoring independence relies on reason rather than passion. Congress can reciprocate by specifying clearly and fairly what Puerto Ricans can expect, whichever way they vote.

HEADLINE: In Working for Mideast Peace, Fairness Is Vital

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Since returning recently from an extensive trip through the Middle East, I have been disturbed by highly biased attacks on both me and President Bush in columns by A. M. Rosenthal (''Silence Is a Lie,'' March 22) and William Safire (''Bush Versus Israel,'' March 26).
Mr. Rosenthal insinuated (or stated) that I was a liar by commenting publicly on human rights abuses by the Israeli authorities in the West Bank and Gaza while not simultaneously making similar public criticisms of Syria. Mr. Safire wrote that President Bush, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and their top associates are anti-Israel, have shut their eyes to Arab terrorism, are acting to prevent Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union, attempt to cut aid to Israel, want to impose a Palestine Liberation Organization state in the occupied territories, support a divided Jerusalem and are contributing to a possible pogrom or ''death process'' for Jews being retained in the Soviet Union.
In my travels I invariably address known human rights abuse in every country, almost always directly with the nation's leader. I did this forcefully in both Egypt and Syria before arriving in Israel. The particular problem that aroused my comments in Jerusalem, both to top government leaders and to the press, was a recent Israeli policy of deporting to Jordan the Palestinian mothers and children from the West Bank and Gaza who cannot prove birth or residence in the area since it was occupied by Israeli military forces in 1967. There were 251 documented cases of this type. I gave the names of those about whom I knew personally to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and later discussed this issue with Shmuel Goren, who is in charge of civilian administration in the occupied territories.
No one denied the accuracy of these reports. Mr. Goren informed me that they were changing this policy. At my urging, he stated further that the mothers and children already deported would be permitted to return home and rejoin their husbands and fathers. Within two hours I announced this positive decision at a press conference in the Tel Aviv airport.
What would you have me do differently? What would your columnists' policy be if an Arab leader was taking Jewish mothers and children away from their homes and husbands, and forceably deporting them to a foreign country? Palestinians are human also, and their rights must be defended. I am not authorized to speak for President Bush, but I was given a thorough briefing on his policies before my trip and later met with him, the Secretary of State and the national security adviser after my return to give them a personal report. None of Mr. Safire's accusations are true. The President's budget proposal continues the allocation of approximately $10 million daily in aid to Israel, and he certainly does not support Arab terrorism, imposing a P.L.O. state on the West Bank and Jerusalem or obstructing Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union. Additionally, Mr. Safire stated that George Bush is the only President who threatened to cut aid to Israel and affirms a statement by Yasir Arafat that this is the first Administration that speaks of the end of the Israeli occupation.
As a matter of historical record, President Richard M. Nixon used full economic persuasion to halt the Israeli military advance toward Cairo in 1973. Also, I notified Prime Minister Menachem Begin in 1978 that unless the Israeli invasion of Lebanon was stopped, I would notify Congress that United States weapons were being used for offensive purposes, which would have terminated all military assistance from our country.
The invasion stopped, and the forces were soon withdrawn. Furthermore, I worked assiduously to bring about an end of the Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza. In fact, this requirement is written into the Camp David accords, both in an affirmation of compliance with United Nations Resolution 242 and the words ''the Israeli military government and its civilian administration will be withdrawn as soon as a self-governing authority has been freely elected by the inhabitants of those areas.'' It is well known that this agreement was signed by Prime Minister Begin and later ratified by the Israeli Knesset.
I know for a fact that President Bush and Secretary of State Baker are fully committed to bring a just peace to the Middle East and to help guarantee the security of Israel. Also, no one can deny my friendship and support for a peaceful and secure Israel or the persistent and successful effort I made to seek the freedom of Soviet Jews. The Israeli-Egyptian peace treaty and the 51,000 ''refuseniks'' who gained their freedom in 1979 alone are at least partial proof of the preceding statement. I did not seek these goals to gain the approval of Times columnists, but out of deep conviction that I was defending the interests of my country and upholding its basic principles.
At the same time, it is incumbent on you and other Americans to realize that United States leaders must be objective and fair as we work for peace and the enhancement of human rights, even if, on occasion, such actions might displease a friendly nation like Israel or its impassioned supporters in this country.
 
JIMMY CARTER
 Atlanta, March 28, 1990

HEADLINE: Rostenkowski's Critics Are Wrong

BYLINE: By Roger C. Altman; Roger C. Altman is vice chairman of the Blackstone Group, an investment-banking firm.

 BODY:
Representative Dan Rostenkowski's plan for cutting the deficit has been attacked by nearly everyone except the White House. Critics charge that it contains too much deficit reduction, is unfair and would be bad politics for the Democrats. They're wrong on all counts.
The plan calls for a five-year, $511 billion package to wipe out the deficit entirely. Half would come from spending cuts. Defense, Medicare and cost-of-living increases, including Social Security, would be frozen next year. Thereafter, defense would grow only 1 percent yearly - that is, less than inflation. The other half of the package consists of tax changes: excise taxes on alcohol, tobacco and gasoline would be increased. The loophole enabling certain wealthy taxpayers to pay at lower than maximum rates would be closed. And tax indexing would be suspended for a year. 
Political leaders and experts argue that the deficit has not caused much damage and that today's economy would take a nose dive with deeper spending cuts. This ignores the painful slowdown in our standard of living, and its causes. The prime cause of the slowdown is our abysmal levels of private savings, private investment and productivity. There is a direct relationship between the problems and the deficit's size. From 1950 through 1980, net private investment averaged a healthy 3 to 3.5 percent of the gross national product. During the 1980's, elbowed aside by the Federal demand for capital, it plunged to 2.3 percent, dragging down productivity. This anemic productivity growth, the industrial world's lowest, is the real burden that the deficit places on working people. It explains why the middle class's real per-capita income has not risen in recent years. Unless savings and investment rates rise, living standards will stagnate further; to move up the standards, the deficit must shrink.
Our $5 trillion economy, though slowing because of the deficit, is strong enough to absorb those budget cuts. The latest data indicate a growth rate for early 1990 of around 2 percent, after inflation; we are not on the verge of a recession. Besides, the Rostenkowski plan may well sharply reduce interest rates. The kick to growth from lower rates could outweigh or offset the dampening effect of slower spending and higher taxes.
So the deficit is the right problem to attack, and Mr. Rostenkowski does it fairly. Critics say his one-year freeze on entitlement cost-of-living adjustments is unacceptably hard on the poor. Actually, less than 20 percent of entitlements go to people below the poverty level. This is not a large sum, and the plan could be adjusted for rebates to the truly needy.
Liberal critics claim that certain Rostenkowski tax increases are also unacceptably regressive. Half the new revenue would come from higher taxes on cigarettes, alcohol and gasoline. These don't depend on ability to pay, and thus fit one definition of regressive. But discouraging use of alcohol and tobacco is indisputably pro-health. As for gasoline, U.S. taxes and pump prices have always been the lowest in the industrialized world; surely our consumers can afford slightly higher prices. New revenue also would flow from making the maximum tax rate identical for all Americans. Today, certain taxpayers earning up to $217,000 per year still don't pay the maximum 33 percent rate, while other affluent citizens do. This has never made sense, and closing the gap is certainly not regressive.
As for politics, Democrats need a budget solution much more than Republicans. Big deficits kill Democratic initiatives on education, children and rebuilding our infrastructure. The plan also would eliminate the need to raise taxes for years, and thus promises to sideline tax issues in the nation's political dialogue.
The White House has shown surprising flexibility on the tax and defense portions of the Rostenkowski plan, making a sweeping agreement possible - if it's done by the political equivalent of the immaculate conception, without fathers and witnesses. That's how the Social Security financing reforms of 1983 were put together. Mr. Rostenkowski has given us the chance to do it again.

HEADLINE: Airplane Seats

 BODY:
To the Editor: ''You Can't Be Too Thin in Economy Class'' reminded me of my Tower Air charter flight from New York to Athens last August. Like the plane seats described in the article, ours created extremely cramped conditions. A woman's complaint that when the man in front of her leaned back in his seat, his seat was practically in her face, turned into a very loud argument that attracted the attention of many passengers.
Two airline employees did their best to resolve the dispute, with little result. Later in the flight, I saw a man several seats ahead of me turn around and angrily threaten the man behind him as his hand formed a fist that appeared ready to strike, because this man had dared to ask him not to lean back too far. Luckily, no violence broke out. In such tight conditions, it could have.
After an exciting two-week tour of Greece and its islands, I dreaded the flight home, until a thoughtful tour guide responded to our complaints about the flight to Athens with good news: ''For your return flight, I booked you all on first class.'' Since the flight was a charter, there was no difference in price, and the much-appreciated extra space on the way back felt like an extension of our vacation.
 
NAOMI HEILIG
 New York, N.Y.
