Copyright 1990 The New York Times Company 
The New York Times

PUB-DATE: April 1, 1990

SECTION: Section 7; Page 10, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1724 words

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
I HEAR AMERICA SWINGING

BYLINE: By ROBERTO GONZALEZ ECHEVARRIA; Roberto Gonzalez Echevarria, formerly a catcher in a semiprofessional baseball league, is the R. Selden Rose Professor of Spanish and Comparative Literature at Yale University.

 BODY:

BASEBALL
The People's Game.
By Harold Seymour.
Illustrated. 672 pp. New York:
Oxford University Press. $24.95.
Is there baseball without the major leagues? To hear some interested parties speak could lead one to believe that Commissioner Kenesaw Mountain Landis once said, let there be baseball, and there was baseball, and he saw that it was good, and since then we have had the National and the American Leagues. Harold Seymour's ''Baseball: The People's Game,'' which dispels any such notion, is must reading for all lovers of the game and should be absolutely required for those who presume to meddle with its well-being and future. 
This is the third volume of Mr. Seymour's history of professional baseball in the United States. (''Baseball: The Early Years'' was published in 1960 and ''Baseball: The Golden Age'' appeared in 1971. A fourth volume is in preparation.) However, the current book is his most important because it raises broader issues about the game and touches the lives of more people. Very few Americans ever play professional baseball and an even smaller number put on a major-league uniform. But millions have played the game Mr. Seymour writes about here. He gives us a broad and detailed history of baseball as it was played from sandlot ball to the semipro and professional level in the so-called Negro Leagues; he includes American Legion, Y.M.C.A. and church-sponsored leagues, as well as softball and women's baseball. In short, Mr. Seymour covers the gamut of American baseball outside self-proclaimed Organized Baseball, from the origins of the game to just before World War II. ''Baseball: The People's Game'' is significant not only for the history it tells, which is rich, detailed and lavishly researched, but for the questions it raises about baseball as a game and as a United States institution.
One of Mr. Seymour's implicit arguments is that what began as a children's game was soon taken over by adults, who not only regularized it but regimented it, and eventually endowed it with an ideology. This ideology, first derived from theories about the benefits of sport in physical education, escalated to pieties about character-building and was then inevitably elevated to patriotism, bordering at times (during the 1930's) on fascism. It would be all too easy to cast Mr. Seymour as a romantic. But those of us who as children were lucky enough to play unsupervised by adults probably associate the pleasures of catching, throwing, hitting and running with freedom from school and home, an unlikely feeling for those who toiled in leagues designed to entertain parents and extend their control over kids.
The result of all this is clearly Little League, which Mr. Seymour's history does not reach. Perhaps today's children, exposed to so much professional baseball on television, never really play the game but play instead at playing major-league baseball. The replicas of the majors offered by amateur leagues from college down to Little League, I am sure, reinforce this. Perhaps children can still experience that unmediated feeling of physical pleasure and psychic release that the very act of hitting one squarely or picking up a hot short hop can afford. Perhaps even professionals, as they intone the platitudes that make up the ideology of professional sport, are aware that these have very little to do with the game itself. Mr. Seymour's thorough research scrupulously separates the game of baseball from the economic, political and social institutions that embraced it and used it for their own gain. This is a healthy antidote to self-serving presumptions about the deep, natural affinity between baseball and the values of United States culture, a debate I wish my friend A. Bartlett Giamatti and I had been granted more time to pursue.
The game, as Mr. Seymour understands it, is essentially the physical activities of catching, throwing, hitting and running, and the exhilaration of executing them for no other gain than the momentary pleasure of performing them. This is the special time bubble of play, a space outside the pressures of the real world, in which rules other than society's govern. It is the whooshing of a fast ball as it sails right into your motionless mitt or the elation of knowing, after a long run, that a fly ball is going to be yours. But it is also the freedom to make up rules to adjust for the lack of enough players, equipment or a big enough field.
Built on top of this is the edifice of social and economic regulation, from the money paid to players by industrial teams to the athletic scholarships offered by colleges in an increasingly professionalized sports environment after the turn of the century. Around this structure, like a scaffolding of (hot) air, are the words contrived to support it by hiding both the nature of the game and the true intentions of its sponsors.
Of course, one wonders if any game ever really develops outside social institutions, if the very rules that make it up reflect in some way - even a negative one - those of the larger systems that contain it. Could baseball, with its contrived rural cast (outfield, infield, mound, horsehide, stick) and its rejection of time as a factor, hide the essentially urban, industrial dreariness of United States society during the game's history? The unhampered sandlot game may be a delusion, a mirage of memory, a field of dreams.
Mr. Seymour's most poignant pages about freedom, restraint and baseball in a closed environment are those devoted to the game in prisons. These make up almost a book within the book and serve to present, in dramatic fashion, the use of baseball for social purposes. But they also show the benevolent aspect of the game, its ability to shelter momentarily the players and spectators from the harsh realities of lives without hope, by engaging them in an activity with limited but attainable goals - like ''running home'' without being stopped by the warden. The same is true of the various chapters devoted to baseball in the armed forces, both in peacetime and during World War I, when thousands of teams played in Europe and the game became further ingrained in patriotic ideology and propaganda.
While Mr. Seymour's is a baseball book that can be read with pleasure, it is also a wide-ranging study of cultural history in the United States from the mid-19th century to the beginning of World War II. The author focuses on the effect of larger socioeconomic systems, such as welfare capitalism, on baseball, and on the use of the game in broad social processes, like the Americanization of immigrants. But he also zooms in on smaller institutions like the general store, which spawned the Hot Stove League, and the organization of town teams in rural areas. The overall picture is one where baseball is part of a vast, unplanned campaign to impose upon the majority of the population values that will ease the growth of capitalism by diverting the workers' attention from their harsh working conditions. This political scheme holds for Mr. Seymour's study of the spread of baseball to other parts of the world, particularly the Caribbean, Mexico, Central America and the Pacific. The beginning of baseball in those regions is the direct result of the rise of the United States as a world economic, political and military power.
This is the first baseball book in which I find that research on Caribbean baseball is unbiased and reliable, though much remains to be done. Unlike other writers, Mr. Seymour does not assume that Cubans, Dominicans and Puerto Ricans play or watch baseball differently because they are imperfect imitators of the conventions and rituals of the game in the United States. Games, like languages, can be imposed by imperial powers and then used (as Caliban warned Prospero) to curse them. The dominance of Cuban teams in international amateur play since the late 1930's is a case in point.
The overwhelming presence and protection of Father is rarely felt when children play ball in the Caribbean. In the provinces of Cuba, where I grew up, we played mostly unsupervised sandlot ball until, as teen-agers, those with talent joined organized town or school teams. I remember, when I was about 12, traveling to a nearby town to play a team whose pitcher was a full-grown man and threw curves that hissed around your ears before they dove over the plate. They called him Vinagre Mizell after the St. Louis Cardinals pitcher Vinegar Bend Mizell, who set a strikeout record in the Cuban winter league in the 50's. I was proud to crack a hard foul off him before he struck me out in my only time at bat. Was this experience good or bad for me? I have no idea, and I was not too worried about it then (my parents either, thankfully). I remember the excitement of playing those guys, whom we had never seen before, and who, less than 10 miles from our town, were strangers and, during the game, enemies. Sizing them up was part of the fun.
The homogenization of baseball by the major leagues is another important issue raised by Mr. Seymour's book. Today baseball is like a pyramid that players climb from Little League to the big leagues, within a stable environment where plays and even gestures are set, uniforms down to wrist bands are the same and stadiums are facsimiles of professional fields. I am sure that there must be some gains in this, but there are many losses. The heaviest, I think, is the impossibility of playing against a team that is truly dissimilar, that will test your intelligence and adaptability as the game goes, bringing freshness and adventure to the whole experience.
This process of homogenization is fortunately not complete. I treasure a recent acquisition: a facsimile copy of a history of Cuban baseball published in Havana in 1889, and have been enjoying ''Dobleplay,'' a book by Edgard Tijerino recently published in Managua, Nicaragua, that a friend who knows my weaknesses brought me the other day. The story Mr. Seymour tells has analogues in those countries, but much is different, from the smell of coffee and cigar smoke in Cuban stadiums (in the United States they smell of beer), to the kind of player assessment Cubans and Nicaraguans make, an assessment that values savvy more than raw physical talent. I hope those differences are preserved and enjoyed.

43 of 763 DOCUMENTS

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: April 1, 1990

SECTION: Section 7; Page 13, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1501 words

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
THERE'S GOLD IN THEM THAR DIAMONDS

BYLINE: By LOUIS RUKEYSER; Louis Rukeyser is a syndicated columnist and the host of ''Wall Street Week With Louis Rukeyser'' on public television.

 BODY:

THE BASEBALL BUSINESS
Pursuing Pennants and Profits in Baltimore.
By James Edward Miller.
Illustrated. 382 pp. Chapel Hill:
The University of North Carolina Press. $24.95.
In 1930, the Yankees paid Babe Ruth the unprecedented sum of $80,000 to hit home runs. When reminded that this was more than President Herbert Hoover earned, the Bambino reportedly quipped, ''I had a better year than he did.'' Today, when even the average major leaguer's salary is about two and a half times what President Bush makes, there is far less laughter on the scene; as this past winter's lockout again dramatized, baseball has become not just big business but confrontational big business, with the worst labor-management relations on the national sports scene. Now comes a timely book purporting to tell us how it happened. 
James Edward Miller is a historian, and he has written a scholarly, immensely detailed book, which focuses on the Baltimore Orioles to identify the issues that have arisen since the 1950's, with the modern commercialization of baseball. The sport was never just the innocent fun and games that sentimentalists imagine, as the Ruth anecdote suggests, but changes in the past four decades have been authentically profound - ranging from the purely financial, such as the explosion of television revenues, to the intensely human, such as the belated and still incomplete acceptance of blacks at all levels of the game.
Interestingly, the sport itself may have altered least. In the 1960's, as professional football claimed precedence as America's new national pastime, many commentators thought the decrease in baseball's attendance would be permanent; they argued that the sport would have to be jazzed up or disappear. (To one such persistent television interrogator, the St. Louis Cardinals' great pitcher Bob Gibson exploded in exasperation: ''It's a baseball game!'') With the single and still hotly debated exception of the designated hitter, baseball has had fewer major rules changes than football or basketball in the ensuing years, but has had a resurgence of attendance nonetheless. Explanations range from fashionable nostalgia to complicated theories about subtlety and strategy, but the indisputable reality, as Mr. Miller points out, is that the game now attracts a more diversified, younger and more affluent audience than ever before. Somebody must be doing something right. As Mr. Miller sees it, though, that somebody is certainly not the owners. They have been guilty of ''a textbook case of bad industrial management,'' he tells us, and they have ''ignored legal restraints and practiced collusion in an effort to destroy free agency and impose limits on players' salaries.'' Massive, periodic labor-management clashes have thus become inevitable. One has to stop and remind oneself from time to time that, whatever the owners' motives, a journeyman second baseman now pulls down what was approximately the total payroll of the Orioles less than 30 years ago. Can it all have been due, as Mr. Miller seems to believe, to the brilliant negotiating skills of two heads of the players' union, Marvin Miller and Donald Fehr? Other historic forces, including those pervading the broader society, also played a part in shifting the sport away from its traditional paternalism. (The author is out of date, incidentally, in citing ''major tax benefits'' as a leading reason for owning a sports team. These have largely disappeared, and nowadays the most significant lure, aside from the enormous ego baths, comes in the potential for resale. The Seattle Mariners, for example, were sold for $13 million in 1981 and almost six times that figure in 1989 - a turnaround that was particularly lovely for a team that has never had a winning season.) But Mr. Miller is surely on target when he decries baseball's sorry record on race relations. The sport that long banned nonwhite players from its organized precincts was slow to accept them, he recounts, at positions other than the outfield or first base, unless they were superstars. ''The overall statistics continue to show a marked tendency to hand the so-called thinking positions to white players,'' he concludes. The rawest bigotry has occurred at the managerial level, but change is finally occurring there, too. Baltimore's current field manager, Frank Robinson, is the same superb athlete who was a symbolic victim of prejudice in 1966. Mayor Theodore McKeldin, unsuccessfully urging Baltimore's tavern owners to serve blacks during World Series games there, declared in disgust: ''I find it a distasteful piece of irony that I must make this plea in light of the fact that without Frank Robinson, a person who would be excluded by such businesses, we would probably have no World Series.''
As any team would, the Orioles make an imperfect metaphor for the sport as a whole. They could once be reasonably described, as they were by Roger Angell in 1983, as ''the dominant American League team of our time''; they were an early example of the postwar realignment of franchises, and until 1979 they were the last publicly traded franchise in the major leagues. But in the decades when the minor leagues lost nearly all power and television became the ninth-inning home run for baseball owners and players alike, Baltimore had special problems as a smaller market fighting for fans not just against the usual competitors but against the perennial effort to re-establish a team in nearby Washington. Mr. Miller is absorbing on all these questions, and he is unabashedly a fan - though he criticizes most cities, including Baltimore, for making too many financial concessions to keep their teams.
The 1990 season may well provide an objective test of whether the evident revival of America's love affair with baseball can survive its increasingly frequent labor-management disruptions. Meanwhile, Mr. Miller has written a useful book. One might wish for a livelier style; his addiction to formulations like ''On 2 December 1964 . . .'' is more suited to the barracks than the bleachers, and his narrative is interrupted by no fewer than 1,102 footnotes - or more than six times the total number of games the Orioles played last season. (Still, the occasional error creeps in; Baltimore's Mayor from 1959 to 1963 was J. Harold Grady, not Henry Grady.) We also learn perhaps more than we need to know about Mr. Miller's other prejudices - as, for example, when he informs us, for no particularly relevant reason, that Ronald Reagan was ''the amiable ideologue whose economic policies deprived the urban poor of basic assistance, enriched the well-to-do, and turned the United States into the world's biggest debtor nation.'' (Gosh, professor, who's on first?) For the most part, though, in his thoughtful chronicle of baseball's often grudging movement into modern American life, Mr. Miller has provided enthusiasts and critics alike with a solid double to left.
 
 
 
25 YEARS OF HAGGLING
 Only one out of every 4,000 high school varsity baseball players will ever play in the big leagues. Those few who do make it often receive extraordinary salaries - player earnings in 1989 averaged $512,804, and 152 players will receive $1 million or more this year. Such affluence does not inspire much sympathy from the public when players and club owners are involved in labor disputes. But life in baseball has not always been so plush. Kenneth M. Jennings, in BALLS AND STRIKES: The Money Game in Professional Baseball (Praeger, $24.95), describes some of the earlier problems ballplayers faced: salary caps, a reserve system that curbed player mobility, minimal or nonexistent retirement provisions and, in the nonunion years, almost complete managerial control over players' careers and wages. In 1966, however, the Major League Baseball Players Association took on a new and more aggressive stance with the hiring of Marvin Miller, a former chief economist for the United Steelworkers of America. Mr. Miller led the association to a new era of player-owner relations, notable for major gains in salaries, pensions, arbitration procedures and working conditions. Mr. Jennings, a professor of industrial relations at the University of North Florida, gives a detailed account of collective bargaining in baseball during the last 25 years, leading up to the owners' lockout this year. He discusses the participants on both sides and how disunity among the club owners has contributed to the union's ability to achieve large bargaining gains. He also deals with salary arbitration and how it has been used to settle pay disputes, noting that it can resemble ''a high-stakes crapshoot'' that leaves management incapable of controlling a team's payroll costs. For aficionados of the sport, this book provides clarifying insight into the complicated issues of baseball's labor relations and offers fascinating anecdotes and a shrewd commentary on the diverse and colorful personalities involved.
 
DAMON STETSON

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: April 1, 1990

SECTION: Section 8; Page 10, Column 2; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 1307 words

HEADLINE: VIEWS OF SPORT;
TV Cash Can Give Colleges High Marks

BYLINE: By NEAL H. PILSON; Neal H. Pilson is the president of CBS Sports.

 BODY:
The business of televised sports has undergone dramatic changes over the last two decades and will continue to evolve as we look ahead into the 1990's. What was once a stable, structured and predictable marketplace is now one of unparalleled growth and transition, resulting in a far more complex and uncertain economic environment.
Several industry statistics point to changes in a marketplace that supported the uninterrupted growth of network television for its first 35 years.
* While the average television viewer in 1970 received only four or five channels, three of which were networks, the average television household today receives almost 20 television channels and many receive 40 or more.
* Cable has grown from nine basic services in 1970 to more than 50 basic channels and seven pay services, offering a diverse menu of programming from news to sports to music videos. Today, nearly 57 percent of all homes with television subscribe to basic cable service. 
 
* In 1980, there were 129 full-power independent television stations; today there are 339.
* In 1979, 480,000 videocasette recorders were sold; today, 61 million households are equipped with VCR's.
This changing marketplace clearly affects the business of televised college athletics because these factors affect the bottom lines of most universities and colleges. I would like to explain how CBS is involved with collegiate sports, particularly in light of our recent seven-year, $1 billion agreement with the National Collegiate Athletic Association to televise its men's basketball championships and 15 other sports. And I urge college administrators and the public to consider television revenue more favorably than it is usually portrayed, not as a seed of corruption but as a resource and a business opportunity.
Changes in the television marketplace have dramatically affected the three basic elements of the business: audience, advertising and programming. The audience shift has been profound, from a combined 90 percent prime-time share for the networks in 1980 to 67 percent last fall. Advertising revenue must now be shared with competing video services, like cable and barter syndication. Programs and sports events that used to go to the three networks automatically are now being aggressively bought by these alternative distribution systems.
A decade ago, network television was the only carrier of major collegiate football. But in 1989, CBS and ABC broadcast less than 20 percent of the approximately 300 college football games carried on television. The growth of college basketball on television is even more pronounced. Before 1970, not one regular-season game was broadcast on network television. This season well over 1,300 games have been available to college basketball viewers in this country via broadcast and cable networks.
Increased competition has forced CBS to re-examine what we feel makes network television unique and determine how we can best serve a changing audience. Network television remains the only system that can deliver programming simultaneously to all 92.1 million television homes in the United States. ESPN, the largest cable service, reaches only 55 million. It is therefore far more economical for the networks to reach all of the television homes with one event than it is for cable services to distribute two, three, or four events at one time.
As a result, I think the networks will be concentrating on marketing national games to the widest possible audience. It is our strongest suit and we must move in that direction, since every business (and every university and conference, for that matter) seeks a distinctive and unique image to differentiate its product or sell its service.
Considering the notoriety that comes with such major deals as our $1 billion contract with the N.C.A.A., television's role in college sports is often criticized as adversarial, manipulative and detrimental to the health and welfare of athletes and their schools. Some say television's money breeds commercialism, the pressure to win at all costs, the resultant violations of N.C.A.A. rules and the abuse of student-athletes.
I find fault with this criticism; we in television are very sensitive to the issue of our medium's influence on college athletics. In the next five years, we estimate that the entire television industry will disburse between $1.2 billion and $1.5 billion to colleges and universities. But that money should be viewed by society and by college administrators as a positive force and as an enormous and attractive resource for higher education. It is money the educational institutions do not have to raise from taxpayers, parents, alumni and students, and it is money they can use for any purpose: to build new classrooms or dorms, to reduce tuition, or to pay coaches' salaries.
Traditionally, we have not involved ourselves in the expenditures of the rights-fee money by any of the organizations we do business with. And in the future we don't want to tell the N.C.A.A. how to spend its money.
But I have gone out of my way in the last few years to talk about television money as a resource for colleges. Besides being a television executive, I am a citizen, a taxpayer, and a father of three children, two currently in college. I would like to see this money used for broad educational purposes as well as athletic purposes. It is a major challenge for the colleges to use this money wisely.
Fortunately, I think the N.C.A.A. has the leadership to put this money to proper use. The N.C.A.A.'s executive director, Dick Schultz, recognizes that the $1 billion the N.C.A.A. will receive from CBS is an opportunity to create major reform. He has suggested that increased television money could go into a merit pool with each member school eligible for the money. If a school has a certain number of full scholarships in a variety of sports, they would receive X number of dollars. If athletes have a graduation rate that is equal to or above the rest of the student body or above a certain minimum, they would qualify for so many dollars. This kind of approach may help to restore the balance between education and athletics and help to reduce the win-at-all-costs attitude at colleges and universities today.
I also think university presidents now better understand that they are in a business whether they like it or not. They have an obligation to conduct their end of the business in a professional manner. I have talked to people like Chancellor Martin Massengale of Nebraska and Dr. Edward Foote, president of Miami, and they understand that presidents need to have some control over the use of the money television is providing.
There is no real disagreement between the colleges and the television industry, and I think college presidents now understand that the so-called domination of television over college sports is a myth. Yes, there are instances where television does ask colleges to kick off a football game at 2:43 or 7 P.M. or noon, but they are free to say no. If they do, however, we are also free to take our business elsewhere. If we are going to pay two institutions a million dollars to play a football game, we want them to play during a time period when we can televise them; if they don't want to play during that time period, then we are not going to pay them. This isn't blackmail; this is Economics 101.
The relationship with television is a good business proposition for the schools if they manage and administer the television money properly. We see them now bringing into their administrative and athletic departments people trained in business evaluations and opportunities. Financial consulting services are also available. Institutions are treating college sports as an important business, and we strongly encourage them to do so.

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES: Office Construction;
As Building Slows, So Will Tax Growth

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
LOOKING east and looking west in Manhattan, it is hard to find new office projects starting. That foreshadows low figures for completions in 1992 and 1993. For New York City, this is one sign of the impending slowdown in the remarkable rate of growth in tax revenues from Manhattan office buildings - sobering news for fiscal managers.
During the strong construction years of the 1980's, 79 new office buildings were produced in Manhattan. Taken together, those buildings in this fiscal year are paying the city $400 million in property tax and an additional $98 million in commercial occupancy tax.
But it now is clear that there has been too much new construction for the market's need - especially in West Midtown. There, a special six-year zoning bonus enacted in 1982 by the administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch caused a splurge of construction. The new buildings eased development pressures on the East Side and opened a new section of Manhattan for office growth, as they were intended to do. They represent a generally positive long-term development for the city, but meanwhile the market is having a hard time digesting the space. 
While office completions in most of the 80's were running from 5 million and 7 million square feet a year uptown and downtown, they now are falling to levels reminiscent of the mid-70's. In those years, completions ranged from zero to 2 million square feet. Construction picked up in 1978.
The pattern appears to be repeating itself. ''Significantly less space will be completed in the early 90's than in the 80's,'' said Raymond T. O'Keefe, executive vice president of Cushman & Wakefield, the office-leasing firm.
Joseph DeLuca, managing director of the realty group at Chemical Bank, described the demand for construction loans in Manhattan as ''off drastically.''
To be sure, office development has not stopped dead in its tracks. On the East Side, construction has started on the 900,000-square-foot 40-story building at 450 Lexington Avenue, at 45th Street. It will house a rebuilt midtown postal facility in its base. The developers - Sterling Equities, Gerald D. Hines Interests and Prudential Insurance -already have a major tenant in the law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell. Completion is likely in 1992, or perhaps a bit earlier. On the West Side, the Rockefeller Group is likely to start 745 Seventh Avenue this year. This 57-story, 1.3-million-square-foot structure will be the western anchor of Rockefeller Center, between 49th and 50th Streets. The owners completed the site assemblage in January when they reached a deal to buy out the lease of an F. W. Woolworth store. The building could be ready for occupancy in 1993 or 1994.
BUT there are not many other buildings going into construction, and the situation calls attention to just how heavily New York City has relied on office development and a healthy demand for space to support its budgets.
Assessments on existing properties have been rising smartly, high-priced sales of occupied buildings have brought sharply higher assessments and the new construction has been the icing on the cake.
The City Council, moreover, seized the opportunity of market health to shift an even greater share of the tax burden from owners to office properties. It took advantage of the right to shift up to 5 percent of burden from one class of property to another during most of the 80's.
Higher taxes have helped shove up office rents, making it still harder to absorb excess space.
Nevertheless, the city has revenue problems. Just last month Mayor David N. Dinkins warned of an impending shortfall of $1.8 billion in revenues with which to balance the budget now in planning for fiscal 1991. The gap was $700 million greater than he had predicted only six weeks earlier. In future years, it may be even harder to balance budgets.
The surge in building prices, and the activity in building sales, has already slowed. Attention has centered on whether the Japanese will continue to be as active as purchasers of Manhattan real estate in the 90's as they were in the 80's. If the dollar continues to rise in relation to the value of the yen, Japanese investment may slow.
LAST year, for example, Mitsubishi Estate Company bought a 51 percent interest in the Rockefeller Group for $846 million. And the Paine Webber building at 1285 Avenue of the Americas was sold for $550 million to a partnership that is 80 percent owned by Nippon Life. For the city, sales mean money from taxes on transfers, as well as higher assessments in time.
But the stock market collapse in 1987, and the subsequent retrenchments and even failures on Wall Street have taken their toll on the real estate market. It was the financial sector and allied businesses that spurred the city's growth in the 80's. Advertising firms were merging and enlarging as well. Now it is the law firms that are the principal shoppers for major office space, and the customary prime tenants in the new midtown buildings.
Some brokers say there is no shortage of major space seekers. Forty of them are said to be in the market for about 40 million square feet. The question is, how soon do they require the space? Currently the vacancy rate for prime office space is about 14.3 percent downtown and 13 percent midtown, according to the Real Estate Board of New York. These rates are about 6 points higher than the comparable rates three years ago. Availabilities in so-called secondary space are running higher - about 15 percent midtown and 20 percent downtown, according to recent Cushman & Wakefield data.
The city's total office inventory is probably around 360 million square feet. Some brokers put the total availability figure at 60 million square feet in new and occupied buiildings.
Those figures explain why new construction has slowed. ''When there has been a fair amount of building for a while developers sit back and say, 'Let's wait,' '' Mr. O'Keefe said. ''Also, it's harder to find new sites.''
One broker, who asked not to be identified, said that part of the problem in finding tenants is that owners are insisting on rents that pay yields based on 100 percent of the development cost. They have put little or no equity into projects. But the market does not justify the rents they had projected.
If it were easier in New York City to find properly zoned sites within the central business district, land prices might be more moderate. Development costs and asking rents would in turn be lower and the city would be in a better competitive position to hold tenants it has lost to other regions. The need for tax abatements to keep the city competitive would subside.
The city's reliance on a strong Manhattan office market is demonstrated by figures prepared by the Real Estate Board.
IN 1985, Manhattan office buildings produced $1.05 billion in revenue, or 25 percent of all the money collected from the property tax citywide. In the current fiscal year (fiscal 1990, ending June 30), they will have produced 29 percent, or $1.9 billion. For fiscal 1991, the current subject of budget preparations, the projection is 31 percent - $2.2 billion of the $7 billion the Dinkins administration expects to collect.
These numbers are not the full picture, it is true. They are not ''net,'' so they do not show how much revenue was lost from property the new buildings displaced. Nor do they take account of the indirect economic gains and job growth associated with new development, or the social consequences, sometimes undesirable, that growth engenders in a highly developed city.
The winding down of the development cycle was most recently confirmed in the February issue of Real Estate Forum. The publication found 1989 office completions to total 7.35 million square feet. The figure for 1990 is projected to be 5.7 million and for 1991 it was only 1.56 million.
Brokers, for their part, feel that the winding down in new construction is on the whole a favorable development until the excess space is absorbed. But at City Hall, where officials are trying to deal with a budget crisis, the slowdown in growth of the office sector is viewed with concern.
''I think it may last for two or three years, but then there will be a turnaround,'' said Sally Hernandez-Pinero, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development. ''But we won't be where we were in the boom years. We're coming down so big because we were up so high.''

HEADLINE: ART;
Helping Black Artists Start Their Careers

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
NOW in its last two weeks, the exhibition ''Against the Odds'' has successfully inaugurated the ''new'' Newark Museum and at the same time celebrated black art in an unusual way. The first must have been the easier task, since the museum can make anything look good now that Michael Graves has transformed it from an old lady down on her luck into a ''dish.''
Except for some minor changes and the addition of a side entrance, the building looks pretty much as before on the outside. Inside, however, it is scarcely recognizable, what with the new spaces and windows and, finally, the collection on permanent display. 
A $20 million project that has been in the works for more than 20 years, the renewal called for the unification of four separate buildings. Yet the results seem effortlessly achieved and are a bit reminiscent of an Italianate villa, although the black and white floor tiles are vinyl and the marble facing some walls is simulated - substitutions that reflect budgetary constraints.
The museum may be new and improved, but that's not to say it has become a place where visitors fear to tread; on the contrary, it invites them to tread all over.
''Against the Odds'' fills the galleries surrounding the center court. Organized by the curator of painting and sculpture, Gary Reynolds, and his assistant, Beryl Wright, the exhibition numbers more than 130 paintings, sculptures, drawings, prints and photographs by some 30 black artists working mainly in the 1920's and 30's.
Some, like Hale Woodruff and Lois Mailou Jones, have become famous, but during this period most were getting their first break participating in exhibitions staged by the Harmon Foundation. Founded in 1922 by the real-estate magnate William E. Harmon, this organization is the show's real subject, with half the catalogue's 300 or so pages filled with essays on it by David Driskell, Clement Alexander Price, Richard J. Powell, Deborah Willis and the curators.
The foundation's purpose was general philanthropy until 1925, when it turned its attention to black artists. Then, in collaboration with the Commission on Race Relations, a body organized by the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, the Harmon began dispensing awards for distinguished achievement, staging juried exhibitions, purchasing art and generally going where no institution had gone before. It lasted until 1967, under the direction of Mary Beattie Brady.
Call it paternalism or not, the Harmon's intention was to encourage an ethnic expression comparable to that of jazz that was of a piece with the heady cultural atmosphere prevailing in Harlem and the efforts of individuals like the dealer Edith Halpert. Nevertheless, the United States was still a cultural backwater, and black artists still had an unspoken consensus to reckon with. Hence, the participants in this show reflect the same influences as those sustained by their more conservative white counterparts.
But white critics were, on the whole, not insensitive to the problem of black artists struggling to be themselves and make a living. Romare Bearden, however, contended that the Harmon patronized black artists by encouraging them ''to accept standards that are both artificial and corrupt.''
The Harmon was a good thing, as the W.P.A. was a good thing. But evidently nobody commented on the sheer absurdity of trying to admit black Americans to a scene that had already been overturned by Cubism, a movement that would not have been possible without African art - coals to Newcastle.
The catalogue leaves the reader better informed about the situation but as depressed as ever about the way the scene is affected by sociological, psychological, economic - anything but esthetic - forces.
Aside from paintings of masks by Malvin Gray Johnson and Ellis Wilson, Africanness is mostly expressed in the appearance of the models - but without the narcissism afflicting much figuration of the 1960's and 70's. Examples are the portrait of a beautiful, fashionably dressed young octoroon woman, the study of an old black woman mending socks and a genre scene of young black men carrying on in a bar - all, unbelievably, the work of the same painter, Archibald John Motley Jr. An early convert to Abstract Expressionism, Hale Woodruff is here represented by, among others, Nabi-influenced landscapes, two of them skillful watercolors, one a rather clumsy oil. Sargent Claude Johnson, Palmer Hayden, Laura Wheeling Waring and the sculptors Richmond Barte, Nancy Prophet and Augusta Savage are some other ''names.''
But the most memorable are Beauford Delaney and William Henry Johnson, both of whom spent time in Europe and both of whom were felled by mental illness late in life, together with Allan Crite. It is hard to choose between Delaney's barely touched-in pastel of a man's head and his self-portrait, a tour de force of impasto. Johnson, too, is an expressive impastoist, but his best effort is the relatively thinly painted portrait of a boy.
One of the few artists in the show still working, Mr. Crite is at his best in the dour profiles of a young black couple walking on a snowy street and a triptych of a black Holy Family flanked by choristers, where all but the Wise Men are haloed in gold leaf.
A show that will travel to Charleston, S.C., after closing here on April 15, it provides much food for thought. Situated at 49 Washington Street, the Newark Museum is open Tuesday through Sunday from noon to 5 P.M.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY OPINION;
Keeping Up the Fight For Clean Air

BYLINE: By Jim Florio; Jim Florio was elected a United States Representative eight times before becoming Governor of New Jersey.

 BODY:
AS a new Governor in Trenton, I find that the ongoing debate in Washington over the Clean Air Act is even more disheartening than a similar debate I took part in as a young Congressman in 1976 and 1977.
It's more disheartening because the bill as it now stands throws the responsibility for controlling air pollution into the laps of the states, without giving us the ability to stop it.
For New Jersey the result may well be devastating. We have some of the most polluted air in the country. According to the Environmental Protection Agency, American plants spew 2.7 billion pounds of toxics into the air. New Jersey has the second highest concentration of toxic air pollution in the nation (after Rhode Island), with 5,173 pounds of toxics released per square mile. 
But even if we control air polluters in our own state, which we are beginning to do, we may still lose the battle for clean air. That's because air pollution ignores borders.
Every day we breathe toxic pollutants generated outside our state. It's similar to the New York garbage that sullied our beaches last summer.
Efforts to strengthen the bill by amendments seem likely to fail, as seen by the recent defeat of a provision that would restore language from the original Clean Air Act allowing the Federal Government to impose minimum air pollution standards on all states. Without that measure, states with tough laws like New Jersey will be out on their own looking for a way through the smog.
Of course, that doesn't mean we shouldn't have tough standards. But the lax regulations in other states may mean that some businesses will opt to set up shop elsewhere.
I'm willing to make that choice because I realize that without a clean and safe environment we have nothing. But it's not a choice that I, or the people of New Jersey, should have to make.
Because there is a vacuum on Federal leadership, governors have been forced to take the initiative. At the National Governors Association meeting this winter, I signed a compact with the Governors of Pennsylvania, Delaware, North Carolina and Virginia, as well as with the government of Washington, D.C., to have areawide pollution standards.
The version of the Clean Air Act being considered by the Senate creates serious problems for individual states. For example, the bill extends the first-phase smog reduction period and lets car manufacturers out of the second phase if only 11 cities still have air problems. One polluted city is one too many, whether it's in New Jersey or California - not only because every one of us deserves clean air but also because smog doesn't respect city limits.
The current bill also suffers by no longer requiring car manufacturers to produce alternative-fuel cars. We can't make New Jerseyans own such cars unless they're reasonably priced. And they won't be unless the Federal Government encourages their development.
Fuels like ethanol, methanol and compressed natural gas burn much more cleanly. We should encourage developing the technology necessary for such fuels. Such environmental technology also generates new jobs, a lesson we've learned in New Jersey from our recycling efforts.
In terms of toxic emissions, the bill does little. It only requires factories to use existing technology. If that technology works, great. If it doesn't, too bad. The bill contains no goals for reducing toxic emissions. So plants have no incentive to find and use different technologies. Again, this is an area for national leadership.
I hope my former colleagues in the House can strengthen the bill. My own experience with the Superfund legislation taught me that no battle is lost until you give up. We didn't get strong measures into the law until we hung tough.
I can't think of one issue that more Americans agree on than the need for clean air. Two decades ago, the environmental movement was considered slightly faddish, a byproduct of the 60's. Today it's a consensus issue. The character Hope on the television show ''Thirtysomething'' is an environmental activist. And it doesn't get much more mainstream than that.
Unfortunately, you don't need to watch television to see the results of pollution in New Jersey. Because we suffer from past mistakes, we have been leaders in protecting and cleaning our air, land and water.
Other states can learn from us. The leaders of those not yet polluted should learn to preserve their clean air. Industrial states like our own can learn that a healthy economy is indeed compatible with a healthy environment.
The first Clean Air Act went through with few changes because the popular support was so clear. That was in 1970, the year of the first Earth Day.
My hope is that the many activities surrounding the 20th anniversary of Earth Day later this month will create enough momentum to pass a strong 1990 Clean Air Act, not the polluted version now being considered.

The New York Times

 April 1, 1990, Sunday, National Edition

SECTION: Section 8; Page 1, Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1329 words

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
A Tale of Two Cities: One Thriving, One Struggling

BYLINE: By SUSAN DIESENHOUSE

DATELINE: LOWELL, MMASS.

 BODY:
Despite a slow economy and soft real estate market, this once depressed mill city turned high-technology superstar has more construction going on now than ever - about $173 million in residential, commercial, infrastructure and cultural projects.
Yet Lawrence, another old blue-collar city only 10 miles northeast, has relatively little, even though both cities are on Route 495, the beltway around Boston, and are about 25 miles from Boston.
Lowell has attracted almost $1 billion - including $170 million in state and Federal grants - since 1975 for projects that have been completed, are in progress or being planned. Among them is a planned $350 million expansion of the University of Lowell.
Lawrence attracted investment of about $100 million during its growth period in the 80's but its image is that of economic stagnation, obscure location and the site of three days of racial unrest in the summer of 1984. 
''The two cities are virtually in the same location, but Lowell is in the mainstream of the region's economic vitality while Lawrence is a decade behind and trying to catch up during a downturn,'' said Alden S. Raine, the state Secretary of Economic Affairs.
Lowell has had vacant land for expansion, scenic canals and stately historic downtown buildings. Above all, perhaps, it has had effective local government and political clout at the state and Federal levels, which Lawrence has only recently begun to have.
Lowell's local government has worked closely with business and educational leaders and it has a modern planning department and ''strong ties to the seats of power in state and Federal Government enabling them to take advantage of the boom of the late 70's through mid-80's,'' Mr. Raine said.
Among the players in what became known as the city's ''delivery system'' have been former Senator Paul E. Tsongas, a tireless booster of his hometown; Representative Chester G. Atkins; Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, whose father grew up here, and his former economic adviser, Frank Keefe who had been the city planner here.
Mr. Tsongas recalled that while he was in Washington he spoke with City Manager Joe Tulley, three times a week and that ''without him having real power and being willing to work with me, none of this could have happened.''
Until 1984, on the other hand, Lawrence had what Mr. Raine called a bizarre, anachronistic form of local government. Five aldermen, elected to run five departments of government, became competing power brokers solidifying ethnic divisions and never setting up a modern development department. But in recent years there has been a new, strong-mayor form of local government, a development department has been set up and a State Senator from the city, Patricia McGovern, has gained influence as head of the Ways and Means Committee. Lawrence's Mayor, Kevin J. Sullivan, says that the state Attorney General, James M. Shannon - a native Lawrentian and a resident - is only one of several new forces on the state and Federal level with ties to Lawrence.
''Lawrence has suprassed Lowell, at least in political clout,'' he said, and the city government also now has ''an excellent relationship with the business community.''
Lowell, set up as a planned industrial city in 1826, went through an economic and spiritual depression from the 20's through 60's as textile manufacturers moved South. But in the 70's, Mr. Tsongas teamed up with local leaders to encourage economic growth, historic preservation and an intellectual/artistic presence.
In 1975, they set up the Lowell Development and Financial Corporation to help refurbish downtown buildings. Bankers who balked at contributing to the $350,000 in seed money were told by Mr. Tsongas, then a Representative, that ''as a member of the House Banking Committee, I would ''use my influence to do them damage.'' City leaders won state funds to rebuild the downtown as an urban park with restored historic buildings interspersed with parks and museums. In 1978, Congress made the historic downtown part of the national park system, adding funds for tourist facilities that now attract over 300,000 visitors a year.
In 1975, the State Legislature formed the University of Lowell with a base in engineering, science and business. Last year, despite a severe fiscal crisis, it set up the Toxic Use Reduction Institute at the school.
In 1978,the city won a $5 million Federal grant that helped induce Wang Computers to establish its international headquarters here. Wang attracted other high-technology firms and has been a local philanthropist.
In the 1980's, a Hilton Hotel was built downtown, two old auditoriums were renovated and made into theaters and $1.5 million was committed for art work for public places; six pieces already are in place, one is finished and awaiting installation and seven works have yet to be completed.
Current construction projects include the $60 million renovation of the downtown Massachussetts Mill into 420 rental apartments; the $63 million renovation of Boott Mill into offices; a river walkway connecting Boott Mill to the university; parks, two garages, a cultural center, an outdoor performance center, an industrial museum and the revival of a trolley line.
Congress Group Properties of Boston, developers of the 700,000-square-foot Boott Mill, last December sold an $8 million equity participation to Mission First Financial, a subsidiary of Southern California Edison, and earlier this month signed a 10-year lease for 55,000 square feet with Alliance Technologies of Bedford, an environmental engineering firm now based about 18 miles northwest of Boston. The first 108,000 square feet will be ready this summer and the rest by 1992.
Much of the city's success was ''luck and timing,'' Mr. Tsongas said. In the 50's and 60's, its failure to undertake urban renewal saved the historic downtown for future restoration. ''We moved to set up the urban park months before any other city and won Federal grants before the Reagan Administration turned off the spigot of funds to the cities,'' he said.
But some say the city's luck may have run out. Like the rest of the state and much of the Northeast, it is in an economic slowdown: unemployment is up to 5.8 percent, wages are falling along with commercial rents and residential prices. Commercial vacancy rates are up to about 20 percent and residential rental vacancy rates are at 17 percent, city officials say. Reversals and layoffs at Wang, whose business was expected to fill a quarter of the 250-room Hilton, have hurt the hotel and its California lender recently foreclosed after the city refused it a loan.
But new companies are moving in because the city is attractive and seems able to deal with its problems.
''Unlike the rest of the state,'' said Robert M. Bradway, chief operating officer of Alliance Technologies, ''this city's leadership has come to grips with the current economic problems and has a very complete plan to build up the comercial base.''
As for Lawrence, many firms pass it by, as much for its image as for actual conditions, said Samuel E. Oddo, vice president of Codman & Associates, a Boston real estate firm.
''Lawrence has basic problems of address and character that don't attract the high-tech labor market,'' he said. ''It had riots downtown. The feeling is, once you go there, you may as well go on to New Hampshire for the tax benefits. Its political leadership hasn't generated a lot of energy in the past.''
Mayor Sullivan, however, sees assets that will attract growth: accessibility to Boston and southern New Hampshire, good utility services, a $20 million park the state has agreed to build by 1991 and 400 new small businesses that have moved in in the last four years, including retailers, professionals and services. A $15 million, 175-unit mixed-income residential co-op is due for completion this summer within a walk of downtown.
''I think the 90's will be our growth era,'' Mayor Sullivan said.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 7, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1701 words

HEADLINE: 'A COMMUNIST TO THE MARROW OF MY BONES'

BYLINE: By GEORGE BALL; George Ball was Under Secretary of State in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations and the United States Ambassador to the United Nations in 1968.

 BODY:

MEMOIRS
By Andrei Gromyko.
Translated by Harold Shukman.
Foreword by Henry A. Kissinger.
Illustrated. 414 pp. New York:
Doubleday. $24.95.
The atmosphere at Andrei Gromyko's funeral last year seemed cruelly poignant: few of the Soviet Union's elite made even pro forma appearances. Because of the timing of his death, Gromyko was fortunate; he was spared knowledge of the collapse of everything he had so assiduously worked for throughout his fanatically dedicated life as a Soviet diplomat and, for 28 years, as Foreign Minister. One wonders what his ''Memoirs'' would have been like had he written it amid the ideological rubble of 1990 - or if he would have written it at all. 
In the light of recent events, this book, published in the Soviet Union in 1988 and ably translated by Harold Shukman, has eerie overtones of a moldy chronicle inscribed in the archaic hieroglyphics of Soviet doctrine. Gromyko writes that he was ''a communist to the marrow of my bones,'' and rhapsodically describes the system's achievements with a pride and assurance sharply out of tune with the skeptical voices now echoing from Moscow:
''I respect the profound learning of Marx, Engels and Lenin, and the great spirit of our people as they build the communist society. When I cast my gaze over our great country, I feel I want to share my sense of confidence in tomorrow. What gives me that confidence? First, the fact that we have a wonderful people who are capable of solving the most difficult problems. Secondly, we have a wise and perceptive party, closely bound to the people. Thirdly, we have a leadership worthy of the great tasks it has set before society at this crucial stage in its development and in the international situation.''
These words, and similar sentiments expressed throughout this book, make clear beyond doubt that Gromyko was not merely a disciplined diplomat but a true believer. This discovery should not surprise anyone who ever dealt with him officially, certainly not the many Americans who found it difficult to do business with him when he was Foreign Minister. For here is a man who can proudly recount in his memoirs that when Stalin asked him to identify the ''main social elements that [President Franklin D.] Roosevelt can count on for support inside his country,'' he replied as though he had the ultimate truth:
''The American President above all defends the interests of his own class, of course - the bourgeoisie. His domestic policies may encroach to some extent on the interests of the large monopolies, and right-wing extremists sometimes make the absurd accusation that he is sympathetic to socialism, but it's only a propaganda ploy by people who don't want the USA to have good relations with the USSR.''
Gromyko's conviction that history is dictated by the ''scientific principle'' of Communist doctrine sometimes leads him into historical gaffes. For example, he continually emphasizes that the decisive political clout in the United States belongs to the arms makers, and since Dwight D. Eisenhower was a general, Gromyko's ideology compels him to believe that Eisenhower was their tool. Thus he asserts that when Eisenhower entered the Presidential race in 1952 it was ''with the support of big corporations and companies involved in arms production that his victory was secured.'' Then he writes that during Eisenhower's eight-year term ''arms production speeded up steadily.''
Of course, that is a shocking distortion of history, for during Eisenhower's two terms America's defense budget shrank from $50.3 billion in 1953 to $47.4 billion in 1961 - and those figures make no allowance for inflation. But if Gromyko gets his facts wrong, he at least has the good grace to note with approval Eisenhower's warning in his farewell address against the industrial-military complex.
The most fascinating mystery that ''Memoirs'' might have resolved for American readers is how Moscow envisaged the repeated crises between the Soviet Union and the United States. But on this point Gromyko tells us little that has not already been revealed through other sources - including recent meetings between Soviet and American experts.
He explains that the Korean War began because ''the puppet government of South Korea was being egged on by the USA to start war on North Korea.''
In describing the origins of the Bay of Pigs episode, he says: ''The aggressive intrigues of imperialism continued to provoke serious crises in various parts of the world, and in April 1961 American mercenaries mounted an invasion at the Bay of Pigs in Cuba.''
Later, he writes, during the discussions preceding the Cuban missile confrontation, President John F. Kennedy told him that the Bay of Pigs adventure was ''a mistake'' and that he was ''restraining those who are in favour of actions which could lead to war.'' Yet in spite of Kennedy's reassuring words, Gromyko still defends the emplacement of missiles in Cuba on the ground that the United States was threatening an invasion and thus the Soviet Union was entitled to ''strengthen [Cuba's] defensive capability - precisely that, its defensive capability.'' (His principal concern regarding that crisis, however, is to make it clear for the record that he at no time explicitly denied to the President or to Secretary of State Dean Rusk that there were missiles in Cuba.) Elsewhere he remains an unrepentant apologist for the Russians' bloody intervention in Hungary in 1956:
''I must emphasise as strongly as I can that the help given to Hungary by the Soviet Union was absolutely justified. The forces that were bent on overthrowing the Hungarian leadership intended to liquidate the social order and restore the previous system that had been responsible for making Hungary a bridgehead for Hitler's aggression against the Soviet Union and many other countries.''
Not only does he defend the 1956 Soviet intervention in Hungary but also the events of 1968, when Red Army tanks rolled into Czechoslovakia.
''By 1968 the country occupied a stable position among the fraternal states. . . . Then suddenly the forces that were at one with the previous order, when power had been in the hands of politicians who had cared nothing for the people's welfare or the country's true national interests, decided to turn back the clock - and to do so with guns in their hands and without regard to casualties.''
In spite of the fact that Mikhail S. Gorbachev's Soviet leadership was later to repudiate most of these views toward the end of 1989, Gromyko writes:
''If I were asked what I wish our country and its people for the foreseeable future, I would say this. The leadership under Gorbachev should continue to head the country. This leadership is capable of solving the historically important questions of both economic construction and the country's social development. It is also dealing with complex foreign policy tasks and is defending the cause of peace with initiative and conviction.''
Hovering like an angry cloud over all the pages of this book is Joseph Stalin - a personality who holds a curious fascination for Gromyko, a man Gromyko regards as ''a tragically contradictory figure . . . who created a monstrously arbitrary state machine that sent multitudes of innocent Soviet people to their deaths.'' He admits of Stalin that ''anyone who knew and observed him is bound to compare his knowledge and impressions of him in the past with what is now generally known, and I am of course no exception.'' He believes that the ''overwhelming majority'' of Soviet citizens ''would say that, at a certain time, the people believed in Stalin'' and that, during World War II, ''most people would probably agree that Stalin led the country against the fascist aggressors with energy.'' Yet ''it should also be remembered that for nearly thirty years Stalin ran a repressive apparatus which, as is now clear, had a dual task: to destroy a host of innocent persons as 'enemies of the people,' and by means of a sophisticated system of illegality to hide all trace of its crimes. People perished at the hands of executioners who were then themselves destroyed. This chilling picture is now being revealed in its entirety, as is the fact that Stalin himself stood at the top of the structure.''
Gromyko's attitude toward Stalin will be a subject for psychohistorians to ponder for many years to come. They will no doubt spin elegant theories as to why, in the early chapters of his book, he discusses Stalin's character and achievements, and then, as though by some psychic compulsion, returns to the subject in a whole new chapter at the end. For me, there is an odd parallel here between Gromyko's fascination with Stalin and Albert Speer's fascination with Hitler. Both Gromyko and Speer were technicians patronized by tyrants at an early age, Gromyko at 30, Speer at 28. Though recognizing the evil the two dictators perpetrated, and frustrated by the failure of their masters to follow their sound advice, neither man could altogether liberate himself from the Mephistophelean spell.
Yet in each case, beyond the ideologue and the witness to tyranny was the complete technocrat, the diligent counselor and unyielding servant of an evil system - so colorless in the case of Gromyko that his rise to Foreign Minister and key membership in the Politburo seem almost an afterthought. Only such a faceless person, concealing his real feelings behind a mask of passivity, could have survived the succession of regimes and the purges that accompanied them.
In the end, though he carefully avoided making enemies, Gromyko had no real friends and, once he had been used, he was casually discarded with the same lack of feeling he had displayed to the world. In 1985 he was eased out of the Foreign Ministry by Mr. Gorbachev and given the ceremonial post of the presidency. Gromyko would have been the last to complain or even be surprised at his fate. As he had put it years before, comparing the Soviet system with the Bermuda Triangle, ''Every now and then someone disappears.'' As with the victims of the Triangle, the timing of Gromyko's disappearance will remain a matter for reflection and conjecture.
