50 of 763 DOCUMENTS

Copyright 1990 The New York Times Company 
The New York Times

PUB-DATE: April 2, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 2352 words

HEADLINE: Homeless And Mentally Ill;
Ill, Possibly Violent, and No Place to Go

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

 BODY:
On a recent morning near the subway platform where a deranged homeless man was beaten to death in January, a young man in sweatpants and jogging shoes came upon social workers passing out food to mentally ill people who live in Central Park.
He introduced himself as Johnny and asked for a sandwich.
Told that the food was for people with emotional problems, he fumbled in a pocket for papers: a discharge from the Bellevue psychiatric ward, a prescription for medicine to treat schizophrenia, an unused referral to a shelter.
 
'Opposed' to Medication
Johnny, who would give no last name, said he was afraid of shelters and ''opposed'' to medication. Social workers guessed that he might have a breakdown, possibly a violent one, within two weeks - the time it would take for his last shot of medication to wear off. Meantime, they said, there was no good place to put him - no temporary quarters more inviting than a shelter armory, no halfway house, no ready permanent housing. 
He clearly did not need hospitalization. So they handed him a sandwich and another piece of paper, with a number to call when the crisis came.
Based on surveys of shelter residents, mental health experts estimate that at least 25 percent of the city's homeless people suffer persistent mental illness. Fifteen percent more have either some symptoms or a history of mental illness.
The source of the problem is of little dispute. Beginning in the 1950's, with advances in antipsychotic drugs, American psychiatric hospitals began releasing patients not needing permanent care. The policy, called deinstitutionalization, was hailed as a victory for patient rights.
Roughly a decade after thousands of former mental patients in New York began to lose their homes to a booming real-estate market, parks and subway stations are continuing to fill with people like Johnny.
With scant public money, voluntary agencies in New York have learned how to rescue, rehabilitate and house them. But the promise made when state psychiatric hospital doors were flung open has not been kept: Homeless and mentally ill, they still have no place to go.
Now, amid growing public frustration, their plight is confronting governments and courts on new and potentially decisive terms.
In a class action suit awaiting decision in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, advocates for the homeless are arguing that the law requires the city and state to create special housing for the homeless mentally ill.
In Albany, after years of bureaucratic squabbling, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has proposed to spend $30 million on the first phase of an accord with the city to build just the kind of special quarters being sought in court.
At the same time, though, the fiscally strapped administration has proposed the sharpest cuts in years in community mental health programs. The reductions, say private groups that are fighting them, could flush more mentally ill people into the streets at a time when state psychiatric beds are quickly being eliminated and the use of crack among the emotionally disturbed homeless has risen beyond levels that clinicians are prepared to handle.
''Things are not going to remain quiet,'' said Cynthia Dames, executive director of the Coalition of Voluntary Mental Health Agencies. ''You're going to see a reduction of services by the summer, and by late summer, you're going to see more crises in emergency rooms. These people don't go away.''
Though he defends the proposed cuts as fiscally unavoidable, the state's Commissioner of Mental Health, Dr. Richard C. Surles, shares this sense of urgency. ''The tragedy would be not to do it now that we can,'' he said. ''It may not be so affordable a few years from now.''
 
Who Is Responsible? And Who Will Pay?
In New York State, the number of people in public psychiatric hospitals in 1955 was 94,175. In 1984, it was 23,109. In January, state beds for mental patients numbered 15,599. That number is expected to drop by 150 each month.
In theory, as people left mental institutions, the stark violent wards that typified the worst of them were to be replaced by more humane residential care. But when such care failed to materialize, many mentally ill people, including some former state hospital patients, found cheap refuge in single-room-occupancy hotels. Then New York real-estate values exploded. Many of those rooms, along with other housing occupied by poor mentally ill people, disappeared.
Guesses at the city's homeless population range from 60,000 to more than 80,000, including those in shelters. While such figures suggest that at least 15,000 mentally ill people might need special housing, state officials give somewhat lower estimates.
Clear as the problem has been, efforts to house the homeless mentally ill have until recently faltered not only on financing but on a series of jurisdictional disputes.
The state blamed city development policies. The city blamed the state's rush to shrink psychiatric hospitals. Mental health agencies disclaimed responsibility for housing and housing officials disclaimed responsibility for mental health.
Since the early 1980's, the homeless mentally ill have been a ubiquitous muttering presence: slung over benches, crumpled on grates, led on mysterious crusades by shopping carts filled with scraps of other people's lives.
The issue of their care has gained attention mostly in short violent jolts: when one former psychiatric patient pushed a young accountant into a subway train, when another hacked passengers on the Staten Island Ferry with an ornamental sword, when a third bludgeoned to death an usher at St. Patrick's Cathedral.
The homeless man who attacked Rodney Sumter beneath Columbus Circle died anonymously on Jan. 23. But the man's beating by Mr. Sumter, an unemployed construction worker who had worked with the homeless, suggested that frustration with bizarre street people had caught up to fear of their potential violence. Mr. Sumter argued that he had beaten the man in self defense, and two weeks ago, a Manhattan grand jury decided not to bring any charges against him.
Fears of violence are likely to be fueled by the growing use of crack among the homeless mentally ill.
As visits by homeless people to the psychiatric emergency rooms of city hospitals have risen steadily, those tied to crack shot from 11 percent in 1987 to an estimated 45 percent last year, said Dr. Luis Marcos, vice president for mental hygiene of the Health and Hospitals Corporation.
But more than violence, mental health experts say they are concerned about an overwhelming lack of specialized care. So segregated are services, doctors say, that drug-treatment centers now routinely reject mentally ill people while mental health programs turn away patients they suspect of using drugs.
As public sentiment has seemed to tip from concern toward dismay and anger, voluntary agencies say the notion has persisted that they should somehow sweep clean streets that are littered with the mistakes of the mental health system.
''Everybody thinks in terms of Band-Aid solutions: 'Let's get these people out of the subways!' '' said Sam Tsemberis, who directs Project Help, a team that hospitalizes homeless mentally ill people who might endanger themselves or others.
Instead, the job is one of ginger courtship. Battles are fought in the endless paperwork and telephone calls required to gain Social Security numbers or Medicaid for people who often have no address, no identication and little certainty about who they are.
 
Some Victories, Many More Defeats
The victories are people like Bradley K.
At 39 years old, Bradley is a gentle man with missing teeth and eczema. He remains uneasy with strangers. But those who spent three years coaxing him from rock outcroppings near a playground in Central Park say he bears little resemblance to the wild-eyed man who often scared passers-by.
''I just had other things on my mind,'' he said of the days before Project Reachout, which scours the Upper West Side for mentally ill homeless people, put him up in an apartment. ''I don't remember now. Personal things.''
But for each Bradley, Reachout workers say, there are dozens more Brendas.
When a Reachout van finds the woman who calls herself Brenda Seabrook one frigid morning near the park's southern edge, she peers back with the barest hint of recognition through ragged swaths of clothing. After giving her sandwiches for months, Reachout workers only learned they had established a relationship the day she tossed an empty soda can at one of them.
''She talked to me once,'' says Margarita Lopez, a Reachout worker who has visited Brenda for four years.
Days later, when a reporter encountered her after midnight in a nearby subway station, Brenda snapped words from a hidden trove, seeming as gregarious and articulate as she had been withdrawn. Her story zigzagged from childhood in Ocala, Fla., through nursing school in Newark and the death of a daughter in Plainville, N.Y. She stumbled trying to explain her reluctance to seek help.
''I'm not even living,'' she said. ''I know that. I'm not even part of the system.''
Even for those more willing than Brenda, entry into the system is arduous.
One of the plaintiffs in the suit being tried in State Supreme Court, John H. Heard, complained that starting in 1987, he was shuffled out of hospitals four times without once being helped to find permanent housing.
At the end of his first visit to South Beach Psychiatric Center on Staten Island, he was given $20, he said. The next time, he received only a list of city shelters and subway fare.
''When it was raining or really cold, there were times when I felt like picking up a brick and throwing it through a window,'' he said. ''I felt like maybe if I went to jail, maybe life would be better.''
Lawyers for the Coalition for the Homeless, which brought the suit, argue that under the state's 1977 Mental Hygiene Law, state hospitals must discharge patients to secure housing with ready treatment. The city's cavernous armories, they argue, fall far short of that. Although eight of the shelters offer modest mental health programs, they say, the familiar gamut of problems like bureaucracy and violence menace the mentally ill especially.
 
When Sanctuary Is a Dingy Hallway
Late one Saturday night at the armory on Fort Washington Avenue and 168th Street in Washington Heights, sanctuary was a dingy hallway. In one yellow plastic bucket seat, Evelio Gonzalez, of Havana, New York and mental hospitals in both cities, sat chatting in Spanish to no one in particular. Nearby, Eladio Mendez, 48, said he would like to leave the shelter, but needs the medicine he gets there.
''It's like being a P.O.W.,'' he said. ''You just don't want to go down on the streets. We're going into a biblical, biblical thing.''
In making their case, the coalition's lawyers entered the armory as evidence, giving Justice Edward H. Lehner a tour one night last month.
Instead of the shelters, the lawyers have proposed a settlement that would require the Governor to budget for special housing for 10,000 people. But state lawyers have rejected the proposal.
State lawyers have acknowledged the need for new housing. In court, said an assistant attorney general, Arnold D. Fleischer, they have have argued narrowly that ''there's nothing in the mental hygiene law that requires the state to create specific numbers of housing or specific types of housing.''
Lawyers for the plaintiffs praise the new state and city plans but call them insufficient.
Similar suits have been brought in more than 20 states. In Oregon, Oklahoma and Arizona, courts have ordered mental health officials to establish new community residences, group homes and treatment programs. A judgment in the New York case is not expected for several months.
 
Sure of the Goal, Not of the Method
Behind the debate, mental health officials and advocates say there is strong consensus on how the problem should be addressed if there is the money.
To the delicate task of coaxing mentally ill people off Manhattan's streets, voluntary groups have marshaled a small phalanx of what are called outreach teams. Collectively they represent a model to mental health experts around the country, said Irene Levine, the director of the homeless mentally ill at the National Institutes of Mental Health in Bethesda, Md. Yet while the teams cover most of Manhattan and part of Brooklyn, the three other boroughs are virtually ignored.
For the clients that the teams bring in, therapists have pioneered methods to help them readapt to life indoors. What mental health experts call the rules of indoor living - saving money, bathing, locking doors - are taught sporadically at city shelters and four places called transitional living communities run by the Human Resources Administration. This year, there is money to house 129 people.
In search of an alternative to shelters, the administration will begin to set up reception centers this year for more vulnerable homeless people including the mentally ill. If successful the centers are expected to shelter a few hundred people.
''The idea is to find a model that would get people to come in off the streets,'' said Dr. Frank R. Lipton, the administration's chief of psychiatry.
Keeping them off the streets, experts say, will require permanent housing that is flexible, private and equally unthreatening. So far, only a handful of such places have appeared in Manhattan, mostly at private initiative.
The city-state accord reached last fall seeks to fill the gap by housing 5,225 more homeless mentally ill New Yorkers by 1992.
To create 3,500 apartments by converting single-room-occupancy hotels and refurbishing buildings in different communities, state officials say they will need about $30 million in each of the next three years.
Mental health officials differ on how much of the immediate need the plan would address. Some say less than a third; some say half. But for even the first year, the financing is not entirely certain, Dr. Surles said.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
WEST EUROPEANS NEAR A CONSENSUS ON EAST-BLOC TIES

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, April 1

 BODY:
The disintegration of the Eastern bloc, though generally welcomed across Western Europe, is challenging the European Community's vision of the future just when it seemed to be moving confidently along a path toward economic and eventual political union.
Senior government and community officials say that over the last four months, the need to make room for East Germany and help Eastern Europe's other emerging democracies has threatened to distract the 12-nation group from its task of creating a single market by the end of 1992.
But a consensus has now emerged on how to deal with Eastern Europe: rather than being treated as a 13th member, East Germany will join the community simply by being absorbed by West Germany, and broad new association agreements will be worked out with other Eastern bloc nations.
 
Meeting Set for April 28
This scenario is to be presented to the heads of state and government of the 12 countries when they hold a special summit meeting in Dublin on April 28. If the plan is approved, experts here believe, much of the new uncertainty over whether the community will soon join the United States and Japan as the world's great economic powers should evaporate. 
The officials say the community is also concerned that, with German reunification, Bonn might lose interest in European integration or, alternatively, that a single Germany will be so rich and powerful that it will completely dominate the community.
The result has been something of a crisis of identity as community members and the European Commission, the bloc's influential executive body, struggle to redefine their objectives in what is coming to be known as the ''new architecture'' of Europe.
 
Gloom Begins to Lift
''One of the great illusions is that the community can continue as it is,'' one Western diplomat said.
This period of tension has been characterized most sharply by a wave of distrust between France and West Germany, the countries that have long served as the motors of European integration. Yet, no less unexpectedly, the gloomy mood at the community's headquarters here has begun to change over the past two weeks.
''People ask if the community has lost its way and the answer is no,'' said Peter Ludlow, director of the Center for European Policy Studies, an independent research center. ''Its structures have proven to be strong and, far from slowing down the process, the German issue has given a big push to integration.''
With an intimidating list of unresolved problems and unfulfilled dreams on the agenda, such confidence is still hard to find here. But after long months of standing at a crossroads and >studying the map of Europe, the com-munity's leading members, notably France and West Germany, appear to have agreed on the direction they should take.
In broad terms, it involves choosing the ''little Europe'' path - that is, maintaining the 12-nation bloc, with its 320 million inhabitants and $4.3 trillion gross product, and moving rapidly forward beyond the single-market stage to full economic and monetary union and closer political cooperation.
The community's members are France, West Germany, Britain, Italy, the Netherlands, Belgium, Denmark, Luxembourg, Greece, Spain, Portugal and Ireland.
The drive toward faster integration has been led by France's President, Francois Mitterrand, who views it as the best way of ''anchoring'' a united Germany to the West. In this, he has been supported by Italy and Spain and by Jacques Delors, president of the European Commission.
''We must be strong if we are to be generous to others,'' Mr. Delors told the European Parliament in January, alluding to new pleas from Eastern Europe for assistance. ''We must be strong if we are to have any hope of overcoming the national antagonisms which may well re-emerge in Europe.''
The turning point came only on March 23, when the West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, traveled to Brussels to reassure the community that Bonn not only remained committed to European integration but also favored early economic and monetary union and even new moves toward political union. He cemented that position in remarks on Friday after meeting with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in London.
 
A Push From Germany
''In five years, it will be completely evident that this German union will mean a push and not a decline for the community,'' he told reporters in Brussels last month after a three-hour, closed-door meeting with the commission. ''We don't want to be the Fourth Reich. We want to be European Germans and German Europeans.''
Having been a target of criticism throughout Western Europe in recent weeks, Mr. Kohl seemed to take special pleasure in suggesting that the main resistance to community integration came not from him but from Mrs. Thatcher.
He used a metaphor to argue that she would not prevail. ''The Rhine only flows in one direction and I have never met anyone who can make it flow in another,'' he said. ''Nobody can dam it. And so it is with Europe. If anyone were to make a dam, it would burst its banks and bring destruction all around.''
At the Dublin summit meeting, Mrs. Thatcher is nonetheless likely to disagree once again with her 11 colleagues, less on the proposals for dealing with Eastern European countries than on economic and monetary union, which will involve the creation of a regional central bank and a common currency.
 
Anathema to Thatcher
While supporting the establishment of a single market and the elimination of internal borders by the end of 1992, Mrs. Thatcher believes economic and monetary union would undermine Britain's sovereignty. And the mere mention of an eventual European political federation is anathema to her.
Despite her objections, the community has already called a conference for December to negotiate changes needed in its founding agreement, the 1957 Treaty of Rome, to permit economic and monetary union. Several governments also want another conference to be held simultaneously to prepare greater political integration.
Since community rules require unanimous approval of treaty changes, Mrs. Thatcher may try to block them. The view here is that, if necessary, the community will move ahead without her. ''How can she hope to stop this machine?'' Mr. Ludlow asked. ''Since 1985, she has simply been dragged along.''
 
Testing the Members' Resolve
Community officials said that while Mrs. Thatcher reportedly hoped events in Eastern Europe would slow the integration process, the changes there may have had the opposite effect: early economic and monetary union is now seen as a test of the community's willingness to press ahead despite the convulsion in Europe.
The economic focus is possible because of confidence that the single market will be largely completed by 1992. Disagreements remain on tax questions and problems linked to the elimination of border controls, like drug trafficking, terrorism and illegal immigration. But the 12 nations have already approved 60 percent of the 279 directives prepared by the commission to create the market.
More complicated in the short term are the arrangements needed to smooth East Germany's entry into the community. Even when unified with West Germany, it would need a period of transition before it can adhere to community rules on quality control, subsidies and the environment.
This in turn has raised the question whether the 12 will share the cost of rebuilding East Germany, an issue of greatest concern to Ireland, Spain, Portugal and Greece. As the poorest members of the community, they fear that aid programs for Eastern Europe could divert resources that might otherwise go to their most backward regions.
 
Urgent Need for Institutions
Nonetheless, the proposal to conclude association agreements with Eastern European countries reflects the community's recognition that the tumultuous events of recent months have created an urgent need for new institutional arrangements throughout Europe.
Inevitably, the 12 countries have also been caught up in the broader debate about the ''new Europe,'' which has variously included calls for a European Confederation, a federation of nations and an enlarged community as well as for transformation of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and abolition of the Warsaw Pact.
If community leaders agree in Dublin on a strategy for the future, however, they could help stabilize what is now a fluid situation. The plan calls for the association agreements with six Eastern European countries to be complemented by similar accords with the European Free Trade Area, which embraces Austria, Switzerland, Finland, Sweden, Norway and Iceland.
''This is a good arrangement,'' a senior community official argued, ''because the E.F.T.A. countries want to be part of the common market but don't want political union, while the East-bloc countries are not ready for a common market but want political ties to the West.''
 
Defining Political Union
By opting to ''deepen'' rather than ''widen'' its structure, albeit leaving open the door to new members after 1993, the community has also assumed the challenge of defining its own political future. Today, its goal is said to be political union, but there is no consensus on what that means.
Until now, political cooperation has at most involved a sporadic coordination of foreign policy. France's idea of giving the community a security role, on the other hand, has found little echo among governments anxious to preserve a strong United States presence in Europe through NATO.
Yet, perhaps more significantly, as the debate goes on over whether the 12 will ever become a United States of Europe, the decisions being made each day here to create a single market are quietly transferring more and more sovereignty from member states to the community.

HEADLINE: Pulling Families Out of Welfare Is Proving to Be an Elusive Goal

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS

 BODY:
Two years ago Congress overhauled the welfare system on the premise that people on public assistance did not need handouts so much as they needed a helping hand to find and keep a job.
Now, as states try to comply with a central provision of the law that became effective yesterday, sparks are flying as idealistic policies confront tight budgets.
Under the law, states must now provide one year of subsidized child-care and medical benefits to welfare clients who get jobs outside the home, with the additional costs to be shared by the states and the Federal Government. Some public policy analysts say the effort was crippled even before states began to address these latest requirements.
These critics say that welfare clients will not receive enough money to pay people to care for their children while they work and, more broadly, that the law does nothing to solve the nationwide shortage of child-care options already faced by working parents. Furthermore, they fear that when the 12 months of child-care and medical benefits expire people will be pushed back into the welfare system. 
 
Effects on Other Services
Some states have found that the only way they can put the benefits into effect is at the expense of other social services. Massachusetts and Minnesota, for example, say that to get money for the new benefits they will have to take child-care sudsidies away from the working poor, forcing some parents to quit jobs and go on welfare at much greater public expense.
No Federal official has a clear picture of what all the states are doing to come up with the additional money as well as the child-care services they are now required to have.
''Some of the welfare data systems out there are real nightmares,'' said David Rich, an aide to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who was the principal sponsor of the Family Support Act of 1988.
 
'Nobody Knows How It Will Play'
Roberty J. Ivry, the senior vice president of the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, a nonprofit social science research organization in New York that has a Federal contract to study the impact of the welfare changes over the next eight years, said, ''There are major changes in the law and nobody knows how it will play out.''
The experts' uncertainty is echoed among welfare recipients. For example. Miriam O. Jugger of Tallahassee, Fla., said she thinks the new benefits will be enough to help her get off public assistance. The single mother, who has been on welfare since her son was born last May, already has subsidized hous-ing and strong support from her family.
 
'I Don't Want Any Handouts'
She hopes the benefits will make it possible for her to get a job in a fast-food restaurant while she finishes her last year at Florida State University, where she has a B-minus average. Then she wants to work her way through law school.
''I don't want any handouts,'' said the 21-year-old Ms. Jugger. ''If I can work, I can make it.'
But others say the new benefits are not enough.
''I wanted to go back to work, but I couldn't find something without having an education for anything,'' said Debbie Ayres, a 22-year-old mother of two small children who lives just outside Flint, Mich. She said she was forced to drop out of an adult education program three times last year because she had trouble keeping a baby sitter who would work for the state fee of 85 cents an hour. Ms. Ayres said her sister would babysit this spring so she could take a five-week course in retail sales and get a job paying the minimum wage of $3.80 an hour, plus commissions.
But she worries that her earnings, combined with the state's new child-care subsidy, will not be enough to pay for child care. The state will provide up to $350 a month for her two children for one year, depending on her income.
An informal survey of 1,500 licensed providers of child care, recently conducted by the Michigan Community Coordinated Childcare Association, a nonprofit educational organization, suggests that such care, where available, would cost from $260 a month in the least expensive family setting to $1,375 a month in child-care centers.
The welfare law covers recipients of Aid to Families with Dependent Children, which includes 3.3 million women who head households, 425,000 men who head households and 7.3 million children under 18 years old.
 
Annual Benefits Are Locked In
Previously, when families left welfare for work, most states provided up to three months' of subsidized child care and Medicaid coverage as long as family income met state criteria. Now, under the Family Support Act of 1988, these benefits are locked in place for one year.
In addition to the child-care and medical benefits, the law requires that states establish job training and education programs by Oct. 1 and that the programs be offered throughout the state by Oct. 1, 1992. So far, 27 states have begun offering job training.
The law requires parents of children over the age of 3, or over the age of 1, at a state's option, to seek work or to enter the educational or job training programs as a condition for continuing to receive benefits. Previously, a parent receiving welfare was not expected to work until the youngest child reached the age of 6, and there was no requirement that parents be given job training or education.
A provision of the law already in effect requires states to make greater efforts to make absent fathers pay child support, with steps like mandatory payroll deduction plans.
States that do not comply with the law lose Federal matching money under the plan and, theoretically, could lose all other Federal welfare subsidies.
Over the next five years, under matching money provisions of the law, the Federal and state governments will share the cost of the program about equally. An estimated $2 billion a year will go to job-training and education and greater enforcement of child support laws. Child-care and medical benefits will cost more: there is no ceiling on these costs.
The Federal Family Support Administration, which oversees welfare, could not give an estimate for the cost of these benefits but said the Government had budgeted $489 million for child care under the new law.
The flaws in the new benefits program are widely recognized.
''The benefits are a move in the right direction, but they obviously are not a fix,'' said Gina Boyd, staff manager of the Aid for Families with Dependent Children Policy Bureau in the California Department of Social Services. ''We do recognize it is a problem that people are only eligible for the benefits for one year and we are worried about what will happen to people. Some will transition to other subsidy programs, some will rely on relatives for child care, some will fall through the cracks and recycle through welfare again.''
Many of those families falling through the cracks wind up in the office of Nancy Claxton, the administrator of the Child Development Program in California's Orange County Department of Education. ''I don't know where we are going to put all these children,'' Ms. Claxton said.
She said that 3,000 children whose parents are working but poor are already on waiting lists for subsidized child care in Orange County, and that the new welfare law would add 6,000 more children to the waiting lists as their parents exhaust their one-year benefits for child care and medical aid. Around the state, 135,000 children of the working poor are on waiting lists for child-care subsidies.
Ms. Claxton refers to the state's revamped welfare program, called Greater Avenues for Independence, as ''Greater Agony to Insanity.'' Part of the problem is that California is also trying to cope with a projected $2 billion deficit in its budget in its 1991 fiscal year, which begins July 1. The state's welfare system, second only to New York's in size, serves 592,000 families at an annual cost of $4 billion.
 
States Already Give Transition Benefits
Some states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, have been offering child care and medical benefits during a welfare recipient's transition from the welfare rolls to self-sufficiency, and officials said their programs would not change much after April 1.
''In Connecticut we have been providing unlimited transitional benefits for several years,'' said Claudette J. Beaulieu, a spokeswoman for the State Department of Income Maintenance. She described the program as ''economic development, not welfare,'' in a state with such a low unemployment rate that businesses will hire people who are usually considered surplus labor.
About 37,000 families receive welfare, and the state provides subsidies of up to $325 a month for each child for as long as parents need them and do not earn too much to qualify.
The benefits offered in the transitional year may have the most impact in poor states with low welfare grants. ''It's the most exciting thing I've ever seen,'' said Andrew P. Hornsby Jr., commissioner of the Alabama Department of Human Resources. The state pays the nation's smallest welfare grant, $118 a month for a family of three. Alaska pays the most, more than $800 for the same size family, according to a 1989 report by the House Ways and Means Committee.
But Massachusetts and Minnesota, two states that have had relatively generous and successful welfare-to-work programs, have had to cut optional programs for the working poor to finance mandatory programs for welfare recipients. Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts has proposed eliminating 4,000 to 5,000 child-care subsidies for the working poor next year, and Minnesota has already eliminated child-care benefits for about 120 families.
''We had to find the money, so we had to kick working poor folks off child-care subsidies,'' said Paul Timm-Brock, director of the Assistance Payments Division in the Minnesota Department of Human Services. ''Some of them quit their jobs and went back on welfare.''
That is what Nancy K. Murphy did. The 28-year-old single mother had been working for three years as a children's photographer in shopping malls near her home in Clearwater, Minn. The job had good benefits and a company car, but her weekly pay of $160 entitled her to state subsidized child care for her 16-month-old son, Spencer.
Last November, the state began complying voluntarily with the new welfare law, and it soon ran out of money to provide the required transitional benefits for welfare families.
Without her $200-a-month subsidy for child care, which often cost $300 a month, Ms. Murphy said she was unable to pay her bills. She quit her job in February and applied for public assistance. She expects to receive, on a monthly basis, a $437 welfare grant, $90 in food stamps and Medicaid coverage. And, when she enters a job training or educational program, the state will pay all day-care costs.
''I saw an ad for my job in the paper and it made me sick,'' Ms. Murphy said.
Welfare changes apparently, will not occur without growth pains.
''The law establishes dramatic new principles in American welfare practice by giving people an entitlement to job training and an entitlement to child care to help them get off welfare,'' said Michael B. Katz, director of the Urban Studies Program at the University of Pennsylvania and author of ''The Undeserving Poor: From the War on Poverty to the War on Welfare'' (Pantheon Books; 1990). ''But, for now, it allows states to punitively force women into the work force with low-paying jobs without guaranteeing them adequate child care or a future.''
Senator Moynihan, who describes the law as a good first step, says it will take a decade to assess its effectiveness.
''It's what the governors asked for, and most of the states are just roaring ahead,'' he said. ''Whether other people get in the spirit of this legislation and try to make it work or sit around and complain about it remains to be seen. But there will not be another bill in this century, so let's do the best thing for the children.''

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
STOCKS PLUMMET ON TOKYO MARKET

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, April 2

 BODY:
The two-month erosion of confidence in Japanese financial markets grew more serious today, as share prices and the yen plunged in value, causing the second-worst delcine on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.
Most worrying to many analysts is not just the fact that the markets have fallen steadily and at times wildly this year, but that each new battering is shaking the market's foundation of confidence. If the turmoil grows more serious in Tokyo, it is feared that panic could well spread to New York and other primary financial centers.
On Monday, the closely-watched Nikkei 225-stock average fell by 1,978.38 points, or by 6.6 percent, to 28,002.07. The Tokyo market's worst day was a 14.9 percent plunge on Oct. 20, 1987, when the Nikkei fell by 3,836.48 points. 
 
Imbalance of Sell Orders
But in a sign of how seriously unsettled the markets have become, many shares were not even able to open for trading today, the first day in the new Japanese fiscal year. There was such a heavy imbalance of sell orders, that over half the shares listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange were shut down in the morning, a frightening sign of market paralysis. By late afternoon, about three-quarters of the shares could trade.
In addition, the stock-index futures markets were not able to open for trading. They fell their daily allowable limit immediately, and so could not function. Those closings added to invester concerns, analysts said, casting a dark shadow over the markets that is not likely to clear up soon.
Stock prices were pushed lower by many of the same factors that have been worrying the market all year. The dollar soared against the yen early today, hitting a peak of 160.35 yen, its highest level in more than three years. Analysts have said that even many large Japanese institutions have been selling yen and moving their capital into the United States and West Germany.
The Bank of Japan has intervened heavily in recent weeks and increased interest rates sharply in an effort to defend the yen, but is has failed to arrest the slide in the currency.
Market interest rates also leapt higher early today, causing bond prices to plummet and raising fears that the Bank of Japan would be forced to boost interest rates yet again.
''It's when all these things coincide that the market comes apart,'' said John Charlton-Jones, a trader at James Capel Pacific, a brokerage concern here.
''The market remains fundamentally weak and we see little hope it is going to turn around,'' said Liam Newberg, an analyst with Merrill Lynch.
Another factor was a front-page arrtile in theNihon Keizai Shimbun, Japan's leading economic daily, saying that Japanese insurance companies had plans to sell huge amounts of Japanese stocks. Specifically the report claimed that the Dai-Ichi Mutual Life Insurance Company, one of Japan's largest, was preparing to sell 200 billion yen worht of shares, about $1.26 billion worth. The report was later denied by Dai-Ichi Mutual Life. ''The report was not exactly true, but the fact that it had such an impact shows just how vulnerable the market really is,'' said a senior executive at the Nomura Securities Company. ''There is just no buying sentiment.''
The market tumble leaves stock prices down more than 25 percent since the beginning of this year.
 
Hong Kong Issues Fall
HONG KONG, Monday, April 1 (Reuters) - A surprise increase in interest rates here and a drop in the Tokyo stock market caused a heavy slide in stock prices today.
The Hang Seng index fell by 59.34 points, or by 2 percent, in the first 45 minutes of trading, to 2,938.64. In Japan, the Nikkei 225-stock average ended the morning session down by 1,720.13 points, or 5.7 percent, to 28,260.32. The index ended the trading day at 28,002.07, down by 1,978.38, or by 6.6 percent.
A 1 percent rise in interest rates, bringing the prime lending rate to 11 percent, took effect today. ''This morning's losses are 80 percent interest rates, 20 percent Tokyo,'' said Ravi Narain, an analysist at Peregrine Brokerage, a prominent securities house.

SECTION: Section A; Page 16, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 355 words

HEADLINE: National Debt Becomes Beast That Ate America;
Elusive Peace Dividend

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In your excellent editorial on how to spend the peace dividend (''$150 Billion a Year,'' March 9) you unfortunately come a cropper on one crucial point. You accept the Gramm-Rudman law!
You suggest that we could free $150 billion a year by 1999 and you wisely urge investment in the future - in human resources of education and health and in our deteriorating infrastructure of highways and airports. It is indeed on a wide range of public investment that our own prosperity and that of our children and grandchildren will depend. 
But then, after stating that ''cutting back the mountainous deficit, per the Senate resolution . . . is misguided and unnecessary,'' you explain that under Gramm-Rudman, the deficit ''will be eliminated by the mid-90's . . . If it is the wrong target, it would not seem to err by much.''
That, though, is exactly the issue. The deficit is just about the $150 billion a year that you foresee in an eventual peace dividend. If we eliminate the deficit according to Gramm-Rudman - without more smoke and mirrors, or sealing President Bush's lips - it is precisely the peace dividend that will be gone before it is even realized, and with it our vital public investment.
And whether or not private saving and investment are adequate, as I suggest, or insufficient, as is frequently asserted, how can you be so sure that cutting the budget deficit would increase them? If the Federal Government leaves us less to spend - either by giving us less or taxing us more -we will certainly consume less. But if as a consequence we do not buy that new Chrysler, will Lee Iacocca decide to build a new plant or, more likely, cut his investment spending?
Most analysts see at best a period of slow growth for the United States ahead. If the fiscal austerity of further reductions in the budget deficit pushes us into a recession, we can be sure that all saving and investment, public and private, will take the hit, and with it all the more of our prospects for the future.
 
ROBERT EISNER
William R. Kenan Professor
of Economics, Northwestern U.
 Evanston, Ill., March 11, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 16, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 271 words

HEADLINE: National Debt Becomes Beast That Ate America

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your March 18 editorial says the Federal Government's ''deficit-reduction path seems right.'' What deficit-reduction path? There has been no deficit reduction. You concede that ''budget gimmicks'' evade the deficit-reduction law. They sure do. The actual deficit is accurately reflected in the annual growth of the national debt. That has grown between $225 billion and $300 billion in every one of the six years through 1990. Keep in mind these have been years of peace and economic growth, years when the increase in the national debt should have been declining. How much will the debt grow each year when the next recession hits?
You say nothing about the immense cost of this $3 trillion national debt. Thanks to huge annual deficits, interest costs on that debt have skyrocketed to $175 billion a year. Here is the most rapidly rising cost of our national government. It is already second only to military spending. Within 10 years it will be our biggest cost.
This is also the one cost of government we cannot reduce by a penny, the one cost we must pay in full and on time. And it is useless. It doesn't educate even one child, build a house for a single homeless family, provide medical assistance to save one human life or a dime's worth of environmental protection or national defense.
The Administration and Congress continue to be guilty of political cowardice and gross irresponsibility. And now you chime in to say this budgetary irresponsibility ''seems right.'' For Shame.
 
WILLIAM PROXMIRE
Washington, March 18, 1990
 The writer was Senator from Wisconsin from 1957 to 1988.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
The Eternal Aim To Make Cities More Livable

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Far-sightedness in state and local government seems to be defined nowadays as anticipating next week's budget deficit forecast. In that context, a 15-month contract authorized last month by the New York City Transit Authority is positively visionary.
The contract is for work on the Second Avenue subway. It will not complete the 14-mile route. Rather, transit officials plan to spend $2 million to maintain and secure the one mile that was bored before the project was abandoned in 1975 during the city's last fiscal crisis. 
That transit officials have not forgot the future altogether is grounds for optimism among planners. So is the belated debut of the city's Office of Strategic Planning, inspired by Mayor Edward I. Koch's Commission on the Year 2000 - which was a response, in part, by Mr. Koch to complaints that vision was not one of his things.
So, too, in one sense, is Mayor David N. Dinkins insistence on planning expertise, rather than political acumen, as the primary qualification for the City Planning Commission chairmanship - itself the subject of a search that, after nearly five months, qualifies as long term.
Last week another effort was begun to shape the metropolitan area's future, this one by the Regional Plan Association, a nonprofit research group.
In 1929 the association published its ''Regional Plan of New York and Its Environs,'' a futuristic blueprint. Most of its proposed network of roads ringing the region were built, but plans to expand commuter rail lines were scrapped during the Depression.
A second regional plan in 1968 promoted redevelopment of downtowns, a strategy credited with speeding the rejuventation of New Brunswick, N.J.; Stamford, Conn., and White Plains, and with the potential revivals of Jamaica, Queens, and downtown Brooklyn.
The name of the proposed third plan and the cover photograph on the prospectus are illuminating. The first two regional plans were blandly titled (in contrast with the Commission on the Year 2000's report, which, despite significant caveats, was boldly called ''New York Ascendant).''
The third plan, due to be produced in stages over five years, is to be called ''The Region Tomorrow.'' The title does not imply any judgment as to what tomorrow will be like. Nor does it mention the word plan.
Both omissions may represent a concession that previous plans could not have anticipated the epidemics of AIDS and crack, just as the next plan is unlikely to predict with precision the impact of events in Europe or Hong Kong on business and immigration in the New York region or the consequences of crises still waiting to occur.
The cover photograph for the Regional Plan Association prospectus is of the gleaming Philip Morris building rising behind the rusted, but since restored, viaduct around Grand Central Terminal in midtown Manhattan. It is a graphic reminder that New York City is likely to remain the driving force behind the region's economy. It is also emblematic of the city's struggle to balance growth with tradition and with overtaxed public works. The back cover features three photographs: a schoolteacher, two children and a retiree.
The plan's goals include making the region more competitive in the global economy, easing access to airports, forging new transit links, particularly in Rockland and Orange Counties and between Englewood and Elizabeth in northern New Jersey, improving the enviroment, encouraging cooperation among overlapping government jurisdictions and eliminating obstacles to affordable housing.
Another goal is to make the region more ''equitable'' - a mission addressed recently by a committee of the association in a report called ''Bridging the Social Chasm.''
That report recommends that a regional agency be created to help replicate programs that have successfully shepherded poor people into the economic and social mainstream; that policies be considered to promote racial, ethnic and income integration, and that forums be convened to create a consensus on solutions to poverty.
''It's not our natural business,'' acknowledged William B. Shore, senior vice president of the Regional Plan Association.
But the association is filling a vacuum again. No government organization represents the entire metropolitan area. Moreover, as a private group, the association is singularly equipped, said Richard Ravitch, the businessman, former public official and defeated mayoral candidate who will be chairman of a panel overseeing the plan.
''Planning,'' he said, ''is not the strong suit of the democratic political process.''

HEADLINE: 48 Who Died in Bronx Fire Return Home

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

DATELINE: SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras, April 1

 BODY:
Accompanied by the President of Honduras and other government officials, survivors of those who died in the Happy Land fire in the Bronx gathered on the runway here today to meet the cargo jet carrying the dead. It landed shortly before noon.
As doors swung open, revealing 48 coffins within, some survivors embraced in clusters, some screamed in grief and still others collapsed in sobs on the runway.
The plane arrived in unrelenting heat. About 40 Honduran Red Cross volunteers, carrying first-aid kits and jugs of water, offered assistance. They put out chairs for people, and one woman who was seated bent over, crying, while a relative fanned her with a piece of cardboard. A man was carried away on a stretcher. 
A young woman, the girlfriend of Marco Tulio Gamoneda, a 23-year-old victim who attended Bronx Community College and worked part-time at a supermarket, shouted, ''Bring the Honduran flag out, so everyone knows these are Hondurans.''
The coffins, packed in wooden crates, were unloaded in fours and laid out in three rows on the runways. Bouquets were placed on each coffin. The families walked between the rows, looking at the pieces of paper. Some fell on the coffins, crying. Msgr. Jaime E. Brufau, the Bishop of San Pedro Sula, said a short prayer as relatives gathered around. Burials were planned Monday in 11 towns throughout northern Honduras.
The dead are among the 87 people who were trapped and killed eight days ago in an arsonist's fire at the Happy Land Social Club, an illegal operation in the Bronx.
 
Suspect Facing 170 Charges
The police say the man charged with setting the fire, Julio Gonzalez, was trying to kill his estranged companion, Lydia Feliciano, the coat-check clerk at the club. Ms. Feliciano was one of five people who escaped the fire.
A grand jury has indicted Mr. Gonzalez on more than 170 counts in connection with the fire, including 87 counts of murder.
A DC-10 jet chartered by the American Red Cross flew the 48 bodies to Ramon Villeda Morales International Airport here, about 150 miles north of Tegucigalpa, the Honduran capital. From the airport, relatives followed military trucks or private hearses carrying the coffins to municipalities dotting the Northwest of the Central American country.
Eight coffins with destinations in coastal towns as far as 275 miles to the north were transported by a Honduran Air Force DC-3 passenger plane whose seats had been removed. Relatives followed on another military flight and by land.
The flights were a concession to families of the victims during an emotional morning in which mourners openly shared the pain of receiving the bodies and also vented anger at the Honduran Government, which many perceived as not having done enough in response to the tragedy. The Government had originally planned to move all of the coffins from the airport by truck, which would have meant a six-hour trip to some of the farther towns. But officials relented under pressure. Many of those complaining were among the 130 relatives who had arrived earlier from New York and were anxious to take the bodies to their families in Honduras, eight days after they had identified the dead at Public School 67 in the Bronx.
 
'People Don't Understand'
''This is a highly emotional situation,'' said Maj. Napoleon Santos, a coordinator for the Honduran armed forces. ''People don't understand procedures in a moment like this.''
The bodies were taken away in three trucks. Those destined for the towns of Trujillo and Ceiba were taken by plane.
The President of Honduras, Rafael Leonardo Callejas Romero, and the commander of the Honduran armed forces, Gen. Arnulfo Cantarero Lopez, arrived at the airport shortly before the chartered cargo jet carrying the bodies touched down. Forty men from the 105th Military Brigade were also on hand, along with more than 250 relatives.
The President, who had declared three days of mourning for the fire victims, attributed the blaze to ''an irrational act'' by an individual and thanked the City of New York for ''understanding human nature and extending their hand.''
 
President Expresses Sorrow
''We are so sorry,'' he said as he shook hands with relatives. ''We hope you have the strength and faith to accept an act like this.''
But one of the mourners, Alexander Morales, a friend of 32-year-old Francisco Gonzales, who worked in construction, said: ''We don't need the President. What we need is to take the bodies to their houses.''
Mr. Morales, who was accompanying Mr. Gonzalez's widow, Marina Sanchez, who lives in Honduras with the couple's two children, 6 and 4, criticized the Honduran Consulate in New York for not helping families until days after the fire.
''They could have helped immediately with documentation,'' he said. ''The families needed it for moral support. Instead they got there after everything was taken care of.''
Salvador Rodezno, a representative of the Honduran Embassy in Washington, who was at the airport, said: ''Everything was in the hands of the American Red Cross. In the United States, you can't just intervene. There are a series of regulations that need to be followed. The Government of Hondurans has given the best cooperation to Hondurans there. I haven't slept more than six hours in the last eight days.''
 
Immigration to U.S. Rising
The President estimated that 100,000 Hondurans were living in the United States, and immigration has increased recently because of Honduras's economic problems. ''The economic problems have made them go look for jobs,'' he said.
Sara R. Alvarez, who lost a nephew in the Bronx fire, said: ''Our nephews and children were there because there's no work here. If there's work, it doesn't pay anything. Everything is expensive. Our currency has been devalued. Our external debt is huge.''

HEADLINE: Bronx Economy Gaining Vigor After Setbacks

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
More than a decade after the Bronx hit an economic bottom rarely experienced in urban America, a slow infusion of business investment has invigorated its retail areas, pushed up commercial rents and pumped new life into some of its derelict industrial real estate, business people and city officials say.
One aspect of the business investment came to light in a tragic way on March 25 with the fire at the Happy Land Social Club, operated in a two-story structure on Southern Boulevard, off Tremont Avenue. Records showed that the club was part of an entire block of buildings owned by Alex DiLorenzo 3d, a real-estate investor who paid $885,000 for the buildings in 1985.
The response to the fire has been a call for greater scrutiny, not only of social clubs but also of the people who own the buildings. Mr. DiLorenzo had subleased the Bronx buildings to Little Peach Realty, a large management concern, that in turn leased it to Elias Colon, the club owner who died along with 86 other people in the blaze. 
 
A Wave of Investment
''I have no sympathy for investors who gouge our neighborhoods and plead ignorance about the decaying condition of their buildings,'' said Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, in an interview.
But merchants and real-estate executives in the Bronx, which is still trying to shed its national status as a symbol of urban blight, said speculation in buildings like the one that housed the Happy Land club is highly unusual in a wave of investment that began in the mid-1980's. In large part, they said, the investment has been good news for New York City's poorest borough.
One example of the investment is under construction at 161st Street and Grand Concourse, across from the Bronx County Courthouse. There a new shopping mall, the Concourse Plaza Shopping Center, is to be completed by the end of this year. The $100 million project, which is to include a 10-story office building, is the borough's first large-scale, privately financed real-estate venture in more than 20 years.
 
'A Happy Surprise'
''Our project is turning out to be a happy surprise,'' said Bernard Rosenshien, a New Rochelle developer who has financed the Bronx project and designed it to resemble suburban malls he has built in Westchester County, in Connecticut and in other states.
A Waldbaum's supermarket is to anchor the shopping center, which is to include 40 other stores, the developer said. He added that he had decided to enlarge his original plan because of higher than expected demand for space by national retail chains.
Elsewhere in the Bronx, particularly along the retail streets of the Hub - a commercial cluster surrounding the intersection of 149th Street and Third Avenue - and farther north along Fordham Road near the Grand Concourse, retail activity is brisk, rents are rising and merchants expanding.
In the South Bronx, along the Harlem River waterfront, and in other sections where manufacturing concerns have been in a steady decline for decades, brokers say investment in industrial buildings reached boom proportions in the mid-1980's and has only begun to slacken in recent months. Instead of manufacturing, many of the buildings are being used as warehouses for food distributors, theatrical supply concerns and financial service companies.
''Suddenly, a lot of people who would not have thought about investing in the Bronx in the past are putting their money here,'' Mr. Ferrer said.
 
Refurbished Apartments
One reason for the rising level of business investment is a far bigger commitment by New York City to rehabilitate housing. With a total of $5.1 billion budgeted to rehabiltate abandoned, city-owned residential properties, the Bronx, with the city's largest share of abandoned buildings, is getting the biggest share of the funds.
In all, 45,000 apartments are being rebuilt in the city, with 20,000 of them in the Bronx. Officials said close to half the work in the Bronx had already been completed and that all of it was scheduled to be completed by 1993.
As a result, merchants report a surge in business from tenants of refurbished apartments, some of whom have moved to the borough for the first time.
''This store takes off first thing in the morning and doesn't stop until closing,'' said Dick Desanto, manager of the Sears store on Fordham Road between Webster Street and Park Avenue, which itself is being remodeled.
Another retailer in the Bronx, the Ray Department Store, at 149th Street and Third Avenue, has acquired an adjoining lot and is more than doubling its size. The store's manager, Leon Cohen, said the expansion was prompted by sales increases that have been ''very steady over the last three years.''
Over all, retail sales in the Bronx have increased since the mid-1980's. The New York City Finance Department said receipts from the city's sales tax collected in the Bronx rose 28 percent from 1985 to 1989, to $191 million. The rate of increase was roughly the same as the rest of the city.
Investing in industrial properties in the Bronx has been particularly strong in loft buildings and warehouses. Since the early 80's, several large New York City companies, including Zaro Bakeries, Faberware and Hudson Scenic Studio, have rented large blocks of space in the Port Morris, Hunts Point and other industrial sections.
John Ritter, vice president of Sholom & Zuckerbrot Realty, which specializes in commercial and industrial space in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx, said demand for industrial space had slackened in the last six months as the city economy has cooled off.
Nonetheless, he said recent leases signed for Bronx warehouses had gone for $40 a square foot, 10 times more than what it would cost a decade ago.
''Property in the Bronx has climbed more dramatically over the last 10 years than anywhere else in the city,'' he said, adding that the main reason was that values for such property had ''fallen so far'' in the 1970's.

HEADLINE: Drive for Civil Rights in U.S. Faces New Agendas

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS

 BODY:
From Selma to Greensboro to Nashville, the South is awash in remembrances of the alphabet soup of civil rights groups -N.A.A.C.P., S.C.L.C., CORE, S.N.C.C. and others that made history a quarter of a century ago.
But around the nation, the groups that survive, even the mighty National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, find themselves struggling to adapt to a more diverse black America, more complex issues and increased competition for members.
Some see signs of renewed interest in civil rights issues among young blacks, and the N.A.A.C.P. in particular is stepping up its activity in its youth and college chapters. But interviews with blacks around the country indicate that changes in black America, its successes at least as much as its failures, are diminishing the roles of the traditional civil rights groups.
 
'Battlefield Has Shifted'
Although a vast majority of blacks see a continued role for traditional civil rights organizations, the growing power of blacks in politics and the emergence of a strong black middle class have provided other options for effecting political and social change. 
''I think the battlefield has shifted,'' said Sherman E. Stimley, a 45-year-old lawyer in Houston. ''Most of the issues now have to do with economics, and I don't know if young blacks perceive the traditional organizations as able to address those issues.''
In Chicago most traditional black organizations, from Operation PUSH to smaller community groups, are battling dwindling interest.
''The movement has collapsed,'' said Lu Palmer, chairman of the Chicago Black United Communities. ''Different people have different definitions of the movement. Black people are pulling back.''
 
'We're Fighting Each Other'
The Rev. Clyde Brooks, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference in Chicago, whose membership has sunk to 3,700 from 20,000 in the early 1970's, added: ''We're fighting each other. We're critical of this and that, and one has to raise the question, 'Is there a community anymore?' ''
Many of the reasons that civil rights organizations are struggling can be seen here in New Orleans. The city has a black Mayor and has had one since 1978. Blacks dominate the City Council and the school board. With so much political power held by blacks, the action tends to gravitate there instead of toward civil rights groups.
''Some of the young people feel they don't have anything to fight for,'' said the Rev. S. L. Harvey, who was on hand when the S.C.L.C. was founded in 1957 and who, at the age of 71, still heads its struggling New Orleans chapter. ''Things are kind of easy for them. Some of them say they don't want to hear what happened a long time ago.''
 
Divisions Among Blacks
The local N.A.A.C.P. chapter has a rich history dating from 1915, and its chapter presidents have included the late Ernest N. Dutch Morial, who was the city's first black Mayor. About 3,000 residents pay the dues, usually $10, that make them members of the N.A.A.C.P.
But Shirley Porter, who has been the branch president for 10 years, said only 35 or 40 members were active participants, and she admitted that the organization needed new directions and new blood.
''We're really the only organization that's still alive and well, so I guess it's still up to us to push for change and promote change,'' she said. ''But we know our agenda has to change, and I'm sure our national convention in Los Angeles this year is going to come up with a whole new agenda.''
The problem reflects the increasingly fractured state of black America. Roger Wilkins, a professor of history and American culture at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va., said that in the era of segregation blacks shared the same problems.
''It didn't matter if you were rich or poor.'' he said. ''You couldn't go downtown and eat in a restaurant; you couldn't sit where you wanted in the theater or go to the hotel. Now the stronger elements in the community no longer suffer the way the poorer ones do. It's harder to find the commonality of interests.''
Thus in New Orleans, groups like the N.A.A.C.P., the S.C.L.C. and the National Urban League draw criticism from both rich and poor blacks.
 
Concern for the Black Poor
Carl Galmon, a 47-year-old gadfly, says black elected officials and civil rights groups alike have lost touch with the black poor.
''It's embarrassing to see black elected officials and people heading up civil rights organizations capitulating to folks who have been our oppressors, just to sit at a table for a social event,'' he said. ''The N.A.A.C.P. here ought to close up shop; the S.C.L.C., too. They're not doing anything to get African-Americans involved in the economic mainstream.''
The most successful blacks often find the groups either irrelevant to their lives or mired in old approaches to new problems.
''There's almost a paint-by-the-numbers script that you can rely on N.A.A.C.P. leaders to deliver,'' said Keith Butler, 34, an investment banker educated at Harvard. ''They're telling the white community that it's whites who are responsible for the position black people find themselves in. They're telling the black community to rely on the leadership of the N.A.A.C.P. to tell whites they're responsible for the position black people are in. I'm not sure either group is listening to them.'' Whatever Happened to . . . ? Many groups, like the Student Non-Violent Coordinating Committee, no longer exist. And CORE, the Congress of Racial Equality, which under Roy Innis is openly hostile to the traditional civil rights agenda, bears little resemblance to its earlier self.
The N.A.A.C.P. remains the largest and most powerful organization by far, with 1,700 chapters and 500,000 members, matching its all-time high after dipping in the 1970's. Its influence at the national level is probably as significant now as it has ever been, and in many communities the N.A.A.C.P. remains the dominant voice on civil rights issues.
In the past few years, it has begun to accentuate economic issues in a way it never did before. Its main vehicle is its Fair Share program, which negotiates agreements with national and regional businesses to increase minority hiring and the use of minority contractors.
''Really, over the past three or four years, we've come to realize that economic empowerment is the means we must use to raise the living standards of black Americans, not just civil rights standards and civil rights laws,'' said Dr. William F. Gibson, chairman of the N.A.A.C.P.
He denied that there was any significant diminution of the N.A.A.C.P.'s impact but conceded that today's issues posed difficulties that those of the past did not. ''You had a central focus when you were dealing with a bill to relieve discrimination in public accommodations, when you had segregated lunch counters and black and white water fountains,'' he said.
 
A Surge in New Groups
Still, it is hard to find an N.A.A.C.P. chapter without concerns about bringing along new leadership. In Atlanta, which once had one of the nation's most vibrant chapters of the N.A.A.C.P., the local chapter's dwindling influence has been widely publicized.
In Memphis, which has long had one of the strongest local chapters, Maxine Smith has been in charge since 1962. ''I hoped I would have been replaced two decades ago,'' she said. ''The drive in the young is not the same it was when I returned to a completely segregated society here.''
Over the past two decades, there has been an explosion in the number of black organizations. For example, a guide to black organizations printed by Philip Morris Companies Inc. includes dozens of black professional organizations - for black entertainment technicians, black female entrepreneurs, black women in higher education, black public administrators. Nearly all of them started since the 1970's. Black social organizations and fraternities are increasingly active, as are groups of black professionals like the ''100 Black Men,'' a group that works with youths in at least nine major cities.
''There are more blacks in the mainstream today, and the thrust is from the inside out instead of outside in,'' said State Representative Irma Brown of Little Rock, one of six blacks in the Arkansas Legislature.
 
Black Conservatives' View
The most extreme sign of disaffection comes from the small but increasingly vocal group of black conservatives who say the traditional civil rights agenda, focusing on racism and race-based remedies like affirmative action instead of economic and social change within the black community, is not only out of date but also harmful to black aspirations.
''They're locked in the past,'' said Robert L. Woodson, president of the National Center for Neighborhood Enterprise in Washington. ''All they're doing is celebrating history. Their concern on racial and social justice while ignoring economic marketplace strategies has harmed us in a most profound way.''
But even Mr. Woodson concedes that the civil rights agenda dating to the era of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. has a sacrosanct place for blacks.
''Civil rights is a threshold issue, an emotional issue for blacks,'' he said. ''If you don't come right on civil rights, you don't get a hearing on anything else.''
For many blacks, that sentiment and continuing racial friction insure the relevance of groups like the N.A.A.C.P., as part of a broad array of black voices.
''If you had asked me 10 years ago, I might have questioned whether or not they were still effective,'' said Brenda Siler, who works in public relations for the American Association of Retired Persons in Atlanta. ''But it is obvious that there has been a resurgence of a lot of racism, which has demonstrated their work is not done.''

HEADLINE: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS: BASKETBALL;
National Pastime Hearing Footsteps

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr.

 BODY:
IF you are one of those whose hearts jump when Michael Jordan leaps, and if you plan to be among the millions who will be glued to their television sets for the collegiate showdown between Duke and Nevada-Las Vegas tonight, you'll hardly be surprised that a recent poll has confirmed what you and television executives have known all along: basketball is booming.
In the telephone survey conducted by the Gallup organization in mid-February, basketball, which had held steady as the favorite spectator sport of about 10 percent of the American population in periodic polls from 1948 to 1981, was listed as the favorite sport to watch by 15 percent of the 1,235 adults surveyed, putting it within a point of baseball, the No. 2 spectator sport, Football, which replaced baseball as the favorite sport in the 1960's, continued in the No. 1 position with a 35 percent following, statistically indistinguishable from 38 percent in the 1981 poll.
The good news for baseball, whose popularity had dropped steadily and steeply from 39 percent in 1948, is that the decline seems to have leveled off. It remained at the 16 percent level, the same as in the 1981 survey. 
The bad news is that its popularity is concentrated among those over the age of 50 and among those who say they are only lukewarm sports fans.
Basketball, by contrast, was especially popular among younger people, black fans and those who consider themselves hard-core fans, a group, incidentally, the survey found to have a disproportionate representation of black fans.
Although the more than 50 percent increase in the popularity of basketball from its 9 percent rating in 1981 to 15 percent in the 1990 poll was just outside the survey's 4-point margin of error, the increase clearly reflects the sport's growing appeal over the last decade.
The results of the survey, to be sure, were studded with the inevitable contradictions found in such polls.
For example, when asked how interested they were in following professional or college sports, 30 percent said they had no interest at all. Yet when asked about their favorite sports to watch all but 13 percent identified a specific sport, indicating that the popularity figures included those with no interest in their own ''favorite'' sports.
