HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
New York's Magazines In a Slump

BYLINE: By RANDALL ROTHENBERG

 BODY:
For magazines, New York has be-come a town without pity.
Faced with reduced advertising from a troubled retailing industry and a cluttered field, publishers of several city and regional magazines in and around New York have bailed out or changed their strategies.
Last week, 7 Days, a weekly journal of news, style and culture aimed at New Yorkers in their 30's, was put on the block. The vitriolic New York humor magazine Spy is also seeking a buyer or primary investor, as is Long Island Monthly. And Conde Nast Publications said recently that it would reposition Details, a chronicle of New York's downtown demimonde, as a men's magazine, presumably to make it more attractive to advertisers. 
These and other publications that cover New York are suffering from a severe slump in retailing, the primary advertising category for city magazines as well as newspapers. Indeed, travails in retailing and suffering among city magazines are national phenomena. Publishing executives describe a domino effect, in which retail empires like the Campeau Corporation, which owns Bloomingdale's, Jordan Marsh and other department store chains, are saddled with debt, curtail their ad expenditures and frighten their suppliers into zipping their own purses.
''It's a scary time in the city magazine business,'' said Thomas O. Ryder, the president of the American Express Publishing Corporation, which owns New York Woman, L.A. Style and Atlanta magazines. ''With the bankruptcy of Campeau and the downturn of fortunes of department stores, anything that sells through those chains is nervous.
''Any time people are nervous, they begin to hold onto their marketing money more tightly,'' Mr. Ryder added. ''So you've got everybody from fashion people to beauty and fragrance people tightening up their spending. The guys feeling it most are the small city books.''
In the New York area, the problem is particularly acute. Retail advertising linage in New York City newspapers, a barometer of the state of the retail industry, was down by 13.6 percent in January from the year before, according to Media Records, an industry research group. Among newspapers in New York's suburbs, retail advertising was off 7.7 percent.
For New York area magazines, the picture is grim. So far this year, ad pages are down by 27 percent in New York Woman, 16 percent in Manhattan,inc. and 12 percent in New York magazine, according to tabulations by New York magazine. The April issue of Spy has only half the ad pages of the April 1989 issue.
Outside of New York, through March, ad pages at L.A. Style were down by 12 percent from 1989; New England Monthly's were off by 21 percent and those for D, in Dallas, were down by 22 percent, according to Media Industry Newsletter, an industry publication.
But counting pages can be misleading. Increased ad pages can mask discounted rates and declining revenues; conversely, advertising rate increases and new circulation can make up for shortfalls in ad pages. Although 7 Days says its ad pages are running about even with last year, the prospectus being circulated for it by the Jordan Group, a communications consulting firm, says the publication's ad revenues are 10 percent higher than they were at the same point last year.
Still, when ad pages are down in an entire publishing category, it shows clearly that less overall advertising is available to be shared. And the burden generally falls on smaller publishers, who cannot cut the same deals with advertisers that large companies like American Express or Time Warner Inc. can.
This has been one of the challenges facing some of the newer city magazines. Shortly after they made their debuts, in 1987 and 1988 respectively, Spy and 7 Days were dubbed ''hot books'' by advertising executives. But one rule of the publishing jungle is that when the economy worsens, the hot books turn cold and advertising executives turn to deal-making and a reliance on the primary magazines in a category.
''When I came to New York magazine in 1980, the principal universe was us, The New York Times Magazine, The New Yorker and Avenue, which was just starting,'' said Edward Kosner, the editor and publisher of New York. ''From three or four magazines, now you have seven or eight. The market got too cluttered. There isn't enough business to go around.''
While 7 Days was growing, its profit picture was clouded because most of its circulation is controlled -provided without charge to a defined and demographically desirable list. The magazine tested converting those free subscriptions to paid, and succeeded in getting a third of its 75,000 subscribers to pay.
Publishing experts close to the magazine say its strategy was similar to that of many trade publications, which give away a large portion of their circulation to a core audience that trade advertisers must reach. Manufacturers of kitchen supplies, for example, might willingly advertise in a magazine given away to restaurant owners.
The strategy is also becoming a favored one among publishers of niche-market newspapers. Local weekly ''shoppers,'' filled with reprinted press releases and supermarket ads, are being replaced by newspapers distributed without charge that contain more sophisticated journalism and a larger retail advertising mix. The publishers of these papers try to show the interest of their readers by asking them to send in cards requesting the subscriptions.
When he started 7 Days, Leonard N. Stern, its owner, considered it a newspaper. His intention was to sell advertising in packages with ads in The Village Voice, another newspaper he owns, utilizing The Voice's sales staff and achieving other economies of scale in production and distribution. But ad executives saw 7 Days as a magazine. That required a different approach to marketing and eliminated the economies that might have been achieved between it and The Voice.
It also made competing for dollars tougher, pitting 7 Days against New York magazine and national publications. And publishing executives say that in consumer magazines, when an advertiser is forced to choose between two publications, it will naturally pick the magazine whose readers pay.
Despite the challenges, several companies remain interested in 7 Days and the New York market. The New York Times Company, for example, has developed plans for a weekly magazine, tentatively entitled Blocks, that would be distributed to Manhattan residents with the newspaper every Thursday. Although company executives would not comment publicly, it is known that the concept is similar to 7 Days's and includes regular service features on real estate, restaurants and children.
Straight Arrow Publishers, the owner of Rolling Stone, has expressed interest in 7 Days. Mr. Ryder of American Express Publishing said he would consider acquiring it. And Time Warner, which owns regional magazines in the South and recently acquired Sunset, a Western regional magazine, is said to be a suitor.

HEADLINE: Stocks Hold Up in Tough Quarter

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
The first quarter was a period of surprises for many financial analysts. The stock market showed remarkable strength and resilience in the face of some troubling developments, and for the most part, negative forecasts for the quarter did not hold up.
''All the things that one could say would be very negative if they happened, did happen in the first quarter, and yet the market came out in pretty good shape,'' said Laszlo Birinyi, head of Birinyi Associates, a market research firm in New York.
Indeed, Mr. Birinyi, like most Wall Street analysts, was pleasantly surprised to see that corporate earnings in the quarter were not nearly as bad as had been predicted late last year. Another surprise was that the unexpected rise in interest rates did not have an overly adverse impact on the market. In addition, the sharp declines in the Japanese stock market have not had a significant effect on Wall Street, as many analysts had feared. 
 
Dow Off 1.7%
''Everyone always wondered what would happen to the United States market if the Japanese market cracked,'' said Byron Wein, the chief market strategist at Morgan Stanley & Company. ''And here the Japanese market has declined by 25 percent, and while our market did not have a terrific quarter, it did not go down totally in sympathy with theirs.''
End-of-the-quarter buying by institutions looking to round out their portfolios was not enough to offset a jittery bond market on Friday. For the quarter, the Dow Jones industrial average posted a loss of 45.99 points, or 1.7 percent.
Broader indexes fell slightly more. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks lost 3.8 percent, to 339.94, and the New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 4.2 percent, to 186.85.
The big winner on the Big Board for the quarter was the Storage Technology Corporation, a Louisville, Colo., maker of high-performance disks and tape subsystems for computers. Its stock rose 82 percent, or $9.625 a share, to end the quarter at $21.375.
Sales and revenues of the disk maker, which emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings in 1987 after a reorganization, have grown much faster than the industry average. Revenues advanced 11 percent in 1989 alone, and investors have come to recognize the success of some of its new products. Last month, the company raised $120 million in a public offering that was oversubscribed. Underwriters sold 6.5 million new Storage Technology shares, although only 5 million had originally been offered.
Leading the Big Board losers was the Amdura Corporation of Denver, a hardware distributor and the country's largest distributor of automotive after-market products.
Amdura lost 75 percent of its market value, or $4.50 a share, to end the quarter at $1.50. The troubled company registered large losses in the third quarter of last year, has yet to release its fourth-quarter earnings and is suffering from a severe shortage of cash. Amdura recently had to reschedule payment on $100 million of debt, and one executive said on Friday that it may soon seek Chapter 11 protection.
The executive, D. Scott Ross, who is head of investor information, described Amdura's problems as a ''liquidity crunch.''
On the American Stock Exchange, the top performer was Lazare Kaplan International Inc., based in New York, a diamond merchant whose income has risen with expanded international sales. Its shares soared 84.4 percent in the quarter, or $6.75 each, to close at $14.75.
Another big Amex winner was the New Line Cinema Corporation, the producer of the five ''Nightmare on Elm Street'' movies and current hits like ''House Party'' and ''Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles.'' New Line posted a gain of 81.3 percent, advancing to $10.875 a share.
A big loser on the American exchange was the Incstar Corporation, a maker of medical diagnostic equipment, whose shares fell 70.9 percent, to $3.125 each, after quadrupling the number of outstanding shares through acquisitions and other transactions. The company, based in Stillwater, Minn., reported sharply lower profits.
In the over-the-counter market, the Peerless Manufacturing Company, a Dallas-based maker of industrial air filters, registered the biggest gain. Peerless stock rose $15.25 a share, an increase of 119.6 percent, to end at $28. The company's quarterly earnings tripled.
The big over-the-counter loser was the Amcor Capital Corporation, an Irvine, Calif., agricultural company that manages more than 1,600 acres of California grape farms. Amcor stock fell 98.7 percent, to 25 cents a share, after the company reported liquidity problems.
 
Debunking Session
In addition to the surprising performance of the market during the quarter, some analysts said the period was instructive because several widely held assumptions were debunked.
Monte Gordon, a market strategist at the Dreyfus Corporation, said the last three months ended the belief the Japanese and American markets were so interconnected that a fall in one would cause a similar reaction in the other.
Many analysts had long argued that the Japanese Ministry of Finance would prevent significant declines in the Tokyo equity market by encouraging large-scale buying, but that did not happen.
''The Japanese market had always been seen as invincible because of the support of the Ministry of Finance,'' Mr. Gordon said, ''but now that has changed.''
The period was also eventful for the American securities houses. The bankruptcy of the Drexel Burnham Lambert Group was the most significant development, and it added to the disarray in the junk bond market.
But beyond Drexel's quick demise, Wall Street found that its troubles lingered as most brokerage firms continued to retrench because of flat or declining income and the sharp fall-off in the mergers and acquisitions business.
 
Impact of Real Estate
A number of big banks and publicly traded companies were battered in the quarter by the continuing reappraisal of the residential real estate market.
The big losers included stocks of some regional banking companies. The Bank of New England Corporation was the fourth-biggest loser on the Big Board for the quarter, beaten down by its huge portfolio of nonperforming real estate loans. The bank announced huge write-offs, dismissed its chairman and is trying to sell some of its businesses. Its stock lost 50.6 percent of its value, and ended the quarter at $4.625 a share.
Among the most encouraging signs through the quarter was the strength of the dollar and the overall economy.
''In the first quarter, we established clearly the role of the Fed in the monetary market,''Mr. Gordon said, pointing to the Federal Reserve's clear focus on fighting inflation. ''In addition, it became clear that the United States economny is stronger than people thought and, in the first quarter, it emerged as an oasis of quality.''
 
Strength in Blue Chips
Some analysts suggested that the strong performance of some of the large and previously out-of-favor blue-chip stocks, like I.B.M. and the General Motors Corporation, indicated that the economy was doing better than most experts had predicted.
The stock of the International Business Machines Corporation was up 15 percent over the quarter, to $106.125, and General Motors' shares climbed 13 percent, to $45.875.
''There are indications that the stock market is going to be O.K.,'' Mr. Birinyi added. ''I do not think you can have a really bad stock market and have good results coming out of an I.B.M. and General Motors.''

An article in Business Day yesterday about the stock market's recent performance omitted a reason for the decline in the Incstar Corporation's share price. The company paid a large one-time dividend during the first quarter.

PUB-DATE: April 2, 1990

SECTION: Section D; Page 1, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2229 words

HEADLINE: Strategist Quietly Gains Power Amid CBS Shifts

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

 BODY:
Only a few years after being brought into the exclusive circle entrusted with resuscitating CBS, Jay L. Kriegel, a lawyer and one-time political aide with no background and little interest in television, has quietly emerged as the key strategist of the network's effort to pull itself out of the broadcasting basement.
Running last in prime-time and evening news ratings, CBS has adopted what amounts to a simple strategy: improving its programming and streamlining its operations to concentrate on broadcasting. The execution is far more complicated, and many people inside and outside the company wonder how Mr. Kriegel has come to be the man who seems most responsible for putting the strategy into effect.
Laurence A. Tisch is the company's chief executive and largest stockholder, the man who essentially owns CBS. Also in the inner circle is Howard Stringer, president of the CBS Broadcast Group, who was tapped in 1988 to bring his producer's skills, acquired in 20 years in the news division, to the job of running the network. 
 
A Slide in Prime Time
Another key executive is Jeff Sagansky, the new president of the entertainment division. He was selected in December to devise programs to pull CBS out of its five-year prime-time slide.
But many CBS employees say not one of those men is the hands-on management figure at CBS now. Instead, they point to Mr. Kriegel, an unorthodox power player who was once chief of staff for Mayor John V. Lindsay of New York. In that job, Mr. Kriegel played an important and much debated role in the disclosures of police corruption in New York City in the early 1970's.
''To take nothing away from Howard Stringer, Jay Kriegel runs the company,'' one longtime employee said bluntly. ''Larry makes the command decisions, but very few things happen here that Jay doesn't decide.''
Mr. Kriegel, who is 49 years old, is senior vice president of CBS, a job he has held since January 1988. ''I came from out of nowhere,'' Mr. Kriegel said, adding that he thinks of himself as a partner with Mr. Tisch and Mr. Stringer in a three-sided CBS leadership group.
Mr. Kriegel brings to the partnership a talent for quiet administration of power. Although he says he has been visible enough recently that there should be no confusion about his role, he then jokes: ''I'm mysterious, and I want to stay that way. That's part of the craft - no fingerprints.''
He flatly denies that he is running CBS and emphatically dismisses suggestions that he threatens Mr. Stringer. ''There is Kremlinology at every large institution,'' he said.
Mr. Stringer said he had ''a good relationship'' with Mr. Kriegel. ''I need him,'' Mr. Stringer added. ''If he wasn't there, I'd have to invent him. To have someone that smart, who knows Larry so well, frees me up to do what I have to do - concentrate on our programming.''
Mr. Tisch did not respond to several requests for an interview.
Though not officially defined, Mr. Kriegel's duties are wide ranging. He is in direct charge of the company's efforts to gain legislative help in Washington, especially in winning a stake in profits from program syndication, now legally untouchable for the networks. But he also heads business development for CBS, an area that gives him broad influence over the company's future. He was deeply involved in the recruiting and hiring of Mr. Sagansky, who had been president of Tri-Star Pictures. Influence That Stems From Ties to Tisches Mr. Kriegel's power springs from his close 20-year relationship with Mr. Tisch. In the early 70's, after leaving city politics, Mr. Kriegel was director of special projects for the Loews Corporation, a company controlled by the Tisch family. With Mr. Tisch he made a bid to buy The Daily News in 1982. When Mr. Kriegel formed a consulting business, Mr. Tisch became a client after he took over CBS in 1986.
''Jay is really the only person who can tell Larry anything that he's likely to listen to,'' one longtime CBS employee said.
Some industry analysts find rather amazing the very fact that Mr. Kriegel, a virtual unknown even to them, has become a partner at the top decision-making level of CBS. Both he and Mr. Tisch have been criticized, inside and outside CBS, for being interlopers in the world of broadcasting. ''These guys simply aren't broadcasters,'' one longtime CBS employee said. ''That's their main problem.'' CBS is buried even deeper in last place as the current prime-time season comes to an end - it has fewer real hits on its schedule than even the three-night-a-week network, Fox Broadcasting - and its news division is slumping. The problems prompt some analysts to question whether the strategy Mr. Tisch is pursuing, and Mr. Kriegel appears to be implementing, can possibly work.
The critical view holds that Mr. Tisch has sold important parts of the company, including the records and publishing divisions, without a coherent plan for the future, which is cloudy for all television broadcasters because of intensified competition.
''You have to question what CBS is doing,'' said John Reidy, media analyst of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, ''when one of their prime competitors is looking at the marketplace and getting into every other kind of business, including direct-broadcast satellite.''
NBC, the competitor to which Mr. Reidy was referring, has been aggressively pursuing positions in cable, pay television and, most recently, the delivery of programming directly to homes by satellite. Mr. Reidy also pointed to ABC's interests in cable and its expanding role in foreign broadcasting as examples of ambitious approaches.
For its part, CBS is following what it calls a ''broadcasting first'' strategy, an approach that Mr. Kriegel concedes does not sound visionary. ''Larry tends to be a contrarian, not a faddist,'' he said. ''The business press expects everyone to have a grand strategy for the future. We don't have one. Our strategy is to be cautious, and we're not defensive about it.''
That means, he said, selling assets unrelated to the core activity of broadcasting, finding executives to create programming that will take the network out of last place, and making deals that enhance the network's main business. One such prospective deal could be an arrangement with the Cable News Network, part of the Turner Broadcasting System, to merge resources on foreign news coverage.
 
'Lousy Ratings'Vs. 'Good Value'
Ed Atorino, a media analyst for Salomon Brothers, said he had been advising clients to ''stay away'' from CBS stock. His simple reasons: ''lousy ratings, rising costs.''
But the critical view is not unanimous. Some analysts, including Lisa Donneson of County Natwest Bank, have upgraded their forecast for CBS Inc. in the last year. Ms. Donneson recommends it to investors as her best media prospect.
''It's a very good value,'' she said. ''Profits were up last year.'' Ms. Donneson also gives CBS good marks for its so-called sports strategy, under which it has spent about $3.5 billion in the last two years for rights to big events. CBS believes sports will bring in viewers while it is trying to fill many holes in its entertainment programming.
Despite his doubts about the company's overall strategy, Mr. Reidy also has a ''buy'' recommendation on the stock. He considers it likely that the networks will win concessions on the syndication rules. Such a change could transform the economics of the business, he said, and perhaps make CBS a desirable property for a buyer like the Walt Disney Company, if Mr. Tisch ever decided to sell.
Mr. Kriegel contends that he and Mr. Tisch actually have more faith in the future of broadcasting than the top executives of the other networks.
Records and publishing, and even most cable opportunities, make little sense, he said, if the goal is to strengthen the core broadcasting business. But under this strategy a deal with Turner Broadcasting would be most advantageous.
No specifics of a CBS News-CNN arrangement have been worked out. If such a deal simply adds to the reach of CBS News by bringing coverage from locations where CBS has no presence, the news division would be unlikely to object, one news executive said. Mr. Kriegel said that would be the only basis on which a deal would be made. ''If it doesn't strengthen CBS News, we won't do it,'' he said.
But some people in the news division fear a CNN alliance could bring further staff reductions, like those disclosed by one executive last week, as Mr. Tisch looks for ways to economize.
 
Treating Bruises,Recruiting Generals
When he first came to CBS, Mr. Kriegel earned some high marks within the news division for trying to smooth morale battered after large-scale layoffs in 1986. He is also considered largely responsible for the hiring of David W. Burke as CBS News president. He also aggressively supported Dan Rather, the ''CBS Evening News'' anchor, after a confrontational interview with George Bush during the 1988 Presidential campaign.
Indeed, there is speculation in the news division that Mr. Kriegel will be crucial to all future decisions about the department - and Mr. Rather. The division now faces greater scrutiny because ratings for the evening newscast have fallen.
The most significant move the company has made in the last year, Mr. Kriegel said, was the hiring of Mr. Sagansky. Three weeks ago, in announcing the network's development plans for the fall season, Mr. Sagansky said his goals were to be different, to attract star performers and producers and to broaden the base of CBS viewers, which has grown older and less desirable to advertisers. Mr. Kriegel said Mr. Sagansky would not have to worry about interference or second-guessing from him.
In truth, what Mr. Kriegel does at CBS is much more reminiscent of a political operative than of a broadcast executive: he talks, he proposes and he schmoozes with other executives, with managers of CBS's affiliated stations, with Hollywood producers.
Most people at CBS, even some of the network's best-known personalities, decline to talk about Mr. Kriegel at all, or discuss his role only if they are not identified. He is regarded not necessarily with antipathy - indeed, many people at CBS say they find him engaging and likable - but with uncertainty. The extent of his perceived power is clearly a cause of some concern.
As to criticism that he does not have a broadcasting background, Mr. Kriegel admits that he was not ''a child of television'' or even a ''traditional viewer of television'' and that he came to CBS knowing little about the business. ''I still don't know a lot about TV,'' he said.
But he has been busy learning, he said, the way he learned about politics. At countless breakfasts and lunches, he has culled insights and advice from the most prominent minds in the industry. Historical Footnote From a Political Past Mr. Kriegel, a native of the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, is a graduate of Amherst College and the Harvard Law School. He joined the Lindsay staff after the Mayor was first elected in 1965. He calls politics ''the highest calling'' and considers the late 1960's ''a remarkable historial period.''
But not all the memories are wonderful. In 1971, he became a key witness in the Knapp Commission hearings on police corruption. It was at a late-night meeting in his office in City Hall that a frustrated police officer, Frank Serpico, first reported to any city official the incidents of corruption he had witnessed.
Mr. Lindsay's political enemies accused Mr. Kriegel of lying to protect the Mayor by changing his testimony about whether he had informed the Mayor of Mr. Serpico's allegations of corruption. Mr. Lindsay came to his aide's defense, calling him ''a man of unbending integrity and decency.''
Mr. Kriegel survived the incident and remained on the staff. He now says the publicity growing out of his testimony surely set him back.
Politics remains not only a special love - a single, softball-sized ''Lindsay for Mayor'' campaign button resides in the center of the bulletin board that covers the back wall of his office - but a crucial talent.
Jack Valenti, the president of the Motion Picture Association of America and Mr. Kriegel's main adversary in the fight over television syndication, has observed Mr. Kriegel up close. ''Jay is a political pro,'' he said. ''Someone who can wake up in the morning and sniff the air and tell whether it's fair or foul.''
Many of those who have worked with, or against, Mr. Kriegel agree that he is extremely bright, a quick study and a capable executive. The big question is whether he is a capable broadcasting executive.
''I still don't think Jay knows the business,'' one industry executive said. ''If you're going into the entrails of television to make a deal, I just don't think Jay's the one to do that.''
Not surprisingly, Mr. Kriegel remains confident: ''I think being the underdog, taking contrarian positions, can be very attractive. People tend to magnify the difficulties and then are stunningly surprised when people pull an upset.''
No such upset is in sight at CBS, but Jay Kriegel, looking out from under the rim of his CBS baseball cap, sees only the rosiest shades ahead. ''It's a wonderful company. It's a wonderful period. It's a terrific challenge.''
The one sentence that no one would question is the last.

HEADLINE: Efforts to Speed U.S.-Japan Trade Talks Are Working

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 1

 BODY:
An accelerated effort to ease trade friction between the United States and Japan is yielding results, with recent agreements to open Japanese markets to American telecommunications equipment and supercomputers and the possibility that an accord on satellites will be reached this week.
Over the weekend, talks on opening the Japanese satellite market to American products were near a successful conclusion but were temporarily adjourned as the two negotiating teams sought further instructions on a technical point from their Governments. The talks are to resume Monday, and an announcement is possible on Tuesday.
A new test of how far Japan will go in meeting American trade demands will come this week as negotiators meet at the State Department for a fourth round of talks on ''structural impediments'' - the more pervasive obstacles to trade that stem from public policies and cultural habits. These include, for example, land-use policies that make doing business in Japan extremely costly, or levels of spending on such things as housing, schools and public works so low that domestic growth is dampened and dependence on exports for economic growth is increased. 
 
Concessions Promised
Japanese officials said their negotiators would bring concessions in their briefcases, but it remains to be seen how far these would go in narrowing a $49 billion imbalance in trade between the countries last year. Over the last decade, the gap was nearly $400 billion.
Both sides are racing to meet a mid-April deadline for an interim report that could influence feelings in Congress, where frustration over Japanese policies that block imports is rising. A final report is due in July.
''Japan has, to some degree, opened its market,'' the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said in a recent interview. ''But we need to have them open it much more, and when people ask how much more, I say I want them to respond to the competitive criteria of price and quality.''
Some of the Japanese seem to have heard Washington's message. ''The mounting discontent in the U.S. Congress against the huge Japan-U.S. trade imbalance can be said to be a hair trigger,'' the Japanese Foreign Minister, Taro Nakayama, said recently. ''Deterioration of sentiments towards Japan appears to be spreading nationwide in the U.S.''
In the background on Capitol Hill is legislation recently introduced by Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana and chairman of the Senate subcommittee on trade, that increases the chances of reprisal by subjecting the structural impediments to the Super 301 provision of 1988 trade law, which sets rigorous negotiating targets and deadlines.
The Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act of 1988 provides a structure for the United States to identify and retaliate against unfair trade practices. Last year the United States decided to pursue intensive negotiations with Japan over its trade practices in supercomputers, satellites and wood products.
Under the law, if the Japanese markets in these sectors are not open by June 16, the United States may retaliate by imposing up to 100 percent tariffs on selected imports from Japan.
Political stakes are also high in Tokyo, where factions of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party have protested some American demands, particularly one that seeks to eliminate a law that delays the opening of large stores for up to 10 years. The law is intended to protect Japan's many small retailers.
 
Pressure on 2 Sides
Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu is walking a tightrope between opponents within his party and President Bush, who stepped up the pressure on Japan at a meeting with Mr. Kaifu in Palm Springs, Calif., a month ago.
That meeting is coming to look more and more like a turning point in the long history of trade disagreements between the countries. Mr. Taifu, who had just won election, promised to make changes in structural reforms a priority of his new Cabinet, and seems to have at least partly delivered on that pledge.
To win support in Parliament, the Japanese leader has argued that the reforms are needed not just to ease frictions with Washington but to help Japanese consumers.
Polls suggest that he is getting public support. One survey by Nihon Keizai Shinbun, a leading business newspaper, found that more than 80 percent of 10,000 Japanese surveyed agree wholly or in part with American criticism that the Japanese economy should be more open.
 
Not as Difficult
This suggests that trade concessions may not be as difficult to achieve as many in the Government and the ruling party have been saying.
In addition to seeking a relaxation of restraints on big retailers, who are usually more willing to risk introducing new products, including goods directly imported from abroad, the United States wants, among other changes, a much tougher Japan Fair Trade Commission.
 
Moving Rapidly
While preparing for the new negotiating round on structural impediments, the two Governments have moved rapidly to bridge differences in other areas.
For example, the Governments, facing retaliation threats, have just concluded a preliminary market-opening telecommunications agreement that could help American companies sell more equipment and services to Japan. And on March 23, they announced a preliminary agreement on measures to open the Japanese market to the most powerful American-made computers.
The Japanese have shown some flexibility in discussions about market barriers in wood products. An assistant United States trade representative, Don Phillips, is to lead a negotiating team to Tokyo next week to make another attempt to resolve the issue.

HEADLINE: Report Outlines Options For U.S. Energy Policy

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
For the first time since the late 1970's, the Federal Government has begun trying to develop a comprehensive energy policy - a system of strategies, goals, inducements and penalties covering everything from how much oil should be produced domestically to the amount of light each watt of electricity should yield.
But the first report in this effort, a compendium of opinions compiled by the Energy Department and scheduled for release this morning in Washington, contains a welter of conflicting advice and hints at a rough road ahead.
The report comes at the midpoint of an 18-month process to develop legislative proposals. It contains written submissions from 1,000 individuals and organizations and summaries of the testimony of 379 witnesses at 16 hearings held in locations like Atlanta, Honolulu and Boise, Idaho. 
 
A Case for Efficiency
The compendium leaves for later the job of putting goals in order of importance and making choices between alternatives. But it clearly sets the stage for action on energy efficiency.
''People are not willing to pay more for energy, either environmentally or economically, unless they are first convinced that you have no choice,'' W. Henson Moore, Deputy Secretary of Energy, said in a telephone interview Friday. ''They say, 'What are you doing to increase the efficiency in the use of energy, so we do not have to do this?' You're never going to get a consensus until you establish your credibility in that area, that you're really serious about efficiency.''
Still, the report offers no conclusions about how efficiency should be achieved. Its first section, for example, notes that vehicle fuel economy, prodded by Federal standards, more than doubled between 1970 and 1987, but that at current fuel prices, a 10 mile-a-gallon improvement in gas mileage would save a typical driver only $94 a year. The options identified by those who testified range from making the standards more stringent to abandoning them altogether.
 
Critical Time for Oil
The effort to establish a comprehensive plan, which is supposed to conclude next January, comes as domestic oil production has fallen and imports have rapidly approached 50 percent of demand for the first time. Some experts have predicted that market conditions once again favor price control by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.
In addition to those trends, some parts of the country appear to be approaching a critical juncture in electricity production. As demand increases, these regions face decisions about whether to build more plants or reduce demand through efficiency, or accept a higher likelihood of occasional blackouts. Other pressing policy questions include how to reduce air pollution from energy use.
As part of the process of gathering the contents of the report, James D. Watkins, the Energy Secretary, and Mr. Moore held meetings that included the Secretaries or Under Secretaries of Agriculture, Transportation, Treasury and Interior, as well as the heads of the Environmental Protection Agency and the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, and the White House science adviser.
More hearings are contemplated, with competing interests offering their positions on what the policy should include.
The 230-page interim report charts the view of business executives, academicians, advocacy groups and other experts on the problems and possibilities for oil, gas, coal, nuclear fission and fusion, renewable energy sources, scientific research, technology transfer, waste handling, air and water pollution from energy extraction and use, and even energy education.
To this, the Energy Department added five white papers written by Government laboratories and others covering the greenhouse effect, the potential for renewable energy and the limits of energy efficiency.
Mr. Moore said that the effort was the most comprehensive he had seen the Federal Government undertake. ''The closest thing to it was in the Carter Administration,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Association of Retirees to Abandon Credit Union Venture

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The credit union of the American Association of Retired Persons, created nearly two years ago with high hopes of becoming a giant in the financial services industry, announced last week that it would go out of business.
When it was created in May 1988, bankers and credit union officials expected that the association's 29 million members would provide a huge base of relatively wealthy customers. While the credit union grew large by credit union standards, with 90,000 customers and assets of $150 million, it never reached the size expected. 
Operating with no employees except a president and a secretary, the credit union kept expenses to a minimum but never developed a lending ability. Deposits were invested in short-term securities, a practice that analysts said prevented it from offering rates as high as those available from many other banks and savings institutions that use deposits to make loans, which pay much higher interest rates than short-term securities.
 
Return of Deposits
The credit union's decision to close was initially reported in the American Banker, a trade newspaper.
The credit union said it would stop accepting deposits and accounts, and would transfer its credit card business to a commercial bank. Its growth apparently slowed in recent months.
Deposits and interest - which were insured by a federally backed insurance fund - will be returned to credit union members.
''The decision to phase out the credit union was based on a lack of participation by members of A.A.R.P.,'' said Bob DeFillippo, a spokesman for the association.
 
Encountered Resistance
Because the credit union conducted all its business with depositors by mail, ''it encountered resistance from people over 50 who wanted to do business with a live person,'' said Jack Blake, director of information at the Credit Union National Association, a trade organization based in Madison, Wis.
The most popular product of the credit union was its Visa card, held by about 75,000 customers. That card will become an affinity credit card managed by Banc One, in Columbus, Ohio. Horace B. Deets, executive director of A.A.R.P., said the change in status for the credit card meant it would be available to all A.A.R.P. members, not just those who join the credit union.
Mr. DeFillippo said the terms of the VISA card would be unchanged, with a $10 annual fee, a 15.6 percent interest rate on advances, and special eligibility standards to accept retired persons whose incomes are low, but whose net wealth is high enough to make them a good credit risk.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
A Roller Coaster Quarter for Foreign Markets

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The up-and-down performance of the world's stock markets in the first quarter of 1990 has left international portfolio managers with some tough investment decisions.
With the Japanese stock market plunging 23 percent through March, the question is whether the bottom is close enough to risk a return to the market.
Gavin Dobson, president of Murray Johnstone International, a Chicago-based international money manager, said yes. He said he thought that interest rates were nearing their top and that the Tokyo market did not have much further to fall. So he has started picking up some blue-chip stocks like Hitachi and Sony. 
''In the first quarter, the key strategy decision was to be out of Japan in January, February and March,'' said Mr. Dobson. ''And another key decision will be when to get back in.''
George Noble, the portfolio manager of Fidelity Overseas Fund, disagrees. He said he thought the weak yen and the bickering inside the Japanese Government over economic policy leave the stock market vulnerable. Even though $1 trillion - about one-quarter of the market's value -has been wiped out this year, Mr. Noble said he thought there was still room on the downside, perhaps as much as an additional 15 percent.
 
Uncertainty Over Eastern Europe
The other question is Eastern Europe. Is its economic development going to be worth as much to companies in Europe as the rush to record highs in the West German and the Austrian stock markets implies? ''The big bets have been very much anti-Japanese and pro-Europe,'' Mr. Noble said.
Mr. Dobson of Murray Johnstone counsels making investment with caution. ''Europe is wonderful,'' he said, ''but don't get carried away by the euphoria.''
Mr. Noble said he was more interested in choosing stocks by company or industry than by country.
After Japan's spectacular decline, the first quarter will be remembered for the way the rest of the world's stock markets resisted Tokyo's siren call to another crash. Surprisingly, the decline is still viewed as a reaction to problems generally peculiar to Japan.
According to the Financial Times-Actuaries World Indices, the Tokyo market fell 31.4 percent in dollar terms in the first quarter, far outdistancing its competitors in decline. The stocks the Financial Times index follows in each country may be different from those included in each market's major local index. Therefore, the increases or decreases in the Financial Times index may not match those of each country's local index. The adjustment into dollars also will change the movement of the index.
The Tokyo market's fall was 34 times the decline in France, 11.5 times the fall in Switzerland, 8 times the decline in the United States, 6 times the decline in Britain and nearly twice the plunge of its closest rivals, Spain and New Zealand.
In fact, Tokyo's decline helped some markets, as investors looked for other places to invest. Brokers in Japan and Europe said Japanese institutions and special investment funds had been pouring money into the stock markets in West Germany and Austria. They are grabbing up stocks in companies likely to prosper with the development of Eastern Europe, including automobiles, construction and utilities.
 
The Nikkei's Plunge
On Thursday and Friday, as Tokyo's Nikkei index fell 273.41 and 1,045.71, the West German market reached two all-time highs, leaving it up 11.3 percent for the year, based on the Financial Times index in dollars. Traders said the flow of money from Japan was helping to set those records.
Rising interest rates and the plunge in Japan meant the world's stock markets together did not do well in the first three months, falling almost 15 percent on average. But Europe, with the stampede for Eastern European profits and help from the small markets in Norway, Denmark and Ireland, did much better, falling only 1 percent. Without the drag of Britain, which has high interest rates, an economy heading for a recession and a stock market down 5.3 percent, Europe would have posted an increase, on average. The United States was down 4 percent.
The top performers of the quarter, except for West Germany, were small stock markets. Austria was No. 1, up 53 percent in dollar terms, after rising 90 percent all last year. The country's largest bank, Creditanstalt, the state-controlled Austrian Airlines and Oesterreicherische Brau A.G., a major brewer, led the way.
Mexico, still riding high on an improving economic outlook and its debt agreement with its commercial banks, rose 18.4 percent, after finishing No. 1 for 1989, just ahead of Austria, with a 101 percent leap.
Bolstered by economic reform, oil prices and a revival in shipping, Norway jumped 17.9 percent.
One surprise was Hong Kong. Since the Chinese Government crushed the pro-democracy movement last June, many market analysts have been worried about Hong Kong's market, particularly because control of the British colony reverts to China in 1997. But the market has climbed back quietly, shrugging off the decline in Japan. For the quarter, it ranked seventh of 24 markets, up 5.3 percent.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: PUBLISHING;
More Books Offering First Aid for Planet

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell

 BODY:
For authors and publishers of books about the environment, this is anything but a silent spring. Shelves are brimming with books about the dangers of pesticides, toxic waste and rain forest destruction, and how it supposedly takes 20 trees to keep one baby in disposable diapers for two years.
One reason for the surge in such books is the 20th anniversary of Earth Day, on April 22. The Waldenbooks and B. Dalton bookstore chains are running two-week Earth Day promotions, with environmental titles prominently displayed. The Doubleday Book Shops also plan a two-week promotion, and will donate part of the proceeds from the sales of those books to the Nature Conservancy, a group that buys parcels of undeveloped land for preservation. 
 
Steadily Growing Demand
But Earth Day is not the only reason for the proliferation. The book-buying public's appetite for works about the environment has been growing steadily over the years. And a new focus on environmental subjects at colleges and universities has helped to increase demand for books that can be used in courses.
Publishing executives are betting that the thaw in East-West relations will result in greater concern about environmental problems. ''Policy makers will finally realize that questions of long-term economic growth and international security are intertwined with the world's resources,'' said Charles C. Savitt, president of Island Press. Island, of Washington, publishes books on the environment exclusively, and Mr. Savitt said its sales doubled in each of the last four years.
Environment books are now so important that Waldenbooks plans to group them in one section in each of its 1,100 stores, and many independent bookstores are adding environment sections. The Elliott Bay Book Company, a large independent bookstore in Seattle, has had such a section for about a decade. ''Sales have grown every year,'' said Kristine Anderson, the co-manager of Elliott, ''and this year we are selling more copies of more titles than ever.''
For publishers, the scramble to acquire some of these books is starting to resemble the competition for a celebrity biography or blockbuster novel.
This summer, for example, three big publishers plan to go head-to-head with books on the murder of Francisco (Chico) Mendes, the leader of the Brazilian rubber tappers' union who was killed in 1988 for his efforts to protect the rain forest. Houghton Mifflin will publish ''The Burning Season'' by Andrew Revkin; Little, Brown plans ''The World Is Burning'' by Alex Shoumatoff, and Doubleday will bring out ''Rain Fire'' by Marcio Souza. The environmental implications of the Mendes murder are also discussed in a coming book from the Sierra Club, ''Lessons of the Rainforest,'' edited by Suzanne Head and Robert Heinzman.
Many of the current crop of books are written under the auspices of environmental organizations, and most are printed on recycled paper. But Harper & Row San Francisco, the publisher of ''2 Minutes a Day for a Greener Planet,'' said problems posed by bleaches and chemicals used in the recycling process made printing on recycled paper impractical. It is planting two trees in the rain forest for each tree used to produce the book.
The most successful of the new environment books has been ''50 Simple Things You Can Do To Save the Earth,'' a self-published handbook from the Earthworks Group/Publishers Group West. After a first printing of 26,000, there are 1.6 million copies in print, and the book has been a best seller for eight weeks.
Much of its success is the result of its modest $4.95 price, plus the fact that it is written in everyday language. ''We wanted it to be very accessible, not in any way didactic or political,'' said Julie Bennett, who helped to develop the book with John Javna, the overall editor.
Its recommendations to readers include turning down the water heater to 130 degrees, because every 10 degrees saves 6 percent of the energy required; saving water by installing low-flow faucet aerators and shower heads, and taking one's own shopping bags to the supermarket, since the authors say it takes a 15-year-old tree to make 700 grocery bags.
It will take publishers years to build a solid backlist of titles by environmentalists and naturalists similar to those of the Sierra Club or Houghton Mifflin. Some houses may not be willing to invest the time and money.
''We're clearly seeing people trying to jump on the Earth Day bandwagon, and some of the publishers who are in it today because it's a fad will be gone tomorrow,'' Mr. Savitt said. Mr. Javna said he was also worried that ''the commercial exploitation of the environmental issue will make people numb.''
But the issues are unlikely to fade, publishers say, because each year there will be another Earth Day as a reminder. And the next United Nations Conference on the Environment and Development is set for 1992 in Brazil, where the dwindling Amazon rain forest is a serious concern to nearly everyone interested in environmental issues.

HEADLINE: America's Catholic Bishops Move Closer to Pope on Women's Issues

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS

 BODY:
A committee of Roman Catholic bishops in the United States, revising a major statement on the Catholic Church and women's concerns, has retreated from the liberal tone and content of important sections in a draft issued two years ago.
In a new draft of what is intended to be a pastoral letter to American Catholics, the bishops reaffirm in detail the church's official prohibitions of artificial contraception and the ordination of women. While not entirely foreclosing further discussion on these issues, the new draft, released today, takes a position closer to that of Pope John Paul II, who has insisted these are questions on which debate is closed.
Although the 1988 draft also affirmed the church's positions on these points, it acknowledged the widespread dissatisfaction they had provoked among Catholic women, and called for further discussion of these issues among Catholics at all levels. 
 
Framework for Church Policy
While both drafts strongly assert the equality of women, the latest revisions are considered significant because conservatives and liberals alike view the issues of ordination and contraception as symbolic of the church's attitude toward change. Pastoral letters are not strictly binding on Catholics, but they do serve as the framework for church policy, providing authoritative guidelines for Catholic educational efforts, for preaching, for training of seminarians and for programs of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops.
In practice, there is great variation on how Catholics respond to these statements. On the issue of contraception, for example, the new draft recognizes that many Catholics have long departed from strict church teachings and use birth control.
The earlier draft, after presenting the Vatican case against ordaining women, acknowledged that some Catholics ''do not find all the arguments'' of the Vatican ''to be convincing,'' and added, ''Continuing reflection, dialogue and even controversy in regard to the ordination of women demonstrate the value of further study.''
At the same point in the new version, the bishops simply call for more ''reflection on the meaning of ministry'' without specifying women's ordination, but suggesting that this reflection will bolster the traditional teaching.
The new draft also mutes earlier criticism of the role of sexist attitudes in the church itself, and abandons a format that allowed roughly a third of the earlier version to consist of summaries of Catholic women's testimony to the committee. This format was adopted in reponse to objections raised about an all-male committee writing on women's issues.
The new document does repeat the strong condemnation, contained in the draft released by the bishops in April 1988, of the ''sin of sexism,'' expressed in violence against women, sexual exploitation and economic discrimination.
And, like the earlier draft, the revised version urges that women be swiftly admitted to all leadership positions in the church except those requiring ordination to the priesthood.
 
'Sin of Sexism' Denounced
Some conservatives reacted to the condemnation of the ''sin of sexism'' by complaining that the bishops were ''inventing a new sin.''
But Bishop Joseph L. Imesch of Joliet, Ill., chairman of the committee drafting the letter, said: ''We didn't invent anything. We just named what was already there.''
Bishop Imesch said that to avoid ''engaging in a great deal of self-flagellation'' the new version toned down the first draft's statements that sexist attitudes had colored many actions by the church throughout its history. But he added, ''I don't think we want to avoid the reality of sexism in the church.''
In at least two respects, the new document strengthens the first draft's call for greater church sensitivity to the concerns of women. It asks every diocese to establish a commission to assure the rights of women in the church and to develop a plan for addressing the issues raised in the statement.
It also acknowledges the criticism that much of the language used in traditional prayers and preaching appears to exclude women. Although the bishops tell the faithful to respect biblical traditions and be cautious in changing language used in referring to God, it endorses ''expressions that respect both the 'masculine' and 'feminine' attributes of God.''
 
Consultations With Women
The attempt to write a pastoral letter on women's concerns has been under way since 1983 and has involved extensive consultations with Catholic women throughout the United States.
Last year the Pope published a major statement on womanhood that heavily influenced the bishops' new text. But Bishop Mathew H. Clark of Rochester, a member of the drafting committee, said the committee had not received any directives from the Vatican about revising the first draft.
Other American bishops had pressed the committee, he said, to make it clear that the bishops stand behind the church's rejection of contraception and women's ordination in the new version. Bishop Clark, frequently identified as a liberal in the hierarchy, said he did not consider the new draft ''substantially different.''
By dropping the format of citing ''voices of affirmation'' and ''voices of alienation'' among the many women who gave testimony to the bishops, Bishop Imesch said that the document avoided repetition, although he added that it ''loses some vitality by becoming more didactic and less dialogical.''
The extensive use of women's testimony in the first draft allowed the committee to take note of diverging views without having to take an explicit stand on them.
 
Liberal and Conservative Fears
Both conservative and liberal churchwomen have periodically urged the bishops to abandon the project. Conservatives fear that the bishops will be swayed by feminist arguments, and liberals fear that the Pope's reassertion of traditional views would predetermine the outcome.
Sister Maria Riley, who deals with women's issues at the Center of Concern, a left-of-center educational and advocacy group in Washington, echoed the liberals' view yesterday.
While praising the bishops for listening to reactions to their earlier work, she said, ''But it is obvious that they really aren't able to respond to the implications of what they heard, and even what they wrote, because of the present patriarchal structure of the church.''
Bishop Clark said the drafting committee had received more than 100 substantial reports of diocesan discussions of the 1988 draft. The committee, which was unable to rewrite the statement in time for last November's meeting of the bishops' conference, hopes that a final vote on the letter can be taken at the meeting next November.

HEADLINE: German Union Instills Vision Of a Great Continent Reborn

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, March 31

 BODY:
When European business leaders describe their vision of Europe, they usually talk of building a bigger, more united, more dynamic continent. German unification fits neatly into that vision.
Chief executives at several of Europe's largest corporations said, in a series of interviews, that the unification of West Germany and East Germany would be the crucial first step toward a merging of Western and Eastern Europe that could result in a family of nations larger and more dynamic than today's Western Europe.
''The European challenge is to restore the Europe of 1914, when Europe was the biggest economic power in the world and had the best-educated population, one that is twice the population of the United States and four times the population of Japan,'' said Hans-Jorg Rudloff, chairman of Credit Suisse-First Boston, a leading investment bank in London.
But German unification may hurt some countries and companies, the European executives warn. As investment money flows into East Germany, it might be harder for struggling African and Latin American nations to attract funds for development. 
Similarly, the stream of West German capital that has poured into factories in southern Europe may largely be rechanneled toward the East, halting the investment benefits enjoyed recently by Spain and Portugal, for example.
Still, the executives view German unification as a welcome prospect in general. After complaining for years about slow European growth, a malady they called Eurosclerosis, executives say a greater Europe will provide vast opportunities for growth. It will also give European companies a stronger foundation for competing against American and Japanese corporate giants.
West Germany is expected to spend hundreds of billions of dollars to rebuild East Germany and bring its living standards up to the much-envied levels of the Federal Republic. That will require stepped-up production by West Germany's potent industrial machine; ''the locomotive of Europe'' will have to pull all of the continent to faster growth.
Some Western European business leaders worry that unification will make West German companies even more formidable competitors. Titans like Siemens, Daimler-Benz and Deutsche Bank will expand their reach, and British, French and Italian executives say their companies will have to work hard to stay in fighting trim.
These business executives assert that German unification should in no way slow the European Community's plans to drop all internal trade barriers by late 1992, creating a single central bank and currency for the 12 nations.
Instead, they say, European unification should be accelerated so that a united Germany is created under a large, watertight European roof.
Rather than gloating at the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe, some of the eight modern knights of capitalism interviewed say it is a time of unusual responsibility for the West.
''We have to pay the bill,'' said Carlo de Benedetti, chairman of Olivetti, the Italian company that makes office automation equipment and personal computers. ''The bill has to be paid by the ones who have the money and not the ones who don't have the money.'' A Bigger Market Open to Everyone LARS RAMQVIST Recently chosen chief executive of Ericsson, the Swedish telecommunications company.
German unification is bound to be the first step toward building a great, united Europe, East and West. This united Europe will be 700 million people, according to the old definition of Europe from the Atlantic to the Urals.
In the beginning, it will be tough to do business in East Germany, but long-term it will be a bigger market that will open up to everyone. What's important in all this is that it is the first step in a bigger Europe, and that will be positive for Swedish industry. Running 'Like Mad' To Stay Competitive SIR DENYS HENDERSON Chairman of Imperial Chemical Industries, Britain's largest chemical company.
There is a pent-up demand to improve standards of living, not just in East Germany but in the East bloc as a whole. There is a somewhat naive view that it is going to create a massive new market overnight in the East bloc. My view is that it's great, but you are not going to switch overnight from a totalitarian economy to a market economy.
In the short term, it might make it slightly easier to compete against German industry. The Germans are committed to achieving unification and there will be a cost to that absorption. If their capital priorities are directed toward the East bloc, it might mean some distractions about what they hope for in other parts of the world: Asia and the United States.
In the long term, it will make German competition tougher because the German market will be an even bigger market. In a decade when demography is going to be a problem in terms of getting new skilled workers into the economy, it will give the Germans access to a very skilled work force. After the absorption period has gone through, that will put German industry in a very strong position. We will have to run like mad to improve our productivity, our technological base and international presence to compete satisfactorily.
The negative part is that it is just possible that West Germany's absorption of East Germany's ostmark may produce higher inflation in West Germany, which will undoubtedly produce higher interest rates. This will be matched in other parts of the world, and that means the United States and Japan. That could produce a slowdown in growth. Solving the Problems Left by Communism CARLO DE BENEDETTI Chairman of Olivetti, the Italian office machine and computer company.
The real unification in terms of willingness and spirit is a fait accompli. The consequence of this is that we are at a turning point for Europe.
I think we should negotiate politically with Germany that it is in the best interests of all of the community's partners to speed up the process of European integration before a negative climate appears in other European countries that Germany is too powerful, too arrogant.
We couldn't be more happy seeing the total and irreversible collapse of Communism, ideologically and practically. Communism has failed because it hasn't been able to solve the real problems of those countries in terms of democracy, economic freedom, social structure, consumer satisfaction.
The real news is that we have to be the ones who will be in charge of solving those problems. The challenge for the Western world, for the capitalistic world and specifically for Western Europe, will be to help solve those problems. Renewing a Nation In Need of Repair PERCY BARNEVIK Chairman of Asea Brown Boveri, a Swiss-Swedish company that is Europe's largest electrical engineering group.
During a short-term transition period, German unification could create some problems, such as higher inflation and, consequently, higher interest rates.
Medium-term, the reconstruction of East Germany represents enormous business opportunities. We estimate that 600 billion Deutsche marks will be needed for housing, 40 billion for new power plants, 8 billion for new telephone lines and 100 billion to 150 billion marks to renew the transportation system. This means larger markets for both West Germany and the European Community.
Industry and governments have to act quickly to support East Germany to build an adequate industrial infrastructure. Only this will keep the East Germans there. A mass migration could thus be avoided.
Environmental issues are a top priority. East Germany urgently needs new equipment to reduce toxic emissions. Its power plants are 35 percent less efficient than those in the West.
At first, West German companies will be more absorbed with East Germany and thus have to slightly reduce capacity available for other markets. At the same time, suppliers from other Eastern European nations will have a harder time supplying East Germany as their trade system changes to hard currency dealings. Product quality will play an increased role.
In the second phase, the position of West German industry will be improved because of the larger market and better production-sharing possibilities with East Germany. This will create tougher competition for non-German companies.
There is a real risk that West German interests are, for the moment, somewhat diverted toward East Germany. As a result, some people in Brussels are afraid of a slowdown in the integration process. This need not be the case if the other European Community members insist strongly enough. West Germany has the capacity to go both ways at the same time. Balancing Emotions Against the Realities MICHEL FRANCOIS-PONCET Chairman of Compagnie Financiere de Paribas, a French banking group.
German unification is a complex and a not-so-complex situation. East Germany is about 10 percent of West Germany in terms of gross national product, but it's at least 25 percent in terms of population. It is one-fifth in terms of productivity ratios. Therefore, you have a set of problems balancing the political emotions and the consequences on East Germany of issues like unemployment.
German unity will mean a different economic balance in Europe. It will become a country of 80 million people, and the game will not be exactly the same.
For some French companies, there is already a certain feeling of inferiority. It varies from one company to the next. Unification will create a larger market for industrial companies in Germany; it gives them a more powerful base. French companies will have to maintain their cool and not hesitate to take chances. More Consumption And a New Impetus JEAN-LOUIS BEFFA Chairman of Saint-Gobain, the Paris-based glass and packaging company.
German unification is a very positive development. It expands the market. It's going to be a new impetus for economic demand.
When the Common Market was formed, everyone worried about what would happen to French industry as opposed to German industry, but basically it was a positive factor. It will be the same now. It will be good for the good companies, whether German of French. The dynamic companies in France are already reacting and signing agreements.
If all goes quickly and in the right direction, the so-called German question will be solved and we will be in a position to integrate Europe and more quickly. I am in favor of not slowing down European integration and support pushing for German reunification within the European Community.
When a country like East Germany starts growing, its people will improve their housing, buy cars, buy packaging, and all that is going to help us. Showing Willingness To Transfer Wealth HANS-JORG RUDLOFF Chairman of Credit Suisse-First Boston, a London-based investment bank.
If what the Germans have is economic and monetary union, then it will be nothing else than a huge investment program. A lot of money will have to be invested in industrial stock, streets and railways.
Germany being a first-class borrower, if it starts borrowing heavily, whether for companies or government, it will clearly divert investment money from other areas. What we will see is a competition for capital all around the world. All this will happen when monetary policy all over the world is very tight and when there is a huge debt burden out of the 1980's to pay off or refinance. It will create a big competition for savings.
I'm not talking about East Germany alone, but the entire East, and that includes the Soviet Union. If you divert huge streams of capital to these areas, wherever these funds are diverted from will have to tighten their belts.
Will unification be inflationary? My answer is no. The Germans have a superb tradition of handling inflation. They are always willing to make the sacrifice to avoid inflation.
Will it be impetus for growth? Yes. But will that additional growth be negated by less growth in other areas of the world? That could very well be.
No one should have the illusion that it is good enough to applaud the liberation of 120 million people from 40 years of dictatorship, praising our own system and how we proved beyond any doubt that the capitalistic liberal system is superior in economic terms to the 80-year-old Marxist system. To applaud that is not good enough. Now we have to help these people who aspire to the same living standards that we have. We have to show that we're willing to transfer some of that wealth. New 'Marshall Plans' To Prime the Pumps CORNELIS VAN DER KLUGT Chairman of Philips N.V., the international electronics group based in the Netherlands.
German unification is inevitable. It will strengthen Germany, and therefore it will also strengthen the European Community. Everyone is hell-bent to make sure that it doesn't slow down European integration. We should never slow down European integration - it's already 30 years late. But it might slow down if everyone places their priorities elsewhere.
There is no longer an Eastern bloc. Some countries will move fast, like Hungary. Others will move almost as fast, like Czechoslovakia, and then there is the next layer: Poland, the Soviet Union, Romania, and Bulgaria, countries that will come later. In countries where there is so little and such low purchasing power, the interest for business will be the initial infrastructural projects, which will be done with money from our side.
These improvements will bring these countries to a higher productivity, which will give them possibilities to export to Western Europe and to increase their material well-being. This is a long-term process, with the initial business based on a Marshall Plan-type of approach.

HEADLINE: Starving Children of Malawi Kill Leader's Boast of Plenty

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LILONGWE, Malawi

 BODY:
For the 26 years of his authoritarian rule in Malawi, President H. Kamuzu Banda has insisted that human rights, white power in a black state and coziness with South Africa are minor matters compared with the full stomachs of his people. Now, as it turns out, many young and infant Malawians do not have full stomachs either.
''Only Ethiopia, a land of ecological depletion and frequent drought, has levels of child malnutrition comparable to those in Malawi,'' says a report by the United Nations Children's Fund, which the Malawian Government, usually reluctant to highlight such shortcomings, helped write.
This sliver of land, which looks lush and green, has long boasted of figures attesting to food self-sufficiency on a national level, a rare feat in Africa. But these statistical claims mean little, said international aid workers, who reported not only extraordinary levels of mortality from child malnutrition but also high levels of stunted growth among those who survive. Since the mid-1980's, despite claims of self-sufficiency in food, Malawi, like most of black Africa, has had to import food, the workers said. 
 
Conformity Is Demanded
Like everyone else in this country who talked with a reporter, they insisted on anonymity. In a society where surveillance is constant - a benign joke about the President can land you in jail - political conformity is also mandatory.
To enter the outdoor market in Zomba, the town where Parliament sits and the university is situated, shoppers on a recent day had to possess or buy at the gate a membership card in the sole legal party, the Malawi Congress Party.
''The politics is so byzantine that even we Malawians don't understand it,'' an educated Malawian said.
The tangible results of Dr. Banda's policies are particularly visible in this capital, which was built and paid for by the South African Government of John Vorster early in the 1970's. In its sleek buildings designed by the South Africans, Government bureaus are headed largely by expatriate professionals. For example, the head of the central bank is a German, and the man who runs the public works department is a Scot.
 
Aid From South Africa
The South Africans have their only embassy in black Africa here and they give military aid and, Western diplomats said, training to the Young Pioneers, a paramilitary governmental youth group.
Though Dr. Banda has long been appreciated in the West as a pro-Western anti-Communist, his Government's record on human rights was criticized by the State Department in its annual human rights report last year.
The United States, which gives $2 million in military assistance and $20 million in economic aid, generous amounts for the African aid program, made one of its harshest assessments of human rights on the continent here. The State Department report said the observance of human rights in Malawi had ''deteriorated, as a leading political dissident was murdered, and arbitrary detention continued to be used to suppress any sign of dissent.''
The report said there were ''life-threatening conditions in prisons; lack of fair trials; interference with privacy; severe restrictions of freedom of speech and press, assembly and government; and serious discrimination against northerners.''
 
Many Reported Tortured
Amnesty International said last year that many of the political prisoners were tortured. It said that a number of political prisoners arrested in the 1960's were still believed to be held and that those arrested in the 1980's included the country's only neurosurgeon, Dr. George Mtafu, and the country's best known poet, Jack Mapanje. In jail since 1986, Brown Mpinganjira, deputy chief of information, was locked up for providing information to foreign journalists.
Last year, West Germany and the United States made a special plea to Dr. Banda for two of the political prisoners, Mr. Mapanje and Dr. Mtafu. Diplomats from both countries said the approaches were angrily rejected.
International aid workers stationed here said the high infant mortality rate - one in three children under 5 dies -and the 55 percent rate of stunting among those who survive have long been masked by Malawi's reputation among Western donors for being self-sufficient in food. The reputation was no longer justified by 1987 and perhaps before, the workers said, The false sense of well-being was further accentuated within Malawi, they said, by an annual ritual that involves the octagenarian Dr. Banda making a highly publicized crop inspection at the beginning of every year. Of course, the corn that he was always pictured alongside was as ripe and tall as that in any lavish agricultural catalogue. Left unsaid, the aid workers said, was the fact that Dr. Banda, a physician, was steered to plots that had been specially endowed with high-yielding seeds and expensive fertilizer.
In a rare act of defiance last year, several hundred farm workers who had toiled on corn intended for presidential viewing but were not its beneficiaries cut down the high-bred corn the night before it was due for scrutiny. Dr. Banda was diverted elsewhere, the aid workers said.
