HEADLINE: Court to Decide Damage Award Issue

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2

 BODY:
The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a jury's award of punitive damages can be so excessive or disproportionate as to violate the Constitution's guarantee of due process of law.
The Justices accepted an appeal by a California life insurance company of a $1.04 million judgment by a jury in Alabama. The plaintiff was a woman who learned only after she was hospitalized with a kidney infection that the policy on which she had been paying premiums had been canceled. She was left without coverage for $3,800 in medical bills, representing more than half her annual take-home pay of $6,700. 
Whether the Constitution places any limits on punitive damages is a question of major concern to the insurance industry and to manufacturers that face frequent product liability suits. While people can also be found liable for punitive damages, most such lawsuits are against corporate ''deep pockets'' that can afford to pay the growing number of multimillion-dollar judgments.
Punitive damages, in contrast to compensatory damages, are meant to punish or to set an example that will deter similar behavior in the future. Each state has its own laws and procedures for the awarding of punitive damages. In response to lobbying by the insurance industry and other business groups, the trend in state legislatures in recent years has been to place ceilings on the size of punitive damage awards in certain cases.
 
Browning-Ferris Case Cited
In a number of rulings beginning in 1986, the Supreme Court has skirted the question of whether the constitutional concept of due process requires that punitive damages bear some relation to the actual damages, or at least that the jury act according to some guidelines.
Last June, for example, the Court decided an appeal brought by Browning-Ferris Industries Inc., a big commercial waste-collection company, which was ordered in an antitrust case to pay $6 million in punitive damages to a competitor that had suffered $51,000 in economic damage. The Court rejected the argument by Browning-Ferris that the punitive damages violated the Eighth Amendment, which prohibits ''excessive fines'' and ''cruel and unusual punishments.''
The majority ruled that for procedural reasons, the question of whether punitive damages are limited by the Constitution's due process guarantee was not properly presented in the Browning-Ferris case.
But in concurring opinions, four Justices indicated that they would like to decide the question in an appropriate case. The four, Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia, William J. Brennan Jr. and Thurgood Marshall, indicated considerable sympathy with the argument that unlimited punitive damages are unconstitutional.
 
Alabama High Court Ruling
The case the Court accepted today, Pacific Mutual Life Insurance Company v. Haslip, No. 89-1279, is an appeal from a ruling by the Alabama Supreme Court, which rejected the insurance company's due process arguments.
The company, based in California, does not sell group medical insurance. But an agent in its Birmingham office, Lemmie L. Ruffin Jr., also worked as an agent for an unrelated health insurance company. In 1981 he solicited the business of Roosevelt City, a small town near Birmingham, Ala., to issue both life and health insurance policies for its employees.
He collected the premiums, some of which the employees paid in cash. But the employees did not know that he did not forward the premiums to the insurance companies. He kept the money himself and did not tell the town that its policies were in arrears, and later that the policies had been canceled.
The situation came to light in 1982 when one of the employees, Cleopatra Haslip, was hospitalized and learned that she had no medical insurance. She was left with bills she could not pay. According to the lawsuit she and three other employees filed against Pacific Mutual, charging fraud, breach of contract and bad faith, her credit rating was ruined and she suffered mental anguish.
The jury awarded Ms. Haslip $1.04 million, without specifying which portion of the award was intended as punitive damages and which was designed to compensate for Ms. Haslip's mental anguish.
 
Insurer's Arguments
In its appeal to the Supreme Court, Pacific Mutual is arguing that a jury's power to award unlimited punitive damages permits jurors ''to punish selectively'' and to ''indulge bias, prejudice and any wealth-redistribution inclinations they may have.''
The company also makes a narrower argument, that an employer should not be liable for punitive damages in connection with the wrongdoing of an employee. If Pacific Mutual prevails on this question, the Court may not find it necessary to address the broader punitive damages question. The case will be argued next fall. Today the Court also refused in four separate appeals to rule on whether people injured in car accidents can sue the automobile manufacturer for not installing an air bag. Such suits have been brought under state laws that permit negligence suits for ''design defects.''
But several state and Federal appellate courts have ruled that these lawsuits are pre-empted by a Federal transportation regulation that gives automobile manufacturers the choice of installing air bags or other automatic restraints.

HEADLINE: Iraq's Murderous Threats

 BODY:
Brazen blackmail - that's how Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein, reacts to being caught red-handed trying again to build nuclear weapons. Now he threatens to destroy half of Israel with chemical-armed missiles if Israel attacks his weapons factories. The threat from a leader who already has mercilessly used chemical arms cannot go unanswered by civilized powers. 
It's not too late for the U.S. and other suppliers to deny Iraq further military capabilities and in the process to send a tough message to any other leader willing to practice mass murder. As a cooperative U.S.-British ''sting'' arrest showed last week, suppliers can keep critical parts and material out of proliferators' hands. And civilized powers can also impose broad economic sanctions on states that violate basic international norms.
The six people arrested in Britain are suspected of smuggling U.S.-made krytrons into Iraq. These devices can be used innocently in office copiers - or to separate stages of a missile. They are particularly suited to triggering nuclear weapons.
The seizure aroused concerns that Iraq had renewed efforts to develop nuclear weapons. Those concerns had been laid to rest in 1981 when Israeli bombers destroyed a French-supplied nuclear research reactor outside Baghdad that was suspected of making plutonium.
Iraq has reason to be insecure. It fears the hostility of Iran, Israel and Syria. Intelligence officials believe it has long sought to develop its nuclear capability as a counter to nuclear-armed Israel, and out of fear that Iran also would go nuclear. What intensifies concern now is that Iraq has built new fixed launchers for ballistic missiles on an airfield within range of Tel Aviv and Damascus.
Iraq is years away from producing its own nuclear warheads. But it used missiles to attack Iranian cities after starting an eight-year war. It also has chemical weapons, which it used on Kurds in Iraq and on Iranian troops and civilians.
Then, anxious to check Iran, Western states responded with diplomatic protests but continued to supply Iraq with advanced weapons. That weak reaction and subsequent feeble attempts at restraint cannot have persuaded Mr. Hussein that he had much to fear from the outside world.
Supplier nations, including the Soviet Union, need to demonstrate otherwise. They might begin by tightening cooperation to prevent the transfer of missile technology. The 40-nation Conference on Disarmament needs to complete a treaty banning chemical weapons. And suppliers can impose economic sanctions against Iraq and other outlaw states that employ chemical or nuclear arms.
The U.S. and others that have long subordinated proliferation to other security concerns need to take dead aim against Iraq. If Iraq is worried about Israel or its other neighbors, there's a wiser course than to make murderous weapons: Make peace.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Auto Pollution Has Decreased for a Decade;
Raise Tax on Gas

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I agree, the damage we are doing to the earth's environment and our health by increasing dependence on private automobiles is deplorable (''Big Wheels: How Dreams of Clean Air Get Stuck in Traffic,'' Week in Review, March 11). It is all the more tragic as it could be greatly reduced. 
Also, with more than 20 percent of our trade deficit going to feed our fuel-wasting habit, legislative inaction is compromising national strategic interests. Our inability to decrease this wastefulness will deplete the wealth that has made the United States a superpower and allowed our democratic institutions to stand as an example for the world.
The slower we are to act, the further our landscape will adapt to transportation economics: suburban sprawl increases, cities decay, forests become shopping malls, and the cost of mass transportation climbs. With each year, the risk increases that changes will not be democratically chosen but an economic force, possibly a disaster, affecting all Americans.
We are a society where it is expensive to own a car and cheap to drive one. Any shift in this equation would thus be a change for the better for our society.
However, ''no new taxes'' and the failure of most of our citizens to attribute any of the world's problems to their own consumption-oriented life style make the outlook grim.
Instead of shifting the responsibility to the states, Washington should impose a substantial uniform Federal excise tax on gasoline, to be phased in over a period of years. Disposing of the additional cash should prove no problem.
 
WHARTON SINKLER
 Philadelphia, March 11, 1990

HEADLINE: Independents Offer an Education Aid Bargain

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In ''Fiscal Fire in New York'' (editorial, March 14), you say education spending in New York State is ''up 84 percent in seven years.'' But not across the board. Higher education -both public and independent - has experienced much smaller increases. Independent institutions actually received $19 million less from the state this year than in 1986. Indeed, the state's independent colleges and universities have lost 20 percent, or $87 million, to inflation since 1986 in direct institutional aid.
New York's disinvestment in independent institutions of higher education poses a serious threat to one of the state's important assets. Our institutions enroll 290,000 students a year, produce 64 percent of all baccalaureate and higher degrees in the state and grant 60 percent of all such degrees earned by minorities.
While the state and city university systems serve vital missions and need adequate funds, independent colleges and universities cost New York only 12.7 percent as much to educate a student. Clearly, a very good investment for the state.
All of higher education has suffered in the state budget process in recent years. In 1982 higher education represented 13.4 percent of the state budget; today it accounts for only 11.6 percent. And the independent institutions have suffered a double decline since their share of higher education expenditures have declined 22 percent since 1986.
In tough financial times it is tempting to sacrifice investments that pay off in the future. Higher education is such an investment. What is at stake is New York's ability to maintain the highly skilled work force to compete in a global economy and to achieve a society that is open to those who have been excluded from full participation.
 
JONATHAN F. FANTON
President
New School for Social Research
 New York, March 15, 1990

HEADLINE: Research in 'Virgin' Amazon Uncovers Complex Farming

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
OVER thousands of years, scientists have discovered, ancient inhabitants of the Amazon and their present-day descendants have evolved a sophisticated blend of agricultural and forestry techniques to shape and reshape the region's vast forests, savannas and river valleys to their needs.
In an earlier form, the scientists say, the system enabled the ancient Amazonians to build a civilization whose size, power and achievements far outshone the conventional picture of the ancients as small, primitive tribes living on the edge of existence. And they say in its present form, the system has enabled the descendants to prosper in a way that eludes many settlers who follow more modern practices - without disrupting the ecology of the tropical forests.
Even while the scientists strive to learn more about this remarkable system of resource management, they and others are starting to search for ways in which it might be applied to help head off the destruction of the Amazonian forests. And at a time when expanding populations and growing poverty are overwhelming third world economies, they believe, the system could enable millions of poor peasants to make a good, secure living based on self-renewing resources. 
Beyond that, the scientists say, the techniques can be used to tap the tropical forests - while leaving them basically intact - for a broad range of export products that under ideal circumstances could bring billions of dollars into the debt-ridden economies of the Amazonian countries. The potential export products include foods, medicines, natural fertilizers, pesticides, body-care products and fragrances. A study last year by American experts on the Amazonian forests calculated that these products would be more profitable than the widespread logging and cattle ranching that today are largely blamed for progressive destruction of the forest.
There is ''a whole range of possibilities that could be carried out based on what ancient people did for thousands of years,'' said Anna C. Roosevelt, an anthropologist and archeologist at the American Museum of Natural History who has investigated the ways of the Amazonian ancients in depth. Dr. Roosevelt, a great-grandaughter of Theodore Roosevelt and winner of a MacArthur Foundation award, was the co-organizer of a symposium on the past, present and future of the Amazon at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science in late February in New Orleans.
The practices of present-day Amazonian natives offer ''thousands of ways of making the living forest more valuable than the destroyed forest,'' said Darrell A. Posey, an American anthropologist who works for the Goeldi Museum in Belem, Brazil, and who has lived with the natives in the forest and observed their agricultural and forestry techniques closely.
In one such technique, for instance, Amazonian Indians have learned to manage agricultural plots so that over a period of decades years they evolve in pre-planned phases from cleared farmland back into thick forest. The plots move through stages in which conventional crops predominate at first, but then wild species of useful plants and trees are encouraged to encroach gradually. These are tapped for a variety of uses, including medicine, insecticides and pesticides. Eventually the forest reclaims a given plot. Meanwhile, other plots are in varying phases. The result is that the forest continually renews itself even while sustaining its exploiters.
Some agencies concerned with development in the Third World have begun exploring the feasibility of applying the techniques of traditional cultures more widely. ''I think it's time we started looking for some new ways of doing business,'' said Thurman Grove, a Cornell University ecologist who has been detached for two years to help the United States Agency for International Development find ways to adapt the traditional techniques to modern use. ''Mother Nature has a lot of tricks,'' he said, and ''old cultures have already run a lot of the experiments.''
The challenge, Dr. Grove said, is to learn how to augment the natural systems so that they can be made productive enough to sustain a large population without, as was true in ancient times, relying so much on labor-intensive methods. ''That's a field where I think we are in a very nascent state,'' he said.
Scientists who have studied the present-day application of these techniques and skills are finding that they provide a more reliable and sustainable living over the long term than can be achieved by neighbors who rely on modern cash-cropping. Ancient SocietyA Civilization Of Chiefdoms The system evolved through millennia of practical experimentation in response to changing conditions. In archeological investigations that over the last 10 to 15 years have challenged a number of conventional beliefs about both the Amazonian forest and its inhabitants, Dr. Roosevelt and others have traced the origins of the natives' manipulation of the Amazonian environment back thousands of years.
The conventional beliefs have held that the ancient native populations were small, scattered, primitive and sickly, and that the forest itself was mostly virgin and undisturbed and was poorly suited to sustainable agriculture. But at their peak in the centuries around the birth of Christ, according to archeological evidence that is still unfolding, the ancient Amazonians forged a civilization of agricultural chiefdoms that lasted 2,000 years - a vast, powerful rural economy that some scientists believe sustained millions of people.
Many of them lived in settlements of up to 4,000 people, built atop huge earthen mounds to keep them away from floods. The mounds were linked by causeways, and other causeways led to fields where corn, the staple crop, was grown. The natives of this era carried out their agriculture in the forest, in reclaimed swamps and on alluvial plains along the rivers. It sustained them well enough, said Dr. Roosevelt, to produce a populace that, on the basis of the archeological study of skeletons, was on the average tall and healthy.
There have been people in the Amazon forest about as long as the forest itself has existed, or since the end of the Pleistocene 10,000 years ago, and they have exploited it intensively, said Dr. Roosevelt. But their manner of exploitation has allowed the forests to regenerate so completely, she said, that they have fooled some into thinking they are virgin. This is so even though at their peak, the ancient Amazonians greatly outnumbered their modern descendants.
''What people did in ancient times may be ecologically sensible,'' said Dr. Roosevelt. ''At least we know the forest survived.''
With the arrival of Europeans in the 1500's, a new chapter opened. The Spanish established new economies on the flood plains, and cattle ranching emerged as a major economic activity that survives to this day. This was the forerunner of today's industrial-age exploitation of the forest. Driven by economic pressures, millions of acres of Amazon forest have been exploited for timber or burned and converted to cropland that, under presently employed methods of cultivation, plays out after two or three years and then sustains no one.
The Spanish conquest also brought disease that wiped out most of Amazonia's native population, with 85 percent of the people in some localities dying out within the first year of contact. Many of the survivors fled to the interior, where, in response to new conditions, their peculiar blend of present-day agricultural and forest management evolved from the ancient ways. Farms in the JungleForest to Field And Back Again In one application of this approach to what scientists call agro-forestry, the Kayapo tribe of Brazil, studied by Dr. Posey, operates as follows:
A circular field is prepared by felling several large trees at key junctures so that their crowns fall on the periphery of the circle. This also brings down smaller trees that have been weakened by notching. They, along with the leafy crowns of the big trees, also fall on the perimeter, providing nutrients for the highest-consuming plants, which are to be concentrated around the edges.
Yams, potatoes, manioc and other tubers are planted between the fallen tree trunks. On a windless day just before the year's first rain, the dead, felled trees are burned under carefully controlled conditions. The rains wash the fresh ashes into the soil, where the tubers' root systems are already established.
In this new field, crops are planted in concentric rings radiating out from the center: Sweet potatoes and yams in the middle, mixed corn and rice next, then manioc, then more yams. The outer zone contains papaya, banana, pineapple, mango, cotton and beans. In an older field in its later stages, the corn and rice have disappeared, the potato-yam zone has been expanded and manioc continues. The forest begins to encroach on the field. Gradually, fruit trees, palms and medicinal herbs move into the field.
Eventually, the forest re-covers the field entirely. Each phase of reforestation has its own inventory of useful plants and animals.
Other fields in both Peru and Brazil follow much the same pattern, with varying mixtures of crops, according to scientists from the New York Botanical Garden's Institute of Economic Botany, who have studied the practice extensively. The institute is in the forefront of study about such matters.
For a given plot to go from first cultivation back to forest takes 10 to 15 years, said Wil De Jong, an international fellow at the institute, who has taken part in field studies in the Amazon. ''Then it's continued for a longer time as forest,'' he said, ''maybe 50 or 60 years.'' During some stages of cultivation, he said, the plots propagate a number of forest species. ''People are preserving their resources by actually multiplying them,'' he said.
 
Supermarkets of a Sort
Among the Kayapo, said Dr. Posey, an ''enormously wide range'' of plants are brought from vast areas of forest and re-planted on small plots of three acres or less. Most have multiple uses as, for example, natural fertilizers and pesticides, insect repellants, building materials, medicines and food. ''These islands are sort of supermarkets concentrated in specific places,'' Dr. Posey said.
In creating the islands, he said, the Indians actively reshape the environment, transplanting forest species to the savanna in a sort of ''mix-and-match'' kind of ecological management. The Forest Economy Cash Crops Vs. Self-Sufficiency One demonstration of the effectiveness of the native way of farming as compared with modern ways has been documented by Jane L. Collins, an anthropologist at the State University of New York at Binghamton. Working in the Peruvian Amazon, she compared the performance of natives who pursued the old ways with the modern, cash-crop pursuits of migrants who had moved into the local region from elsewhere in the country.
In the modern application, she found, cash-cropping tends to force farmers who pursue it ''to be hooked up to the markets differently'' from the practitioners of native agro-forestry. That is, the cash-croppers, relying on one crop and on debt financing to produce it - as is commonly the case in many parts of the world - tend to ''be more dependent on cash, so they need to get more out of the land over the short term.''
The natives, on the other hand, tend to produce for their own use to a greater extent and to be less reliant on the market. Although they do sell some of their crop, they have a more stable, long-term source of sustenance. ''The migrants don't have the agro-forestry management skills,'' said Dr. Collins, ''and often there are lots of incentives to go other ways.'' For instance, she said, the government provides loans for cattle ranching, which encourages farmers to clear-cut land for pastures. ''If push comes to shove,'' she said, ''they can sell the cleared land and move on.'' Their one-crop practices are also more destructive to the soil, she said: ''That's why it gets worn out.''
 
Question of Compensation
Pharmaceutical companies have long exploited the medicinal properties of plants discovered from native cultures, said Dr. Posey, and the potential for broadening that exploitation into other areas is considerable.
In a study reported last year in the British journal Nature, Charles M. Peters of the Institute of Economic Botany, Alwyn H. Gentry of the Missouri Botanical Garden and Robert O. Mendelsohn of Yale University calculated that the long-term economic value of products taken from the living forest, excluding field crops that might be grown there, is about double that of the timber that might be harvested from it and the cattle that might be raised on cleared land.
Already, as awareness grows, Dr. Posey and many others are worrying about what might happen to the native peoples if the outside world begins tapping their intimate, detailed knowledge of the Amazonian environment in earnest. Will they expropriate the expertise, denying compensation to those who have developed it? That would be ''nothing more than another form of neo-colonialism,'' said Dr. Posey, who last week, in a sign of the times, attended an international conference on ''intellectual property rights'' in York, England.
The traditional systems of resource management and the knowledge that undergirds them, he says, ''are rare and priceless resources.''

HEADLINE: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;
Trips Through Geography and Time

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS

 BODY:
AS the school year wanes, it is time to put two educational software programs on the honor roll of the class of 1990.
PC USA, for I.B.M. PC's and compatibles, is a computerized atlas that can help students learn about the United States. It is a companion product to an earlier program, PC Globe, which is also highly recommended.
PC USA is more than a geography program. It is also a data base of statistics and other information on each state, plus the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico. The user can highlight a particular state or region and call up a variety of facts about it, ranging from broad economic statistics to the number of lawyers for every thousand people. 
On a purely geographical level, the map of the United States can be broken down into its states. One view might show all of the major cities. Another might highlight the principal natural features, including rivers, mountains and lakes.
The idea of merging maps with data bases is not new, but most such programs, called geographic information systems, are expensive and highly complex. PC USA and PC Globe contain a wealth of data, but they remain accessible to pupils from elementary school on up.
The map is the entry point to both programs. The user can ''point and shoot'' at the map to select a state, using either a mouse or keyboard commands, or select states from a list. We pointed and shot at Texas, a large target, which brought a map of the state to the screen and automatically loaded the underlying data base about the state.
In one view, the state's largest cities were shown. In another, the rivers, plateaus, lakes, elevations and other natural features were displayed. At this level, the program does not show any advantages over a more conventional printed atlas.
The real strength of PC USA, and of PC Globe as well, is in the data base. The user can call up information about government, history, tourist attractions, population, age distribution, education, crime, health, ethnic groups, natural resources and agriculture, taxes, principal products, highways, and even telephone area codes and ZIP codes. Much of the information can be broken down further to the city level.
Even more useful, the data on one state can be compared with similar data on another, and the results are displayed in graph form. For example, one might wish to compare average teacher salaries in Texas with those in other states. The user can select the states to be compared or compare the ''active'' state, in this case Texas, with the 10 states that rank highest or lowest in any given category.
PC Globe has similar capabilities, but on a broader scale. Both programs are easy to use. Each time we start, we wind up spending hours just browsing through their many features.
PC USA and PC GLOBE are $69.95 each and can be ordered from PC Globe Inc. of Tempe, Ariz.; phone (602) 894-6867. Both require a minimum of 512 kilobytes of memory and a color graphics adapter. A mouse is helpful but not necessary.
For the Apple Macintosh, the star of this year's class is Culture 1.0, The Hypermedia Guide to Western civilization.
Like PC USA, Culture 1.0 combines a data base with a sort of map. However, the terrain in this case is time: a time line of history and culture, in fact. Unlike conventional time lines, which are linear, the time line in Culture 1.0 is multidimensional. It lets you see, and even hear, events and cultural developments in an interrelated way that more accurately reflects the way history unfolds.
Hypercard, a software utility that is included with each Macintosh, is an ideal educational tool. It allows links to be forged among related bits of information. Used with a data base, Hypercard permits the user to roam through text, pictures and sound, guided only by his or her imagination and interests.
In the case of Culture 1.0, the underlying information and essays have been compiled over the last 20 years by Dr. Walter Reinhold, a professor of music history and the humanities at New York University.
In his classes, and in Culture 1.0, Professor Reinhold urges students to consider historical events in context, not in isolation. It is one thing to memorize the dry fact that Beethoven was a Romantic composer who lived from 1770 to 1827 - snore - and quite another to see him, hear a passage of his music (even in computer beeps) and place him amid the political, theological and artistic environment in Europe at the time. Who were his contemporaries? What great painters and architectural masterpieces might Columbus have admired before setting off for the New World?
From any starting point, the user can explore the history, music, philosophy, architecture, politics and art of the major periods of Western history from ancient times to the 19th century. The 20th century will be added later this year, the program's developers say.
For those who prefer a more structured way to explore the program, Cultural Resources offers a $35 companion guide called ''Interdisciplinary Lessons Covering Various and Sundry Things Every Secondary School Student Should Learn and Every College Student and Graduate Should Know.''
Culture 1.0 for the Macintosh is $175 from Cultural Resources Inc. of Cranford, N.J.; phone (201) 709-1574. It requires about five megabytes of hard disk space.

HEADLINE: Weak Profits Seen for Banks Hurt by Real Estate Loans

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
With the almost daily reports of losses from bad real estate loans, many large banking companies are expected to report weak profits for the first quarter.
The latest banking company to disclose bad news was the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group of Providence R.I. Although Federal regulators are not finished with a special examination of real estate lending at the company, Fleet/Norstar said results of the examinations so far point to a sharp rise in the level of troubled loans to at least $600 million from $400 million at the end of the year.
Fleet/Norstar, the 16th-largest banking company in the country, did not say how much its earnings would be reduced by the rise in troubled loans. But some analysts estimated that the company's reserve for loan losses would rise enough to eliminate most of the company's profit for the first quarter. 
In parts of the country, where real estate prices have weakened after several years of rapid incrases in real estate lending by banks, like New England and the Southeast, Federal regulators have been conducting special examinations, using tougher standards than bankers were expecting.
Other banks to have recently announced real estate losses following visits from examiners include the Bank of Boston Corporation, the Bank of New England Corporation, the Shawmut National Corporation, all in Massachusetts, the Southeast Banking Corporation and Barnett Banks Inc. both of Florida, and the Hibernia Corporation, Louisiana.
Other banking companies, including Citicorp, the Chase Manhattan Corporiaton, the First Chicago Corporation, and the NCNB Corporation have warned investors that problems with real estate loans are likely to increase. Steep declines in stock prices and rating reductions at the First Fidelity Corporation, the UJB Corporation and the Summit Bancorporation, all of New Jersey, are signs that heavy real estate loan losses are expected at those companies as well.
James McDermott, director of research at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, a securities firm that specializes in banking companies, said the median earnings gain for the first quarter would be about 3 percent above last year's quarter, with substantial declines among the largest banks and only modest increases for banks in California and the Midwest. In 1989, the median earnings gain for the 175 banks followed by Keefe Bruyette was 12 percent.
Analysts also said that bank profits were hurt by the cut in the prime rate to 10 percent from 10 1/2 percent on Jan. 7. Although the prime rate fell, the rates banks pay to borrow money did not decline as many expected. Earnings were also weakened by a slowdown in business loan demands, and the more cautious attitude bankers have about making loans when the economy is slowing.
 
Fees for Corporate Takeovers
Among large banks, a drop in fees earned from financing for large corporate takeovers, and lower profits from trading of bonds and foreign exchange will limit earnings, banking experts said.
In the case of Fleet/Norstar, Olivia Asher, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company, estimated that earnings could be near zero in the first quarter, assuming that troubled loans rise by about $400 million to a level of $800 million, and the company adds about $275 million to its reserve for bad loans. Fleet/Norstar estimated its troubled loans increased $200 million, to $600 million March 31, but might rise more as examinations are completed at other parts of the company.
John W. Flynn, Fleet/Norstar's chief financial officer, said that ''we don't have the slightest idea'' what the level of troubled loans will be at the end of the quarter. He said the $200 million increase in problem loans so far has come primarily from banks in Maine, Long Island and Syracuse, where the examinations are mostly completed. Those three banks account for less than a quarter of the assets and earnings of all Fleet/Norstar's subsidiary banks. Examinations are too incomplete to estimate any increase in bad real estate loans at Fleet/Norstar's bank's in Rhode Island, Connecticut, New Hampshire, Albany and Buffalo, which account for about three-fourths of its banking business.
To cushion the financial impact of the increase in bad loans, Fleet/Norstar said it earned $90 million of one-time profits by selling nearly half of its credit card businessand restructuring its pension plan.
Because Fleet reduced its real estate lending sooner than other New England banks, its losses are expected to remain significantly below other large New England banking companies. Analysts said that Fleet was benefiting from the diversity of its businesses outside the New England market.
''In the next few years, as the banking industry consolidates, Fleet will emerge as one of the winners in New England,'' Ms. Asher said. ''They are in a strong position to gain market share at a time when other banks are weakened and pulling back.''
Fleet stock fell 62.5 cents yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange closing at $21.25, or about 27 percent below its peak price last year.

HEADLINE: Japan Acts To Raise Imports

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2

 BODY:
In an effort to reduce trade tensions with the United States, Japan outlined proposals today to curb some of the more pervasive policy and cultural obstacles to American imports.
The measures would increase opportunities for American and other foreign companies, for example, by allowing the opening of more supermarkets and department stores, which tend to stock foreign goods. They would also put more Government money into housing and public works, which could use foreign goods and services like those offered by American construction companies.
Some of the Japanese proposals were discussed during a 15-minute telephone conversation this morning between the Japanese Prime Minister, Toshiki Kaifu, and President Bush, after which Mr. Bush said he was ''encouraged by recent progress.'' 
 
'Utmost Efforts' Reported
According to Taizo Watanabe, spokesman for the Japanese Foreign Ministry, Mr. Kaifu described the ''utmost efforts'' he had been making to resolve trade issues since his meeting with Mr. Bush in Palm Springs, Calif., on March 2 and 3.
At those talks the President warned that trade problems could poison the relationship of the two countries, and Mr. Kaifu, who had just been re-elected, pledged to make the resolution of those problems the highest priority of his new Cabinet.
Initial American reactions were cautious. In recent years, the Japanese have prepared a number of trade packages that have not yielded promised results. Although it has been falling modestly since 1987, the United States trade deficit with Japan is still running at $49 billion a year.
''I am pleased that Japanese negotiators seem to have come to Washington with some substantive offers, but I caution against declaring a breakthrough until we have had time to study the fine print,'' said Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee's trade subcommittee.
 
Aid to Japanese Stressed
To win political support at home for his potentially far reaching measures, Mr. Kaifu has argued that such changes are needed not just to ease frictions with Washington but also to help Japanese consumers, whose living standards have not kept up with Japan's stunning rise as the world's No. 2 economic power.
This point was echoed by Mr. Watanabe, who told reporters here that the proposals were made ''for the interest of improvement of quality of life for the Japanese public.''
Japanese newspapers and public opinion polls now show strong support for market-opening measures, suggesting that trade concessions may not be as difficult to achieve as many in the Government and ruling Liberal Democratic Party have been saying.
Mr. Watanabe was part of a 64-member delegation beginning a fourth round of talks on ''structural impediments'' that both countries have identified as broad-based barriers to trade.
Both sides are racing to meet a mid-April deadline for an interim report that could influence attitudes in Congress, where frustration over Japanese policies that block imports is rising. A final report is due in July. Measures Sought by U.S. Although details were not available, the Japanese, according to American and Japanese officials, outlined measures to their American counterparts that would stiffen antitrust enforcement, allow large retail stores to open in major cities after 1992 and increase expenditures for public construction.
Such measures are among those sought by the United States to increase general business opportunities for Americans in Japan and help redress the trade deficit.
But the Structural Impediments Initiative, which was started by the two Governments last July, is a two-way affair. For their part, the Japanese want the United States to help reverse the big American trade deficit by cutting the budget deficit, increasing savings, improving the education of workers, and increasing and expanding corporate research and development.
According to Japanese press reports, Tokyo has made some 90 recommendations to the United States, some of them specific and personal, like calling for a reduction in the number of credit cards in the United States, an increase in the gasoline tax, cuts in executive bonuses and the withdrawal of homeowner tax deductions.
The United States, in turn, handed Japan a proposal for 270 policy changes, prompting Asahi Shinbun, one of Japan's leading dailies, to comment that Washington wants to ''remake Japan.''
 
Satellite Accord Reported
In the last 10 days the United States and Japan announced market-opening accords in supercomputers and telecommunications, and today, according to Japanese officials, there was an agreement ''in principle'' on opening the market in communications satellites.
But an American trade official said that Washington was still waiting to hear on a ''fairly important point'' from the Japanese side, adding that from the United States viewpoint, ''there is no agreement.''
Still, American officials acknowledged that substantial progress had been made in this sector. Such an agreement could help companies like Hughes Aircraft and the aerospace division of the Ford Motor Company. General Motorsd (Hughes Aircraft)

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (98%); JAPAN (97%); 

STATE: CALIFORNIA, USA (79%);

HEADLINE: Talking Business; with Cook of Atlantic Richfield;
Oil Industry's Environment Role

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
Lodwrick M. Cook is chairman of the Atlantic Richfield Company of Los Angeles, one of the nation's most profitable oil companies. He discussed environmental and other issues during a recent visit in New York.
Q. What has changed in the oil business since this time last year?
A. One change is the increasing activity relating to the environment, particularly the Clean Air Act. The main thing we have been concentrating on is the alternative fuel section as it relates to gasoline. We introduced reformulated gasoline, EC 1, last fall. We substituted for unleaded regular in Southern California and it does produce a cleaner burn and reduces emissions. We think it is important to clean up the cars that are out there today, and that is what our reformulated gasoline will do. 
Q. What else is different?
A. The outlook for crude oil prices has changed. We think the price of crude will increase with inflation, which would put it at $25 a barrel by 1995.
Q. What is your feeling about conservation as we become more dependent on imported oil?
A. I know what triggers it, I just do not know how to get there. Higher prices trigger it. You could have taxes go up. I am supporting a tax of 9 cents a gallon in California to provide money to improve our transportation infrastructure. But it is still 50-50 whether it will be approved.
Q. Is conservation good for the country?
A. It is obviously good for the country and what is good for the country is good for ARCO, so I will not argue against conservation. Having said that, though, a gasoline tax to offset the deficit is not a good idea. If it were used to improve the transportation infrastructure of the country, I would support it and it would also have a conservation effect.
Q. What about regulation? What is the role of Government-mandated conservation, such as mileage reguirements?
A. I think it is appropriate. I think it was a mistake to go off the 55 miles per hour speed limit.
Q. What do you think is an attainable automotive fleet average? We have had people say it should be 50 miles per gallon.
A. It would take a long time to get the fleet up there. It would take a lot of small cars. Directionally the country has been going the wrong way, backing off mileage standards, speed limits, not emphasizing insulation in housing.
Q. What is the lingering impact of the Valdez spill on Alaska?
A. It has improved; a lot of the hysteria is gone. There are issues that remain, including whether Exxon is doing the right job. But you have to remember that the oil business pays 85 percent of Alaska's budget
Q. What about double hulls for tankers?
A. I think we are going to have to go to double hulls. The American people are saying to me that they will be more comfortable if we have double hulls because there are certain kinds of accidents where they are helpful. The Valdez was not one of those. It would have ripped through both hulls.
Q. How much is greater concern for the environment, such as double hull ships, adding to your costs?
A. We have announced a $600 million reserve to take care of environmental things that we need to go back and clean up. Some of these go back 20 or 30 years and we do not operate there anymore, but under the law we are responsible. To retrofit a double bottom on a ship costs $20 million. To make reformulated gasoline will probably require $300 million to $400 million in refinery changes.
Q. What about solar energy? Have you written it off completely?
A. As a company investment, yes. I personally feel solar will have an energy role in the next century as an important niche. The technology was fine, we were as good as anybody. But to produce the panels, we needed a factory setting, and we are not good at that. We built two solar farms and they worked fine, but we lost money even with a Government subsidy. We lost $200 million over 10 years.

HEADLINE: Trammell Crow Will Refinance 150 Properties

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, April 2

 BODY:
The Trammell Crow Company, the nation's largest commercial real estate developer, said today that one of the largest United States insurers had provided $456 million to allow the refinancing of more than 150 of its commercial properties, mainly in the Southwest.
The deal with the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States is the largest of its kind, and some analysts called it an important vote of confidence in the recovery of real estate markets in Texas.
Rumors had circulated in Texas in recent weeks that Trammell Crow was on the brink of bankruptcy because of difficulty in reaching agreements modifying its bank debt on dozens of properties in the Southwest, the weakest sector of its nationwide operation. Executives of Trammell Crow, who had denied the rumors, said the financing by Equitable removed the biggest uncertainty over the company's operations. 
 
'A Very Important Deal'
''This was a very important deal for the Trammell Crow Company,'' said David G. Schulman, director of real estate research at Salomon Brothers in New York. ''It shows that they can finance in Texas.''
The money provided by Equitable is in the form of a 10-year mortgage through its real-estate financing and management company. The insurer is also one of the nation's largest commercial real-estate companies, with $35 billion invested for its own account and for other investors, including several pension funds.
Trammell Crow has an interest in 3,300 properties. The overall equity value of those properties is $3 billion, and Trammell Crow's stake is about half the total, or $1.5 billion, said a person close to the company.
''We are not immune from having certain projects impacted in other areas of the country, but for us the concentration of underperforming properties was clearly here in the Southwest,'' said Robert A. Whitman, chief financial officer of Trammell Crow, which is based in Dallas.
Douglas A. Tibbetts, president of Equitable Real Estate Investment Management Inc., in Atlanta, said, ''We saw several months ago some stabilization in the Southwest markets and had an interest in taking a major position in the recovery.''
Analysts cautioned that the latest deal, although a good sign for Trammell Crow, did not mark a shift in investors' views on the nation's generally overbuilt commercial real-estate markets. Weakening occupancy and lease rates have lowered commercial property values in many regions, most recently in the Northeast.
In effect, the deal with Equitable enables Trammell Crow to convert equity in some of its most valuable industrial properties, built in the early 1980's, into cash to repay past-due and nonperforming loans on 67 properties built in the mid-to-late 1980's.
 
Refinancing Loans
Mr. Whitman said Crow was using $350 million from Equitable to refinance original loans with interest rates averaging 11.3 percent on 90 properties built in the early 1980's. The growing equity from those 90 properties is being used as collateral for an additional $106 million from Equitable that was paid to lenders on the 67 properties that were behind on debt payments.
In addition to the 10-year mortgage on the 157 properties, Equitable also received rights to a percentage of cash flow and profits generated by the properties. Most are in Texas, Arizona and Colorado.
None of the dozen banks involved in the agreement was forced to record a loss as a result of the restructuring, Mr. Whitman said. Citicorp is Crow's largest bank lender. Some insurance companies, which held mortgages on Crow properties built in the early 1980's, agreed to waive rights to pre-payment penalties in exchange for taking full payment on the unpaid portions of the mortgages.
People familiar with terms of the transaction said that although Trammell Crow had traded away a portion of its equity to Equitable, it had increased its equity position by roughly the same amount in properties for which bank debts were reduced.
Over all, 17 million square feet of space was involved, with 70 percent of it in warehouses and other industrial property. The other properties included about 20 percent in retail space and 10 percent in office projects.

HEADLINE: Dow Off Only 6.76 Despite Tokyo's Plunge

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
After shaking off another sharp decline in the Tokyo stock market, stock prices on the New York Stock Exchange bounced back yesterday in slow trading, with the Dow Jones industrial average ending the day at 2,700.45, down 6.76 points.
Volume fell to 124.4 million shares, the fourth-lowest level of the year, with 434 issues advancing and 1,122 issues declining.
At around 9:30 A.M., the Dow was down 38.52 points, to 2,668.69, because of the sharp drop in the Japanese market.
''The market made a nice comeback,'' said Peter G. Grennan, head of stock index futures trading for Shearson Lehman Hutton. 
Part of the recovery, he said, came from pension-fund investments placed at the start of the second quarter. More importantly, he said, ''as each week goes by and the economy improves, our market looks more attractive'' than many leading foreign markets.
One indication that the economy was mending slowly came from the National Association of Purchasing Management, which said that its index of economic activity rose to 48.8 percent in March, an improvement but still under the 50 percent level that would mean real expansion.
Unlike Japan, Mr. Grennan said, ''our market is not the one to sell and raise cash.''
 
Rumors in Japan
Rumors published in Tokyo by Japan's leading business newspaper, Nihon Keizai Shimbun, helped unsettle the Japanese market. The report suggested that some of the biggest life insurance companies in Japan might sell huge blocks of stock in American companies. In spite of denials by the Government, analysts said they expected Japanese investors to move money out of stocks and into bonds anyway.
In a continuing sign that American investors expect further declines in Tokyo, ''put'' warrants (or rights to buy a particular stock at a specified price in the future) on the American Stock Exchange advanced in heavy trading. And Japanese stocks traded here fell, including Mitsui, which dropped 6 3/4, to 104 1/2, and Tokio Marine, down 1 1/2, to 42 1/8, both on the over-the-counter market.
Most industry groups showed weakness, including gold, banking, insurance, chemicals, machinery and stockbrokers. Among the stronger groups were the beverage stocks and some computer stocks. Oil issues were mixed.
Compaq Computer, one of the most widely followed computer stocks, rose 2 1/8, to 97 5/8, after it announced a faster controller device. But in a sign of how nervous investors are about the continuing trend toward weak profits reports, Network Equipment Technologies plunged 6 3/8, to 23 1/2, with 1.75 million shares trading after the maker of advanced communications products said it expected a drop in fourth-quarter earnings.
Among the oil issues, Unocal rose 1 3/4, to 33 5/8, after Moody's Investors Service upgraded its debt while British Petroleum fell 1 3/4, to 63.
 
Slide in Transportation
The Dow transportation stocks slid 4.26 points, to 1178.88, with Burlington Northern down 1, to 36, in brisk trading, the only transportation issue to change as much as a point.
Amax, the metals company, headed the Big Board's most active list, rising 1/2, to 28 1/4, on 2.04 million shares. Amax has said it does not know why its stock is so active but Wall Street professionals have repeatedly mentioned takeover rumors.
Motorola rose 1, to 66, in heavy trading after a court lifted an injunction issued in a patent-infringement case involving Hitachi of Japan. Pfizer fell 1 5/8, to 59, on 1.09 million shares, in continued investor concern over the liability claims arising out of its Shiley heart valve.
Among other leading market averages, the Amex market-value index fell 2.38, to 359.37; the Standard & Poor's 500 fell 1.24, to 338.70, and the Nasdaq composite fell 2.36, to 433.18.

HEADLINE: Pension Fund Rating Shift

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 2

 BODY:
The California Public Employees Retirement Systems, considered by some to be the nation's most influential pension fund, said today that it had started a system to evaluate corporate performance that will help it with investment decisions.
The fund, also known as Calpers, is the nation's largest public pension fund, with $56 billion in assets. 
''No one has a crystal ball, and this is not a magic key to prosperity,'' said Gray Davis, California State Controller and a Calpers trustee. ''But it offers a rational, objective and meaningful analysis of how a company is performing alongside its competitors.''
The new rating system evaluates three key areas - stock returns, fundamental economic performance and corporate governance - and is being used to review Calper's investment portfolio, Mr. Davis told a meeting of the Council of Institutional Investors in Washington.
The fund said it would initially rate companies in which Calpers has investments and then broaden the evaluations to other corporations.
Calpers is the first pension fund to put into effect an objective monitoring system for comparing companies within an industry, a spokesman for Mr. Davis said.
The system evaluates portfolio holdings for short- and long-term stock returns and five-year measurements of return on investment. It also factors in operating margins, asset turnover, and cash flow-asset ratios.
The plan provides institutional investors a method to evaluate current proxy proposals, said Mr. Davis, who is also co-chairman of the Council of Institutional Investors.

HEADLINE: SENATORS APPROVE CLEAN AIR MEASURE BY A VOTE OF 89-11

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 3

 BODY:
After a decade-long stalemate over clean-air legislation, the Senate passed a compromise bill tonight intended to reduce acid rain, urban smog and toxic chemicals in the air. The vote was 89 to 11.
The bill, crafted in nearly a month of closed negotiations between White House aides and Senate leaders, met President Bush's demand for a less costly solution to the nation's clean air problems than the initial Senate plan.
It came after the Senate narrowly beat back a number of challenges in recent days that would have toughened the measure and raised the cost of pollution control.
The measure, the first attempt to toughen air pollution legislation since the 1970 Clean Air Act was amended in 1977, would require auto makers, chemical manufacturers and coal-fired power plants to make substantial investments in equipment and processes to lower pollution. The bill is likely to add more than $20 billion a year to the estimated $33 billion cost of meeting current pollution laws, according to Administration estimates. 
 
Senate Gave Way to Bush
In arriving at the compromise, the Senate leadership acquiesced to Mr. Bush on several points. These included less stringent requirements for reducing tailpipe emissions and for controlling toxic chemicals in the air.
The full House of Representatives has yet to take up a clean air bill. The one being drafted in committee would impose stricter controls than the Senate measure in some areas.
Both industry and environmentalists remain dissatisfied with crucial elements of the Senate compromise.
Industry contends that the costs are still too high and will result in lost business and jobs. Electric utilities say that scientists have not confirmed acid rain as the cause of serious damage and that rates charged to customers will soar as a result of the new requirements. Chemical companies have said huge costs will be borne to achieve relatively small advances in protecting public health. And car makers insist that the law will require technology that has not yet been developed.
But by lowering the cost of the new clean air requirements, the compromise bill met some of the demands of industry, which had contended that the original Senate bill would have imposed excessive costs on their operations. The Bush Administration estimated that the initial Senate bill would have cost $42 billion, but Democratic and some Republican lawmakers said the estimate was too high.
 
Environmentalists Not Satisfied
Environmentalists complain that the changes in the law will be inadequate to protect public health and the environment. But the compromise retained many of the elements sought by them, including substantial reductions in the pollution that leads to acid rain.
In the House, the Energy and Commerce Committee is currently writing a somewhat different bill to amend the current law.
Like the Senate bill, the House measure would also address acid rain, smog and toxic air pollution. But the legislation emerging from the House committee would be more stringent than the Senate version in several ways.
For example, the House would require the Environmental Protection Agency to impose a plan for achieving air quality standards in areas where state governments are unable or unwilling to do so. This provision was part of the initial Senate proposal that was eliminated in the compromise between the Senate and the White House.
The House committee may complete its work on the bill this week. House leaders say action on the floor could take place later this month or early next month. Once the House endorses its own clean air measure, the differences with the Senate will be worked out by House and Senate conferees.
 
Mitchell Praises Measure
The Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, a leading Congressional advocate of a more stringent clean air measure for over a decade, said the bill passed today would be ''a dramatic expansion of current law.''
''This is a very strong bill,'' Senator Mitchell said.
Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, a former Democratic leader, said that he voted against the bill because it did not include provisions for coal miners who would lose their jobs because of the measure's acid rain provisions. ''I cannot vote for legislation that can bring economic ruin to communities throughout the Appalachian region and the Midwest,'' he said.
The debate in the Senate divided regions of the country that would be affected in different ways by changes in the law. Areas that would bear most of the burden of cleaning up acid rain, particularly in the Midwest and Appalachia, contended they were being unfairly asked to bear all the cost of solving a national problem. Areas with concentrations of chemical plants complained that the costs imposed by the new provisions would require some of those plants to close.
While President Bush's commitment to a stronger clean air law opened a path out of the long legislative deadlock, his opposition to the original Senate bill as too expensive had threatened to undermine Congressional efforts. But White House aides and Senate leaders, headed by Mr. Mitchell, crafted a compromise agreement after nearly a month of intense negotiations.
The Senate bill, like the legislation being drafted in the House, addresses the three unsolved problems that continue to afflict much of the nation: acid rain, smog, and toxic chemicals in the air.
Acid Rain. The Senate bill would require 111 coal-fired power plants, most of them in the Midwest, to reduce sulfur dioxide emissions by a total of 10 million tons in two stages. Sulfur dioxide is the principal component of acid rain. The requirement would cut current sulfur emissions by about 50 percent.
Smog. More than 100 major cities are still not in compliance with the requirements of the Clean Air Act of 1970 for reducing the pollution that causes urban smog. The original 1975 deadline for compliance has been extended twice by Congress.
This legislation would again provide for an extension depending on the seriousness of the problem in the individual cities. Los Angeles, with the most extreme problem, would get an additional 20 years. New York, Houston, Chicago, Philadelphia, Baltimore, Milwaukee, San Diego and Hartford would have 15 years to comply. Other areas would have 5 or 10 years.
Cars in the most polluted cities would be required to burn reformulated gasoline that emits less pollution for each gallon used.
In a change from the current law, cities would be required to make annual reductions in smog levels - 4 percent a year for the first six years and then 3 percent a year until they are compliance. But the compromise agreement with the White House would waive the 3 percent a year reduction indefinitely if the cost of achieving the levels was excessive.
Airborne Chemicals. While the original bill required the Environmental Protection Agency to control toxic chemicals in the air so as not to pose a threat to public health, only seven such chemicals have been regulated in the last 20 years. The Senate bill would require all major sources of pollution of some 200 chemicals to install the ''maximum available control technology'' to reduce such pollution. If there is still a large health risk after the controls are installed, additional measures might be required.
Among the other provisions of the Senate bill is a requirement that all use of chlorofluorcarbons, chemicals that scientists say are causing the destruction of ozone in the upper atmosphere be phased out by 2000. Atmospheric ozone protects the earth from harmful ultraviolet radiation from the sun. 11 Senators Voted No These are the Senators who voted against the legislation tonight:

Malcolm Wallop, Republican of Wyoming Fuel Efficiency Backed In a related development today, the Senate Commerce Committee approved by a 14 to 4 vote, a requirement to require all automobiles achieve a fuel efficiency of at least 40 miles a gallon by the end of the century as a means of reducing carbon dioxide emissions. Carbon dioxide from the burning of fossil fuels is accumulating in the atmosphere and, many scientists say, will cause a substantial warming of the earth in the next century by absorbing radiation from the sun.
The fuel effiency provision had been removed from the Senate clean air bill in negotiations with the White House. Daniel Becker, a Washington representative of the Sierra Club, said before tonight's Senate vote that the provision was the most important immediate step that Congress could take to address global warming.
David Hawkins, a lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Fund who was an assistant administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency in the Carter Administration, said before the vote that environmentalists were not asking Senators to vote for or against the clean air legislation. He complained that ''skilled vested interests'' had weakened the bill to the point where it would not meet the nation's air quality needs in the future. The best hope of adequate legislation would come on the floor of the House, Mr. Hawkins said.

HEADLINE: Lebanon's Currency Hits All-Time Low; Mediation Bid Ends

BYLINE: By IHSAN A. HIJAZI, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 3

 BODY:
Lebanese saw the value of their money sink to a new low today as mediators trying to end more than two months of Christian fighting ended their mission without success.
The Lebanese pound dropped on the free market here in relation to the United States dollar and other foreign currencies, selling at 585 pounds to $1. This compares with 556 to $1 at the end of last week. 
''The fluctuation in the value of our national currency is political, not economic,'' an official at the central bank in West Beirut said. The informant, who declined to be further identified, argued that once the political and security situation stabilizes, ''so will the rate of our pound.''
The currency has been dropping ever since civil strife broke out in Lebanon 15 years ago. But the latest losses were seen as a reaction to the bitter fighting since the end of January between Christian army troops and rival militiamen who are also Christians.
The Lebanese pound's losses coincided with an announcement by a three-man committee that it had concluded its shuttle between the adversaries - Gen. Michel Aoun, who commands the army, and Samir Geagea, head of the Lebanese Forces militia.
The announcement did not say what results the two Maronite Catholic monks and a lawyer had achieved. It said a report has been submitted to Patriarch Nasrallah Butros Sfair, the head of the Maronite church, and that it is up to him to determine the next step.
The cleric was reported to be planning to summon leaders of the sect, the largest Christian group in lebanon, to a special meeting to discuss the sharpening crisis. General Aoun and Mr. Geagea are both Maronites.
Mr. Geagea today spelled out his stand unequivocally, rejecting General Aoun's claim to power and supporting President Elias Hrawi. He said the way to a solution in Lebanon is to recognize President Hrawi, who is based in West Beirut and supported by the Syrians.
LAST GRAF CAN BITE IN PART OR WHOLE.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
Nothing but Nice Things to Say of Gorbachev

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 3

 BODY:
A week after the Kremlin barred foreign correspondents from the crisis in Lithuania, they were invited today to get their news directly from the new office of the presidential press secretary and its inaugural occupant, Arkady Maslennikov.
Waiting in an office just past the the Spassky gate of the Kremlin, Mr. Maslennikov turned out to be a smiling, confident, garrulous practitioner of the art of making a President sound omniscient and irreplaceable.
This is an art labored at endlessly inside the Washington Beltway but long neglected here across centuries of such negative image making as Ivan the Terrible and Brezhnev the Stagnant.
The creation of the spokesman's post was further evidence of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's intention to cut a new executive swath for himself clear of many of Communism's traditional Kremlin shadows. 
 
The Human Touch
''All sides of the life of the country - political, economic, cultural, social - are included in the sphere of President Gorbachev's attention,'' the 58-year-old former journalist was soon declaiming of his boss.
He disclosed how Mr. Gorbachev has his ranking ministers seeing not only to the failing economy and the Lithuanian crisis, but also to the police confiscation and slaughter of that poor farmer's five pregnant milk cows that angered people so the other day in the north Caucasus and to those earnest army veterans proposing still another memorial medal for the nation.
The latter is the stuff of human interest stories, and Mr. Maslennikov appeared well aware that Mr. Gorbachev, for all his dynamic chase after a brighter national future, is often criticized for being aloof from the people. The spokesman also showed the requisite knack for never allowing his client to be less than galvanic in any single sentence.
''If necessary, the President will create operative groups for leadership and coordination of the activities of various bodies of power in various different directions,'' Mr. Maslennikov said, in a typical answer to one question about the new powers recently enacted for Mr. Gorbachev.
Lest anyone imagine a napping President in the Kremlin, he also took care to describe ''minimal differences and maximal coordination of forces'' under Mr. Gorbachev's baton as participants at one presidential meeting ''concentrated their attention on the questions of the perfection and renewal of the Soviet federation.''
Mr. Maslennikov, an economist by education who worked more than 20 years as an editor and correspondent for Pravda, the Communist Party newspaper, was fatalistic about the notion of a ''first 100 days'' for Mr. Gorbachev's new presidency, noting that a honeymoon from criticism is something unaimaginable in these chaotic days in the nation.
''Whatever you do those 100 days are going to pass anyway,'' he said. ''At least that's the way I see it.'' The press secretary was Pravda's London correspondent when he first met the future President in 1984 when Mr. Gorbachev visited the British capital as party secretary and drew one of his early favorable bursts of Western publicity as the Communist most likely.
Last summer, Mr. Gorbachev had him installed as the press spokesman at the Supreme Soviet, or parliament, and this week he promoted him, an ascension reflected in the spokesman's self-confidence, in which he was even willing to plead ignorance and stare unapologetically back at a questioner.
''I don't know of any big events in the next two or three days,'' he said, speaking like the spokesman of a government that has such a daily diet of crises that manufacturing news, as in the current doldrums reported from Washington, can only seem a distant luxury.
 
Salary? 'I Don't Know'
''I don't know what his salary is,'' he answered another questioner, not bothering to say he would get back with an answer.
''From the time I have worked with President Gorbachev I have not noticed any health problems,'' he replied to another of the staples of Western presidential press coverage slowly seeping within Moscow's executive beltway.
''I think our President is a physically strong man, strong enough to deal with the nation''s responsibilities,'' he said, the West-Wing-like forthrightness seeming to grow with each reply.
By the end of the new press secretary's hourlong debut, none of the correspondents were complaining about being thrown out of Lithuania. They crowded around smiling at him, begging further tidbits and getting his office phone number and the name of his secretary, Yelena Gregorievna Bobish, the better to begin seeking luncheon dates.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The new Soviet press secretary, Arkady Maslennikov, holding his first news conference yesterday. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: China Ties New Demand to Dissident's Fate

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 3

 BODY:
Stiffening resistance to American efforts to free the dissident Fang Lizhi, China has made new demands on the United States in discussing terms for his release, American officials said today.
The United States tried again recently to arrange the release of Mr. Fang, who has taken refuge at the American Embassy in Beijing, but China still refuses to let him leave the country, the officials said.
Indeed, they said, after the United States met one of China's original conditions for Mr. Fang's release, allowing the resumption of some World Bank loans, China issued another demand: that the United States resume exports of military goods and high-technology products to China.
State Department and White House officials said they saw no prospect that Mr. Fang would leave the Embassy in the near future because Chinese authorities were tightening their political control over the country to prevent protests and demonstrations as several important anniversaries approach. 
 
'He Is Not Isolated'
Chinese authorities have demanded that Mr. Fang write an ''admission of guilt,'' acknowledging that he helped organize the demonstrations in Tiananmen Square in May and June last year. American officials said Mr. Fang was unlikely to admit guilt now after having railed against the Chinese Communist Party, complaining of arbitrary, dictatorial rule, corruption and nepotism for several decades.
Mr. Fang, an astrophysicist, continues his work and study at the American Embassy and is able to correspond with scientists all over the world, Administration officials said. ''He is not isolated,'' one official said.
Another American official said of the Chinese: ''It's in their interest to resolve the case, to regain the confidence of intellectuals in China, to gain the respect of the world community, to revitalize scientific exchanges with the outside world and to improve bilateral relations with the United States.''
A program assistant at the National Academy of Sciences, Derek S. Wilson, said the Academy suspended scholarly exchanges with China after the Tiananmen Square crackdown. Most of the programs are still suspended, although the Academy has sent several social scientists back to China in the last few months, he said. Chinese Deported by U.S. On a separate matter, Administration officials confirmed today that President Bush had not issued an executive order to protect Chinese students in the United States, even though he says repeatedly that he has issued such an order.
Administration officials said the difference between an executive order and the President's action was one of semantics, not policy.
The term ''executive order'' refers specifically to a Presidential proclamation with the force of law published in the Federal Register. On Nov. 30, when he vetoed a bill to allow Chinese students to remain in the United States, Mr. Bush said he had directed the Attorney General to ''insure that no nationals from the People's Republic of China be deported against their will.''
Mr. Bush's directive has not been published in the Federal Register, does not have the force of law, can be changed without public notice and protects only those Chinese who were ''present in the United States on June 5, 1989.''
Chinese who took part in the Tiananmen Square demonstrations in early June were obviously not in the United States at that time. Immigration lawyers said the Immigration and Naturalization Service had arrested, detained and deported some Chinese who supported the student demonstrators, came to the United States and sought political asylum after June 5.
 
Assertions on Executive Order
Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, the author of the bill vetoed by Mr. Bush, said he should issue a formal executive order if he truly has no intention of sending Chinese students back to China.
In a television interview broadcast by NBC News on Feb. 28, Mr. Bush bristled at criticism of his China policy. ''I put into effect an executive order that's broader than the legislation that was so touted,'' he said.
Likewise, in a news conference on March 13, Mr. Bush said, ''The approach I took, accomplishing something by executive order that the Congress wanted to do dramatically later on through legislation, was the proper approach.''
In a handwritten letter to Senator Connie Mack, Republican of Florida, on Jan. 24, Mr. Bush said, ''The executive order, in my view, protects the Presidency and does better by the students.''
But White House and State Department officials confirmed that Mr. Bush had not issued an executive order. Asked why the President continually boasted of having issued an executive order, Douglas A. Davidson, a White House spokesman, said: ''He is the executive, and he ordered it. These distinctions are semantic. It has the same effect. It doesn't really matter how it's done, by a Presidential memorandum, directive or executive order.''
