HEADLINE: Besieged Vermont Governor Rules Out Race for 4th Term

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, April 3

 BODY:
Vermont's Governor, Madeleine M. Kunin, faced with budget problems and a backlash against a tough environmental planning law, announced today that she would not seek a fourth two-year term this fall.
The decision by Mrs. Kunin, a Democrat, puts her predecessor, Richard A. Snelling, in a strong position to regain the governorship. Mr. Snelling is currently the only Republican in the race.
Mrs. Kunin is the latest of several Northeast governors to be hurt by budgetary problems after a downturn in the region's economy. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts and William A. O'Neill of Connecticut, both Democrats, have announced that they would not seek re-election, in part because of deficits and the political repercussions of tax increases they proposed. 
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York has also come under increasing criticism for his inability to stop the flood of red ink in Albany, although he does not appear to be in any danger of losing his seat this year.
 
Having It All
Mrs. Kunin, who is 56 years old and the first woman to serve as Governor of Vermont, made her announcement in Vermont's capital, Montpelier.
In explaining her decision, the Governor said in a telephone interview that ''we have a climate today that says you can have it all,'' a climate fostered by an Administration in Washington that says ''you can have reduced taxes or no tax increase without losing anything.''
''Unfortunately, governors can't play by these rules if you face the budget realistically,'' Mrs. Kunin added. ''So there is bound to be some discontent.''
Garrison Nelson, a professor of political science at the Unversity of Vermont, called Mrs. Kunin's decision ''a smart move for her personally.''
He said he had learned of recent private opinion polls, taken by both the Governor and by Mr. Snelling's campaign office, indicating that Mrs. Kunin had fallen behind him in the governor's race.
Professor Nelson said that Mrs. Kunin had ''received a lot of unnecessary abuse'' in the past few weeks because of debate over how to handle the budget and a stringent state land use planning law she had helped to push through. The law requires towns to go through a rigorous planning process before approving new development that its critics say would diminish the power of communities to control their own growth.
 
Likely Democratic Hopefuls
The two most likely Democratic candidates for Governor are Lieut. Gov. Howard Dean and Peter Welch, a former State Senator. Both are believed to face difficulty against Mr. Snelling. Mr. Dean is not well known, and Mr. Welch is regarded as more liberal than most Vermonters.
But Mark Gearan, the executive director of the Democratic Governors Association, predicted that Mr. Snelling, who held the governor's office for four terms, could be easily beaten. ''Snelling is a has-been,'' Mr. Gearan said. In 1986, the last time he ran for office, challenging Senator Patrick J. Leahy, a Democrat, Mr. Snelling won only 10 of the state's 250 towns, Mr. Gearan said.
During her three terms in office, Mrs. Kunin closed a budget deficit she inherited from Mr. Snelling and increased state aid to education and child care.
But to finance her new programs Mrs. Kunin greatly expanded state spending. The approach appeared to work in the mid- to late-1980's, when Vermont was enjoying prosperity. But in the last two years the state has been faced with declining revenue in downturn similar to what is happening elsewhere in New England and in New York State, though on a smaller scale.
Mrs. Kunin has apparently been able to head off a deficit for this fiscal year, ending in June, through a series of budget cuts. But she has asked for tax increases to meet an expected shortfall for the fiscal year 1991.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Madeleine M. Kunin acknowledging an ovation after she announced yesterday that she would not seek another term. (Associated Press)

SECTION: Section A; Page 24, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 607 words

HEADLINE: Moscow's Reforms: Turning Radical

 BODY:
The Soviet economy is sliding downhill so fast that Mikhail Gorbachev must jettison milquetoast reforms in favor of radical change. That will bring pain to Soviet workers. And that, in turn, will exact a political price. Even then, the economic outcome is uncertain. 
Americans, and the world, can do little more than watch anxiously, hoping for the best. What lies ahead for the Soviet Union is a rough road indeed.
With remarkable candor, Mr. Gorbachev says he wants to create ''market relations.'' First he tried piecemeal reform. But a collapsing economy has forced him to abandon that go-slow strategy. One reason is sabotage by bureaucrats who have remained firmly in control. Ed Hewett, an economist at the Brookings Institution, provides a telling illustration of their stifling grip:
As part of Mr. Gorbachev's earlier reforms, the Soviets legalized small private enterprises. But the would-be owners had to get licenses from the appropriate ministry. The ministries balked, or extracted bribes. And the few enterprises that got licenses had little access to credit or raw materials.
For all these reasons, the new owners had high costs and little competition. So they charged exorbitant prices, creating bitter resentment toward ''markets.'' Such sorry experiences have apparently convinced Mr. Gorbachev that piecemeal reform is unworkable. But comprehensive reform has its own perils.
Over the years, the Soviet Government has run huge deficits that were financed by pumping billions of rubles into the economy. The combination of excess rubles and low, controlled prices has created severe shortages of consumer goods. Swiftly decontrolling prices in this environment, in an attempt to create markets and bypass the bureaucrats, would create ruinous inflation.
So what will Mr. Gorbachev do? American Sovietologists list the following necessary ingredients for plausible reform:
Price Decontrol: Markets can work only if prices reflect realistic value. For the process to succeed, wages must be controlled, which means Soviet workers will suffer.
Monetary Reform: Price decontrol can work only if excess rubles are eliminated. That can be done by wiping out the existing ruble and replacing it with a limited supply of a new currency. Or it can be done by allowing inflation to eat up the value of existing rubles. Again, either way, Soviet workers will suffer.
Fiscal Reform: Monetary reform can work only if Government deficits are controlled. To do that will require eliminating subsidies to unproductive businesses. Some of these will go bankrupt. Layoffs, once again, would make workers suffer.
Even these painful measures won't suffice. Herbert Levine, a University of Pennsylvania economist, calls attention to the need also to create an efficient banking system and laws that guarantee the right to buy and sell property. To create competition, the Soviet Union has to figure out how to break up the huge state businesses and to get new ones to compete against each other.
To accomplish such changes will shake Soviet society. In Poland, real incomes have plummeted and the unemployment rate has skyrocketed since a similar program started in January - and there, unlike the Soviet Union, the Government enjoys popular support.
There is not much the United States can do about any of this. The Bush Administration can offer valuable technical assistance and, perhaps, trade credits. But even if the U.S. were willing to offer massive relief, that would only delay the necessary transformations. For all the distance Mikhail Gorbachev has brought his country in five years, the hardest part still lies ahead.

HEADLINE: Relief for the AIDS Disaster

 BODY:
In a recent heartfelt speech, President Bush called for more compassion and less discrimination against victims of AIDS. That was welcome moral leadership, but AIDS, now pushing health care systems of big cities into crisis, demands much more from Washington. A bill pending in Congress recognizes the urgent need. 
More than 121,000 cases of AIDS have been diagnosed in the United States since 1981; it's estimated that a million people now are infected, with a high percentage likely to develop the disease. Medical care for each case costs tens of thousands of dollars, and the total for AIDS care may now be more than $5 billion annually.
Those bills are paid haphazardly, forcing hospitals to absorb huge losses. Private insurers shrink from the problem. The poor are entitled to some help from Medicaid, the Federal-local insurance program. But state reimbursement rules differ; rates aren't always sufficient to cover actual costs of treatment, and not all poor patients get covered. One recent study found that a quarter of AIDS patients have no insurance at all.
In addition to inflicting financial stress, AIDS may severely aggravate crowding in urban hospitals already troubled by drug-related illnesses and staff shortages. AIDS swells the numbers seeking hospital treatment; many remain when they no longer need the full range of hospital services. Some are in no shape to function completely on their own, but have no way to get help at home. AIDS leaves others unemployed and homeless. There is universal agreement on the need for more resources and for alternatives to the hospital: nursing homes, home-care services, hospices and apartment complexes that offer access to medical help. Use of such facilities and services to limit hospital stays can, typically, cut the cost of care to half or even a quarter of the usual $150,000 per case.
The new Federal legislation, introduced by Senators Edward Kennedy of Massachusetts and Orrin Hatch of Utah, would address the need. It calls for spending $300 million in the next two years in emergency relief for urban hospitals with high AIDS caseloads. The most afflicted are in New York, New Jersey, California, Florida and Texas, five states that account for 64 percent of all American AIDS cases.
The bill would provide $300 million more to communities that come up with comprehensive case management plans. Such money could equip smaller cities, where the problem remains in the early stages, to avoid the ruinous costs and crowding experienced by New York or Los Angeles.
Late last year, Congress quickly voted $4 billion in disaster relief for victims of the northern California earthquake and Hurricane Hugo. Cities bearing the brunt of the AIDS epidemic are experiencing similar disaster, even if not quite so sudden.
Perhaps more important, the Kennedy-Hatch bill would promote aggressive management of the AIDS-care crisis rather than reactive management. Continued neglect of that need compounds devastating disease with financial waste.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Supercollider Stands at the Frontier of Science;
Pound Foolish

 BODY:
To the Editor:
To abandon the supercollider project in Waxahachie, Tex., as you suggest (''The Behemoth and The Boson,'' editorial, March 21) would be to abandon one of America's more important bids for supremacy in the complex, high-technological research that will dominate the economy of the 21st-century.
When the world entered the 20th century, the United States was striving for leadership of the industrial revolution, which it subsequently acquired and which resulted in the unequaled standard of living America has enjoyed for this century. Now you would have us enter the 21st century trying to save money on research and development.
For what purpose? To pay for more luxurious conferences for the Postal Service in the best hotels in the world? To finance the pet outmoded defense establishment of each member of Congress? To pay for an unneeded ''Star Wars'' defense system or let Congress waste, as it wastes most of our money?
 
WYLIE F. L. TUTTLE
New York, March 21, 1990

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Rocket May Open A New Era

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

 BODY:
A small company, working with the Pentagon and NASA, is scheduled to launch a 50-foot winged rocket from a B-52 flying over the Pacific Ocean today in a pioneering effort to provide a new way to send spacecraft into orbit.
If the launching is successful, it will represent a major step forward in the nation's efforts to develop a relatively low-cost and reliable rocket to place in space the small, lightweight satellites that could have a wide range of military, scientific and commercial uses. But if the rocket does not ignite and falls into the sea, or explodes, or fails in any other big way, it will be a severe setback not only to the dreams of its developer, the Orbital Sciences Corporation, but also to the nation's first generation of space entrepreneurs.
Instead of being fired from a pad on the ground, the rocket, called Pegasus, will be dropped from the right wing of the B-52 almost eight miles over the Pacific 50 miles off the central coast of California. All going as planned, it will ignite five seconds later and soar into a polar orbit with its cargo of two Government satellites. 
 
Others Have Tried
Other entrepreneurial efforts to develop low-cost space transportation have so far resembled something from ''America's Funniest Home Videos.'' Last fall a rocket built by the American Rocket Company lifted a few feet off its pad at Vandenberg Air Force Base, Calif., then toppled onto its side, where it burned, like a smoldering cigar, for hours. Pegasus has its risks as well. For one, there is some question as to whether its 22-foot wing will be able to withstand the acceleration to 5,800 miles an hour, or more than eight times the speed of sound.
But on paper, at least, Pegasus has a lot going for it. Space experts envision using the small satellites transported by efficient rockets like Pegasus for a variety of military communications and surveillance missions, for scientific experiments, and for commercial purposes like automatic navigation systems for cars, tracking fleets of ships and rail cars and manufacturing drugs and other materials in the low gravity of space.
The emerging new class of satellites that would be carried by Pegasus, often called ''lightsats,'' are roughly the size of television sets and weigh a few hundred pounds. Although it remains unclear how quickly lightsats will be developed, or how strong the demand for them will be, space analysts have high hopes for them. But Pegasus will never put the space shuttle out of business, or be a major competitor to the huge ground-launched rockets like the McDonnell Douglas Corporation's Delta or the Martin Marietta Corporation's Titan. All of those vehicles are designed to carry bus-sized satellites weighing tons and costing hundreds of millions of dollars.
As an air-launched, winged rocket, Pegasus requires less thrust to reach space than an equivalent-sized ground-launched rocket, since at launching it is already at a high altitude and a high speed. In theory at least, it is therefore a less-expensive form of space transport, even factoring in the cost of using an airplane to begin its voyage.
 
'Holds Great Promise'
''One of the many keys to developing a commercial space industry is reducing the cost per pound of payloads in orbit,'' said Peter Nesgos, a lawyer in New York who specializes in space issues. ''Any kind of launch system that can offer access to space at a reasonable cost will encourage further commercial space exploration. The Pegasus program holds great promise for that kind of launch service.''
If Pegasus works, the company said it could sell commercial launchings for $6 million to $7 million each, or about $6,000 per pound of payload. That would be a vast improvement over the $20,000 per pound to send a small satellite aloft on the only other rocket designed specifically for lightweight payloads, the ground-launched Scout rocket made by the LTV Corporation.
Some small satellites are sent aloft as secondary payloads on the space shuttle or on the heavy-lift boosters like the Titan and the Delta, but availability is often limited and the needs of the small-satellite user, including timing and the precise orbit, are invariably secondary to those of the large satellite owner.
An air-launched rocket also provides more flexibility than a fixed ground pad as to when and from where a payload can be sent into space. That capability is of particular interest to the military, which dreams of being able to put communications, intelligence-gathering and perhaps missile-defense satellites into the skies at short notice over battlefields and political hot spots.
 
Government Support
Orbital Sciences is generally considered the most credible of the upstart rocket companies, and the Pegasus project is getting a lot of attention from the Pentagon and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The Pentagon's Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, known as Darpa, is paying Orbital Sciences $6.5 million for the launching. NASA is providing the B-52. The payload being carried by Pegasus consists of an experimental Navy communications satellite and a NASA satellite that will conduct atmospheric experiments.
While the European Arianespace consortium is now at least an equal competitor to the United States in heavy-launching capability, and the Japanese are catching up fast, Orbital Sciences and other companies have kept the United States ahead of the rest of the world in the development of low-cost rockets for small payloads.
If Pegasus works, it will be the first major success for the dozens of small companies that have sprung up in recent years in the belief that there is profit to be wrung from the void of space. Formed in 1982 by three young Harvard Business School graduates, the company, based in Fairfax, Va., has developed a somewhat diversified business base, mostly through the 1988 acquisition of the Space Data Corporation, a maker of suborbital ''sounding'' rockets, satellite tracking systems and weather balloons.
Still, like virtually every company in the business, Orbital Sciences exists in a precarious state. Although it has twice turned annual profits, it has generally run up big losses, including a $5.4 million loss for the first nine months of last year, the latest period for which figures are available. The company had revenues of $56.8 million in the period.
 
Stock Offering Canceled
Executives of Orbital Sciences, including David W. Thompson, the chief executive, declined to be interviewed for this article, as did the Pentagon and NASA officials overseeing the Pegasus program. Late last month, the company had to shelve indefinitely its plans for a public stock offering when an article discussing the company's risky outlook appeared in The Wall Street Journal on the day the offering was scheduled to begin.
In an interview last year, Mr. Thompson outlined a vision he calls ''microspace,'' or the idea that smaller and more affordable rockets and satellites will make space and space-oriented products and services appealing to governments, companies, even consumers.
''Our orientation is toward smaller and much more affordable systems that can make space accessible to a wider range of users than ever before,'' Mr. Thompson said. ''We want to make space economically relevant to a much larger fraction of the population.''
Orbital Sciences has survived by entering a series of partnerships with the Government and other companies. It is building the Pegasus vehicles as a joint venture with Hercules Inc., a leading maker of solid-rocket motors. It has also forged an alliance with Martin Marietta, with which it builds small boosters designed to lift satellites from the low earth orbits flown by the space shuttle and other launchers into much higher orbits.
Orbital Sciences' own backers have put $100 million into the company, and its joint venture partners have invested $100 million.
But until Mr. Thompson's vision of microspace comes to pass, the company remains overwhelmingly dependent on the Government as a customer and also to provide credibility. The Pentagon has already committed to using Pegasus for at least one more launching.
 
'The Anchor Customers'
''Darpa and NASA are the anchor customers for the products we've developed,'' Mr. Thompson said. ''They are the largest and most sophisticated consumers of space products, and other customers look to them as indicators of reliability.''
The company's continued credibility with the Government will depend to a great extent on the success of the first Pegasus flight. Pegasus is different from traditional rockets in design but not in technology. The three-stage vehicle uses solid-rocket motors of the general variety that have powered missiles and launchers for years. Its guidance systems are more or less off the shelf. The rocket casing is made of lightweight graphite composites built by Burt Rutan, the designer of the Voyager aircraft, which flew around the world three years ago on a single tank of fuel.
But Pegasus's winged design is a first for unmanned rockets, allowing the vehicle the extra lift to head toward orbit most efficiently from its horizontal airborne launching. Despite the questions about the wing's stability at extremely high speeds, people involved in the program say they are confident of the wing's strength.

LENGTH: 1103 words

HEADLINE: Recession Coming? Ask the Consumer

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANN ARBOR, Mich.

 BODY:
When the United States economy succumbs to recession, as it sooner or later must, it is a good bet that Dr. Richard T. Curtin and his colleagues here at the University of Michigan will have seen it coming before almost anyone else.
Dr. Curtin makes his living by constantly monitoring consumer attitudes, and the consumer in this country accounts for fully two-thirds of all business activity. Predict what the consumer will do, logic dictates, and you will predict the course of the economy.
The Commerce Department now uses Dr. Curtin's monthly index of consumer expectations as part of its index of leading indicators, a group of 11 items designed to predict the nation's business cycle. 
Dr. Curtin's consumer survey appeared to do just that after the the October 1987 stock market crash. His findings convinced Susan M. Sterne, a financial consultant to institutions with large securities portfolios, to reject the common belief at the time that the crash would lead to recession. The Government's forecasting index fell five straight months and did not rebound until February 1988, signaling a recession. But Dr. Curtin's index of consumer expectations turned back up in December 1987. Sure enough, there was no recession. Attempts to measure sentiment, as against actual purchases, has an undeservedly poor reputation among economists as a predictor, Ms. Sterne said. ''But I think it's extremely valuable,'' she added.
The Federal Reserve Board, among others, pays $4,000 a year for the full survey package, including the monthly publication Surveys of Consumers, containing the expectations and other indexes of sentiment. The latest reading, for February, shows a distinct ''weakening'' but nothing unexpected or very severe, Dr. Curtin said.
The Michigan forecasting record shows that consumers are particularly adept at predicting broad trends, anticipating with high probability changes in unemployment rates by an average of nine months ahead of time, in interest rates by six months and in inflation by three months.
But good as its record is, Surveys of Consumers commands far less public attention than such official gauges of economic performance as employment, output, prices, foreign trade and even the privately compiled report on the views of industrial purchasing managers.
Indeed, the Commerce Department decided to add the Curtin index only at the beginning of 1989, although some version of the Michigan survey has been around since the end of World War II. Dr. Curtin, interviewed in his data-filled office on the edge of Michigan's main campus recently, does not lament the lack of recognition by the public on whose collective knowledge he has founded his career. The endorsement of 100 or so mostly corporate sponsors, who use the information to help plan things like production runs and strategies for marketing and investment, appears enough. Yet he says that many economists still disparage his work because they believe themselves superior judges of the future than a random assortment of citizens.
 
'Know Their Interests'
Although individuals often have a poor grasp of economics or may show little fiscal practicality, consumers in the aggregate have a way of groping their way to advantage.
''Even if unsophisticated in economics, consumers know their interests,'' Dr. Curtin contends. ''They may not know the latest figures for, say, housing starts or gross national product, but they know that a neighbor has lost his job or that paychecks aren't stretching as far as they once did.''
The Michigan surveys date from 1946, when a survey pioneer, George Katona, and some Agriculture Department colleagues left the Government for Ann Arbor. The surveys are grounded in the fact that since World War II large numbers of Americans have had money available for so-called discretionary purchases after paying for food, shelter and clothing.
Consumers thus were no longer passive creatures, but an increasingly powerful force whose collective decisions on when to buy expensive vehicles and appliances, purchases that could be put off, would come to have a significant impact on the economy.
This subjected the economy for the first time to widespread and repeated psychological influence, and before long the consumer had leapfrogged business and government to become the prime economic force.
Discretionary spending, much of which goes for cars and refrigerators, also tends to be a kind of investment because the items purchased last a long time and are often financed by loans against future income. This means that what consumers do with their discretionary income depends to a considerable degree on their economic expectations. 500 Telephone Interviews To compile the data each month a cadre of about 30 Michigan interviewers telephone at random 500 Americans and ask two dozen basic questions. Consumers are asked not only for their opinions but also the reasons they hold them, with their responses helping to anticipate possibly different reactions to the same economic phenomena, such as inflation, at different times.
Five of the questions make up the index of consumer expectations, part of the larger index of consumer sentiment, and further breakdowns categorize responses by age, census region and income level.
A similar, mail poll is conducted by the New York-based Conference Board, a business organization.
This kind of work has illuminated over the years some fundamental characteristics of the American psyche and some important shifts as well.
Conditions in the job market, for example, seem to be the most powerful single determinant of the consumer's mood. There has also been a big shift of consumer focus to prices. In the 1970's ''you couldn't talk to consumers without them mentioning inflation,'' Dr. Curtin said, and people unwittingly made inflation worse by buying merchandise before they really needed it just to beat the next price increase.
 
Consumers Adjust
Now, when prices start to accelerate, the assumption is that the authorities will put on the monetary brakes. Consumers, instead of scrambling to buy, turn cautious in the face of possible recession.
Dr. Curtin points to such evidence of how people learn and adapt to rebut fellow economists' suggestions that consumers are mere conduits for economic forces and that their behavior might become completely predictable, doing away with the need for surveys.
Interestingly, questions about consumers' intentions to buy - as opposed to what they expect conditions to be for buying - became less and less reliable during the 1970's and are now no longer asked.

HEADLINE: G.M. Picks Its Next Chairman

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 3

 BODY:
Directors of the General Motors Corporation, in a widely expected move, announced today that they had chosen Robert C. Stempel, the company's president and chief operating officer, as the next chairman and chief executive. He will succeed Roger B. Smith, who will retire this August after nearly a decade in office.
Mr. Stempel differs in some ways from Mr. Smith. He is an engineer with a deeper understanding of cars and trucks than Mr. Smith, who, like most G.M. chief executives in recent times, came from the financial side. He is known to be more collegial and low key than Mr. Smith. 
In the style of executives successful at G.M., Mr. Stempel is not outspoken or flamboyant, and has been careful not to overshadow his superiors. As a result, it is not yet clear what kind of a mark he intends to make on the company. But, at age 56, he is still nine years from mandatory retirement, and it is widely expected that he will have a substantial amount of time at the helm. Mr. Smith is 64.
 
Top Structure Left Intact
The promotions of Mr. Stempel and several other executives become effective Aug. 1. Other than some changes in titles and reporting relationships, the main effect of the changes was to formalize Mr. Smith's departure and his replacement by Mr. Stempel. The top management structure remains largely intact.
Mr. Stempel said at a news conference today that he was beginning to prepare strategies with the six executives on the company's management committee.
Three of those executives received promotions yesterday and could be regarded as roughly equal in the highest positions under Mr. Stempel.
 
Promotions for Three
G.M. named as president Lloyd E. Reuss, 53, who was executive vice president; he will remain in charge of North American operations and will assume responsibility for component operations. John F. Smith Jr., 51, was named a vice chairman and elected a director, and will continue to oversee international operations. Robert J. Schultz, 59, was named a vice chairman and elected a director; he will continue to oversee GM Hughes Electronics, Electronic Data Systems and the company's technical staffs. The position of chief operating officer remains vacant.
Mr. Stempel is taking command of the world's biggest auto maker during one of the most difficult periods in its 75-year history. For the last decade G.M. has been losing a big share of the North American automotive market, partly to Japanese auto makers and partly to the Ford Motor Company.
In January, two large institutional investors - the California and New York public employee pension funds - expressed dismay over the competitive decline of G.M. and asked that they be consulted as the board chose a replacement for Mr. Smith. But G.M. declined to include them in the selection process.
Moreover, the United States auto industry is preparing for bargaining on a new contract with the United Automobile Workers union this summer at a time when relations with the union have grown tense because of G.M. plant closings.
The union sent a congratulatory message to Mr. Stempel in which its president, Owen Bieber, said of the union work force, ''The leader who fully taps this resource will be the leader who can decisively turn G.M.'s fortunes around.''
Since Mr. Smith's tenure began in 1981, in the midst of a recession, G.M. has struggled through a major reorganization of its United States operations and has made large acquisitions of the Electronic Data Systems Corporation and the Hughes Aircraft Company. G.M. has remained strong financially, partly because of diversification and partly because of a turnaround of its European auto business, which has started showing strong profits after years of losses.
 
How a Crisis Might Help
Indeed, the lack of an immediate crisis at G.M. could prove to be one of the biggest problems Mr. Stempel faces, said James Womack, research director of the automotive study project at Massachusetts Institute of Technology. ''G.M. never had a crisis like Ford or Chrysler, which forced those companies to make changes,'' he said. ''G.M. is dying the death of a thousand cuts. If this continues, G.M. simply will become less and less influential in the automotive business.
''It's time for a new G.M. and Stempel's first 100 days, as with any new officeholder, are terribly important,'' Mr. Womack said. ''He should offer a profound agenda before he starts getting bogged down in the details.''
Mr. Stempel, while declining to talk yet about specific tactics or strategies, said G.M.'s most important task was to ''profitably increase North American market share.''
Scott Merlis, automotive analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, said for G.M. ''the name of the game is to cut costs faster than rebates are going up in North America.'' He said G.M. must continue to streamline its capacity, which means ''converting some car plants to trucks; combining some car plants.''
 
Approaching the Top
The eventual promotion of Mr. Stempel to chief executive appeared increasingly likely after his appointment as president and chief operating officer in September 1987. Still, many wondered whether G.M. might cling to its preference for choosing leaders with backgrounds primarily in financial management, like Mr. Smith and his predecessor, Thomas Murphy.
In recent years, however, top automotive executives have been forced to prove their talent in several disciplines, said Philip Caldwell, a retired Ford chief executive who is now a senior managing director of Shearson Lehman Hutton.
Mr. Reuss may have to confront the new management team's most immediate and pervasive difficulties as he tries to match G.M.'s North American production capacity with the demand for G.M. vehicles. He acknowledged that G.M.'s current capacity was appropriate for a 40 percent share of the market, although G.M. now has only about 35 percent.
''We're expecting new Chevrolet and Buick products to pick up additional market share,'' he said.
Mr. Womack of M.I.T. said: ''Basically, G.M.'s domestic business can either lose money or lose market share. At the moment they've chosen to lose money, but the moment they drop rebates, they'll lose share.'' Most analysts share Mr. Womack's assessment that G.M.'s domestic automotive business currently makes little or no profit.
 
Summer Job as a Mechanic
Before being named president, Mr. Stempel ran G.M.'s Buick-Oldsmobile-Cadillac group and was general manager of the Pontiac and Chevrolet divisions. His first automotive experience was a summer job as a service station mechanic in Bloomfield, N.J. He got his start at G.M. as a chassis designer in 1958 and held engineering jobs at Oldsmobile, most notably as a designer of the 1966 Toronado, which was considered an innovative example of front-wheel drive.
In 1980 he became managing director of G.M's Adam Opel subsidiary in West Germany, which makes him one of the few top G.M. executives to have gained international experience.
Mr. Stempel has a bachelor's degree in mechanical engineering from Worcester Polytechnic Institute in Massachusetts and a master's degree in business administration from Michigan State University. He is married and has three children.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Cellular Phones: Room for Three?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
EVER wonder why cellular mobile telephones, the communications miracle of the 1980's, cost so much to use? One corporate maverick, Federal Digital Cellular, claims to know the answer: monopoly power. It is asking Federal regulators to make room for a third cellular phone competitor in each city.
There is, however, a giant catch: The slice of the airwaves the company wants is already being used by GTE Mobile Communications to operate air-to-ground pay phones on domestic airliners.
Putting this piece of radio spectrum up for grabs would put GTE's Airfones out of business. Perhaps more significant politically, it would threaten the interests of established cellular telephone companies, whose lock on mobile communications is now valued in the tens of billions of dollars. 
In the mid-1970's A.T.&T. estimated that by 1990 just 100,000 Americans would be willing to shell out $100 or more each month for the luxury of phones in their cars and briefcases. Competition-minded policy analysts thus thought they had scored a victory in convincing the Federal Communications Commission to make room for second cellular systems, independent of the local phone company, in every metropolitan area.
But the cellular phone has proved to be the biggest electronic hit since the Walkman. The investment firm of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette now predicts that the current army of 3.5 million cellular subscribers will mushroom to 26 million by 1998. Cellular phone companies must race to keep the supply of circuits ahead of demand.
It is not surprising then that franchise holders are not competing on the price of calling time. According to Paul Kagan Associates, a consulting firm, mature cellular systems enjoy a 60 percent profit margin on sales - five times the average margin for regulated public utilities.
Cellular franchises, by custom freely tradable once they have been assigned, now change hands for about $200 per resident. This figure implies that the right to run one of the two cellular systems in every big city is worth a staggering $37 billion.
One way to prevent consumers from being gouged would be to regulate rates. But the F.C.C. is loath to extend its reach in an area of rapid innovation and productivity improvement.
The alternative, Federal Digital Cellular argues, is to carve out enough room on the airwaves for a third competitor in each market. Little space would be needed, the company asserts. While the two current systems take up 50 megahertz of spectrum, a third using new digital technology could be squeezed into four megahertz.
As a practical matter, however, the only chunk of spectrum available is the one used for air-to-ground phones. In April 1988 the commission proposed to convert GTE's experimental license, issued in 1984, into what would amount to a permanent entitlement. Federal Digital Cellular is now petitioning to reopen the proceedings.
Some members of the commission staff are reported to be reluctant to undo a completed deal. And no one is eager to penalize GTE for its innovation in air-to-ground communications, or disrupt Airfone service to consumers. But a number of considerations may yet convince the regulators to think again.
Even by GTE's optimistic revenue projections, the potential value of a third cellular franchise in major markets is at least five times as great as the value of Airfone service. Air-to-ground service, moreover, could be accommodated on higher radio frequencies by using satellites. Indeed, one company, the American Mobile Satellite Corporation, is already licensed for the service and expects to be in operation this year.
Federal Digital Cellular's real ace in the hole, however, may lie in the White House. The Bush Administration has taken no public position on how best to allocate the contested chunk of spectrum, and is not likely to do so.
But as part of the effort to meet the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction targets in 1991, Administration budgeters projected $3 billion in revenue from a new system of auctioning communications rights to the highest bidders. And it is virtually inconceivable that the goal could be met without earmarking the most desirable portions of the unallocated spectrum to cellular phones.
A reopening of the proceedings would not necessarily mean victory for proponents of the third cellular option. But it would give them a chance to make their case - and perhaps make a side deal with GTE to drop out of the contest. After all, if additional cellular service is so much more valuable than current air-to-ground service, there ought to be some way to compensate GTE for its loss of the franchise and still come out ahead.

HEADLINE: Leading Indicators Plunge by 1%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 3

 BODY:
The Government's main gauge of future economic growth plunged by 1 percent in February, its steepest drop in nine months, the Commerce Department said today. But analysts said the decrease was misleading.
The index of leading economic indicators - intended to forecast economic activity in the next six to nine months - wiped out three months of increases with the largest decline since a 1.1 percent fall last May. 
But analysts said the report was an aberration caused by a record 25 percent drop in building permits in February from January's 26.8 percent gain as builders took advantage of warm weather and tried to beat deadlines for new governmental regulations.
 
'Distorting Effects'
''It would have been down just two-tenths of 1 percent without the distorting effect of the building permits,'' said David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a dealer in government securities in New York.
Gilbert Benz, an economist with the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York, said the gauge would bounce back next month to its levels of late 1989 and early 1990. The index rose one-tenth of 1 percent in November, four-tenths in December and two-tenths in January.
Nevertheless, seven of the 11 statistics in the index were down, which analysts interpreted as meaning a soft economy, particularly in the manufacturing sector.
 
Rebound Called Unlikely
''February's leading indicators show a substantial industrial rebound is unlikely to occur in the next six months,'' said William K. MacReynolds, forecasting director for the Chamber of Commerce.
But Lanston's Mr. Jones said that ''recent signals suggest that while the goods-producing sector is still flat, it's not getting any worse and there's no evidence that its weakness is spreading to other sectors.''
According to a recent survey of 51 top economists by Blue Chip Economic Indicators in Sedona, Ariz., the gross national product - the nation's output of goods and services - will avoid a recession and grow 1.7 percent in 1990.
But the survey concluded that the economic outlook ''remains the most sluggish since the recession year of 1982.'' The economy grew 3 percent last year, although it slowed to 1.1 percent in the final quarter.
 
Other Data Show Declines
In addition to building permits, other statistics contributing to the index's decline in February were faster business delivery times, lower stock prices, a decline in plant and equipment orders, a decrease in the price of raw materials, a decline in the backlog of manufacturers' unfilled orders and a drop in an index that measures consumer confidence.
Three of the components were positive, including an increase in orders for consumer goods, a gain in the money supply and a drop in weekly unemployment claims.
One indicator, the length of the average workweek, was unchanged.
The various changes left the index at 144 percent of its 1982 base of 100. The index fell six-tenths of 1 percent from September through February after declining five-tenths of 1 percent the previous six months.

HEADLINE: House Approves Latin Aid; Senate Troubled by Priorities

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 3

 BODY:
The House approved a special spending bill today that provides nearly all the money President Bush requested for Panama and Nicaragua, including $30 million to demobilize and resettle the Nicaraguan rebels.
But the $2.4 billion bill for additions to 1990 spending faces a difficult passage through the Senate, and the maneuvering over it in both chambers foreshadows bigger battles on foreign aid later this year, when Congress takes up the 1991 budget.
The $2.4 billion includes $420 million for Panama and $300 million for Nicaragua. Mr. Bush had requested $500 million for Panama, but under an agreement with the Administration, $30 million of that sum was allocated for aid to Africa to replace a similar amount that had been taken from the African account and used for an initial package of aid for Panama earlier this year. 
The bill also includes more than $1 billion in additional spending for domestic programs including food stamps, veterans affairs, low-income-energy assistance and fighting forest fires. Most of this total spending was offset by rescinding money that had been approved last year as part of the 1990 Pentagon budget.
 
Where to Allocate Resources?
Lawmakers are divided on priorities. Many are torn between the obligation they feel to address long-neglected domestic needs, to assist the emerging democracies in Eastern Europe, and to aid Latin American nations whose economies are in shambles as a result of American economic or military action.
Before the House agreed to the spending bill, 362 to 59, it defeated a series of amendments by Representative James A. Traficant Jr., Democrat of Ohio, that would have cut the foreign-assistance money by 5 percent. "I know I'm going to be called a demagogue or un-American, but I'm tired of seeing the money go all over except to America," Mr. Traficant said. "I'm not going to vote for another cut in programs for American kids, for housing, for education, for infrastructure."
On Monday, the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maine, served notice that he would oppose the President's full request until the Administration provides a comprehensive long-term plan spelling out American foreign aid objectives and explaining how they are to be met, given current budget constraints.
Mr. Mitchell did not specify what amount of aid he would favor or when the Senate might act. But in a letter to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, Mr. Mitchell sharply criticized the Administration for making "piecemeal" special requests without any thought to an overall strategy.
"The Administration asks that we approve a one-shot infusion to Panama and Nicaragua by cutting the defense budget," Mr. Mitchell said in a floor speech. "But they provide no information for the long-term needs in Panama and Nicaragua. And what about Eastern Europe? What about other parts of the world?"
 
Deadline Likely to Pass
Even the House's seemingly straightforward approval involves complications that make it unlikely that the aid money will be in place by April 25, when the newly elected government of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro is to take power in Nicaragua. None of the money in the House bill can be spent until a separate piece of legislation setting guidelines for the assistance is approved. That legislation is stalled in committee pending discussions between the Administration and House members over aid to El Salvador. The House Speaker, Representative Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, said:
"I do not think all of the funding has to be provided immediately. I think the important thing probably is to provide some assurance to the Governments of Panama and Nicaragua that we are going to provide assistance."

HEADLINE: CASTRO UNBENDING ON CUBA'S FUTURE

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAVANA, April 4

 BODY:
Thumbing his nose at a changing world, President Fidel Castro is embellishing one of his sturdiest themes, the resolute defiance of tiny Cuba against its gargantuan neighbor, the United States.
Now all but alone in the vanguard of hard-line Communist leaders, Mr. Castro is asking his people to join him in resisting the political and economic change that has swept his closest allies even as he prepares to ask for greater sacrifice, Calling Cuba ''the symbol of resistance, the symbol of the defense of revolutionary ideals,'' Mr. Castro rejected any profound restructuring of Cuban society at a news conference on Tuesday. ''The road of concessions is the road of submission,'' he said.
If Cubans have to fight, alone and to the death to preserve their revolution, Mr. Castro insisted they would do so proudly. ''If you ask, are we going to adopt a capitalist system, we will say no,'' he said in a two-hour performance Of those who speculate on the demise of his Government, he said, ''I am sure they are wrong.'' 
 
Change Called Necessary
But for all the Cuban leader's fervor about the correctness and durability of his revolutionary course, diplomats from both East and West in Havana say that to avoid economic catastrophe Mr. Castro's Government must quickly see its way to change.
''The Cubans are trying their best to get hard currency,'' a Soviet official said. ''This is their No. 1 problem. I think the Cubans in the future must develop deeper economic relations with the West, but the only way I see is by improving relations with the United States.''
Asked whether the Soviet Union, with serious economic difficulties of its own, would maintain its huge aid program to Cuba, the Soviet official said, ''I don't think it is possible for us to cut off our aid abruptly.''
Even though he said current levels of Soviet aid would likely last at least five more years, the official said the Cuban Government must ''take into consideration the situation'' and ''look for higher efficiency in our cooperation.''
 
Russian Expresses Frustration
In January, when an interruption in Soviet shipments to Cuba temporarily caused shortages of bread and other food items, speculation was rife that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, weary of Cuban oratory interpreted as critical of his policies, had decided to rein in Mr. Castro by reminding him of his economic dependency on Moscow.
Denying that there was any such message, the Soviet official nonetheless expressed frustration with what he said was the Cuban Government's failure to use its resources properly and build stocks of critical staples.
''Because of this, everything depends upon the arrival of our ships,'' the official said. ''The Cubans must take some steps to deal with this situation. They should have done this long ago; we have been telling them this all along.''
Western diplomats here agree that Cuba desperately needs to produce foreign exchange, but there is an increasing sense that with important economic relationships dissolving in Eastern Europe, it will not be able to develop hard currency earnings quickly enough to keep its economy from crumbling.
 
Serious Problems Predicted
''They face a whole range of problems and shortages even if the Soviets do what they can to help,'' said a Western diplomat who spoke on the condition of anonymity. ''There are going to be some very, very serious economic problems. They have already started, but next year will probably be the crunch.''
The diplomat credited Mr. Castro with taking good propaganda advantage from the United States' mostly unsuccessful trial efforts to broadcast television programs to Cubans recently, but said distractions of that kind will quickly be followed by daily reminders for the Cuban people of their economic hardships.
''For the moment he has blurred the image of standing alone on the lonely island,'' the Western diplomat said. Referring to the United States television broadcasts, he added, ''TV Marti has sailed up and rescued Robinson Crusoe, but the real serious problems he faces haven't gone away.''

HEADLINE: Why Tax Apartment Dwellers More?

 BODY:
With New York City's budget gap widening, a painful rise in the real property tax rate becomes inevitable. Property valuation under present law makes the pain much worse for apartment house dwellers and commercial tenants than for homeowners. The impending increase can force attention to the need for reform. 
An unfair valuation system requires apartment house owners and their tenants - including residents of co-ops and condos - to pay $4.17 per $100 of market value. The typical homeowner, however, pays only 84 cents per $100. The reason for this striking disparity is political timidity.
The city's appraisers have long favored low valuations for single-family homes because their owners, receiving tax bills directly from the city, are not only numerous, but quick to respond angrily to increases. In 1975 the State Court of Appeals, noting the unfair appraisals, ruled that the law required all properties to be taxed according to a fair estimate of their true market value.
Instead of changing the valuation process, members of the Legislature changed the law that mandated equality. They replaced it in 1983, with a law that divides properties into four major classes - homes, apartment houses, public utility property and commercial property. Each class was expected to contribute the same fraction of total real estate taxes it paid under previous law.
But the law gave New York City the right to vary the share of total tax revenue that homeowners pay by 5 percent a year and limited the increase in valuation of any individual home. Instead of using the 5 percent flexibility to raise the valuations of Class I, the ''homes'' class, to approach the valuation standard of the other classes, the city used it to lower Class I values, thus widening the gap.
If Mayor David Dinkins, the Legislature and the City Council raise the real estate tax to close the budget gap, they need to remedy its glaring flaw by requiring the city to increase Class I's share of total tax by 5 percent a year while reducing other classes proportionately. And any cap on valuation increases ought to apply to all properties.
Inequitable taxes discourage investment in apartment houses and create immediate problems for commercial and industrial tenants. Requiring homeowners to pick up more of their share would serve the economy as well as fairness.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Sit-In Movement Had Origins Outside the South

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Pioneer of Sit-In Movement Remembered'' by Prof. Louis Jolyon West (letter, March 15), on Clara Luper's 1958 Oklahoma City sit-in with a group of black schoolchildren at the lunch counter of a large drugstore, contains at least one factual error and one critical omission.
The error is in the sequence of the sit-ins he discusses. The Wichita, Kan., sit-ins at the Dockum Drug stores took place for several weeks in the spring of 1958, and the management desegregated the stores by early summer. I was president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People youth chapter that led the Wichita demonstrations.
The Oklahoma City sit-ins occurred in the fall of 1958 and, as the letter suggests, Clara Luper was a driving force as the youth N.A.A.C.P. chapter's adult adviser. The omission, however, is that adequate attention has never been given to the role of my Oklahoma City counterpart, the courageous Barbara Posey, then 16 years old, who daily faced down harassment in leading the Oklahoma City N.A.A.C.P. youth chapter in those sit-ins. Now Dr. Barbara Jones, she is an economist at Prairie View State University in Texas.
Someday the connection between these Kansas and Oklahoma sit-ins and the so-called first sit-ins in Greensboro, N.C., in 1960 - also sparked by N.A.A.C.P. youth movement people - will be understood (see Aldon Morris's ''Origins of the Civil Rights Movement,'' New York, 1984). Until then, the origins of the civil rights movement will have a Southern emphasis, which makes dramatic stuff for book prizes and television documentaries, but ignores the struggle for justice by blacks elsewhere in the country.
 
RONALD WALTERS
Professor of Political Science
Howard University
 Washington, March 19, 1990

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Overkill in Panama

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
On the same day the U.S. invaded Panama last December, the Lithuanian Communist Party declared its independence from the overall Soviet party. In an article on Dec. 22, 1989, I pointed out that the news from Lithuania had been ''little noticed among the headlines'' about Panama.
In the same article, President Bush was urged to provide quick and ''convincing evidence'' in support of a major reason he had given for the invasion - ''eminent danger to the 35,000 American citizens in Panama'' from the Government controlled by Manuel Antonio Noriega.
As usual, both in the press and in the public mind, the dramatic use of armed force in Panama was rewarded with greater attention (and an inflated poll standing for Mr. Bush) than were nonviolent and faraway political events. But more than three months later, it's clear that that first step in Lithuania's movement for national independence was of more lasting importance than any of the sins and threats of General Noriega. 
It's not so widely realized that Mr. Bush has not yet provided the evidence to prove his claim of ''eminent danger'' to Americans in Panama. In the continued absence of such evidence, or any White House effort to provide it, it's reasonable to conclude that there isn't any, or not much.
The trigger for the invasion was the killing of a single U.S. soldier while he was running a Panamanian roadblock in a restricted zone. That was deplorable but insufficient cause either to envision a real threat to the lives of 35,000 other Americans, or to warrant a costly military invasion of a sovereign nation. Mr. Bush and Administration spokesmen also spoke of danger to the Panama Canal. But Gen. Colin Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, has pointed out that 14,000 U.S. troops, a force ''quite adequate'' to defend the canal from General Noriega, were in Panama before the invasion. That force, on the face of it, also seems adequate to the defense of all American residents against whatever threat existed.
Nor was the operation a necessary anti-drug action. Even if General Noriega was up to his neck in illicit drug traffic as late as 1989, the huge dollar cost of a military operation involving 24,000 troops would have been better devoted to providing drug treatment slots in the U.S. Now additional millions must be spent to make up for economic losses inflicted on Panama by the U.S. during and before the invasion.
No wonder, then, that William Webster, the Director of the C.I.A., has said that ''we made a mistake in overemphasizing the importance of Noriega.'' And no wonder that lawyers for the dictator charge that Operation Just Cause - the ludicrous code name for the invasion - was ''outrageous'' and ''the first time the U.S. has invaded a country and leveled it to arrest one man.'' Such drastic ''justice,'' they might have said, was never considered in the cases of the brutal Anastasio Somoza of Nicaragua, or any of the several murderous generals who have ruled Guatemala, or Papa and Baby Doc Duvalier in Haiti.
General Noriega's lawyers further claim that because of these circumstances all charges against him ought to be dismissed. But an illegal arrest - which is essentially what the defense contends the general suffered -has never been grounds for dropping charges against a defendant; and recently the Supreme Court ruled that the U.S. Constitution does not protect a foreigner against the actions of U.S. agents in a foreign country.
Sending 24,000 troops to bag Manuel Noriega nevertheless is likely to stand in the history of overkill higher even than Ronald Reagan's Grenada operation. This long after the invasion, for example, Washington is not able to state with any certainty how many Panamanian civilians died; some estimates range into the thousands and most of them substantially exceed the official U.S. death count - 202 civilians and 314 soldiers.
Even taking the latter figures at face value, and adding the 23 American soldiers killed in the invasion, 539 people lost their lives as the primary human cost of putting handcuffs on one thug. But when a defense lawyer referred to ''indiscriminate'' U.S. firepower, Judge William M. Hoeveler protested that ''a war was going on - why do you say it was indiscriminate?''
He did not say what word would have been better, or how a ham-fisted exercise in executive muscle-flexing could be distinguished as a war.

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
We Are Warned

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
Once more we have been clearly warned and once more we have a choice.
We can accept the plain warning of mass murder to come, and act to prevent it. Or we can say again that no man could be that evil, no nation could follow his madness, he is bluffing - and do nothing.
The first choice will mean that the major nations of the world will lose a profitable business - the death trade. 
The other choice will mean that peace will not come for generations to one of the most important areas of the world, perhaps never. Quite likely, hundreds of thousands of people will die as the result of our decision.
In fact, the new warning is a direct threat to the lives of millions, not thousands. But even now the civilized mind cannot encompass that.
No, even though that first warning, which came from Adolf Hitler, resulted in the death of scores of millions.
Hitler proclaimed what he intended to do - wipe out the Jews and then rule the world. But until the day he started the war against the world -even after - the world said he could not mean it, impossible.
A half-century later, a new statement of intent to kill - this one from Saddam Hussein, dictator of Iraq. He rules absolutely and commands one of the largest armed forces - air, ground and missile - in the world.
He wants to wipe out the Jews of Israel and rule the Middle East. He has made that as clear as ''Mein Kampf.''
Nations in other parts of the world already toady to him and his power. What will they do then? Dictator Hussein told the world that he would annihilate ''half of Israel'' with missile-delivered chemical weapons if Israel ''tries to do anything'' against Iraq, now only a few years from the nuclear bomb.
Please, no delusions about timing. If already he intends to use missiles and chemical weapons, against Israel as he did against Iran and his own Kurdish population, Saddam Hussein will not wait passively until Israel attacks.
He will decide when the moment has come, because of Israeli loss of strength or allies, to strike for the ultimate goal, annihilation of Israel. Then he will do what every dictator does - claim provocation by the enemy.
Afterward the great powers will try to forget who gave him the missiles, chemicals and the nuclear technology. They all did - the United States, Britain, the Soviet Union, China, France, Germany, Italy and Japan. For love of money they gave these things to him.
Mass murderers like Hitler and Hussein have a deep urge to tell the world of their blood lusts. That is their weakness - but only if the rest of the world believes, and acts.
The Western powers and the Soviet Union have it within their power to stop Hussein before he strikes.
All exports and imports involving Iraq should be embargoed - all, arms, technology, food, oil - and seized as contraband whenever found. All air traffic to and from Iraq should be banned, all.
In a year or two this would break Iraqi economic power. But it would leave him with the missiles, chemical bombs and nuclear technology sold to him by the West and the Communist world.
The only way to deal with that is to make it officially clear that if he uses those missiles and weapons of hell against Israel he can expect strong and swift military retaliation from the nations that armed him.
But united action is not likely. Neither the Soviet Union nor our allies show any appetite for anything that would reduce their Middle Eastern profits. They seem hungrier than ever.
American business also knows how to crowd around the Iraqi trough. American electronic technology helps the Iraqis turn out their long-range missiles.
But even alone the U.S. could stop the death trade. It would take the political courage to carry out two steps - the declaration of embargo against Iraq, and a clear statement that any country that did continue to sell materials or technology of war to the Iraqis would face heavy economic penalties from the United States.
These are precisely the steps needed to stop Iran and Syria from being paymasters and safe havens for the terrorists. That never happened; all we have had are mutters and whines.
Still, just faintly possibly, Iraq's open threat to use chemical weapons again might stir the Bush Administration to take world leadership and initiative at last.
The least the rest of us can do is shout out to believe this man Hussein - he intends to kill.

TYPE: OP-ED

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1225 words

HEADLINE: Behind Atlantic City's Glitz Lies Decay 878>

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY, April 4

 BODY:
The grandmotherly ladies on the three-acre casino floor cooed, ''Donald, Donald, there's Donald,'' when Donald J. Trump sauntered onto the floor to open the Taj Mahal on Monday, but most of them continued to pump money into his slot machines without letup.
The result was that the Taj, as everyone calls Mr. Trump's $1 billion extravaganza, broke all records for an opening day of play, $925,000 in just eight hours.
It was an auspicious opening for the huge casino, billed as the world's largest, though that claim is contested in both Las Vegas and Monaco. Yet it came amid a tide of concern for the future of Atlantic City's $3-billion-a-year casino industry, and indeed for the viability of this city.
The casino industry is at a crisis point, with most analysts saying that the clientele is at the saturation stage. And the city has yet to benefit substantially from the 12 years of casino gambling that was supposed to save it from decay. 
''People look at Atlantic City and say it's a toilet,'' said Seth Grossman, a City Councilman who is one of seven candidates running for mayor next month in a campaign dominated by questions of corruption and racial politics. ''I say you're looking at the future of urban America.'' That is perhaps hyperbole, but Atlantic City is perhaps given to excess. Mr. Trump bills his new casino, his third, as ''the eighth wonder of the world.''
At the opening Monday, only the casino's 3,010 slot machines were taking in real money. Other players had to be satisfied with ''funny money'' - scrip used to test operations monitored by New Jersey's Casino Control Commission, which approved the Taj Mahal for full-scale operation today and its official grand opening on Thursday.
''I think Donald is fixing to make some money,'' said Al Glasgow, publisher of Atlantic City Action, a gaming industry newsletter, and a consultant to Mr. Trump and other Atlantic City casinos.
''Donald Trump is the baby boomer's Howard Hughes,'' he said.
The image of the button-downed Mr. Trump is at odds with the eccentricities of Mr. Hughes, the billionaire who shuffled about with his feet in tissue boxes to protect himself from contamination. But there is no question that Mr. Trump now dominates the Atlantic City gambling industry in the same way that Mr. Hughes dominated Las Vegas in the 50's and 60's.
 
A Pervasive Influence
With the opening of the Taj Mahal, Mr. Trump now controls nearly a third of the town's gaming tables and 40 percent of its top-line hotel rooms and convention space.
So pervasive has the Trump influence become on the casino industry in Atlantic City that the Casino Control Commission held months of hearings before granting Mr. Trump a license for the Taj Mahal, and before that, allowing him to buy the failed Atlantis.
He is allowed to operate the Atlantis as only a hotel, since with the Taj Mahal he has reached the state's limit of three casinos. The others are the Trump Castle and the Trump Plaza.
Not everyone thinks the Taj Mahal will be another winner for Mr. Trump. One industry analyst, Marvin B. Roffman, recently questioned the Taj Mahal's prospects for success because of the $1 million a day that the casino must bring in to meet its huge debt.
Mr. Trump reacted to the criticism by demanding a retraction and an apology. When Mr. Roffman refused, his Philadelphia brokerage firm, Janney Montgomery Scott, dismissed him.
 
'We'll Break Every Record'
A smiling Mr. Trump flashed a victory sign in his big hall, but bridled a bit at questions about the casino's chances for success. Analysts say it may not be all that difficult for the casino to take in $1 million a day, given that the Trump Plaza, half the size of the Taj Mahal, logged a gross win of $850,000 a day last year.
''I think we'll break every record in the business,'' Mr. Trump said.
Beyond the question of what effect the Taj Mahal will have on the gambling industry - some analysts warn that if the Taj Mahal succeeds, other casinos could fail - the opening comes at a time when Atlantic City is at a critical crossroads.
Three recent Mayors have been convicted of corruption, and the incumbent, James L. Usry, is awaiting trial. Crime is rampant, racial tensions are intense, half the city's population receives public assistance, residents continue to leave the city and vast areas have been boarded up or bulldozed in the face of a critical housing shortage.
The 12 casinos here represent more than $5 billion worth of glass, concrete and steel, but Atlantic City is a small town. In the last census, it had about 37,000 people, down 20 percent since 1976, when casino gambling was approved, and still declining. By most estimates, the population will be down to about 30,000 when the new census figures are released.
But the city supports 33 million visits a year from gaming patrons - about 7 million people making multiple trips to the gaming tables - and that makes Atlantic City what Councilman Grossman calls ''a small town with the visibility and problems of a metropolis.''
''And we still only have the voting power of a small town,'' he added. #48,000 Work in Casinos The town is the workplace of about 48,000 casino employees, some 7,000 of them in the Taj Mahal alone.
The taxes on the casinos provide about two-thirds of the town's annual tax income of about $130 million. It is not the lack of tax income that plagues the city, its critics say.
''It's a lack of leadership,'' said City Councilman Jim Whelan, another candidate for mayor, who admits he is not without bias. But he is not alone. Spurred by the city's long history of corruption, including the charges that Mayor Usry took a $6,000 bribe from a Boardwalk vendor, the Assembly is considering legislation to put control of the city government in the hands of a state-controlled commission.
That, says Councilman Grossman, is not only a denial of local self government, but also a result of state prosecutors trying to make a name for themselves by prosecuting city officials.
''What causes mayors in Atlantic City to go to jail is that we're a prosecutor's dream,'' said Mr. Grossman, who is also such a sharp a critic of the incumbent Mayor that he is often accused of racial politics. Mr. Usry is black and Mr. Grossman is white.
 
'What You Must Do'
Mr. Grossman is not the only one accused of racial politics.
This week, a four-page circular distributed in the predominantly black section of town and attributed to Mr. Usry made what appeared to be an overtly racial appeal.
''There is nothing that anyone can say about me,'' the circular read, ''that you don't already know - for the color of my skin tells the true story. Deep down in your heart you know what you must do and on May 8, 1990, you will do it.'' The circular asks ''my people'' to re-elect Mr. Usry.
The Mayor was in New Orleans attending the Conference of Black Mayors. An administrative assistant, Rosalind Norrell-Nance, said, ''He doesn't even know there had been any flak about it,'' and said there would be no immediate response to accusations from other candidates that the appeal was clearly racial.
Ms. Norell-Nance said Mr. Usry would be back for the official opening of the Taj Mahal on Thursday. ''The Mayor is very optimistic the Taj will bring a very positive force to gaming and to the city,'' she said.

HEADLINE: As Bush Hails Progress by Blacks, Veto Is Seen on Rights Bill

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, D.C., April 4

 BODY:
As his Administration threatened to veto new civil rights legislation, President Bush tonight told a black audience that he dreamed of the day that a black man or woman would occupy the White House.
''The day will come - and it is not far off - when the legacy of Lincoln will finally be fulfilled at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, when a black man or woman will sit in the Oval Office,'' Mr. Bush told a dinner honoring the 20th anniversary of The Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a research group devoted to the role of blacks in America.
He continued, ''When that day comes the most remarkable thing about it will be how naturally it occurs.'' 
The President's comments came only hours after the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee approved, 11 to 5, and sent to the floor a bill that would strengthen Federal protection against racial harassment on the job and would shift back to employers the burden of proof on a key issue in some employment discrimination cases.
 
Bill to Counteract Court Rulings
The bill, which was drafted to reverse several Supreme Court rulings last year, would also sharply limit lawsuits that challenge court-approved agreements on affirmative action plans to reduce discrimination.
In a letter to Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh threatened to recommend a veto of the bill saying the Administration opposes ''any legislation that would encourage quota systems or otherwise divide our society along racial lines.''
Members of the audience tonight said the President's statement and Mr. Thornburgh's letter were contradictory. Eleanor Holmes Norton, a law professor at Georgetown University, said: ''All I can say is the President forgot one item. He forgot to explain himself for his untimely action. Blacks will find it unacceptable for the President to come to dinner and then go home and veto bills that are critical to our progress.''
 
'Very Unkind Action'
Ronald Brown, the national chairman of the Democratic Party, said, ''I am particularly distressed in view of the gracious nature of the press appearance that we've seen another example of kinder and gentler rhetoric and very unkind action by the Adminstration.''
Roger Wilkins, a professor of history and American culture at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va., went through the ballroom at the Washington Hilton pointing out the statements to other dinner guests.
Mr. Brown, who was on the dais, described the civil rights act in an interview as the most important piece of civil rights legislation in 25 years and said the Administration threat to veto it was ''a disgrace.''
In his speech Mr. Bush also teased Jesse Jackson, who was in the lobby of the hotel at the time of the address. Mr. Bush spoke of his visits to black ghettos, saying he wondered which of the children could someday reach the Oval Office. ''Jesse,'' the President said, ''I'm talking about little kids. I'm not talking about 49-year-old guys. Let's not rush it.''
