HEADLINE: GARDENING;
For Annuals, a Renaissance

BYLINE: By LINDA YANG

 BODY:
THE title, ''The Importance of Being Annual,'' seemed innocuous enough. Yet when Steven Frowine delivered his talk on annual flowers in October at the New York Botanical Garden, it came smack in the middle of a symposium on perennials, the plants that have been in the horticultural limelight for close to a decade.
But garden fashions come in waves. And notwithstanding the clamor for perennials, the consistent rise in interest in annuals has not gone unnoticed by commercial suppliers. ''Annuals are inexpensive and give gardeners immediate gratification and quick effects,'' said Mr. Frowine, who is the nursery merchandise director of the W. Atlee Burpee Company in Warminster, Pa. ''Traditionally, perennial flower beds were not supposed to be tainted with other plants, but I think that attitude's really changing now.'' 
Annuals differ from perennials in that they go from seed to flower to death within a year, while perennials can live for several years. True annuals, like marigolds and morning glories, are stalwart bloomers, and are further distinguished from perennials by their ability to add carefree color, nearly nonstop, all summer.
''The feeling we get from commercial growers is that the market boom in perennials is not quite what it was,'' said Terry Humfeld, the executive director of the Professional Plant Growers Association in Lansing, Mich. ''I suspect that people are now finding that perennials are not exactly the low-maintenance plants they sought, and it's hard to plot a garden filled with color all season.''
Mr. Humfeld's group specializes in growing annuals and other similar mass-flowering plants better known as bedding species. These are sold as seedlings at garden centers and nurseries, and include the many colorful geraniums and begonias, which regularly outsell all other kinds of flowers.
While interest in perennials grew through the 1980's, annuals ''continued to go like gangbusters,'' said Alvi Voigt, a professor of agriculture economics at Pennsylvania State University who monitors the industry for the grovers' association. He said bedding-plant sales for the 50 states were about $61 million in 1970. By 1979, they had more than quadrupled, to $285 million. Although not all of the 1989 figures have been tallied, Professor Voigt said the numbers he has seen have led him to expect conclude that the decade's sales total will again show a quadruple increase in sales.
''In the last few years, we saw that some of our most popular annuals were used for special situations,'' said Klaus Neubner, the vice chair man and executive vice president of the Park Seed Company in Green wood, S.C.
There was, for example, globe am aranth or gomphrena, an easily grown, lollipop-shaped flower with white, rose or purple blossoms that are superb for dried arrangements. ''Four years ago, we sold a few thou sand dollars' worth'' of these plants, Mr. Neubner said. ''Last year, sales increased 10 times.''
William John Park, the company's chairman, added, ''We were certainly surprised to experience this rise of interest in this kind of flower.'' And so, Park added to its spring catalogue this year the annuals he lichrysum, a bright yellow bloomer, and Crepis rubra, which has pink blossoms. Both plants are described as especially useful for cutting and drying.
In This year's Burpee catalogue, of fers the number of annuals listed increased at atleast 10 percent more annuals than last year's. ''We wanted to give people more of a choice,'' said Su zanne Bayles, one of the company's owners. ''In particular, we wanted to fill a niche that the garden centers don't.''
Two years ago, the Burpee cata logue began listing several old-fash ioned annuals, like mignonette, a fra grant lavender-hued flower that was popular during the early years of the company, in the late 19th century. Among the more unusual flowers this year are abelmoschus, with pink or red flowers resembling those of its cousin, the hibiscus, and melampo dium, with star-shaped bronze-or ange flowers.
''People seem to be looking at their gardens in a different way,'' said Antoinette Serrell, horticulturist for Thompson & Morgan. Ms. Serrell fields the public's questions for this British mail-order seed company, which has offices in Jackson, N.J. There is definitely more attention be ing paid to annual flowers that were not widely used before, she said.
Ms. Surrell said she has noticed more interest in the annual poppy, for example, which blooms in orange as well as shades of yellow, rose and crimson. Also more popular recently is the annual candytuft, a compact plant with clusters of pink, crimson, red, purple or white flowers that have long-lasting, sculptural seed heads.
''I suspect that once perennials are finished flowering, gardeners want something special to replace them,'' Ms. Surrell said.
Christopher Cohen and Rita Wong are two backyard gardeners who, in recent years, have given over more of their plots to annuals. Mr. Cohen, a landscape architect, and Ms. Wong, an architect, have a This Brooklyn couple's 25-by-40-foot garden is on a sunny site behind their row house in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn.
''We found that in this small space, it was tricky orchestrat ing a good sequence of bloom with perennials, and we really wanted to fill it with long-lasting color immedi ately,'' said Ms. Wong said.
The couple - she's an architect, he's a landscape architect - are partial, in particular, to old-fash ioned varieties like four-o-clocks, whose trumpet-shaped blooms open in midday, and the bell-shaped baby blue eyes. For several years, they have been poring over catalogues looking for seed species that were grown in turn-of-the-century gardens. Some of the old favorites they have planted include heliotrope, larkspur and sweet peas, which were not espe cially successful in the heat of the New York summer.
''There seems to be a trend toward new traditionalism,'' Ms. Wong said. ''It's the idea of home as a cozy bungalow. Part of that idea is a com fortable kind of garden with old-fash ioned annuals in subtle hues and sim ple forms.
''At least when annuals don't work out, you've lost only one season and can move on to something else. You can experiment yearly. It's not like the commitment you must make to perennials. And shrubs are a lifelong endeavor.''
 
Some Colorful Candidates for a Garden
THERE are many more kinds of annual flower shapes, sizes and colors than any gardener has room for. Here are a mere dozen to start:
Blue lace flower: 2 1/2 feet tall; rounded, pale blue, lacy blooms. Browallia: 10 inches; pale purple star-shaped flowers. Cornflower or bachelor's buttons: 18 inches; fluffy round flowers in purple, white or pink. Cosmos: 2 feet; flat flowers in white, pink, red or gold. Heliotrope: 15 inches; clusters of fragrant purple blooms.
Love-in-a-mist or Nigella: 14 inches; flat flowers in white, pink or purple.
Nasturtium: 18 inches; crinkle flowers in yellow, pink and crimson.
Pot marigold or Calendula: 18 inches; round, flat topped flowers in cream, yellow and orange.
Spiderflower or Cleome: 3 feet; spider-like blooms in pink, purple or white.
Torenia or wishbone flower: 9 inches; trumpet-shaped flowers in white, violet or blue.
Verbena: 10 inches; rounded flower clusters in white, pink or purple.
Xeranthemum: 2 feet; daisy-like flowers in white, rose or purple.

LENGTH: 2527 words

HEADLINE: Industry Wary of Clean-Air Bill

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Industrial companies across America reacted with varying degrees of pessimism to the clean-air legislation passed by the Senate on Tuesday. They are resigned to paying billions of dollars in additional pollution-control costs but warn that those costs will be passed on to consumers.
The bill, which appears likely to be the basis of the first Federal clean-air law since 1977, would require auto makers, chemical manufacturers, steelmakers and coal-fired power plants, among others, to make substantial investments in equipment and processes to lower their pollution. The Senate bill now goes to the House of Representatives, where several industries hope for amendments that will make it less stringent. But environmentalists see the House debate as an opportunity for strengthening the legislation. The version of the bill now in a House committee would impose stricter limits in some areas.
The Administration estimates that the cost will be $20 billion a year. Yet some corporations said that more than money is at stake. They said they were not sure how to meet the new requirements at any reasonable cost. Here are the viewpoints of four industries on the legislation. 
 
The Auto Industry
Jump in Cost Seen For Consumers
Auto industry representatives said yesterday that the measure approved by the Senate included standards for the equipment that controls tailpipe emissions that would stretch the limits of their technology and cost consumers a minimum of hundreds of dollars extra for each car.
But those interviewed stopped short of saying the Senate was placing impossible limits on the industry. However, vigorous lobbying in Congress for a less restrictive bill appeared certain, they said.
Thomas Hanna, president of the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association, an industry trade group, said, ''It's an extraordinarily tough bill but it's the best we thought we could get from the Senate, given where some of the parties were.''
The provision in the Senate bill that seems most worrisome to auto makers is a requirement that makes standards for auto tailpipe emissions applicable for 10 years or 100,000 miles starting in 1993, doubling the current longevity standard. The tailpipe standards would reduce oxides of nitrogen 60 percent from the current level and hydrocarbons by 40 percent.
A second round of tailpipe-emission reductions in the year 2004 would halve the 1993 level.
''Anything mechanical deteriorates, especially something underneath a car,'' said Rob Liberatore, a government relations specialist for the Chrysler Corporation, referring to a car's catalytic converter, which removes pollutants from engine emissions. ''To engineer a system that can last this long it has to meet very, very low standards when it's new so it still meets the limits after a decade.'' Can Standards Be Met? Automotive engineers are reluctant to estimate the cost of a pollution-control system that meets the 100,000-mile standard, but Mr. Liberatore said the additional rare metals and other costs certainly would amount to ''several hundred dollars'' a car, which auto makers say they would pass on to consumers.
''We're not sure if we can meet the standard,'' said Donald R. Buist, director of emissions and fuel economy for the Ford Motor Company. ''If we can't, we'll have to go back and see the Government again,'' he said, referring to the mid-1970's, when auto makers obtained a relaxation of regulations because they were not able to meet pollution-control standards.
Auto makers are also wary of a provision in the Senate measure that requires special canisters for cars to trap fumes lost during refueling. The canisters would add $80 to $100 to the cost of a car and the auto makers say they pose a safety hazard in an accident. Instead, the Big Three prefer the solution used in California: a special hose at each gas tank that catches the vapors and collects them underground.
But the auto makers said their picture was not entirely bleak. The Senate failed to impose a fuel-economy provision mandating that each car maker's fleet reach an average of 40 miles a gallon, up from the current 27.5 miles a gallon. That much-discussed proposal is aimed at reducing carbon-dioxide emissions thought to contribute to global warming, by cutting the consumption of gasoline. Auto makers have warned that it could force an end to big-car production. The Senate also did not mandate the production of alternative-fuel cars like those that would burn methanol, which the Environmental Protection Agency had favored. DORON P. LEVIN
 
The Utilities
Delay Is Sought On Cleaner Coal
The bill approved by the Senate is intended to reduce acid rain by cutting 10 million tons a year of sulfur dioxide from the smokestacks of power plants, half of it from generators in the Midwest that burn high-sulfur coal. In addition, companies would be limited after the year 2000 to the amount of sulfur dioxide they emitted in 1985.
''We are extremely disappointed,'' said Thomas S. Ayres of American Electric Power, based in Columbus, Ohio, which serves seven million people in seven states and is in some years the nation's largest purchaser of coal. The company has not had time to analyze the effect of this legislation, he said, but an earlier proposal that would have cut the same amount of sulfur dioxide would have cost $750 million a year. That would be equal to nearly 15 percent of revenues.
If electric prices increased by a similar percentage, the company's residential rate would rise to about 7 cents a kilowatt-hour, which is still a penny under the national average price. Defending the proposed cleanup, William Reilly, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said yesterday that costs would rise for the utilities that are the biggest polluters. But he said that even after the increases, ''almost everywhere, the rates in those areas will be competitive with adjacent areas that have met the performance standards already.''
But coal-burning utilities think the standards could be met at less cost if Congress would delay action while cleaner ways to burn coal are developed. The alternative is to put ''scrubbers'' on existing plants, which are costly to build and require vast amounts of electricity to run.
Another controversial point is the choice of 1985 as the base year. At the Edison Electric Institute, a trade association in Washington, Mary Kenkel, a spokeswoman, said that a recession in the industry in 1985 reduced electricity generation - and thus emissions - to unusually low levels.
Ms. Kenkel and others also complain that the Senate legislation is inflexible. For example, at the Centerior Energy Corporation, which serves more than a million customers in northern Ohio and relies on coal to meet 70 percent of its load, Lee Bailey, a spokesman, complained that the proposed law sets a limit for each plant. ''If we could average over our entire system, it would give us the possibility of scrubbing our two biggest coal units to meet the goal,'' he said. That would be just as effective as putting less-efficient scrubbers on each plant and it would be cheaper, he said.
 
Complaint on Standards
But not only the most polluting utilities have objections. At Wisconsin Electric, which is 60 percent coal-fired, Lisa Berman, a spokeswoman, said the company had reduced sulfur dioxide emissions by 46 percent since 1980, and already meets the standards that would come into effect by 1995 under the legislation voted by the Senate. ''We want to have credit for what we've done so far,'' she said.
For a second round of reductions, taking effect in 2000, Wisconsin Electric would have to switch to lower-sulfur coal or install new equipment or both, at a cost of $125 million to $135 million, she said, raising rates by 8 to 13 percent. The company might retire one of its older coal-fired plants, she said.
Utilities facing growth also complained. At the Florida Power and Light Company, where a growing population is pushing up demand by 4 percent a year, company executives say that the choice of 1985 is especially unfortunate for them because in that year all four of their nuclear plants ran very well, with little time lost for refueling. As a result, they got 35 percent of their power from that sulfur-free source, a percentage that they do not think they can match now.
What the Florida utility would have to do under the proposed legislation is buy the right to emit more pollutants than it did in 1985, according to Gary G. Mehalik, a spokesman. A section in the proposed legislation would allow a company in the Midwest to clean up a coal plant even more stringently than the law requires and ''sell'' the difference. If, for example, a utility in Illinois cut emissions by 1,000 tons a year more than was required, it could sell to Florida Power the right to emit that 1,000 tons.
But he said, ''Our interest is in having our customers protected from having to pay for cleaning up other people's plants.'' MATTHEW L. WALD
 
The Chemical Industry
Permit Process Called a Nightmare
Chemical manufacturers and the trade groups representing them reacted warily yesterday to the clean-air legislation passed by the Senate. ''There's no doubt we are talking about millions of dollars of spending requirements but we haven't made an estimate of the impact on us because so much could change,'' said David Graham, Dow Chemical's environmental issues manager in Washington.
Chemical manufacturers, most of which are major consumers of electricity, say the bill's provisions to reduce acid rain will drive up their energy costs. But the biggest direct impact will come from the provisions dealing with toxic emissions. The most frequently cited areas of concern were the rules for when a permit is necessary, the requirements for applying the best technology available to control the release of toxic chemicals and the process for establishing how high a residual risk for cancer-causing emissions would be acceptable after such control technology had been applied.
Trade groups say the provisions governing the permit process in the Senate bill may be a nightmare, especially for smaller companies. Companies must not only apply for permission to use processes that emit toxic chemicals but also must seek new permits every time the equipment is altered.
''We are concerned with the Draconian enforcement measures, especially things like jail terms and massive fines for paperwork violations,'' said Ronald Lang, executive director of the Synthetic Organic Chemical Manufacturers Association. ''Smaller companies don't have four lawyers backing people up to make sure everything is mailed.''
 
Impact on Innovation Feared
Mr. Graham at Dow said the lack of priorities in the procedures for issuing permits meant that applications for new processes that a company needs to build a new plant or extend a product line might become tied up in piles of requests from other companies - even for something as small as permission to shift the route of a section of piping for routine maintenance. He said companies will be discouraged from making small changes, thus slowing the pace of innovation.
More broadly, several manufacturers said they feared that the requirements that companies use the best available control technology would not be flexible enough to account for the huge variety of chemicals and processes for dealing with them. Standardizing the required technology could drive up expenses for some companies while producing few reductions in emissions.
The bill refers the problem of how to calculate the impact of toxic air emissions on health to the National Academy of Science. At issue is what standards should be applied to residual emissions after industry has met the first-phase goal of cutting emissions by 90 percent. If Congress does not act within five years on the recommendations it receives on how to determine such standards, the provisions now in the bill apply. The chemical industry contends that the current criteria are unreliable and that if they are retained, plants may be needlessly threatened with closure.
 
'Paying Lip Service'
''By referring the matter to N.A.S. but not leaving the standard up to them, Congress is paying lip service to science,'' said Jeffrey Van, a spokesman for the Chemical Manufacturers Association.
Chemical makers were pleased that the House version of the bill was stripped of numeric targets for residual emissions by Representative John D. Dingell's committee on Tuesday.
A number of manufacturers said that some of the major costs in the bill would remain unknown until state and local regulators acted.
Companies that use solvents to process chemicals into more than 700,000 consumer products, from shampoos to antifreeze, had mixed feelings about provisions reducing allowable solvent emissions. The Senate bill ordered a study of the contribution of solvents to depletion of ozone in the atmosphere and a 1 percent reduction in emissions, which was considerably milder than originally proposed, said Ralph Engle, president of the Chemical Specialties Manufacturers Association. The solvents provisions would also affect dry cleaners. BARNABY J. FEDER
 
The Steelmakers
Rules Criticized As 'Arbitrary'
With the passage of the Senate bill, the nation's major steel producers remain unsuccessful in their fight against provisions that would effectively prohibit the further use of coke ovens, the furnaces that convert coal to coke in the making of steel.
The steelmakers are disturbed by a requirement that they eliminate virtually all emissions from coke ovens by the year 2020 and in the meantime adopt the best available emissions-reduction technology by 1995.
Steel industry officials said that meeting the 1995 deadline would cost the industry about $5 billion. They added that there is no technology yet available that would eliminate emissions completely and that the bill's deadline of 2020 would effectively close most of the nation's coke ovens and lead to the loss of thousands of jobs. They maintain that the standard in the Senate bill - the risk of cancer to one resident in 10,000 in a community near a coke oven - is arbitrary.
''The steel industry is opposed to the use of arbitrary, calculated risk-based standards for shutting down coke plants,'' said Walter F. Williams, chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.
Philip X. Masciantonio, vice president of environmental affairs at the USX Corporation, which operates the nation's largest steel company, said the evidence of the extent of the health risk posed by coke ovens was far from conclusive. He said USX had spent more than $250 million in recent years to reduce emissions from its coke ovens.
A number of steel companies in Europe and Japan are developing processes for the manufacture of steel that bypass making coke. But Milton Deaner, president of the American Iron and Steel Institute, described as nonsense the opinion that in a few years the industry would have a steelmaking process that would do away with coke ovens. JONATHAN P. HICKS

HEADLINE: Group of 7 Meeting Is Expected to Be Quiet

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4

 BODY:
The top economic policy makers from the United States and its six main industrial allies, when they meet in Paris Saturday, will discuss the momentous political and economic changes that have swept the world since their last meeting in September: the moves toward free markets in Eastern Europe, the German unification effort and the battering of the Japanese financial markets and the yen.
But, officials say, these issues no more lend themselves to collective solution now than does the continuing deadlock in Washington over the Federal budget. As a result, the officials say that the finance ministers and central bankers are unlikely to reach the kind of agreements on currency and interest rate coordination that have often followed meetings of what is known as the Group of Seven.
''In all the countries, there is a rather intense preoccupation with domestic matters,'' a senior Bush Administration official said this week. As important as the international ramifications are, this official and others said, the issues must for the time being be tackled on a country-by-country basis. 
Besides Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, the meeting will be attended by the finance ministers and central bank heads from Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada.
They will meet at France's new Finance Ministry building in a neighborhood called Bercy on the Right Bank of the Seine. If some agreement is reached, it will doubtless be called the ''Bercy Accord,'' like the Plaza Accord in 1985, after the New York hotel, and the Louvre Accord in 1987.
A Treasury official said the United States had called the meeting ''primarily for economic surveillance,'' so the countries could ''take account of the consistency and compatibility of our various policies.'' He said he doubted that a joint communique would be issued at the conclusion and added, ''I think it would be quite a successful meeting if we don't make news.''
Normally such meetings are held early in the year. But Mr. Brady was unable to travel in January because he was recuperating from hip surgery, and the British and Canadians were tied up with budget presentations in February and March.
 
Meetings Scheduled for May
The Group of Seven officials are scheduled to meet again early next month in conjunction with the semiannual meetings in Washington of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
Economists and other students of international finance disagree over whether the time is right for further joint action on interest rates and exchange rates.
On one side, Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacurers, argued this week that American businesses were seriously threatened by the rise in interest rates associated with German unification and with the rise in the value of the dollar relative to the yen.
The United States, he asserted, should negotiate to lower its interest rates, while the Japanese raise theirs, and West Germany should be encouraged to slow its move toward monetary union with East Germany to minimize financial disturbances.
 
A New Set of Issues
But Mickey D. Levy, chief economist at the First Fidelity Bancorporation in Philadelphia, argued in an interview that the changing economic conditions in West Germany and Japan were caused entirely by internal conditions and that it was in the American interest that the meeting not try to realign interest rates or exchange rates.
''For the first time in a long time,'' Mr. Levy said, ''United States-specific issues like the budget deficit or the strong dollar are not the key focus of a meeting like this, and we should sit back and enjoy it.''
United States policy makers agree with Mr. Levy on this point. Mr. Brady rejected a Japanese request two weeks ago for help in stabilizing the falling yen, saying that the yen's problems resulted from Japan's own political and economic situation.
The Finance Minister of Japan, Ryutaro Hashimoto, said in Tokyo this week that he did not expect the officials in Paris to shore up the yen.
 
A Matter of Stature
Another factor that works against a unified stand this weekend is that the finance ministers in the three largest countries - the United States, Japan and West Germany - do not have the same standing as their predecessors in the late 1980's.
For instance, unlike James A. Baker 3d, who was indisputably in charge of economic policy in the Reagan years, Mr. Brady shares authority in the Bush Administration with Richard G. Darman, the budget director, and John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff.
Mr. Hashimoto is regarded as one of Japan's rising political stars and is a possible future Prime Minister. But he has been Finance Minister only since August.
The Finance Minister of West Germany, Theo Waigel, has also been on the job less than a year, and he was recently embarrassed politically by the Chancellor, Helmut Kohl. Mr. Waigel announced last weekend that his Government's policy was to exchange one West German mark for each two East German marks. After a political furor arose, Mr. Kohl said that was not the policy after all.
''In all the Big Three,'' said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics here, ''there's been a significant dimunition in the stature of the key players.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
A New Buyout Firm Finds Salt to Its Liking

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
D. G. Harris & Associates, a leveraged buyout firm, has found a niche in the salt mines with the creation of a new company, the North American Salt Company. Michael R. Boyce has been named its president and chief operating officer.
North American Salt is made up of the former American Salt and Carey Salt companies and the Sifto Salt Company, which D. G. Harris acquired last week from Domtar Inc. of Montreal. 
The new company, with annual sales of $200 million, will be the third-largest salt producer in the United States and Canada, after the Morton Salt division and Akzo Salt Inc., the company said.
D. George Harris, a former president of the SCM Corporation, which was taken over by Hanson P.L.C. in 1986, will be chairman and chief executive of North American Salt. In the leveraged buyout firm he heads, his associates are Anthony J. Petrocelli, who was his assistant when he was president of American unit of Rhone-Poulenc S.A. before he joined SCM in 1981, and Richard Donahue, who was Mr. Harris's aide at SCM.
Mr. Harris said it took 13 months for his firm to make the first deal, the American Salt buyout. ''I'd like to say that we were so intelligent that we studied and found a stable industry with a stable cash flow,'' he said.
''But the fact is that we were looking at the Diamond Crystal Salt Company. We were outbid by Akzo, but in the course of that we talked with Chase bankers,'' he said, referring to the Chase Manhattan Bank. ''They knew we were interested in salt and asked us if we'd like to look at American Salt.''
Mr. Harris said the Sifto acquisition gave the new company ''the size and geographic spread we need to be truly competitive in the salt market in North America.'' The company's products include rock salt used for de-icing, solar salt for water softening and table salt. Sifto is a brand-name table salt in Canada.
The D. G. Harris associates say they are pleased with their venture. ''The salt industry goes on,'' said Mr. Petrocelli, who visited many salt mines in researching the deal. ''It isn't affected by recessions. There are 14,000 uses for salt.''
Mr. Boyce, 42 years old, is another former SCM executive who worked with Mr. Harris. Mr. Boyce joins the company from the General Chemical Corporation in Parsippany, N.J., where he was vice president and general manager of the industrial chemicals division. He will be based in Mission, Kan., where North American Salt is based.

HEADLINE: Commercial Bank Growth

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4

 BODY:
Allowing commercial banks to underwrite securities and to open branches nationwide are two crucial steps Congress can take to improve the global competitiveness of the industry, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board said today. Mr. Greenspan told a House subcommittee group that another essential step is to lower the cost of capital for United States banks by cutting the federal deficit. This would allow interest rates to fall and add to the amount of savings available for private investment, he said. 
Fellow bank regulators - Comptroller of the Currency Robert Clarke and L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation - urged the same changes to the United States banking system when they addressed the task force last month.
Attempts to dismantle the Glass-Steagall Act, which bars banks from securities activities, stumbled in Congress several years ago. In response, the Fed slowly is permitting banks to begin limited securities underwriting. Underwriting, which involves buying securities from the issuer and selling them to the public, is currently restricted to investment banks.

HEADLINE: House Drafting Stiff Bill on Urban Air Pollution

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4

 BODY:
Now that the Senate has voted to amend the Clean Air Act, the legislative struggle has shifted to the House of Representatives, where a bill is being drafted that would crack down more strongly on urban air pollution.
The House bill would address the same pollution problems as the Senate's: acid rain, smog and toxic chemicals. But there are significant differences in how each chamber would achieve its pollution reduction goals.
Environmentalists and an industry spokesman said today that they favored major elements of the House legislation, being written by the Energy and Commerce Committee. Industry spokesmen said some provisions of the House version might even be less costly for manufacturers because they might not require the use of expensive pollution-control technology. 
Both the Senate and the House bills call for two stages of controls to be used to reduce pollution from automobile tailpipes and from plants that emit hazardous chemicals. In both cases the second round of controls, which would be more costly than the first, is contingent on different actions or developments. Industry representatives believe that under the House bill, the second round is less likely to go into effect for auto and chemical plants and so the House bill would be less costly over the long run.
 
Differences on Cities
Environmental lobbyists said the House version includes requirements that would be more effective in making cities clean up smog and other urban pollution. In particular, they praised a provision, absent in the Senate bill, that would require the Environmental Protection Agency to enforce a plan for reducing urban air pollution in areas where states are unwilling or unable to act.
S. William Becker, executive director of an association representing state and local pollution control officers, said the House panel had approved provisions that were ''far superior'' to the Senate's, particularly those dealing with cities with dirty air. He noted that the House, unlike the Senate, would not permit cities to avoid making annual progress in reducing smog if they determined the costs were too high.
William Fay, leader of a coalition of companies and trade associations lobbying on the air law, said the House provisions for controlling auto tailpipe emissions and toxic chemicals in the air were likely to be less expensive than the Senate legislation over the long run.
But both sides express concerns about some provisions. Environmentalists complained that the House bill would give New York City, Chicago and Houston a longer period to reduce pollution. They also said that so far, the House bill had only a weak provision for requiring cars to burn cleaner gasoline. Industry complained about unnecessary stringent requirements for reducing nitrogen oxide pollution in cities and requirements that small business would have to pay for costly pollution reductions under the House bill.
 
Drafting Processes Differ
Like the Senate, the House is drafting its bill in a series of closed-door negotiations. But unlike the Senate process, the White House is playing no role in that of the House. It has not been invited participate by House leaders.
Instead, the House bill is being hammered out by lawmakers representing the various regional interests across the nation. Key players are Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan, chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, whose interests in the bill include protecting the auto industry and workers who might be affected by the bill, and Representative Henry A. Waxman of California, chairman of the committee's Environmental and Health Subcommittee, who is interested in the strongest possible clean air bill for his Los Angeles district and for the nation.
The two Democrats, long adversaries over air quality and other environmental legislation, have been able to reach agreements on amendments to the Clean Air Act dealing with urban smog, pollution from cars and toxic chemicals in the air.
Today the committee was seeking to craft a provision that would reduce acid rain without causing economic hardships in coal mining states and in Midwestern states where coal-fired power plants produce much of the pollution that falls as acid rain over the Northeast. The House, like the Senate, would require a 10-million-ton reduction in sulfur dioxide emissions from power plants by the end of the century.
In large part because of the meeting of minds between Mr. Dingell and Mr. Waxman, the House committee is moving more rapidly than expected by its members to write its bill to amend the Clean Air Act. The committee could complete its work this week. If it does, the legislation could move to the House floor by the end of April and be approved in May.

HEADLINE: Most Stock Advisers Failed To Match S.&P. in Quarter

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
The first quarter proved a tough one for the nation's investment advisers, with most failing to match the total return of the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks.
CDA Investment Technologies, which monitors investment advisers, said the average money manager's portfolio declined 3.2 percent for the first three months of this year, while over the same period the S.&P. 500 fell 3 percent, with the quarter's dividends calculated in the stock's performance.
In part, the lackluster performance of the money managers, as well as the performance of the S.&P., was largely a reflection of the difficult market conditions in the first quarter. 
With higher interest rates, weak corporate profits and a falling Japanese market, many market watchers and money managers, some of whom invest the funds of wealthy individuals and institutional investors like pension funds, were happily surprised that stocks in the United States held up as well as they did.
Small capitalization stocks, those with market capitalization of $600 million and less, did extremely well and those managers whose portfolios were heavily weighted in such issues, particularly technology stocks, had a very good run over the last three months.
Many technology companies that had long been out of favor did very well as investors were attracted by their low share prices and relatively high growth rates.
 
Amerindo Leads List
The top-ranked money manager for the quarter was Amerindo U.S. Investment Advisors, a firm based in Larkspur, Calif., that had about 40 stocks in its portfolio at the end of the quarter. Amerindo, which was heavily weighted in capital goods and technology stocks with low yields and high price-earnings ratios, which averaged 31, registered a gain of 11.3 percent for the quarter.
The average market capitalization for issues held by Amerindo was about $600 million, as opposed to the average of $10.1 billion for the managers surveyed by CDA.
Another big winner was Wasatch Advisors Inc., a Salt Lake City-based firm whose portfolio was heavily weighted in small capital goods and financial services stocks. Wasatch saw the value of its portfolio climb 6.9 percent over the quarter, said Samuel S. Stewart Jr., the firm's chief investment officer.
 
'Core Stocks'
''Our basic focus is on smaller growth stocks,'' Mr. Stewart said. ''We tend to have a small number of core stocks that we hold large positions in and then we have our technology holdings that did very well during the quarter.''
Among the core stocks that make up a big chunk of the Wasatch portfolio was the Washington Federal Savings and Loan, a Seattle company that Mr. Stewart said was possibly the best run in the entire industry. Dress Barn, a retail apparel chain, and the U. S. Surgical Corporation, a maker of surgical and medical equipment were also in the portfolio.
About 10 percent of the portfolio was in Washington Federal, and Mr. Stewart noted that many opportunities for investing in strong, well-run savings and loans were being overlooked because of the widely publicized troubles of the industry.
Among the most popular companies to own were Adobe Systems Inc., the Software Publishing Corporation, Autodesk Inc. and the Microsoft Corporation.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Copper Prices Fall Sharply As Miners' Strike Is Settled

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Prices of copper futures fell sharply yesterday on New York's Commodity Exchange. Selling was prompted partly by settlement of a 24-day strike against the Southern Peru Copper Corporation.
On other commodity markets, silver led precious-metal futures higher, coffee futures surged, petroleum futures dropped, grains and soybean advanced, and livestock and meat futures were mixed. 
Copper futures settled 2.95 cents to 4.7 cents lower, with the contract for delivery in April at $1.235 a pound.
The end of the Peruvian strike was ''kind of a surprise,'' said Stephen W. Platt, a metals analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Some traders had not expected the company to negotiate with the striking miners until after Sunday's presidential election.
 
Selling Linked to Japan
Mr. Platt said further selling was linked to the possibility of an economic slowdown in Japan, a fear fueled by the recent decline in the Japanese stock market. Japan has been responsible for heavy demand for copper, a key industrial metal.
Silver futures rallied strongly on the Commodity Exchange, leading gold higher, amid talk that Japanese financial institutions were moving assets out of the stock market and into silver in a ''flight to quality.''
Silver futures settled 15.2 cents to 16.8 cents higher, with April at $5.16 a troy ounce; gold was $1.80 to $1.90 higher, with April at $377.10 a troy ounce.
Coffee futures jumped on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange on talk that Brazil was preparing to set a minimum coffee export price of 80 cents a pound. Coffee settled 2.17 cents to 3 cents higher, with May at 94.99 cents a pound.
Petroleum futures sagged on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid selling that largely reflected Tuesday's weekly report of the American Petroleum Institute showing larger-than-expected United States supplies of crude oil and heating oil, but a smaller-than-expected gasoline supply.
West Texas Intermediate crude settled 21 cents to 52 cents lower, with May at $19.78 a barrel; heating oil was 1.21 cents to 1.5 cents lower, with May at 54.02 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 0.40 cent to 1.02 cents lower, with May at 64.86 cents a gallon.
Wheat and soybean futures rose strongly on the Chicago Board of Trade, partly because of fears of a freeze this weekend in winter wheat country. Wheat for May delivery rose sharply amid signs of tight available supplies for delivery against the May contract.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Narrowly Mixed; Gold Prices Finish Higher

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended narrowly mixed against major foreign currencies yesterday as dealers marked time before the release of Government unemployment data and this weekend's meeting in Paris of finance ministers and central bankers of the seven leading industrial nations.
Dealers said they expected little from the meeting of representatives of the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Canada and Italy.
Zlatko Glamuzina, chief dealer at the New York office of Banco di Sicilia, said, ''There should be more of the same reiteration of how they are committed to free markets and exchange-rate stability,''
He added that the dollar appeared poised for further increases, at least in the near term, because of volatility in the Japanese financial markets and the long process of reunifying East and West Germany. 
Gold prices rose in New York after a mixed performance overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $377.10 an ounce, up $1.80 from late Tuesday. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold at $377.75 an ounce, up $2.50.
Currency dealers said technical factors dominated trading in the absence of any strong buying or selling incentives.
In Tokyo the dollar closed at 158.90 yen, down 0.05 yen from Tuesday. The dollar traded at 158.49 yen later in London. In New York it finished at 158.875 yen, down from 159.765 yen on Tuesday.
The dollar was also weaker against the British pound. Sterling was quoted at $1.6416 in London, up from $1.6345 late Tuesday, and at $1.64055 in New York, up from $1.6358.
The dollar was quoted at 1.6999 West German marks in Europe, down from 1.7005 marks late Tuesday, and 1.6995 marks in New York, up from 1.6990.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.5040 Swiss francs, up from 1.5035; 5.7095 French francs, up from 5.7085; 1,249.00 Italian lire, up from 1247.75, and 1.16725 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16565.
Silver prices were also mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.160 an ounce, up 15.3 cents. Silver traded in London at $5.02 an ounce, unchanged.

HEADLINE: Gorbachev's Need: A Diminished Russia

BYLINE: By Roman Szporluk; Roman Szporluk directs the Center for Russian and East European studies at the University of Michigan.

DATELINE: ANN ARBOR, Mich.

 BODY:
The Lithuanian secession crisis confronts Mikhail Gorbachev with a historic choice: whether to become a George Washington, the leader of a loosely tied and newly created association of free republics, or a George III, the defender of an empire under attack from all sides.
If he chooses to save the empire, his domestic reforms will fail and he will alienate pro-Western democrats throughout his country, including in Russia itself. If he opts for a genuine federalism, he will face the formidable task of persuading ethnic Russians to go along.
At the heart of the Soviet Union's nationalities problem lies a loss of legitimacy, for which Mr. Gorbachev has himself to blame. Under his rule, Communism has been discredited and Marxist-Leninist ideology debunked - leaving an ideological void. Why shouldn't Lithuanians, Estonians, Georgians, Armenians, Azerbaijanis and others clamor for secession? (Jews, Soviet ethnic Germans and Armenians are seceding through emigration in increasing numbers.) Some claim that Mr. Gorbachev has a plan to overthrow the Communist Party and establish a new legitimacy. But what kind of government does he plan to install in place of the party? He wants to reform the economy, establish a law-governed state and make his country a part of Europe - but what is his country? 
This is not a theoretical question. Valentin Rasputin - a leading Russian nationalist whom Mr. Gorbachev recently appointed to the newly created Presidential Council - publicly raised the possibility of Russia's seceding from the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. As Mr. Rasputin's remark shows, ethnic Russians are being forced to examine their status as one of the nationalities in the Soviet Union, something they could avoid under previous Soviet regimes.
The biggest challenge to Mr. Gorbachev, then, may turn out to be the ethnic assertiveness of the Russian nation itself. The relationship between the Russian nation and the Soviet state is the central ethnic problem in the Soviet Union, not least because it defines the nature of other nationality problems.
The non-Russian nationalities define their agendas in light of their perception of the role of Russians in the Soviet state. They have identified Communism with Russia and view the Soviet Union as a state ruled by Russians. Their calls for secession (or emigration) reflect their fear that the survival, let alone autonomy, of the non-Russian peoples will never be secure in such a state. The recent emergence of a vocal, not to say vociferous, Russian ethnic nationalism does nothing to dispel those fears.
Nor do the ongoing revisions of the Soviet Constitution. The open aim of this exercise is to deny Lithuania the right to secede, which it has under the Soviet Constitution now in force. As a member of the Lithuanian Parliament put it the other day, the law now being adopted ''isn't a law of secession. It's a law against secession.''
This legal maneuvering does not inspire confidence in Mr. Gorbachev's commitment to the rule of law or a democratic federation of republics.
What would the Lithuanians, or other non-Russians, want from a federation? Above all they would want equal rights with Russia, includingtheir own language, religion and culture in their own republics and local control of the government and economy.
On the other hand, the Russian nationalists, who oppose both Communism and the West, are advocating a state rooted in Russian values, one with a non-capitalist economic system and with the Russian language in a leading position everywhere. If this is denied, some, like Mr. Rasputin, would rather accept a smaller Russian state.
Most Russian nationalists, however, advocate keeping the non-Russian republics, such as Lithuania, by force if necessary. In that stand they find an ally in the army and K.G.B., as well as the Moscow bureaucracy. For them, the idea of ''reducing'' Russia to the status of an ordinary republic or of denying an essentially Russian character to the Soviet empire is anathema.
At this stage, none of the major Soviet nationalities, in particular the Ukrainians, are demanding secession. If Mr. Gorbachev can show them that genuine national freedom is attainable in a new federal structure, further secessionist movements might be forestalled.
Accomplishing that, however, will require more than fashioning a new constitution. First Mr. Gorbachev will have to create a liberal, pro-reform, non-chauvinistic Russian national consciousness that accepts a diminished Russia as one republic among equals. He must persuade Russian patriots that a lesser role is in the best interests of both Russia and the Soviet Union.
After that, creating the setting for the realization of economic and social programs should seem easier. As in Eastern Europe today, newly empowered republics might then be more willing to swallow painful reforms.

HEADLINE: 2 G.O.P. Senators Would Double Military Cuts Backed by President

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 5

 BODY:
Breaking with the Bush Administration, two senior Republican Senators called today for Pentagon spending reductions that are twice as great as those offered by the President.
The proposals by the two Senators, William S. Cohen of Maine and John McCain of Arizona, would reduce spending on strategic nuclear weapons and on forces designed mainly to defend Europe against a Soviet attack over a five-year period.
Specifically they would curtail the Pentagon's Stealth, or B-2, bomber program, reduce the number of new submarine-launched ballistic missiles and hold off production of new missile and sensor systems designed to block a Soviet armored advance in Europe.
 
Bush Modernization Plan
The Bush Administration has proposed an across-the-board modernization of strategic nuclear forces, asserting that Moscow is continuing to modernize its arsenal of long-range nuclear weapons. 
The comments by Senators Cohen and McCain, both influential voices on military issues, are the first open break between Senate Republicans and the Administration over Pentagon planning and budget issues. They were a further indication of difficulties ahead for the Bush proposals on military spending.
Congressional Democrats have been snipping at the Pentagon's spending plans for weeks in the initial phase of what promises to be a protracted and contentious discussion about how much to cut military spending in response to changes in the Soviet Union and Europe.
The differences among Republicans were underscored today when Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, appearing at a Pentagon news conference, politely but emphatically rebuffed the call for deeper spending cuts and outlined a new management plan for the Defense Department that he said offered a better way to cut costs.
Among Mr. Cheney's proposals was a call for new legal authority over contract arrangements that he said would enable the Pentagon to buy weapons more efficiently. He also complained in a report to Congress that lawmakers frequently imposed parochial requirements that hampered management at the Pentagon.
The Pentagon has proposed a 1991 budget of $295 billion, a 2.6 decrease from the 1990 level once the effects of inflation are taken into account. That does not include about $11 billion in spending for nuclear weapons programs by the Energy Department. $50 Billion Reduction The Administration has also projected annual after-inflation cuts in military spending of 2 percent a year through the fiscal year 1995.
But Mr. Cohen and Mr. McCain told reporters that ''real reductions about twice this level are realistic.''
''Over all, we believe the United States can meet its defense requirements with budget levels lower than those proposed by the Administration,'' the two said in a joint statement Under the Senators's plan, military spending in the fiscal year 1995 would be about $50 billion below the current level, discounting the effects of inflation.
 
Criticism From Nunn
The Senators's statement comes two weeks after Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who is chairman of the Armed Services Committee, sharply criticized the Pentagon for spending plans that he said were based on outdated assumptions about the military threats facing the United States.
Unlike Mr. Nunn, who has yet to present specific budget proposals, Mr. Cohen and Mr. McCain offered a rough guide for refashioning American military policy. The Republicans acknowledged that their recommendations fell short of a detailed blueprint, but they argued that the most important task was to establish a consensus on the broad outlines of military spending issues.
On strategic weapons, the two Senators said that the Pentagon was planning to buy more long-range nuclear arms than necessary. They said the United States should curtail purchases of the new B-2 bomber while relying more on advanced cruise missiles mounted on B-52 and B-1 bombers.
They also urged the Administration to negotiate an accord with the Soviet Union that would curb rail-based missiles with multiple warheads.
The two Senators said further cuts could involve submarine-launched missiles. They also proposed that spending on the ''Star Wars'' missile defense program be held at its current level of about $4 billion a year.
On conventional defenses, the two Senators said the United States should urge its European allies to assume the main responsibility for heavy ground forces and air defense in Europe.
The Senators also urged the Administration to consider reducing the number of Army divisons based in the United States.
On the Navy, the Senators say that a fleet of 14 aircraft carrier battle groups could be reduced by one or two carriers, since the Navy is reoriented toward regional missions instead of planning to attack the Soviet fleet. Mr. Cheney has resisted such a cut in the size of the Navy.
 
Cheney Offers Proposals
At a Pentagon news conference, Mr. Cheney proposed a series of new measures to spend funds more efficiently and to cut the size of the military.
One change would set up an experimental program that would exempt production of six major weapons from rigorous monitoring by the Pentagon. The contractor would be given more leeway to manage the programs in hope that it would be done more economically. Deputy Defense Secetary Donald Atwood, who appeared at the news conference, said the Pentagon would retain the right to carry out inspections of the programs.
The Pentagon also proposed new laws to enable it to award contracts based on overall performance of contractors rather than just the lowest bid.
Mr. Atwood said the Pentagon also needed more authority to manage personnel issues so it could cut up to 90,000 military personnel in 1990 and 1991 and still maintain a balanced force. Mr. Atwood said that he favored the use of severance pay and early retirement to cushion the impact of discharging military personnel.

HEADLINE: JAPANESE PLEDGE TO LOWER BARRIERS TO TRADE WITH U.S.

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 5

 BODY:
In a sweeping agreement with Washington to reduce trade barriers, Tokyo pledged today to take actions intended to make it easier for foreigners to invest in Japan and do business there.
The Japanese steps range from cutting restrictions on large retail stores to altering tax policies so that more land will be available for commercial and residential use.
The agreement is the result of an ambitious effort to deal with the underlying causes of the United States' huge trade deficit. In the past, trade talks between the countries have focused on raising sales of specific American products to Japan or curbing Japanese exports.
 
No Quick Effect Seen
The promised changes were greeted by American officials as a positive step in a long-running effort. 
Because it will probably take years to carry out some of the steps, Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, stressed that there was likely to be ''very little'' short-term impact on the trade deficit with Japan, which last year totaled $49 billion. But she said the agreement should ''facilitate capital flows'' and ''walk the two countries toward greater parity.''
''I told the Japanese I wanted a comprehensive blueprint with sufficient specifics so that I could call it a down payment,'' Mrs. Hills said. ''This is a good blueprint, sufficient to call a down payment.''
Richard T. McCormack, Under Secretary of State for economic affairs, told reporters that the talks were a rare instance in which two governments have sought to address the entire range of domestic policies that affect their international economic relations.
 
World's Largest Economies
The United States and Japan are the world's two largest economies. Together, they account for about one-third of the world's total output of goods and services.
The agreement was the result of intense overtime negotiating sessions this week at the State Department. The agreement was formally announced at 7:30 P.M. in Washington to accommodate Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, who also announced it early Friday morning in Tokyo.
The agreement followed narrower accords intended to increase access to the Japanese market for American supercomputers, communications satellites and telecommunications equipment. It also follows a meeting between Mr. Kaifu and President Bush in Palm Springs, Calif., on March 2 and 3 at which the Japanese leader pledged his ''utmost'' to ease trade friction.
Sensitive to political reaction in Tokyo, Japanese negotiators here portrayed the agreement not as a response to threats to restrict the flow of Japanese goods into the United States, but as an effort to improve the quality of life for Japanese consumers and to integrate Japan's economy with the world's. Most of the measures are subject to approval by the Japanese Parliament.
The new measures are listed in an interim report the two Governments published on the so-called Structural Impediments Initiative, the formal name of the effort to deal with broad-based obstacles to trade.
This week's talks, which were extended to four days, from the original schedule of two, were the fourth round of negotiations since the initiative began in July. A final report is due next July.
The Bush Administration's goal is to make it as easy for Americans to do business in Japan as for the Japanese to do business here.
The Japanese Government acknowledged that prices for most goods and services there were higher than in most other countries and agreed that price levels in the future should be a barometer of the initiative's success. Monitoring procedures have not yet been worked out in detail.
 
Reaction From Politicians
On Capitol Hill, initial reactions were guarded. ''Put me down as a skeptic who's seen too many agreements in which the results didn't match the rhetoric,'' said Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas and chairman of the Senate Finance Committee.
But Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana and chairman of Finance Committee's Trade subcommittee, said he was ''encouraged'' by the first steps. He added, however, that ''much remains to be done.''
In Tokyo next week, the two Governments are to begin another round of negotiations over trade in wood products, a sector in which the Administration contends that the Japanese practice widespread trade restrictions.
Senator John C. Danforth of Missouri, the ranking Republican on the Trade subcommittee, said the talks had been worth pursuing, but noted that in any commercial agreement with Japan, ''seeing is believing.''
The changes promised by Tokyo include: increasing investment in public works; making the intricate Japanese distribution system more accessible to outsiders; stiffening antitrust penalties; changing tax policies to open more land for commercial and residential use; providing import clearance within 24 hours for foreign goods, and curbing the anti-competitive practices of Japanese industrial groups.
 
What the U.S. Pledged
The United States, in turn, promised to work on the structural causes of its large trade deficits. But unlike the Japanese, the Americans did not list any new policy initiatives, but rather echoed proposals already made by the Bush Administration.
For example, the United States pledged to improve education, bolster savings and investment, and cut the cost of capital, all familiar proposals that were part of the State of the Union address.
Japanese negotiators had made a number of specific recommendations on United States policy, some of them seemingly aimed at the American way of life, like reducing the number of credit cards held by individuals, increasing the gasoline tax, cutting executive bonuses and curbing the tax benefits of owning a home. None of those suggestions were included on the list of American pledges.
The negotiations went into extra days because of American demands for greater concessions than the Japanese initially offered regarding antitrust and distribution. The Japanese resisted American pressure to set strict legal penalties for antitrust violations in Japan and to agree to a specific timetable for abandoning rules that protect small shopkeepers and discriminate against large stores.
American companies have long complained that they have trouble doing business in Japan because of price-fixing, group boycotts and market-allocation agreements among Japanese companies. Current antimonopoly penalties amount to little more than a slap on the wrist.
 
Tougher Stance on Monopolies
The Japanese agreed to amend their monopoly law to raise fines and enhance the deterrent effect by publicly naming violators. They also said they would pursue criminal remedies in antitrust cases following procedures similar to those used in the United States. The enforcement staff of Japan's Fair Trade Commission will increase from 129 to 153 persons.
One large obstacle in the distribution system is the approval process required to open large retail stores. Openings are usually opposed by small shopkeepers, who can sometimes delay action for up to 10 years. This has been a particular problem for Toys ''R'' Us, which has sought for some time to establish an operation in Japan, one of the few industrial markets where it has no outlet.
The Japanese made a commitment to insure that consultations delaying the opening of such stores would ultimately not last more than a year. In addition, any retailers who agree to sell foreign goods would be immediately authorized to expand their stores by up to 1,000 square feet.
The Japanese also agreed to raise public investment in housing, port facilities, roads and other programs that would increase demand for imports. Dr. John B. Taylor, a member of the Council of Economic Advisers, told reporters that higher savings in this country, combined with more public investment in Japan, ''will go a long way to reducing trade imbalances.''
As for investment, the Japanese said they would abolish a prior-notification requirement for direct foreign investment and limit use of the Government's authority to block investments on broad economic grounds.
The United States curbs foreign investment only when it impairs national security.

HEADLINE: After 80's Housing Boom, A Decade of Flat Prices?

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

 BODY:
After a long climb in housing prices that has made home ownership all but a sure-fire investment, many experts think those prices will level off or decline during this decade, potentially changing the way people spend, save and invest their money.
Although there is considerable debate about the topic in real estate circles, many economists and analysts foresee a fundamental contraction in the demand for housing, which will hold down prices. They point to the aging of the baby-boom generation, which fueled much of the demand since 1970. That group is moving past its prime home-buying years, and the generation that follows is much smaller.
''We're going to have slower growth in the adult population, and fewer people means less demand,'' said N. Gregory Mankiw, an economics professor at Harvard University, who predicts that housing prices will decline over the next several decades, after adjusting for inflation. 
Professor Mankiw's forecast is among the most pessimistic. Other projections vary widely, but many economists agree that after many years of generally outpacing inflation, prices for single-family dwellings, including cooperatives and condominium apartments, will do no better than match the inflation rate in this decade.
 
Broad Regional Differences
To be sure, the national trend will mask substantial regional differences in the price of housing, as it always has. For example, the median selling price of a single-family house in the New York metropolitan area increased from $70,500 in 1982 to $194,000 six years later, before slipping somewhat to $185,200 last spring, according to the National Association of Realtors. By contrast, the median home price throughout the nation for the same period grew by just 4.3 percent a year.
Moreover, other experts contend that house purchases will be propped up in the years ahead, even though the pool of new buyers may be declining. These analysts note that as the baby-boom adults grow older, into their 40's, they enter their peak earning years, when they are most likely to decide to buy larger, more expensive homes.
And even if housing prices stagnate, owning a home continues to carry clear-cut financial advantages, like tax deductions for mortgage interest and some local taxes, and less tangible rewards, like the pride of ownership.
Still, a long-term weakening in house prices could mean major changes in consumer psychology. While income levels and general economic conditions are the primary influences on individual economic behavior, experts say that because a home is the primary asset for most people, declining or stagnant housing prices could leave people feeling poorer, making them more cautious in their spending habits.
Although the link between home price increases and individual economic behavior is statistically sketchy, researchers say there is some evidence that a sustained period of stagnant or falling prices would prompt consumers to cut back.
Dr. Richard T. Curtin, who directs an economic survey of consumers conducted by the University of Michigan, said that recent surveys in the Northeast, where housing prices in many cases have fallen after several years of rapid run-ups, show evidence that some homeowners in that region are feeling a bit pinched.
Dr. Curtin said that the decline in housing values ''has made families feel that their actual financial condition has declined and that has had a general impact on their willingness to make a wide range of purchase decisions, especially for high-priced items involving credit or debt.''
 
Impact on Investment
The implications extend beyond spending. If housing becomes less attractive as an investment, researchers say, then investors might choose to tie up less money in their homes and put more in stocks and bonds, or in the bank.
There are also implications for the national economy. Any long-term decline in housing demand could mean lower employment in construction and related industries, long an important component of the nation's overall economic health.
''We know less about this than we ought to, and there may be more implications than we know about,'' said Lyle Gramley, chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association.
Many real estate executives and analysts dispute the notion that demand and prices are headed down. They argue that other factors, like smaller households, growing incomes of the baby boomers and the rising cost of land and construction, will keep demand and prices strong.
 
'Very Good Years Ahead'
''We see very good years ahead for housing in the 1990's,'' said Norman D. Flynn, the president of the National Association of Realtors.
Still, there are signs in previously hot markets that the psychology of real estate is starting to change. Homeowners who counted on selling their houses at big profits are forced to scale back their expectations, economists say. People who would previously have scrimped to buy a home as soon as possible, before prices rose further, are now taking a harder look at whether it is worth it to buy. Sometimes they are deciding to wait longer, which leaves sellers facing long delays and forces them to mark down their prices.
''We don't have the appreciation rates we had before and we're unlikely to have them again for some time,'' said Susan Wachter, an economist at the Wharton Real Estate Center at the University of Pennsylvania. ''People correctly perceive this and are adjusting their economic behavior accordingly, in part by postponing home ownership.'' Is Renting Better? One example is Carl Spiegler, a 37-year-old salesman for a legal publisher in Chicago. He thinks that renting makes more sense in an uncertain housing market. ''I'm afraid of the 'last fool' rule,'' he said. ''Home prices have skyrocketed. My concern is that I will buy and they will stop going up.''
The changes would not be all bad news, of course. Should prices stagnate in coming years, the winners would be buyers looking for their first home. Gains in housing prices have outstripped increases in household income since the 1970's, putting the purchase of a home out of reach for a growing number of people. If that trend is reversed, analysts said, it could help solve what many have called a crisis in affordable housing.
The benefits to first-time home buyers are likely to vary considerably by region. In metropolitan New York or Los Angeles, many wage earners feel frozen out of the market for affordable housing. Despite stagnant housing prices, the incomes of many of these people may not rise enough to enable them to buy a house.
 
Caught Between Two Homes
Of those who own homes, many find they are unable to move or to trade up. Some homeowners seeking to move to larger, newer or more fashionable residences often find themselves caught between two homes - the old one they cannot sell at the price they want, and the new one they cannot buy at the asking price.
Rose and Tony Gagliardi of Centerport, L.I., bought a three-bedroom house seven years ago for $119,000. They put it on the market in December for $229,000 and have since come down to $219,000. The most recent offer: $180,000. If the Gagliardis cannot get close to their asking price, they will not be able to buy a larger house, in Melville, L.I. They are trying to hold firm at their asking price.
''People will low-ball anything,'' Mrs. Gagliardi said. ''You could just keep going down and down and down.''
The owners of the Melville house put it on the market more than a year ago at $270,000. It had come down to $220,000 when the Gagliardis saw it. They talked the owners down to $215,000 and had agreed to buy it, but had to pull out when they could not sell their own place. The Melville house remains on the market at a price too high for most first-time buyers, and even a stretch for many homeowners looking to trade up.
Just how severe a downturn the markets face is a matter of intense debate in real estate circles. The pessimists are led by Professor Mankiw of Harvard, who last year published a study along with a Harvard graduate student, David N. Weil, that concluded that home prices, after adjusting for inflation, would fall substantially in coming years.
Births in the United States totaled 4.3 million in 1957, Mr. Mankiw said, the peak of the baby boom. In 1973, the trough of the baby bust, births had fallen to 3.1 million. Historical data show that people are in their peak home-buying years in their 20's and 30's, he said.
''Just as the baby boom of the 1950's led to the housing boom of the 1970's, the baby bust of the 1970's will likely lead to a housing bust of the 1990's,'' Professor Mankiw and Mr. Weil wrote in their study.
Real estate executives have attacked the Harvard study's assumptions, pointing out, for example, that many people who could not afford to buy during the 1980's were likely to enter the market in the 1990's, increasing demand.
Other researchers think the Harvard economists are probably overstating the severity of the impact, but support the notion that the population changes will keep prices lower than they would otherwise be.
