HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
U.S.-SOVIET SUMMIT IS PLANNED MAY 30 WITH BUSH AS HOST

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5

 BODY:
President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union will hold a five-day meeting in the United States beginning on May 30, the White House and the Kremlin announced today.
The announcement of the summit dates is as much a political statement as a scheduling matter. The decision comes at probably the tensest moment in Soviet-American relations since President Bush took office, largely because of Washington's discomfort with the Kremlin's crackdown on the Lithuanian independence movement.
In talks in Washington over the last two days with Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the Soviet Foreign Minister, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has repeatedly emphasized that suppression of the Baltic drive for independence will seriously damage the superpower relationship.
 
Talks to Run Until June 3
Nonetheless, the Administration appears to have determined that the Kremlin's activity in Lithuania, until now at least, does not require any delay in announcing the summit dates or in holding the meeting. The sessions are scheduled to begin on Wednesday, May 30, in Washington and end on Sunday, June 3. 
''I don't have any idea about the private discussions that went on'' between Mr. Baker and Mr. Shevardnadze, said the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater. ''But I don't think there was any anticipation that the summit would be changed on the basis of the existing situation.''
The Baker-Shevardnadze talks are concentrating on overcoming obstacles to treaties limiting long-range nuclear missiles, chemical weapons and conventional arms in Europe, as well as resolving outstanding economic and regional problems.
 
Arms Accords Unlikely
Both Soviet and American officials indicated today that the prospects of signing major arms-control initiatives at the meeting appeared to be dim. The meeting was initially scheduled for February. But at their meeting in Malta in December, Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev stated their wish that the get-together be an occasion for signing a Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, known as Start, or for reaching agreement on all of the accord's major provisions.
Senior American and Soviet officials, briefing reporters on today's talks, indicated that it was highly unlikely that a Start treaty would be ready for signing at the spring session. Whether even an agreement in principle will be completed by then also remains in doubt.
A senior Administration official said that the United States might introduce an important new proposal, either for the current Start negotiations or in the discussion of principles for the proposed Start-2 treaty, which seeks to ban either all land-based multiple-warhead ballistic missiles, known as MIRV's, or those placed on trains.
 
Soviets Oppose Idea
Soviet officials said that introducing such a ban at this point in the Start talks was not a good idea since it might slow the negotiating process. Several prominent Senators have said that Congress would not support the Administration's request for both a truck-mounted, single-warhead Midgetman missile system and a rail-mounted MX multiple warhead missile system, and have been urging the White House to pursue a ban on mobile MIRV's with Moscow.
During today's discussion of regional issues, American officials indicated that the Soviet negotiators seemed to be edging away from their insistence that a unified Germany must be neutral. While they were not ready to accept the American proposal that a united Germany be a full member of NATO, the Soviets appeared more than ever to be open to alternative security arrangements, officials said.
On the Middle East agenda, the Soviets told the American side that they would be ready to consider restoring diplomatic relations with Israel and permitting the direct flight of Jews from Moscow to Israel, if the Israeli Government would provide them with guarantees that the refugees would not be settled on the West Bank or in East Jerusalem.
How the setting of the summit dates might affect each side's room for maneuver on the Lithuania question is uncertain.
Some analysts say it could limit Washington's ability to take a tough line with Mr. Gorbachev on Lithuania, should the situation there deteriorate. Walking away from a scheduled summit meeting would be a move without precedent in United States-Soviet relations.
In 1960, President Eisenhower planned to visit Nikita S. Khrushchev, the Soviet leader, in Moscow, but no date had been set when the meeting was canceled after an American U-2 spy plane was shot down over the Soviet Union. In 1968, President Johnson planned to see Leonid I. Brezhnev in October, but again there was no date set when Soviet forces invaded Czechoslovakia that summer, putting an end to the plans.
 
Dole Meets With Bush
This time, the Administration will have to be careful that it does not try to compensate for moving ahead with the summit talks by turning up its criticism of Moscow to a point where it inflames a Congress already urging a harder line on the Lithuania issue.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, met with President Bush this morning to discuss the Senator's planned visit to the Middle East. He was asked on his way out of the White House what he thought of a summit session given the situation in Lithuania.
''My view is that it makes it a little more difficult,'' he said. ''We tried to express that to Shevardnadze last night - speaking for Congress, not the President. And members of Congress in both parties might have a different view if there's any force used in Lithuania, about trade or anything else dealing with the Soviet Union. We didn't get into arms control. My own view is we ought to go forward with arms control agreements.''
It was apparently with the Congressional sentiments in mind that Mr. Baker told Mr. Shevardnadze of the importance of beginning negotiations with the Baltic states immediately.
Robert Legvold, director of the W. Averell Harriman Institute for the Advanced Study of the Soviet Union at Columbia University, said it could also be argued that setting a date increased the flexibility of the Administration. If it had refused to set a date, it would have lost its best leverage with Moscow, he said. Now it still has the flexibility to postpone or constrict the summit meeting, should the situation in Lithuania deteriorate drastically.
 
'A Kind of Sobering Look'
Administration officials, though, were sensitive to the accusation that scheduling the meeting sent a contradictory message to Moscow, and they tried to dispel the notion that setting the date meant a softening of the United States' position on the fate of Lithuania.
''As it stands now, I would expect the summit to focus on Lithuania for at least some discussion - President Bush will raise it,'' Mr. Fitzwater said. ''I think everybody views the Lithuanian situation very seriously. It does require a kind of sobering look at events and the situation in the Soviet Union. But, as the President said, the important point is that we are talking and, if anything, Lithuania makes a summit all the more important that the President is able to present the U.S. views forcefully and directly to him.''
This will be Mr. Bush's second summit meeting with Mr. Gorbachev since becoming President. The two leaders met on Dec. 2 and 3 aboard ships off the island of Malta in the Mediterranean. President Bush offered a 16-point program of technical and economic support for Mr. Gorbachev's economic and political changes in the Soviet Union, known as perestroika.
''It is very important that we have these conversations,'' President Bush told reporters shortly after the formal announcement was made today. ''Dialogue is important. I'm looking forward to seeing Mr. Gorbachev here.''
Administration officials said that the only thing the two sides have agreed on at this stage are the five days within which the summit will be held. Whether the two Presidents will meet all five days, whether they will hold all their talks in Washington or also meet somewhere else in the United States, and all other logistical details remain to be hammered out.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
Kremlin Troops Move In to Evict Lithuania Aides

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 5

 BODY:
Continuing its campaign of pressure, the Kremlin sent troops on another foray in the Lithuanian capital today and repeated its refusal to hold formal talks with separatist leaders until the Baltic republic voids its declaration of independence.
A Lithuanian spokesman, reached by telephone from Moscow, said 50 Soviet soldiers moved into the Chief Prosecutor's office in Vilnius to evict civil servants loyal to Vytautas Landsbergis, Lithuania's President.
The prosecutor's office, which oversees federal law in the republic, has been the scene of a confrontation over who holds sway in Lithuania, Moscow or the breakaway Parliament. Both sides have named chief prosecutors to run the bureau, but the prosecutor installed by Moscow is in place because of the presence of Soviet troops. 
 
No Resistance Reported
The Soviet soldiers evicted the Lithuanian workers without resistance or injury, the Lithuanian spokesman said.
With Moscow's order last week that foreign correspondents leave the republic, confirmation of the report was difficult.
As the troop movements were taking place, Aleksandr N. Yakovlev, a top adviser and political ally to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, spoke out against Lithuania's March 11 declaration of independence. He called the move a blow ''directed against perestroika,'' the Soviet leader's plan to revive the country through economic and political restructuring.
Tonight, the Lithuanian legislature crafted a message to Mr. Gorbachev pleading for ''honest dialogue'' that is not ''accompanied by arbitrary actions by your armed forces.''
Mr. Yakovlev met informally with Lithuanian representatives on Tuesday, the day that Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze arrived in Washington for talks on a summit meeting between Presidents Bush and Gorbachev. That small concession seemed to ease the crisis for a day and soften Mr. Shevardnadze's arrival. Moscow and Washington announced today that the talks are scheduled to begin on May 30.
In an interview today with Tass, the Soviet press agency, Mr. Yakovlev said that while the initial talks with Lithuania were ''frank from both sides,'' the independence declaration would continue to be viewed as unconstitutional by the Kremlin. ''The Lithuanian deputies were told that a normal dialogue on all issues of mutual interest was possible on the basis of the situation that existed before March 10,'' he declared, referring to Lithuania's status before its legislature voted to secede from the Soviet Union.
 
Developments in Estonia
The separatist movement in Estonia moved ahead at the deliberately slower pace set by leaders in Tallinn, the republic's capital. A new legislative session was called next week to form a ''temporary government'' to lead toward an eventual declaration of independence. President Gorbachev telephoned the Estonian leader, Arnold F. Ruutel, on Tuesday night to warn Estonia against following Lithuania into delacring independence.
In the third Baltic republic, Latvia, a Communist Party congress scheduled Friday in Riga, the capital, is expected to follow the two other republics' parties in splitting from the Soviet Communists over the independence issue. But in the legislature in Latvia, the majority of the Latvia members are expected to remain loyal to the Kremlin. Close to half the population of the republic are non-Latvians favoring Moscow.
Mr. Gorbachev is closely following how united the Baltic republics will be in their separatist drives.
 
Gorbachev's 2 Vulnerabilities
While the Soviet leader must be sensitive to global factors like the cautions by the Bush Administration against using force to resolve questions of sovereignty, he must also try to avoid acceding to a Baltic settlement that would invite other disgruntled Soviet republics and nationality groups to leave the union.
Lithuanian officials today increased their overtures for compromise with the Kremlin. Their chief representative in Moscow, Egidius Bickauskas, said in an interview with Soviet reporters that the republic ''may offer more than the central government expects'' in the way of compromise. He was not specific but again talked of the possibility of submitting the independence issue to a referendum, which Mr. Gorbachev has insisted is a minimum step for the republic before it can legally contemplate independence.
And the legislature in Vilnius wrestled for another day with crafting a diplomatic reply to Mr. Gorbachev's warning last weekend that ''grave consequences'' threatened unless the independence declaration was repealed in order to open the way to full negotiations. The Lithuanian authorities expressed optimism on Tuesday when Mr. Yakovlev finally agreed to meet with Mr. Bickauskas, and they have since avoided fresh denunciations of the Kremlin, hoping that further talks would follow.
 
The Troops Roll In
That hope was not realized during the day as Lithuanian spokesmen reported what they said was the most forceful movement of Soviet troops in a week. They said a well-armed contingent of 50 soldiers arrived this afternoon at the prosecutor's office, where workers loyal to the Lithuanians have been resisting Moscow's attempts to supersede the local prosecutor.
The prosecutor's office is a focal point of Soviet law in the republic, and its functions includes prosecuting those refusing to enter the Soviet military. Many young Lithuanians are resisting the Soviet draft. Others are deserting now that the republic has declared its independence. Their cases are dealt with by separate military tribunals.
The state-controlled press and television continued to present heavily pro-Kremlin reports on the crisis, focusing on complaints from the republic's Russian and Polish minorities. Moscow has said that the rights of the minorities in Lithuania must be considered before any secession can go forward. The controlled reports gave little note to the Lithuanian explanation of why independence was justified.

HEADLINE: DINKINS FORECASTS WIDER BUDGET GAP AS REVENUES SLIP

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that New York City was facing an additional $105 million revenue shortfall for the fiscal year ending June 30. He also said he would seek $309 million in higher taxes to balance the city's budget in the coming fiscal year, on top of the $550 million it is already seeking.
The Mayor's announcement was the grimmest in a string of similar ones in recent months as the city has taken steps to close a total gap in its budget for this year of well over $1 billion and to plug a projected gap of about $2 billion in the coming year. 
Throughout the Northeast, governors and mayors are struggling with similar budget problems in the wake of a regional economic slowdown. $20 Million Shortfall Remains In New York State, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders have been struggling to come up with an agreement on a package of taxes and spending cuts to close a $1.5 billion gap in the state budget that was supposed to take effect April 1. Mr. Cuomo and legislative leaders agreed yesterday on a plan to postpone an income tax cut scheduled for this year. [Page B1.] New York City officials said they hoped about $85 million of the expected revenue shortfall for the rest of this fiscal year could be covered by using reserves from a decades-old rapid-transit sinking fund that issued subway construction bonds many years ago. Those bonds are now about to mature. The officials said they were still studying how to close the remaining $20 million shortfall through service cuts or other actions. But Mr. Dinkins said he still had every intention of hiring a class of 750 police recruits to begin training later this month.
 
Business Tax Receipts Down
With New York State inching closer toward agreement on its own budget yesterday, Mr. Dinkins said he was eager to have the State Legislature begin to focus on his proposed tax package now, rather than when he presents his formal budget next month.
The city's Budget Director, Philip R. Michael, and Finance Commissioner, Carol O'Cleireacain, said much of the shortfall in revenue was caused by a drop in business tax receipts, especially from banks.
The officials attributed that to the Federal Reserve's policy of directing banks to set aside more money to cover expected bad foreign loans and bad real-estate loans, thus cutting their current tax liability.
Asked if yesterday's announcement was the worst of the bad news, Mr. Dinkins said, ''I wish I knew.''
''I know that what's necessary,'' he added, ''is for us to meet each occasion in a forthright fashion.''
 
'Very Disturbing'
Raymond D. Horton, the president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a private group that monitors the city's finances, said: ''It's very disturbing. The numbers are disturbing, and now the solutions are starting to get a little disturbing.'' He particularly criticized the intention to draw on the transit reserves.
Hyman Grossman, a managing director of the Standard & Poor's Corporation, which rates the city's bonds, noting other planned one-time revenue sources in this year's budget, said: ''We've got $200 million in one-shots already. It's a tough situation, and getting more difficult, and will require even higher taxes next year than the Mayor wanted.''
During and after the Mayor's news conference, Mr. Michael said the transit fund involved bonds of the Staten Island Rapid Transit Operating Authority.
 
Restrictive Covenants
But later officials in the office of City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman, who had suggested the reserves, said that was not so. They said the reserve fund had been required under the terms of the old subway bonds, which had very restrictive covenants, and only now was the money available.
Brian Baxter, the First Deputy City Comptroller, said it was possible that some new bonds would have to be issued to make up for the reserve.
Mr. Michael, the Budget Director, sought to play down the emphasis on the city's use of one-time revenues, saying it was proposing cuts and other actions so as not to carry its dependence on the one-shot sources into next year, and had not touched its general reserve fund of $75 million for the current year, which remains a cushion.
He said he did not expect that the city would end the year with a deficit of $100 million or more. Such a deficit would allow the State Financial Control Board to vote to resume control powers over the city's finances.
 
'A Little Premature'
The Control Board's executive director, Allen J. Proctor, said the Dinkins administration's estimate of the shortfall was based on preliminary data. ''The fact that they're coming forward with a number, I can't fault them for that,'' he said. ''But it's a little premature to draw conclusions.''
In fact, Mr. Dinkins's announcement was an indication of the rapidly changing fiscal picture for the city and the state. Earlier this week, his aides had said they expected to seek only about $200 million more in taxes than the $550 million Mr. Dinkins said he would ask for in February.
Yesterday, Mr. Dinkins said he would seek a total of $309 million more in new or higher taxes but would not ask for more property taxes than the $180 million he has already proposed.
He plans to ask the Legislature for permission for a $100 million increase in his proposed $200 million temporary surcharge on the personal income tax in the city, which would cost the typical resident about $85 a year.
 
Other Tax Increases
He will also ask the state to let the city raise $60 million through a one-half of 1 percent increase in the mortgage recording tax, $80 million by tripling the current $15 auto use tax, $12 million by increasing the hotel tax rate to 6 percent from 5 percent, and $5 million through new restrictions in the general corporation tax.
At the same time, Mr. Dinkins will ask the City Council to raise $12 million through a new 4 percent sales tax on dry cleaning and laundry transactions and to delay altogether energy tax cuts to save an additional $40 million, on top of the $90 million the Mayor had originally proposed to save by phasing in the cuts more slowly than first planned.
Mr. Dinkins said the Council had agreed to pass a home-rule message asking Albany to act on its share of the tax package.
A spokeswoman for the Council, Peg Breen, said later that the Council would pass a home-rule message, but not necessarily for the taxes the Mayor has outlined.
''We stand ready to talk with the Mayor's staff to go over tax options to come up with a package that we can pass home-rule messages for and which we think will have the best chance of receiving approval in Albany,'' she said.
Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan urged the Mayor to propose changes in the way the city treats bank loan-loss reserves, by allowing banks to deduct only the actual amount of loan losses, instead of the generally higher amounts they place in reserve in anticipation of losses. She said this change could generate $75 million over the next three fiscal years.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

International A3-10

 
A five-day summit meeting between President Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev will be held in Washington beginning on May 30, the White House and the Kremlin said. Page A1

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
Support for German Unity Found Growing in U.S.

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
While Americans seem uneasy about whether the change in Europe is permanent, support for the unification of East and West Germany has grown and two out of three Americans say they do not fear that a united Germany would threaten peace in Europe, according to the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll.
But the poll showed somewhat more concern about the economic consequences of re-creating a single German nation; nearly 4 out of 10 Americans surveyed said a unified Germany would seek to dominate Europe economically.
The survey found surprisingly strong support for economic aid to nations in Eastern Europe and Latin America that are moving toward democracy. Although surveys since 1971 show that Americans have opposed foreign aid by a margin of 3 to 1, they are now about evenly split on giving aid to those two regions.
Other surveys conducted in recent months have indicated that Americans generally are optimistic about East-West relations. Still, the latest telephone survey of 1,515 adults, conducted Friday through Monday, was tempered by uncertainty about the tumult in Eastern Europe that has brought about new governments and economic systems. 
 
Many Support Troops in Europe
Americans are divided between the 45 percent who say they think that the cold war is over or will soon be over and the 39 percent who think it is continuing. A majority of Americans, 51 percent, say the number of American troops in Western Europe should be maintained or increased, compared with 29 percent who say the military presence should be cut and only 10 percent who say it should be eliminated.
Even among those who said the cold war had come to an end, there was an even split over whether it is now time to bring American troops home from Europe.
The new poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.
In follow-up interviews after the survey, many people said they were not quite ready to trust in the irreversibility of the changes in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.
''That would be sort of like getting rid of all your dogs just because someone killed all the weasels that you'd seen around the neighborhood,'' said Brumley Mathes, 44 years old, a licensed nurse, of Greenville, Tenn. ''There may be other weasels lurking around out there,'' he said.
 
Unnerved by Rapidity of Change
Others said they were unnerved by the rapidity of change. ''How can the wall come down so fast and then all of a sudden everyone's talking about disarmament and unification?'' said Mark Seymour, a police sergeant in Richmond.
Joanne Clarke, 38, a schoolteacher in Philadelphia, said, ''I grew up hiding under my school desk in preparation for air raids, and I've been taught my entire life that the Russians are my enemy. It's difficult for me to trust now.''
Americans continued to give high personal marks to Mr. Bush; 72 percent said they approved overall of the way he does his job. In the previous New York Times/CBS News poll, conducted in January, 76 percent of Americans said they approved of Mr. Bush's performance.
The decline is barely significant statistically and appears to result mostly from a dissipation of the strong backing he enjoyed after the invasion of Panama last December.
 
Approval for Gorbachev
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev also maintained a strong measure of approval among Americans. Forty-six percent said they had a favorable opinion of Mr. Gorbachev, while only 9 percent said they had an unfavorable view; the rest said they were undecided or did not know enough about him yet.
The poll turned up no evidence that Mr. Gorbachev's test of wills with the separatists in Lithuania had hurt his popularity, at least so far. In addition, 39 percent said they approved of Mr. Bush's handling of the Lithuanian crisis and 19 percent said they disapproved. Forty-one percent took the view, also taken by Mr. Bush, that maintaining good relations with Mr. Gorbachev was more important than supporting Lithuania's effort to break away from the Soviet Union.
Still, a substantial minority - 31 percent - said supporting Lithuania was more important. There was a large group that offered no opinion on that question or on Mr. Bush's handling of the crisis. That could indicate that Americans, generally slow to focus on new developments in foreign affairs, are not yet paying attention to Lithuania. This could help Mr. Bush, whose strategy has been to avoid allowing the Baltic crisis to dominate East-West relations. But it also means that public sentiment is particularly susceptible to a sudden turn in response to events in Lithuania.
Asked to explain why they had a good opinion of Mr. Gorbachev, Americans most frequently mentioned his efforts to improve East-West relations and allow more freedom both in his country and in Eastern Europe. That ultimately could be sharply affected by his handling of Lithuania.
 
Favoring Unification
Asked about the future of the Germanys, 76 percent of Americans said they favored unification, a significant increase of 9 percentage points from last November's survey. Sixty-seven percent said they were not concerned that a united Germany would threaten peace while 22 percent said they were worried.
Forty-nine percent said they did not think a single Germany would try to dominate the continent economically, but 36 percent said they did think that could happen.
In both cases, memories of World War II were clearly no factor: there were no consistent differences on these issues between the youngest Americans surveyed, those between 18 and 29, and the oldest, those over 64.
As Eastern Europe has moved farther from its domination by Moscow and closer toward free-market economies and democratic governments, support for aid to those countries has increased. In January, asked if the United States should increase aid to countries that are becoming more independent of the Soviet Union, 59 percent said of Americans said no.
 
On Financial Aid
But in the most recent survey, only 44 percent said the United States should not give financial aid to ''those countries in Eastern Europe which have turned toward democracy,'' and 47 percent said they supported aid.
''A 50-50 split doesn't seem terribly strong at first blush, but it is very good for foreign aid,'' said Tom W. Smith, director of the General Social Survey at the University of Chicago's National Opinion Research Center.
The organization has found opposition to increasing foreign aid in general of between 68 percent and 77 percent since 1971. ''I suspect the change is because you are clearly not talking about military aid and you are talking about an area which has incredible change,'' Mr. Smith said. Still, there were signs that Americans had not entirely surrendered their tightfisted attitude toward spending money on foreign aid. Fifty-six percent said money for Eastern Europe and Latin America should come from the pockets of other countries that receive American assistance, not from an increase in the aid budget.
The poll also had evidence of Americans' priorities for spending at home: 61 percent said any savings from a decline in military spending should go to combating problems like drug abuse and homelessness, rather than a tax cut or reducing the Federal budget deficit as Mr. Bush has proposed.
 
How the Poll Was Taken
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from Friday through Monday with a total of 1,515 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.
The basic sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen so as to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. The numbers were then screened to limit calls to residences.
To reach a number of black respondents large enough to allow more detailed analysis of black opinions, another sample was drawn from seven surveys conducted during 1989 by The Times and CBS News. Telephone numbers of black respondents from those polls were called again, yielding 307 additional blacks. The results were then weighted to reflect the actual racial composition of the adult population.
The results have also been weighted to take account of household size and number of residential telephone lines and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
The percentages reported are the particular results most likely to match what would be obtained by seeking out all adult Americans. Other possible percentages are progressively less likely the more they differ from the reported results.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for blacks it is plus or minus five percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

SECTION: Section A; Page 10, Column 5; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 800 words

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
East Europe Considers Cutting Aid to Indochina

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia

 BODY:
The collapse of European Communism and the withering of Comecon, the Eastern-bloc trading association, have led Eastern European countries to consider reducing their diplomatic representation and aid to Cambodia and Vietnam.
Planned reductions in aid, tied to the negotiation of a new set of five-year plans to begin next year, underline the need for Vietnam and Cambodia to improve their relations with the West. It puts further pressure on both countries to seek a settlement to the Cambodian war, on which improvement of relations with the United States depends.
A Hungarian diplomat in Hanoi said, ''We want a relationship with Vietnam similar to that of any other Western European country, based on clear mutual and commercial interests.'' 
 
Prague Recalls Envoys
In late February, the Czechoslovak Ambassadors in Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos were recalled to Prague for consultations by the new Government. Czechoslovak diplomats say they will be replaced and their embassy staffs reduced, while relations with Laos may be downgraded to charge status.
The Hungarian Ambassador in Phnom Penh has sent an evaluation of his embassy to Budapest that discusses the options of closing it or reducing its staff.
A Hungarian diplomat said cost is the main issue, but doubted the embassy would be closed. ''You can see the high tide coming from the West as part of any settlement,'' he said. ''To close the embassy in the face of this high tide would be stupid.''
Still, another Eastern European diplomat said, the focus of foreign policy among the newly non-Communist governments must be Europe, the Soviet Union and the West, with Indochina only a distant concern.
 
Anxiety in Phnom Penh
He said the changes are causing severe anxiety in the Cambodian Government, which is trying to secure relations with more countries and fears losing ties with any of the 10 that now have diplomatic missions here.
Many Eastern European embassies, a diplomat said, are operating with no clear instructions from their tumultuous home capitals.
''There is a dangerous silence on the part of many East European embassies here,'' he said, while Western countries like Australia, Japan, Sweden, Canada, France and Britain are gearing up for better relations ''as soon as it is seemly.''
Cambodia's main aid donors are the Soviet Union, East Germany and Czechoslovakia.
 
Change in Trade Relations
''These relationships will inevitably change, and soon,'' a Polish diplomat said. ''Comecon is moving toward a hard-currency relationship, and no one can afford to subsidize trade in the same ways.''
Even the Soviet Union, which supplies Cambodia's oil and gasoline at subsidized prices and provides military aid, is now negotiating a new five-year plan, to run from 1991, that will look very different from the last one.
''Many figures may change,'' a Soviet diplomat said.
With the possibility of an Indochina peace settlement and changes in Moscow's foreign policy, military aid to Hanoi is sure to decrease, a Soviet diplomat there said. ''Our relationship, which was before mostly political and military, is now becoming mostly economic and cultural.''
 
'We Start to Count the Money'
''That creates more problems,'' he said, including how to value old loans. Instead of building huge plants and infrastructure projects all on credit, ''with no thought about cost, now we start to count the money.''
The new five-year plan, he said, would concentrate on joint ventures and contracts between enterprises on the basis of hard currency and market prices. ''We seek to balance our relations and make them mutually beneficial,'' he said.
He said Western estimates of $2.5 billion a year in Soviet help to Vietnam were ''roughly right,'' not including direct aid. But he would not comment on suggestions that this figure may be reduced as much as 40 percent.
Such considerations clearly worry the Vietnamese. Nguyen Ngoc Minh of the State Bank said Hanoi's 1989 budget deficit was more than double 1988's, increasing inflationary pressures.
A sizable cut in Soviet aid as Hanoi tries to remodel its industry, create jobs, adopt market prices and eliminate subsidies would be bound to hurt.
In particular, he said, it would intensify Vietnam's credit squeeze, at least until Washington stops blocking new loans from the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank.
Planned Comecon projects, like improving the north-south railroad, ''are as good as dead,'' a diplomat said.
Even the official news organizations of the countries that were once Communist now have little reason to maintain Hanoi bureaus. As Western news agencies negotiate to open offices in Hanoi, at least two Eastern European agencies are planning to relocate to Bangkok or Jakarta.

HEADLINE: Call for Black Militia Stuns Milwaukee

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE, April 4

 BODY:
A Milwaukee Alderman has stunned and divided this quiet, no-nonsense city with his efforts to revive the Black Panthers and build a black militia that he says will take violent action if his demands for racial parity are not met within five years.
The Alderman, Michael McGee, a former Black Panther who represents one of the city's poorest, most crime-ridden districts, says the inner city has watched as the rest of Milwaukee has prospered. He has vowed to promote violence unless the city creates a $100 million jobs program and takes other steps to revive black neighborhoods.
''We've done things the nonviolent way, and it hasn't gotten us anywhere,'' Mr. McGee said in an interview. ''The only way to get respect is to be willing to use violence. We either stand there with our backs to the wall or fight our way out.'' 
Many white Milwaukeeans have responded in outrage, with one white Alderman calling his demands a ''clear-cut case of extortion.'' Mayor John O. Norquist, who is white and a one-time ally of Mr. McGee, has called for his resignation, saying, ''In this business you have to decide: You're in the system or you're out of it.''
 
Words Find a Chord
But the criticism seems only to have fueled Mr. McGee's bombast and his support among many blacks. While more moderate black politicians have denounced talk of violence, Mr. McGee's message of empowerment has struck a chord with his constituents. (Legal officials said they did not think Mr. McGee was breaking any law, since he is not advocating any immediate, specific act of violence at this point.) In the shadows of the glass towers and automated breweries of booming downtown Milwaukee, 600 frustrated and angry blacks packed into a grade school auditorium in a depressed black neighborhood Wednesday night to sign up for the militia.
They cheered and hooted and stood in ovation as Mr. McGee, dressed in black fatigues with a yellow arm patch depicting a black panther, said: ''Dr. King said he might not make it there with us. He won't. We're going to fight our way to the promised land.''
Many in the audience said they were willing to do whatever was necessary to improve their lives. But most said they did not think it would come to violence.
''I'm ready to die if I have to,'' said DeJuan Johnson, a 25-year-old carpenter's aide. ''We can't sit back and let our neighborhoods die.'
 
A Depressing Shift
Indeed, the city has undergone a dramatic economic shift in the past decade that researchers say has most hurt Milwaukee's blacks, 40 percent of whom live below the poverty level.
While non-manufacturing and service jobs have created boom times for the business core, Milwaukee has lost tens of thousands of factory jobs that lured blacks to the city in the first place. Some researchers put the black unemployment rate in the inner city at 25 percent, as against 5 percent for the city over all.
A recent study conducted for the Milwaukee City Council showed that blacks in Milwaukee were discriminated against in many everyday matters.
Last year, researchers from the University of Chicago listed Milwaukee -where most blacks live on the North Side, and most whites live on the South - as one of five American cities whose patterns of segregation were so pronounced and so deeply entrenched that they were deemed ''hypersegregated.'' The other cities were Chicago, Detroit, Cleveland and Newark.
But unlike some poor cities in the South, where impoverished blacks may live in shanties without indoor plumbing, racial discrimination is more subtle in Milwaukee, black residents say.
''It's a very clean city with a clean kind of racism,'' said Jerrel Jones, president of Courier Communications, owner of two black newspapers and a black radio station in Milwaukee. ''You don't see a ghetto as such. But if you knock on a door on our side of town, 25 people might come out who haven't eaten in a week.''
 
'He Scares People'
Many white city officials concede that more should be done to help blacks, who make up about a fourth of the population. But they say threats of violence are only clouding his message. ''Whether intended or not, the words of Alderman McGee have created a lot of dissension and divisiveness in the city,'' said Alderman John R. Kalwitz, who is white.
''He scares people,'' said Thomas P. Donegan, the president of the City Council, who is white. ''There's a sense of outrage that anyone would dare threaten to use guns.''
The 40-year-old Mr. McGee, who was an Army medic in the Vietnam War, has been a renegade on the Council since he was first elected in 1984.
He is considered a passionate and committed spokesman for the disposessed, one who will do almost anything to get his point across. Once, he hung a black baby doll from a tree inside the City Hall rotunda to symbolize racism in Milwaukee. Another time he wore a paper bag over his head in an official Council portrait to protest lack of funds for blacks. Moving Too Fast? In recent years, while his district slipped further into poverty, development elsewhere has accelerated with new shopping malls and skyscrapers, a new home for the Milwaukee Bucks basketball team, efforts to get a hockey team and plans for a new baseball stadium for the Milwaukee Brewers, which alone could cost $100 million.
''People tell me, 'Mike, you want to move too fast,' '' Mr. McGee said. ''But they move fast when they want something downtown. Our community cannot take a back seat to baseball and basketball.''
He said that, for now, his militia would spend its time patrolling black neighborhoods and fighting crime and drugs, much like the Black Muslims have in Washington, D.C. But he said he is ready to fight if black neighborhoods do not get more attention by 1995.
''I'm not advocating what the Black Panthers were advocating,'' Mr. McGee said, recalling that the Black Panthers advocated self-defense, not violent attacks, and promoted community social programs. ''Our militia will be about violence. I'm talking actual fighting, bloodshed and urban guerilla warfare.''
His brand of politics is coming to be known around here as ''the politics of discomfort.''
''He certainly is pricking our conscious about the real world,'' Mr. Kalwitz said. ''It's a legitimate question. Where are our priorities when you spend millions for downtown amenities and dribbles for the neighborhood?''
Others are not so convinced. Alderwoman Annette Scherbert, who is white, likened his demands to blackmail. ''A hundred million dollars, folks, or I start up my army,'' she said just after he announced his plans.
Still, Walter Farrell, a professor of educational policy and community relations at the University of Milwaukee who is black, said that many poor blacks hear Mr. McGee's overall message differently. ''What he has done for blacks in this town,'' said Professor Farrell, ''is restore their dignity.''

LENGTH: 1807 words

HEADLINE: Boston Educator Offers A Bold Campaign Style

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, April 5

 BODY:
John R. Silber is not a conventional candidate for the Democratic nomination for governor of Massachusetts.
His stock speech often includes blasts at incompetent teachers, the women's movement, lawyers, welfare, teen-age sex and television - all things that he contends are causing the decline of America.
As a remedy, the 63-year-old president of Boston University may offer homilies from McGuffey's readers or invoke the example of fifth-century Athens, ''where on a single afternoon you might meet Socrates or Aristophanes.''
The question for Mr. Silber, a native of Texas, is whether his brash, idiosyncratic views can ignite a popular groundswell in a year of widespread disenchantment with politics as usual in Massachusetts. When he announced his candidacy in January, Mr. Silber was given a good chance of doing precisely that, especially at a time when Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, who has dominated the state for the last 16 years, is leaving office. 
But in the first few weeks of his campaign, Mr. Silber, more accustomed to the argumentative Socratic method of teaching than the cautious nuances of politics, quickly developed a reputation for being too outspoken. He described Massachusetts as ''a welfare magnet'' for immigrants, for example, and called Lowell ''the Cambodian capital'' of the United States.
 
'I Don't Speak Plastic'
There is some talk in political circles that Mr. Silber's remarks are part of a deliberate strategy intended to appeal to conservatives or disaffected blue-collar Democrats. But his friends believe Mr. Silber was speaking spontaneously, simply following his combative nature. ''I don't speak plastic like other politicians,'' he said with pride in an interview. But candor may have its price. ''Unfortunately, I think his reputation for controversy now precedes him and this blots out his substance,'' said Thomas Kiley, a respected political consultant here who is not associated with any candidate for governor in this year's race.
''Unlike other politicians who have made our politics so boring and barren, Silber is not afraid to take on the fundamental problems of what's wrong with American society,'' Mr. Kiley said. ''But there is a danger of him becoming a caricature of himself.''
Mr. Silber's potential appeal and troubles as well were evident in the reactions to a speech he made last week before the Parent School Organization at the high school in Cohasset, an affluent seaside suburb south of Boston.
''He knocked me right out of my seat,'' said Martha Gjesteby, a member of the town's governing Board of Selectmen who had come to hear Mr. Silber out of curiosity.
 
Impressed, but Mystified
''He was very eloquent and spoke about things that need to be said,'' said Mrs. Gjesteby, who described herself as a liberal Republican. ''But I don't know whether he believes what he says or is just trying to be provocative.''
Mr. Silber also faces an immediate problem. Under state Democratic Party regulations, he must win 15 percent of the votes of the delegates to the state Democratic convention in June to get his name on the ballot for the September primary.
Unluckily for Mr. Silber, in Massachusetts most of the delegates are liberals, and many are from groups he offended with his unguarded early campaign oratory, including blacks, Jews, women, state employees, teachers, homosexuals and immigrants. Even though Mr. Silber's remarks have greatly improved his name recognition among voters at large, Mr. Kiley and other specialists believe he may have a hard time meeting the 15 percent threshold of the convention delegates.
Some powerful supporters of Mr. Silber, including William M. Bulger, a Democrat who is president of the State Senate, are leading an effort to cut the 15 percent threshold to 5 percent.
Kevin H. White, the former Mayor of Boston, whom Mr. Silber hired as a professor, said that if Mr. Silber does get on the ballot, ''he will be a potent candidate.'' Mr. White, a Democrat, said he saw polls done early in the winter by the firm of Penn and Schoen indicating that ''Silber is exactly what people are looking for.''
By that, Mr. White explained, he means a strong leader from outside the ranks of the usual politicians who can both appeal to disgruntled blue-collar Democrats and offer a new vision for liberals.
 
Other Contenders for Post
The current front-runner for the Democratic nomination is Francis X. Bellotti, a former state Attorney General, whose campaign is well organized and financed but who has the liability of being seen as a longtime political insider with little capacity to inspire. The other major challenger is Lieut. Gov. Evelyn Murphy, who must overcome her close ties to the embattled Dukakis administration. Raymond L. Flynn, Boston's current Mayor, who is regarded with admiration by many voters for his apparent sincerity and compassion, might make the strongest candidate if he can make up his mind to run.
Mr. Silber said his reason for running was self-evident: ''This state is in a terrible crisis, and I think one can stand on the sidelines and watch a vigorous economic power go down the tube through inaction and through paralysis in state government only so long.''
The Massachusetts budget has a persistent deficit that neither Governor Dukakis nor the Legislature seems able to resolve, especially given a strong tide of anti-tax sentiment in the state.
But Mr. Silber said confidently that he could do for Massachusetts what he did for Boston University when he took it over in 1970. At the time it was widely considered a mediocre college beset by a tiny endowment, a faculty with many ''second-raters,'' in Mr. Silber's view, and a serious budget deficit. Mr. Silber immediately ended the deficit and Boston University has run in the black ever since.
The secret to his success, he said, was that he realized that the school's budget ''was a useless managerial document,'' just as the state's is now. Many of the real costs of any division were hidden because they were scattered, not consolidated under one heading.
 
Strong View on Budget
If the state budget was carefully analyzed in this fashion, Mr. Silber insisted, ''the waste would simply leap off the page.'' In his view, there are many excess state employees who could be dismissed, and many poorly run programs that could be trimmed, like bilingual education.
Mr. Silber points with pride to other accomplishments in his 20-year dominion at Boston University. He has remade the faculty, hiring stars like Elie Wiesel, the Nobel Prize winner; he has attracted freshmen with higher Scholastic Aptitude Test scores than those of previous years, and he has increased the endowment tenfold. And he does not apologize for his salary of more than $275,000, the highest of any university president in the country.
''I'm not embarrassed to get one-quarter of what a mindless anchorman on TV gets,'' he once said. ''I'm not average.'' He is on paid leave until the end of his campaign.
But all the progress at Boston University has come with turbulence. Mr. Silber purged the board of trustees, he replaced deans who differed with him and he has fought repeatedly with professors and students over issues like unionization of the faculty, gay rights and Marine Corps recruiting on campus. He has had to cope with death threats, arson in his home and a lawsuit by the American Civil Liberties Union over a student's right to hang a protest poster from his dormitory room.
 
Formative Years in Texas
Mr. Silber's background may have played a role in the formation of his pugnacious personality. A slight youngster with a right arm deformed at birth, he grew up in Texas, a state that exalts in the physical prowess of cowboys and football players.
His father, a German immigrant with strong-minded beliefs, saw to it that the family engaged in ruthless debates around the dinner table.
After entering Divinity School at Yale University, Mr. Silber switched to the philosophy department, where he wrote his Ph.D. dissertation on Immanuel Kant. Kant's belief in the power of man's will is still an active influence in Mr. Silber's life.
Mr. Silber is hard to peg politically. One Boston columnist described him as a ''political hermaphrodite,'' though Mr. Silber insisted in an interview that ''I'm very easily defined as a traditional liberal Democrat.'' He recalled his early involvement, while a dean at the University of Texas in the 1960's, in trying to integrate the school, and he pointed to his work for the Head Start program and childhood nutrition plans.
But he has acknowledged that he voted for Ronald Reagan and George Bush for President, and in his recently published book, ''Straight Shooting: What's Wrong with America and How to Fix It,'' he wrote, ''Abortion is homicide.''
 
Provocative Comments
Among campaign comments that created a storm was a reference Mr. Silber made comparing the Rev. Jesse Jackson's speaking style to Hitler's. Mr. Silber added that if he were President of the United States, Mr. Jackson ''would have a place in my Cabinet, because every President needs someone to write bumper stickers.''
Louis Elisa, president of the Boston branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said this was a calculated appeal ''to the worst parts of society,'' adding, ''It's good politics, but not very sensitive or progressive.''
Mr. Silber also antagonized some Jews by saying in an interview with The Boston Globe that he had given up the idea of converting to Judaism as a young divinity student when he discovered that ''the racism of Jews is quite phenomenal.''
Leonard Zakim, regional director of the New England chapter of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, said Mr. Silber should be held accountable for making an overgeneralization. But Mr. Zakim recalled that Mr. Silber had a long record of support for Israel and Jewish causes and said, ''He is not an anti-Semite.''
In the last few weeks Mr. Silber has been more circumspect in his remarks. But at Cohasset High School last week, he still made the audience buzz when he said one of the major reasons for the decline in the quality of public school teachers was the women's movement, which has enabled women to enter other professions.
From Mr. Silber's perspective, much of the strife around him has grown out of what he perceives as his quest for excellence or greatness, qualities he finds missing from current American life. In his new book, Mr. Silber, quoting from the dramatist Aristophanes, wrote that democracies ''need heroes and require a vision of greatness if they are to achieve their potential.''
Yet, paradoxically, he said, democracies are ''frequently indifferent to heroes and hostile to greatness,'' so that in a democracy, the hero is doomed to suffer.

HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENT BILL SENT TO THE HOUSE

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 5

 BODY:
After agreeing on the difficult issue of how to curb acid rain, the House Energy and Commerce Committee voted tonight to recommend sweeping legislation to strengthen the Clean Air Act. The vote was 42 to 1.
The measure includes a complex allowance system intended to help Midwestern states with the added burden of reducing pollutants that cause acid rain.
Like the bill passed by the Senate on Tuesday, the House bill would provide the Federal Government and state and local governments with new tools to reduce urban smog and toxic chemicals in the air, as well as the acid rain that is harming lakes and streams in some parts of this country and Canada. 
But there are some significant differences in the two bills that will need to be resolved in a conference between members of the House and Senate before a bill can be sent to the President. Many of those differences have to do with tougher requirements in the House bill to reduce urban smog.
As the House committee neared completion of its bill, the Environmental Protection Agency today released its annual report on urban air quality trends, showing that urban smog had increased by 2 percent from 1979 through 1988.
 
Lead Concentrations Decline
The report showed that other air pollutants listed by the Clean Air Act, including sulfur, carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxides and dust, had declined but were still present in urban areas at relatively high levels. Only lead concentrations in the air dropped sharply in the period, largely because lead in gasoline is being gradually eliminated, the report found.
William K. Reilly, Administrator of the E.P.A., said when releasing the report, ''Reauthorizing the Clean Air Act, a top priority of President Bush, is the best way to improve the air Americans breathe without hindering the country's economic growth.''
Like the Senate bill, the legislation drafted by the House committee would set new deadlines for meeting smog requirements and would also require annual progress in reducing smog, a requirement that is not in the current law. The new measure would require stricter controls on pollution from automobile emissions starting in the mid-1990's and, if the environmental agency decides it is necessary, even tighter controls after the turn of the century.
The House bill, like the Senate's, would require factories and other sources of toxic pollution to install the ''maximum available control technology'' to reduce such pollution. It would also have a second stage of controls on air toxics that would be contingent on earlier progress.
 
A Question of Who Pays
Also like the Senate bill, the House measure would require that sulfur dioxide emissions from coal-burning power plants, the chief component of acid rain, be reduced by 10 million tons, to about 50 percent of the current amount, by the end of the century.
At issue in the House panel's debate over acid rain was not how or how much sulfur dioxide should be cut, but who should bear the economic burden of curbing pollution.
Lawmakers from Midwestern states, where most of the power plants are situated, had asked that the cost of reducing pollution be shared nationally. Representative Philip R. Sharp, an Indiana Democrat, wanted an amendment that would have required a fee on sulfur pollution from factories, refineries and other sources other than power plants, to help the electric utilities and their customers meet the cost of reducing acid rain.
 
Aid for Coal Miners
Lawmakers from coal-mining states hoped for financial aid for miners of high sulfur coal, whose jobs would be threatened if utilities were forced to switch to cleaner low-sulfur coal.
But the committee did not adopt either form of aid. Instead, it concentrated on distributing credits that would be awarded to utilities that lower their emissions more than required by the law. These credits could be bought, sold or traded. Plants that lower their emissions below the required level could presumably sell their credits to help pay for the costs of scrubbers or low-sulfur coal.
Representative Terry L. Bruce, Democrat of Illinois, said: ''This acid rain accord is better for the Midwest than the Senate bill. It softens the blow against the Midwest.''
Because the House committee sought to resolve the sharp regional differences in negotiations, a protracted debate on the floor of the House is not expected, aides said tonight. The legislation will probably be taken up by the House within the next few weeks, the aides said.

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Our 'Open Doormat'

BYLINE: by William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In the Shanghai Communique of 1972, the United States and China - whose leaders could never have agreed on a credible ''joint'' communique - used an ingenious method of making parallel but often contrary statements that broke new ground without seeming to give an inch on principle.
Zhou Enlai, in the opening statement of the Chinese ''side,'' put in a thought that has ironic reverberations today: ''wherever there is oppression, there is resistance.''
During the next few years in China, there was oppression. Resistance first made itself felt in 1976 on the national day of mourning, Qingming, when crowds in Tiananmen Square expressed their grief at the death earlier that year of Zhou. After that reformist demonstration came the fall of the Gang of Four, the rise of Deng Xiaoping, and the revivifying capitalist road. 
But Deng failed to grasp the key link between the profit motive and political freedom; in time, the liberator of the Chinese farmer became the brutal oppressor of the Chinese student and worker at the Tiananmen demonstrations of a year ago.
This week, on Qingming, mourners were barred by troops from Tiananmen. No troublesome ''strollers'' allowed; no traditional white paper flowers worn.
Despite this palpable sense of oppression, and despite American public opinion, Mr. Bush has maintained close relations with Deng and his most recent chosen successor, the hard-line Li Peng. The President has been willing to take moral discomfort and critical flak to be in a position to help influence the rise of a reform faction after the death of Deng, who will be 86 this summer.
That moderate faction is no fiction; Chinese leaders like Zhao Ziyang, now under house arrest, understand that prosperity needs democracy.
With the exception of the time the President and Secretary of State brazenly lied about not having sent high-level emissaries to Beijing after the massacre, I have not been in the vanguard of critics of our kowtowing to the aging tyrant. Some moral muttering in this space, but not with the usual zip.
That's because all my old Nixon buddies and most of the old China hands (notably excepting Winston Lord) have been assuring one and all that patience would soon pay off.
Honey was supposed to attact more concessions than vinegar. By continuing to support World Bank loans and GATT gains; by keeping open the flow of technology; and by sending high-level envoys to toast the men who ordered the massacre - we would get the passage to safety of the dissidents given haven in our embassy; we could be sure of no intermediate-range missile sales to the Mideast; and most important, we would see amnesty for protesters and a relaxation of the new oppression.
But it's coming up to a year now. Despite frequent indications (the word ''assurances'' was always withheld), dangerous missile sales seem to be taking place; amnesty is forgotten and the dissident Fang Lizhi is the target of more abuse; Hong Kong's freedom is newly threatened; critics of the crackdown are denounced as ''foreign hostile forces.''
The honey is not working. The lame excuse: The Chinese leaders were so spooked by the overthrow of Romania's Ceausescu that not even our obsequious cheek-turning could contain their panic to enforce stability.
Time for a new assessment. The President cannot say ''Oh, there are those who say, 'Break off all contact, isolate a billion people, stick our heads in the sand,' '' because that nutty alternative to his non-reaction is not being proposed at all. Ambassador Jim Lilley in Beijing should remain in correct contact, and more visas should be issued to students and visitors.
Winston Lord and The Washington Post's Meg Greenfield were right and our China establishment was wrong. Mr. Bush's ''understanding'' of oppression has been interpreted as weakness. Because the Bush policy of the open doormat has been met by arrogant greatwalling, our moral standing has been compromised and our geopolitical influence undermined.
When we sell our soul for a mess of pottage, and no pottage is served, let's at least learn a lesson: no defense technology transfer or trade financing until progress is demonstrated. In diplomacy as in life, cooperation is encouraged when it is clear that contempt has consequences.
To our many Chinese friends looking past Deng's sclerotic grip, Mr. Bush should commend Zhou's words in the Shanghai Communique: ''wherever there is oppression, there is resistance.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Hispanic Residents Rally Against Closing of Social Clubs

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
As New York City clamps down on illegal social clubs, the Hispanic community is rallying to pressure the Dinkins administration to avoid sweeping away clubs that the community says serve vital cultural, economic and educational needs.
Hispanic groups contend that their cultural heritage is threatened by the city's efforts, which, they say, have unfairly lumped together these small, informal civic centers and the bars and dance clubs like the Happy Land Social Club, where 87 people died in a fire last month.
On Tuesday and Wednesday, the city chained and locked 36 clubs that were open in violation of fire safety laws.
''The city has taken a kind of Wyatt Earp approach to this clean-up,' said Carmen Canales-Ambert, a data-base analyst at New York Hospital who belongs to Familias Unidas del Bajo Manhattan, a community club on the Lower East Side. ''What we resent very much is the way the Latino community has been targeted by this approach without any consideration for the role each individual club plays in the community.'' 
But Stanley Davis, a spokesman for Mayor David N. Dinkins, said the Mayor's policy is to shut down any unsafe clubs. ''The Mayor said the most important issue here is safety and that if any club, whether it considers itself a social club or not, if it doesn't comply with fire and safety standards, it will be closed,'' he said.
The 65 members of Familias Unidas fear that their domino games, little league team and the myriad other activities that take root behind the crimson curtains on the second-floor in the building at 225 Avenue B will become a thing of the past. While Familias Unidas has no city code violations, the thicket of building codes and requirements can be overwhelming for small neighborhood groups, she said.
She has invited several Hispanic organizations to meet later this month to find ways to help the city distinguish between clubs like Familias Unidas and those like Happy Land. She said she plans to ask the city to send representatives.
Community leaders said that many of the civic clubs cannot afford to rent space in well-kept buildings so they settle for rooms in structures that look like they should be condemned. They also said that club directors have had difficulty forcing landlords to make repairs to meet city standards.
Such was apparently in the case at El Caney Cultural Center in East Harlem, a traditional campaign stop for political contenders including Mr. Dinkins and Manhattan Borough President Ruth W. Messinger. Famous in the Hispanic community for displays of Hispanic art and performances by Hispanic dancers and actors, the club recently closed after the city posted a vacate order on March 26. A previous vacate order for fire-safety violations was posted in April but had been ignored.
''Felix Cordero exhibited his paintings there, they had poetry readings, and I remember when Eli Alvarado presented a gem of a play about how we culturally view spiritualism and how its blended in with our politics,'' said Elizabeth Juarez Sanchez, a social worker at a private foster-care agency. ''It gave lots of artists an opportunity they didn't have in the mainstream.''
Homesick Puerto Rican immigrants began establishing clubs named for their hometowns in the late 1940's and early 50's, said Roberto Feliciano, a retired postal worker and self-designated historian specializing in Hispanic clubs. He helped found the now defunct Club Progresista Aguadillano at 62 Delancey Street, which gave birth to Familias Unidas.
The clubs initially raised money to pay their rent by selling food and trinkets on the street and holding various sporting and social activities. That changed in 1964, when the Puerto Rican Community Development Project was set up to fight poverty in the Puerto Rican community. The agency, using public and private funds, began to support many of the clubs.
That was the heyday, Mr. Feliciano said, when clubs helped their members register to vote, find housing, get jobs and take out loans. The clubs were scheduled stops on the campaign trail, and rallying centers for political protests.
 
A Lack of Money and Clout
''They serve an important role in the adaptation and assimilation process,'' said Migdalia DeJesus-Torres, who heads the Puerto Rican Studies Department at John Jay College of Criminal Justice. ''They serve as a needed introduction to American life, and they serve to preserve the culture and traditions of the home country.''
Since the demise of the Puerto Rican project in 1978, Ms. DeJesus-Torres said, club directors have lacked the money and clout to pressure their landlords to maintain the buildings where their clubs are located. She contended that a system of payoffs, from clubs to landlords to building inspectors, had developed. ''They can't understand why, now, after all these years, they're closing them down for violations that have existed a long time,'' she said.
In discussing El Caney last week, where his Hispanic affairs adviser, William Nieves, had been a director, Mr. Dinkins tried to draw a distinction between that club and the social clubs that are more like nightclubs, but such a distinction is absent in the law he has proposed to increase penalties for establishments that violate safety laws.
''These are some of the very few organizations we have in our community, and now you see that the city administration, instead of trying to find a way to find out which organizations are which, is practically engaging in a witch hunt,'' said Apolinar Trinidad, who works for the state and is active in Latinos United for Political Action, a Hispanic political group.
''It's very disheartening,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Dean of New School Picked To Head Planning Agency

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Filling the most important vacancy left in his administration, Mayor David N. Dinkins has chosen Richard L. Schaffer, dean of the Graduate School of Management and Urban Professions at the New School for Social Research, as chairman of the city's Planning Commission.
Senior city officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the appointment would be announced today. Mr. Schaffer will take charge of the Planning Commission at a pivotal time, as the way the city governs land use is changing under the new city charter.
The commission, which reviews scores of building projects each year and also oversees long-term planning, will be expanded from 7 members to 13. The commission's duties will remain much the same, but most of its decisions will be subject to final review by the City Council starting this summer, when the Board of Estimate, which has been the final authority on land use, goes out of business. 
 
Upper West Side Consultant
Under the charter, Mr. Dinkins was to have made the appointment by March 1, along with his other six appointments to the commission. Developers, community groups and politicians have been eagerly awaiting his choice of chairman.
Mr. Schaffer, an urban planner, previously served as chairman of the urban planning division of the School of Architecture of Columbia University. He was a consultant last year to a special planning committee that recommended tighter limits on the development of the Upper West Side.
The panel, formed by the neighborhood's community board, Board No. 7, and by the Municipal Art Society, also suggested plans for building town houses within housing projects and suggested increasing the allowable building density on many blocks north of 96th Street.
Mr. Dinkins had let it be known that he sought an experienced professional planner, rather than an experienced politician, to head the commission. Mr. Schaffer would seem to combine something of both.
 
A Previous Candidate
He was a candidate to be chairman of the commission several years ago, when former Mayor Edward I. Koch chose Sylvia Deutsch instead, and is a friend of Robert F. Wagner Jr., the president of the Board of Education and himself a former Planning Commission chairman. Mr. Schaffer's former wife is a daughter of former Mayor John V. Lindsay.
Colleagues say Mr. Schaffer, who holds a doctorate in economics, is also a respected scholar and administrator. Before going to the New School, he served for a time as acting dean of Columbia's School of Architecture.
''He is someone who has been on the edge of New York City politics for a long time,'' said Kenneth Frampton, a former chairman of the architecture division of Columbia's School of Architecture. ''He was a very good administrator and he did a good job in a difficult period between two deans.''
Sigurd Grava, a member of Columbia's architecture faculty, said: ''I think he'll make a splendid chairman. He has plenty of experience and is a very astute administrator.''
Mr. Schaffer is known as an advocate of community participation in planning decisions. ''It's always messy and frustrating when you have community meetings, but the results are always better,'' he said in an interview last year.

HEADLINE: LAW;
At the Bar

BYLINE: By David Margolick

 BODY:
In the opening scene of ''Mountain,'' William O. Douglas is on his deathbed, marshaling his dwindling energies to defend his career. ''The law must be about life!'' he rails. ''About the people and their lives! How can you sit in judgment on them if you haven't lived? If you haven't taken those journeys?''
It is a neat epitaph for Douglas, who served for 36 tumultuous years on the United States Supreme Court, longer than anyone else. And it is the leitmotif of Douglas Scott's unusual new play about the man, starring Len Cariou, which opened last night at the Lucille Lortel Theater in New York. [Review, page C29.] Most Supreme Court Justices are not the stuff of great drama. The cloistered life of reading motions, sitting in conferences, hearing oral arguments presents few dramatic possibilities. Whatever other descriptive labels one might place on William H. Rehnquist, William J. Brennan Jr. or their peers, ''charismatic'' is not one that leaps to mind. 
But there is undoubtedly an epic quality to Douglas's life, which began in Yakima, Wash., and took him to Columbia and Yale law schools and New Deal Washington before he reached the High Court in 1939. He sat there until 1975. Five years later he was buried in Arlington National Cemetery where, to the strains of ''This Land is Your Land,'' he was placed 20 feet from Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr. Along the way Douglas wrote 1,300 opinions, caused continual controversy, married four times and climbed innumerable mountains. It was to those mountains - usually the Cascades, but also the Himalayas -that he retreated all his life for reflection and refreshment. The play's few props include not only the predictable robe and law books, but also a hiking staff and a Stetson.
As he said in his autobiography, those same mountains kept him from becoming a conventional corporate lawyer. When the Swaine of Cravath, Swaine & Moore offered the young Douglas $5,000 a year to practice there, he turned it down, convinced that such a job would sap him of his spirit. Even those who scaled the heights of Wall Street ''did not seem to have much left at 65,'' he wrote. ''If I walked their paths I'd never be able to climb another mountain.''
Mr. Scott, 56, approached Douglas from an unusual direction. Mr. Scott's background is not in law, but in history and English. He spent many years with the Rand Corporation, including a tour with Daniel Ellsberg in Vietnam, and now works for William F. Baker, president of Channel 13. The ''Douglas'' Mr. Scott is named for is Fairbanks, not William O. Mr. Scott began ''Mountain'' in 1985 after reading ''Go East, Young Man,'' the first volume of Douglas's autobiography. Then he read all of Douglas's opinions as well as his 30 books. He spoke with at least one of Douglas's wives and a few former law clerks. And he retraced some of Douglas's steps, beginning by walking the streets of Yakima.
Last October, Mr. Cariou took a similar trip - ''to see the country Douglas was so much in love with,'' he said. To get a better feel for his demeanor, voice and mannerisms, he watched a television interview Douglas gave to Eric Sevareid. From what had been only the most rudimentary knowledge of Douglas, Mr. Cariou came to admire what he saw as his vision, drive and singleness of purpose.
In a sense, it is appropriate that Douglas's lionizers are lay people. Among legal scholars, his reputation a decade after his death is mixed. However much they applaud his civil libertarian instincts, they fault him for shooting from the hip in his opinions and slighting legal theory, texts and precedents. G. Edward White, a professor of law and history at the University of Virginia Law School, has called Douglas ''the foremost anti-judge of his time.'' His point is that rugged individualism is better suited to mountaineering than judging, at least on a collegial institution like the Supreme Court.
Mr. Scott's play touches upon some of these issues, though sometimes only by omission. For all the opinions Douglas wrote, ''Mountain'' contains few references to them. John C. Vennema, the actor who portrays the various men in Douglas's career, is called upon to play Louis D. Brandeis (the Justice he replaced); Franklin D. Roosevelt (the man who appointed him); Gerald R. Ford (who tried to have him impeached and, eventually, appointed his replacement) and Richard M. Nixon (who once told Douglas he inspired his political career). ''I do believe that hearing that compliment was the most upsetting moment of my life,'' Douglas says in the play.
But there is next to nothing from Hugo Black or Felix Frankfurter or John Marshall Harlan, the men who served so long with him.
''America was the better for having Douglas on the Court, and I wish he were still there,'' Mr. Scott said. ''But he could be a very, very difficult man. I admire him, and in a way I love him. But I don't think I like him.''
