HEADLINE: High-Detail TV Faces Fund Cuts

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
The Defense Department has quietly proposed diverting $20 million of the $30 million intended for research on high-definition television, a technology that has become a symbol in the debate over how the United States can best compete with the Japanese.
The department's Under Secretary for Acquisition, John A. Betti, told officials earlier this week at the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, which finances advanced research, that some of the money would instead be spent on a $4 million study on how to streamline the Defense Department acquisition process, said a Pentagon official who asked not to be identified.
Most of the rest of the money might be earmarked by the Bush Administration for foreign aid for Panama and Nicaragua, the official said. The official said that cuts were also being considered in other programs of the agency, known as Darpa. 
 
In Conflict With Report
The planned cut in money for HDTV research comes as an advisory panel to the Pentagon is preparing to recommend that the Defense Department vastly increase its efforts to help American industry develop high-definition television. The study warned that the United States could become dependent on foreign suppliers for the new television, whose fine-detailed pictures have a number of military applications. [Page D13] Talk of the potential cuts has created alarm among some members of Congress, who are urging the Pentagon to reverse its stand. Representative Mel Levine, Democrat of California, said any such cut would be ''outrageous and irresponsible.''
''The Department of Defense seems determined that the military is going to be 100 percent dependent on foreign sources for this tech,'' said Senator Albert Gore Jr., Democrat of Tennessee. ''It's dangerous for defense procurement and tragic for the future of this part of our domestic economy.''
Mr. Betti and Dr. Craig Fields, director of Darpa, did not return calls yesterday asking for comment. But a Pentagon spokesman said that Mr. Betti had not yet actually taken action to divert the money.
HDTV provides television images with finer detail than current systems and could be used in information displays on military aircraft, ships and other vehicles, in intelligence systems and in training and simulation devices.
But American computer and electronics executives have also pointed to HDTV as critical if the United States is to maintain its lead in some areas of electronics.
Darpa has financed advanced computer and electronics research, including work critical in the development of work stations, personal computers and chip-making equipment. But late last year reports circulated that the Bush Administration was planning deep cuts in Defense Department programs intended to bolster commercial research and development in the United States.
The budget director, Richard G. Darman, and Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, were widely reported to have opposed such programs on the ground that they represented a de facto ''industrial policy.'' These officials have opposed such governmental coordination of the economy.
The $20 million for HDTV research has been authorized but not yet been released by Congress because Darpa has not supplied a required report explaining the need for such spending. In February, Dr. Fields wrote Congress saying that he had been unable to obtain the cooperation of the Administration in preparing the report.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Lessons for Japan In Stock Plunge

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
THE drop of almost 30 percent in the Tokyo stock market has provoked widespread fears among the Japanese that their economic miracle is ending.
Japanese economists began the year on a note of high optimism. The well-regarded Japan Center for Economic Research forecast that real output would grow by 4.9 percent in 1990, a bit more than in 1988. The average forecast of 45 other economic research centers, banks and brokerage houses called for 4.5 percent growth. Sumitomo Trust and Banking was highest at 5.2 percent; Mitsubishi Research Institute was lowest, at 3.6 percent. The famed Japanese consensus, in this area as in others, looked solid. 
But it was wrong. The Japanese economy is slowing down, and may be lucky to escape a recession this year. The drop in the stock market is likely to cause many Japanese companies to cut investment in new plant and equipment, and consumers may also choke up. At a conference in Washington this week, Satoshi Niibori, general manager of the Information and Research division of Mitsui & Company, said, ''People are frightened because they lost their paper profits.''
The effect of the falling stock market on corporate investment, however, is likely to be financial as well as psychological. Booming stock prices, built in large measure on soaring real estate prices, had given Japanese companies the collateral they needed for making huge bank loans to finance investments at home and abroad.
The profit outlook for Japanese companies is worsening, aggravated by the fall in the yen against the dollar. The Japanese Government is afraid to raise interest rates much higher to defend the yen, lest it cause a recession.
Japanese profits have also been hurt by the rise in world oil prices; again, the yen's fall hurts profits, because oil must be bought in costlier dollars.
While the drop in the yen makes Japanese exports cheaper, it causes other countries to step up pressure on Japan to curb its exports and open its own markets more widely to foreign goods. In its tense trade confrontation with the United States, Japan has finally blinked; it is now moving quickly to head off worsening relations. This week Japanese and American negotiators reached agreement to allow foreign producers to compete for satellite and other business in Japan potentially worth billions of dollars.
The Japanese are worried not only about the United States but also about being shut out of Europe, which it sees as the ''hot'' region of the future as a result of three exciting developments: the progress toward a single market in 1992 and beyond; the collapse of Communism, and the drive of East and West Germany toward unification. Theoretically, European integration and stronger growth should create greater opportunites for Japanese goods. But the Japanese fear that the European market may be tough to crack for products where there are strong European competitors. This is not a baseless worry, as demonstrated by the restrictions on Japanese autos in Europe: Of the 12 members of the European Community, five - France, Italy, Spain, Portugal and Britain - have quotas on cars imported directly from Japan. And some European countries want to extend those quotas to Japanese cars built in the United States, a move the United States is strongly resisting.
The Japanese are afraid that the Americans and Europeans will gang up on them. Perhaps belatedly, the Japanese may be coming to see that their own long-term interests would be best served by a liberal trading order, and they must be as open as they want others to be. A critical test will be not just in their bilateral negotiations with the United States but also in the support they give to the multilateral Uruguay Round negotiations to reduce barriers both to manufactured and farm goods and also to services and intellectual property, under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
The Japanese boom has clearly run into a snag. The stock market had climbed to levels out of touch with reality, and a painful readjustment is taking place; no one can be sure how long it will last, or how serious its consequences may be.
Though the economy is coming down to a slugggish rate of growth and could conceivably fall into recession, fears of the demise of the great Japanese economic expansion look premature. It was founded on hard work, high educational standards, high rates of savings and investment and a creative use of new technology.
When the stock market slide ends, those factors will still be in place, and Japan will have learned something of the global role it must play. A world of imbalances is an extremely risky one for Japan.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Adviser to Selectronics Is Chosen Its President

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
Selectronics Inc., a developer and manufacturer of handheld electronic reference products, has named James Finke, a longtime executive in the electronics industry, as its president and chief operating officer.
Mr. Finke, 62, will be joining Michael L. Weiner, chairman and chief executive, who is relinquishing the president's title.
Mr. Finke has been serving as an outside consultant for Selectronics and has been building a European distribution network for the company. He founded his own consulting firm called Interconsult in 1982 in North Hampton, N.H. ''I've had dozens of offers to join companies, but none were as promising as Selectronics,'' he said. 
The company recently merged with Microlytics, an affiliate of the Xerox Corporation, and Xerox now owns a third of Selectronics.
The company's annual sales are in the range of $30 million to $35 million, Mr. Finke said, and are expected to grow substantially.
The company's products include an electronic Bible, licensed from Harper & Row, and an electronic encyclopedia, licensed from Random House.
''In the last three months I've spent more time reading the Bible than in the last 30 years,'' Mr. Finke said. The company is optimistic about prosepcts for selling the electronic Bible to scholars and to ministers who want to find references quickly in sermon preparation.
Mr. Weiner was a Xerox employee when he founded Microlytics in 1985 with Xerox's help. Selectronics licensed software from Microlytics, which eventually purchased a third of Selectronics. Mr. Weiner then became president of Selectronics, as well as of Microlytics. The two companies merged in January.
Mr. Weiner said the company, based in Pittsford, N.Y., near Rochester, had the potential to grow to several hundred million dollars in annual sales relatively quickly. Its best-selling products are its Word Finder series and its multi-language translators, licensed from Berlitz.
Mr. Finke, the new president, was president of Commodore International Ltd., the computer maker, until 1982. He has also been vice president of European operationts for Data General. He holds a bachelor's degree in physics from Williams College, a master's degree in economics from Oxford and a law degree from Harvard.

HEADLINE: Consumer Credit Rise Slows a Bit

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 5

 BODY:
Americans took out $3.4 billion more in consumer credit than they repaid in February, but the pace slowed because of slackening demand for car loans, the Government said today.
The Federal Reserve said consumer credit rose at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.7 percent, down from January's revised 6.4 percent pace. The January rate had initially been reported at 5.9 percent.
Consumer credit, which includes all consumer loans except mortgages, was up by 7.3 percent in December.
Automobile loans advanced in February to a seasonally adjusted $889 million. That represented an annual rate of 3.7 percent, less than half the 8.4 percent jump in January when sales incentives were reinstated. The incentives continued in February, but consumers failed to respond favorably.
Without incentives, automobile loans fell by four-tenths of 1 percent in December.
 
Credit Card Debt Up
Credit card debt rose by $485 million, or by 2.9 percent at an annual rate, slightly faster than January's 1.8 percent gain but much slower than the 23.7 percent rate during the holiday shopping period in December.
Loans from banks and credit unions that are not secured by real estate were up by 12.1 percent, to an increase of $2.04 billion, after gains of 9 percent in January and 3 percent in December.
Borrowing for mobile homes continued its recent downward trend, off by $2 million, or by a tenth of 1 percent. With the exception of a 2.8 percent gain in September, mobile home credit has fallen each month since February 1989.
The various changes left total consumer debt at the end of February at $723.7 billion.

HEADLINE: Kaifu Praises Trade Deal But Sees Some Difficulties

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, April 6

 BODY:
Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu pleaded today for popular support of the changes his Government agreed to in trade talks with the United States, saying that they would eventually benefit Japanese consumers. But he acknowledged that the economic shifts would be ''painful'' and that he faced a potentially tough political battle to put the measures into effect.
In his generally vague comments at an early morning news conference here, Mr. Kaifu, whose political future may rest on his ability to muster support for the changes, was least clear on how the measures would be put into effect, perhaps the most important issue to arise from the trade talks. 
He also insisted that Japan would make no more concessions but woud only clarify some details. The new measures were listed in an interim report and talks on many of the issues are scheduled to continue.
 
Oversight Body Considered
When a reporter asked if a special body would be formed to oversee the plan - which includes a commitment for greater Government spending on roads, sewage plants and other projects; an easing of a law that tightly restricts the opening of large retail stores, and a toughening in enforcement of Japan's antitrust laws - Mr. Kaifu said that the step would be considered later.
This question is considered particularly important because most of the changes Japan's trade negotiators agreed to would require not just changes in Japanese law, but cooperation by the Government bureaucracy, which has great leeway in how it enforces and implements policies. The trade talks had hit an impasse earlier this year, in part, analysts in Japan and the United States had said, because the Japanese bureaucracy was not willing to make further concessions without heavy prodding from political leaders.
Mr. Kaifu also conceded in the news conference that although his negotiators managed to water down most of the American demands, he was likely to face trouble in getting the measures through Japan's Parliament.
 
Political Opposition
Currently, the powerful lower house is controlled by Mr. Kaifu's ruling Liberal Democratic Party. But the upper house is controlled by the opposition, which has been bitterly opposing a number of important domestic issues and is expected to challenge Mr. Kaifu on the trade issue.
''The Diet situation is very difficult,'' Mr. Kaifu said in a statement that reflected the reality that the trade concessions have now entered Japan's thorny domestic political arena.
In general, Mr. Kaifu's cautious remarks sought to put the best gloss on the agreement by saying that it only reinforced measures that his Administration was already taking to improve situations for Japan's consumers, who pay some of the highest prices in the world and enjoy a standard of living that is modest relative to the wealth amassed by Japanese corporations in the last decade.
''People in Japan have not been feeling our country's prosperity,'' he said. ''These issurs are related to the points brought up in the S.I.T. talks,'' referring to the Structural Impediment Talks, the formal name of the effort to deal with broad-based obstacles to trade.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
G.E. Shows Bright Side of East Europe

BYLINE: By Randall Rothenberg

 BODY:
AMERICAN advertising's fickle relationship with Eastern Europe will take another turn toward sweetness - and most definitely light - this weekend with the release of a General Electric Company commercial that celebrates G.E.'s venture to produce light bulbs in Hungary.
The 30-second spot, which was partly staged, was created by BBDO New York and filmed in Budapest by Joe Pytka, the commercial director. It is filled with symbols of liberation, some universal, like whirling dancers, and some very American, like an office meeting. Not surprisingly, the spot is bathed in light - a metaphor for freedom and, not incidentally, a G.E. product. 
Five years ago, American advertisers routinely ridiculed the cultural and economic poverty of Communism. The ''Russian Fashion Show,'' a commercial for the Wendy's hamburger chain, was a parody of the Paris couture, with beefy babushkas in identical gray sack suits substituting for slender models.
But last year, as the Soviet Union's policies of political openness began to affect the nation's allies, American companies started to flirt with advertising images of the East bloc that were by turns heroic, romantic and familial. BBDO has specialized in these ads; it has done two for Pepsi-Cola, one promoting Soviet-American friendship and another underscoring the notion that Russians are just like Americans.
BBDO's G.E. commercial, which is to make its debut Sunday morning on several public affairs programs, represents a new wave of pro-Eastern advertising, filmed on location and serving as a witness to the opening of Eastern Europe. It is the second quasi documentary to promote a venture by an American company in the East bloc. Several weeks ago, the McDonald's Corporation released an advertisement about the opening of the company's first restaurant in Moscow.
Celebration is the theme of G.E.'s new commercial, entitled ''Hungarian Rhapsody.'' ''The last 20 years, there've been so many down moves in the world,'' said Ted Sann, executive creative director of BBDO New York, ''this is a chance to reverse it.''
The commercial's goal, however, has a harder edge. As explained by Barbara J. Parsky, G.E.'s manager of corporate advertising, the spot is aimed primarily at the financial community, to showcase G.E.'s aggressive global expansion. The campaign illustrates G.E.'s $150 million acquisition in November of half of the Tungsram Company Ltd., Hungary's largest light-bulb maker.
The spot opens in fading sunlight, as the camera sweeps over the Danube River separating Buda and Pest, the Hungarian capital's two principal districts. As the strains of a ''Hungarian Rhapsody'' by Liszt gradually build, a young man says in accented English: ''Freedom's all that matters. Freedom is everything.''
As the sun sinks, the camera zips between scenes of people lighting candles and smiling. ''There's a new light shining over Eastern Europe,'' says the announcer, who proceeds to explain briefly the G.E.-Tungsram arrangement.
More Hungarians are seen: working in their offices, meeting in the Tungsram factory, congregating in groups, marching over a bridge. Their faces glow. ''Everything is changing,'' one woman says. Another adds, ''I'm so happy.'' The candles reappear, but they are increasingly interspersed with electric lights switching on, illuminating museums, monuments, a ballet and a waltz party.
The camera freezes on a little girl lighting one last candle as the company's 11-year-old corporate slogan appears on screen: ''G.E. We bring good things to life.''
The company could not bring every good thing to light. Its advertising agency had hoped to film the lighting of the Hungarian Parliament. But the building is lighted only when Parliament is in session.
''They would have had to vote on it,'' said Al Merrin, the BBDO senior creative director for the project. ''We couldn't wait.''

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Dip in Slow Day

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dipped in sluggish trading yesterday. Dealers sold securities after a rumor that swept the credit markets on Wednesday - that a major Japanese institution would disclose serious liquidity problems when trading began in Tokyo - proved to be unfounded.
The Japanese rumor had touched off speculative buying that led to a rally in Treasury securities on Wednesday. But the difficulties in Japan never materialized. 
''Nobody went bankrupt Wednesday night,'' one government-securities trader said. ''The rumor that caused the rally just isn't there.''
 
Focus on Employment Data
When the rumor dispelled, traders began to focus on the forthcoming release of March employment data. In advance of the report, which is due this morning from the Labor Department, most Wall Street economists were projecting an increase of 150,000 in nonfarm employment. Dealers said that if the number exceeded 200,000, it would not be well received in the fixed-income markets and could cause the Federal Reserve Board to tighten monetary policy.
''The employment number is very important,'' another bond trader said. ''With prices where they are, it suggests the market is expecting a good number. If we get a negative surprise, it will probably lead to a sell-off, and could make the Fed push the funds rate up.''
A number of analysts took issue with that assessment.
''At this point in time, it is hard to think of a number that in and of itself would dislodge the Fed from its current policy stance,'' said David M. Jones, senior vice president and chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a primary dealer in Government securities. ''The employment numbers were distorted by abnormally warm weather in January and February, and I would think the Fed would at least want to see April data before they contemplate any sort of move. And they won't get those numbers until May.''
Nonfarm employment rose by 332,000 in January and 372,000 in February.
 
Steady Funds Rate
The overnight Federal funds rate, the money market rate the central bank most directly controls, has remained at 8 1/4 percent since the middle of December.
Aside from last-minute positioning before the release of the employment figures, dealers said that little other business was transacted yesterday.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 99 27/32, down 5/32, to yield 8.51 percent. At the end of Wednesday's strong rally, the bellwether issue was offered at a price to yield 8.50 percent.
Note issues also posted modest price declines. In late trading, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 21/32, down 5/32, to yield 8.55 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 31/32, down 1/32, to yield 8.51 percent.
Bids at yesterday's auction of one-year Treasury bills produced an average discount rate of 7.72 percent, down from an average rate of 7.76 percent at the last one-year bill auction on March 8.
In the secondary market for Treasury bills, three-month bill rates were unchanged late yesterday, at an offered rate of 7.73 percent. Six-month bill rates rose by 3 basis points, or hundredths of a point, to a late offered rate of 7.73 percent.
 
Fixed-Income Report
In other developments, a quarterly report released yesterday from Salomon Brothers showed that the sharp rise in interest rates during the last three months did some financial damage to investors in fixed-income securities.
For the first time in more than two years, all asset classes tracked in the firm's Broad Investment-Grade Bond Index posted negative quarterly returns. The Treasury market turned in the weakest performance of the major sectors tracked by Salomon, returning a negative 1.29 percent for the first quarter.
New-issue activity in the investment-grade corporate bond market was strong again yesterday, as several deals were priced.
Among the issues offered was a $500 million sale of 40-year debentures for Hydro-Quebec. The 9 3/8 percent issue, which matures April 15, 2030, was priced at 99.873, to yield 9.837 percent, 68 basis points higher than the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent bonds of 2020 at the time of pricing.
Merrill Lynch Capital Markets acted as lead manager for the underwriting, which is rated AA-3 by Moody's Investors Service and AA-by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
New York Serial Bonds
Activity in the tax-exempt municipal bond market was highlighted by the negotiated sale of $166 million worth of serial and term bonds for New York's Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.
Maturities on the serial bonds are from 1991 to 2005, with yields ranging from 6 percent to 7.25 percent.
The term bonds include a 7 3/8 percent issue maturing in 2016 that was priced to yield 7.48 percent, and a 6 percent issue maturing in 2020 that was priced to yield 7.34 percent.
Dillon, Read & Company acted as lead manager for the transaction, which is rated AA by Moody's. An A+ rating from Standard & Poor's is expected.
Elsewhere, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended March 26. The report had no impact on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Petroleum Prices Decline On Worry About a Surplus

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Petroleum futures prices fell sharply yesterday, for the third straight day, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The declines have come amid perceptions that supplies of gasoline and crude oil are outstripping demand.
On other commodity markets, soybeans surged and grains were mixed; copper futures fell; precious metals retreated, and livestock and meat futures were mostly higher. 
West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures settled 26 cents to 43 cents lower, with the contract for delivery in May at $19.43 a barrel; heating oil was 0.71 cent to 1.16 cents lower, with the May contract at 53.31 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.05 cents to 1.71 cents lower, with May delivery at 63.29 cents a gallon.
Analysts said there was no change in supply-and-demand factors yesterday to account for the selloff. But traders have turned increasingly pessimistic amid signs of rising crude oil production and growing stockpiles of gasoline.
Indications of apparently strong demand for gasoline had helped to support the petroleum markets last month. Some analysts now say the market misinterpreted the signals.
''It appears to me that some of the strong demand of the past couple of weeks was simply some inventory building,'' said Jim Ritterbusch, energy analyst with Paine Webber Inc. in Chicago.
Many refineries are gearing up to increase gasoline production for the summer, when more miles are driven. As a result, Mr. Ritterbusch said, ''we could be flooding the market with gasoline a month or two down the road.''
He said crude oil production by members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was approaching an eight-year high, one factor that caused crude oil for near-term delivery to slip below $20 a barrel on Wednesday. Most market experts foresee steady or falling crude oil prices through the spring.
Soybean futures surged near the close of trading on the Chicago Board of Trade amid expectations for new export sales. Soybean exports from Brazil to Europe have been slowed by confusion over economic reforms in Brazil, prompting speculation that importers may turn to the United States for supplies.
Copper futures extended their losses on the Commodity Exchange in New York, despite reports from Peru that indicated a 25-day strike against the Southern Peru Copper Corporation had not been settled.
News reports on Wednesday said the strike was over, but those accounts were later denied by the Government and the company, which said it was presenting a proposal to workers.
Copper futures finished 1.55 cents lower to 0.05 cent higher, with the April contract at $1.2195 a pound.
Gold and silver futures fell on the Commodity Exchange after two days of gains. Gold settled $2.20 to $2.50 lower, with April at $374.80 an ounce; silver was 1.9 cents to 2.2 cents lower, with April at $5.141 an ounce.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed in Light Day; Gold, Up Abroad, Off in U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mixed yesterday in dull trading on world currency markets.
Gold prices fell in the United States after rising overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $374.80 a troy ounce, down $2.30 from late Wednesday. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted gold at $375 an ounce, down $2.75.
The dollar's biggest move came against the Japanese yen. The dollar lost one yen against the Japanese currency in Asian trading and fell further as trading shifted to Europe and later to the United States.
Dealers stressed that trading was quiet over all. Investors remained on the sidelines, awaiting the weekend meeting of the financial officials of the Group of Seven and today's release of United States unemployment figures for March.
Finance officials from the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada were planning to meet in Paris to review international exchange rates.
''There was a feeling earlier in the week that there would be no new policy initiatives , but now the market's getting a little more nervous,'' said Ron Holzer, a vice president at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago.
Dealers said they had expected the dollar's decline against the yen after speculation that monetary authorities might take action to prop up the sagging Japanese currency.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 157.90 yen, down 1 yen from Wednesday. Later in London, the dollar was quoted lower at 157.74 yen. In New York, the dollar closed at 157.50 yen, down from 158.88 yen on Wednesday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.6427, from $1.6416 late Wednesday. In New York, one pound cost $1.6420, more expensive than Wednesday's $1.6406.

HEADLINE: Condominium Conversions;
New Jersey Developer Offers a Lease-Purchase Plan

BYLINE: By JERRY CHESLOW

 BODY:
The soft New Jersey real estate market has led the sponsors of a condominium conversion to offer potential buyers a lease-purchase program, which state officials say might set a trend. Although many publicly financed projects offer similar programs, the Commons at Princeton Landing in Plainsboro Township is apparently the first privately financed condominium development in the state to offer such terms.
''Real estate experts have been advising developers to do this,'' said Stewart P. Palilonis, manager of the Planned Real Estate Development Office of the New Jersey Department of Community Affairs, where the terms of sale on all condominium developments must be registered. ''But that's the only such offer I know of. I think that if the market doesn't improve soon, we'll see many more offers of this type.'' 
The 12-year-old development contains units ranging from one-bedroom apartments to four-bedroom town houses. The units are sold in either as-is or renovated condition. As-is units range in price from $85,000, for a one-bedroom apartment, to $119,000, for a four-bedroom, one-and-a-half-bath town house. Renovated units sell for $8,000 to $10,000 more.
Under the offer, people buying as-is units may apply up to four months' rent to the purchase price; buyers of renovated units may apply up to six months' rent to the purchase.
The sponsor, the Value Group, Clifton, N.J., acknowledged that it was making the offer because of sluggish sales. In the last three years, since Value began marketing the condominiums, only 20 of the 120 units have been sold, most of them to insiders.
''We looked at the market,'' explained Mary Boorman, director of sales and marketing for the Value Group, ''and came to the conclusion that people are not buying because they just can't come up with the down payment. A straight discount would not help them buy our units, so we are dealing with the root of the problem.''
Since the offer was made, according to Ann Marie Ladis, a sales representative for the Commons, 18 prospective home buyers have begun the process of lease-purchase. None of the sales have been completed yet.
The development is on Plainsboro's Sayre Drive just off Route 1. Its three-story apartment buildings and two-story town houses are set on 11 acres. Owners and tenants share a swimming pool, tennis courts and a clubhouse with the adjoining Princeton Landing development, where the Value Group is building 412 town houses and single-family houses.
For as-is units in the Commons, the tenant must put down one month's security plus one month's rent and must pass a normal renter's credit check. He or she may decide within a year whether to buy at the market rate for the unit at the time that the option is exercised. Those moving in to renovated units must commit to buy and apply for mortgages when the initial contracts are signed.
They must also sign a promissory note for 5 percent of the purchase price and pay one month's rent as a binder, which is refundable when the purchase option is exercised. According to Mrs. Boorman, the note and binder protect the company's investment to fix up such apartments. Since the developer has arranged 95 percent financing, the first six months' rent generally covers most of the down payment.
The development was built in 1978 as economy housing. The Value Group purchased the property from the builder, Harold Sarshik, in 1986. So far, it has invested more than $1 million in renovations. These include new windows and doors in the common areas and new stucco facades with cedar trim to replace the original clapboard.
The as-is apartments come freshly painted and cleaned, but have 12-year old appliances; the renovated units have new kitchen cabinets, appliances, carpets and baths.
Mrs. Boorman said that the company's target markets include first-time home buyers and executives who are relocating to the Route 1 corridor, where many office employers have settled in recent years.
Mr. Palilonis of the state's development office said that lease-buy transactions seemed to work well for everyone involved.
''The developer sells units that he is stuck with,'' he said. ''And even if he doesn't make a sale up front, he gets the cash flow to cover the carrying costs of the unit. The buyer, who has income but no equity for a down payment, can buy,'' he continued. ''And, where there is no binder agreement, the renter can even try out the neighborhood before deciding whether to buy.''
Mr. Palilonis said he would advise buyers to consider the purchase carefully. ''If he is buying the unit to live in, that's fine,'' he said. ''If he hopes to make a quick profit, forget it. If the developer can't sell the units without offering special incentives, the buyer will have no resale potential until the market picks up.''

HEADLINE: New Estimate on Savings Bailout Says Cost Could Be $500 Billion

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 6

 BODY:
The cost of the Government's savings and loan bailout could grow to as much as $500 billion, roughly twice as high as previous official estimates, the head of the General Accounting Office said today.
In testimony before the Senate Banking Committee, the agency's chief, Charles A. Bowsher, said the cost of the bailout could range from $325 billion to $500 billion over three decades, depending on the outlook for the economy and the trend of real estate values. Many of the troubled savings institutions invested heavily in real estate developments.
The estimates by Mr. Bowsher, the Comptroller General, were far higher than the previous official estimates. Last July, the Administration's Office of Management and Budget put the cost at $257 billion. 
The rescue, Mr. Bowsher said, will be ''bigger than all the bailouts of New York City, Chrysler, and Lockheed put together.''
 
The Taxpayers Will Pay
Most of the costs will be paid by the taxpayers. The Administration has estimated that more than $100 billion can be obtained from selling off assets from the hundreds of failed institutions the Government has seized in recent months and from other sources, like the Federal insurance premiums paid by the savings industry. But the rest of the bill must be paid by the Treasury, though the payment could be spread over as much as 33 years.
The rising cost of the bailout will add to the Federal Government's chronic budget deficit, which makes the United States dependent on foreign capital and slows economic growth.
''It looks as if we have spent the peace dividend,'' said Senator Larry Pressler, Republican of South Dakota. He referred to the savings in military spending that many legislators expect as the United States and the Soviet Union agree to cuts in armaments.
Mr. Bowsher said that in the period since Congress authorized the bailout last year the cost estimate had increased because the number of troubled institutions had risen, the interest rates on bonds to finance the bailout had gone up and real estate values had fallen. Declining real estate prices in many parts of the country not only add to the problems of the savings industry, but also decrease the amount of money the Government takes in when it sells the real estate assets of seized institutions, he said.
The $325 billion estimate, Mr. Bowsher said, assumes a fairly strong economy and modest interest costs. If interest rates rise, the cost could easily reach $400 billion, he added. An economic recession, he said, could mean that ''a cost of a half a trillion dollars is possible, unfortunately.''
He warned that new legislation would be needed because the money authorized by Congress last year will not be enough.
Still, analysts said the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency created last year to handle the bailout, apparently does not face any immediate cash shortage. It has $18.8 billion and the authority to issue $20 billion in bonds, so there should be no need for legislation to provide additional money until the middle of 1991, one Congressional analyst said.
Although the cost of the rescue is spread over more than 30 years, the heaviest burden on the Treasury comes in the early years when money is needed to close institutions and pay depositors.
 
Another Estimate Is Expected
L. William Seidman, chairman of the Resolution Trust Corporation, told Congress last month that his staff was preparing new estimates on the bailout's cost. Experts within the agency, who asked not to be identified, said the expectation was that the figure would be far higher than the $325 billion minimum estimated by Mr. Bowsher.
Stephen Katsanos, a spokesman for the agency, said trends within the savings industry indicate that more than 600 institutions will ultimately have to be bailed out. Mr. Bowsher's office, which is an investigative arm of Congress, assumed in its most optimistic estimate that 560 savings and loans would be involved. At present, 351 institutions are controlled by the Government.
Private experts have been even more pessimistic. Bert Ely, a consultant based in Alexandria, Va., estimates that the final tally of institutions needing help will be 700 to 900.
The bailout comes after the collapse of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, which guaranteed deposits and had accumulated losses of $87 billion when it was closed last year and was replaced by the Savings Association Insurance Fund. The Resolution Trust Corporation handles the actual bailout operation, selling off the assets of insolvent institutions to recover as much money as possible.
 
Speculative Investments
The savings industry crisis began after the regulation of savings and loans was eased in the mid-1980's. Many institutions strayed far from their traditional business of collecting consumer deposits and making home mortgage loans. The most aggressive institutions put millions of dollars into speculative investments ranging from real estate developments to ''junk bonds.'' When these markets dropped, the institutions became insolvent.
Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn and a member of the House Banking Committee, warned that the growing cost of the bailout promised more trouble for the Federal budget. ''An increasing part of the rescue funds will come from the Government's general revenues, because the other sources have already been used up,'' he said.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
Outline of a New Europe

BYLINE: By R.W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 6

 BODY:
The talks between the Soviet Union and the United States this week appear to have opened the door at least part of the way for what Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d calls a ''new architecture'' for Europe.
By dropping his nation's insistence that a unified Germany would have to be neutral, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze made a major concession to the West. That is so even though the Soviet Union remains opposed to the American position calling for membership of a unified Germany in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and says it will cling to that view.
Through the mist generated by terms formulated in 40 years of cold war and now increasingly irrelevant, there is the bare outline of what Mr. Shevardnadze, at a news conference tonight, called ''the Greater Europe.'' 
No one knows yet what form it will take, but senior officials in governments all over Europe are beginning to talk of a continent-wide security system or systems that would render NATO superfluous, at least in anything like its present form. NATO's counterpart in the East, the Warsaw Pact, has already lost most of its significance.
At the center of the new Europe -geographically, politically and economically - would have to be a united Germany, which is why the character of that superstate is so important. And it is why the Soviet concession today mattered, even though it still left all sorts of questions open.
 
Why Allies Oppose Neutrality
The United States and the Allies would never have agreed to a neutral Germany because they believe, and the record of the years after World War I tends to confirm, that a Germany lacking a firm anchor to the rest of Europe would be unstable.
Leaving aside arms negotiations, which appear from the accounts of participants in all-night sessions to have gone considerably less well than hoped, the United States and the Soviet Union had something important to show for their efforts here.
President Bush appears to have agreed, implictly of course, to swallow as hard as he can as long as he can if confronted with further evidence of Soviet intimidation of Lithuania. Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said he was not going to comment on individual incidents in Vilnius any more, which must have pleased Moscow.
And Mr. Baker came very close to endorsing the Kremlin's plan for a referendum and a considerable delay in independence.
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev also came away with an announcement of dates for a summit conference in about seven weeks. But he must have had to give fairly firm and fairly convincing assurances that he would stop short of using his tanks to blast an independence-minded Lithuanian state out of existence.
 
Pressure for Triumphant Summit
There are limitations, of course, on how far Mr. Bush can go. A Soviet invasion would surely mean a cancellation of the summit meeting, which would be a terrible blow to Mr. Gorbachev, a man who needs to keep showing progress abroad to insulate himself in part from his terrible difficulties at home.
And even without that, time is working against Mr. Bush. If intimidation and harassment continue in Lithuania, opinion in Congress and the country, which has stayed with him, if only narrowly, is likely to start shifting.
That, in turn, puts pressure on both sides to work out their major remaining disagreements and stage a triumphant summit, because such an event, drenched in the hyperbole and media attention that would inevitably follow, would be the most effective riposte for Mr. Bush to those who suggest that good relations with Mr. Gorbachev are not worth deferring the legitimate aspirations of the Lithuanians.
Indeed, some analysts suggested tonight that more must have been worked out between the two sides than they have admitted. They would not have dared commit themselves so firmly to a summit conference, those analysts reasoned, unless they were reasonably certain that the momentum of warmer relations could be maintained.
 
Europe's New Security Structure
Whether that is true or not, there was a remarkable symmetry in the way several leading figures talked about the future of Europe today.
Mr. Shevardnadze, for his part, spoke only in the vaguest terms, and American officials said they came away from sessions with him persuaded that the Soviet Union does not have a clear policy yet.
But what he said at his news conference centered on the notion that current military and political alliances could be disbanded, and that it was time for the Europeans, the Soviets and the North Americans ''to engage in some serious work to shape all-European security structures.''
Elsewhere in Washington, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the West German Foreign Minister, said that the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation planned for November ''opens upon the possibility of designing perspectives for a new peaceful order in all of Europe.'' Even before that, he called for a renunciation of nuclear, biological or chemical weapons by both Germanys - which would presumably produce a nation armed only with conventional weapons at the heart of Europe.
 
Proposal for Security Pane
In Prague, Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier called for the creation of a European Security Commission that would operate alongside the Warsaw Pact and NATO, but independently of them, until they withered away from disuse.
Everyone, it would seem, is sketching like mad on the backs of envelopes. The sketches don't resemble each other very much yet, and some countries, including the United States, are reluctant to abandon the old buildings just yet. But more and more people are coming to see the need for new plans.

HEADLINE: Puerto Rico Is Seen Facing Economic Troubles as State

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 6

 BODY:
Puerto Rican statehood could undermine the island's economy and cost as many as 100,000 of its 900,000 jobs by the end of the decade, a new study by the Congressional Budget Office has found.
The study, which many people see as a setback for statehood supporters, estimated that the island would lose 73 percent of the investment it receives from United States companies because of the elimination of tax benefits intended to stimulate such investment.
These investments now account for about half of the $22 billion in private investments on the island, according to the study, which was released Thursday.
Although the island would gain $3.6 billion a year in Federal revenue by the year 2000, through Medicare and other social programs, the study said, the loss of investment income would cause its gross national product to decline 3.3 percent in that time. 
When Puerto Rico became a commonwealth of the United States in 1952, residents received all the usual obligations and privileges of citizenship except the right to vote in Federal elections and the duty to pay income taxes.
 
A 38-Year Debate
The debate on the island over statehood, independence or retention of commonwealth status has dominated its politics for decades, and several Senate and House committees are now considering a bill that would allow Puerto Ricans to vote in a referendum to determine the island's political status.
Under proposed legislation, statehood would entail losing the tax benefits that have been essential to the island's rapid development as a manufacturing economy over the last 40 years. The Federal corporate tax would apply with full force in Puerto Rico as it does in other states. In addition, Puerto Ricans and firms would be subject to other Federal taxation.
The report was hailed by opponents of statehood, including Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon, who fears that voters might be swayed by statehood supporters promising additional Federal money for social programs. ''My position has always been that the future of Puerto Rico can not be decided by how much the people would receive in social legislation,'' he said.
Jaime B. Fuster, who represents Puerto Rico as a nonvoting Delegate in Congress, said, ''As a result of this C.B.O. report, key Congressional committees will no longer in good conscience include statehood or independence as realistic alternatives.''
He continued: ''There is no way the Congress is going to offer to the Puerto Rico voters an option that, even after creating a big dent in the already scarce Federal budget, also causes 100,000 jobs to be lost in the Puerto Rico economy.''
 
Other Groups' Concerns
The report was challenged, however, by supporters of statehood or independence, including former Gov. Carlos Romero Barcelo, who said the study failed to take into account intangibles concerning the security that Puerto Rico would enjoy as a state. Uncertainty about Puerto Rico's future has held back investment, Mr. Romero Barcelo contended. He added that Congressional opponents of the tax benefits could repeal the legislation with no offsetting advantages.
Supporters of statehood or independence have argued that personal pride is at least as important as material well-being. But those who seek to retain commonwealth status say that the impoverished island would be hard-pressed to sacrifice needed United States financing.
Commenting on the option of statehood, the study said, it ''seems likely to reduce the average growth rate of the island's income over the balance of the decade.'' But it took note of the argument by proponents that statehood could bring unforeseen economic advantages by ending the uncertainty about possible changes in the island's status that had retarded its progress.
Puerto Rican independence, the study said, would lead to the loss of Federal revenue, but changes in investment ''are not so easily anticipated as those under statehood, because an independent Puerto Rico may be able to construct a set of incentives - through a combination of tax-sparing treaties and local subsidies - that would approach the attractiveness of the current benefits.''
The proposed referendum would allow Puerto Ricans to choose among statehood, independence and a third alternative - an enhanced commonwealth status. The new commonwealth plan would establish procedures under which Federal laws and regulations applying to Puerto Rico could be modified in order to enhance the island's economic growth.
 
A Third Alternative
Concerning the third option, the study said, ''While it is difficult to measure the effects of these enhancements, they would inevitably increase Puerto Rico's ability to compete economically with other middle-income developing countries.''
The budget office, the research arm of Congress, produced the study at the request of Senator Lloyd Bentsen, a Texas Democrat and chairman of the Finance Committee, to give Congress guidance on the bill to allow a referendum in 1991 on Puerto Rico's political future. Senator Bentsen has announced that the committee would hold hearings on April 26.
The Bush Administration favors statehood. Kenneth W. Gideon, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for tax policy, told the Senate Finance Committee last November, ''As the President has noted a number of times, he favors the admission of Puerto Rico to the Union as a state, thereby assuring the people of Puerto Rico an equal standing with other U.S. citizens.''
The island has 3.3 million residents, 1.1 million of whom are employable, and an unemployment level of 16 percent. Per capita income is $5,653, among the highest in the Caribbean.

HEADLINE: A Roundup for the Great Society

BYLINE: By BARBARA GAMAREKIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 6

 BODY:
They gathered tonight for what Lady Bird Johnson called ''a Texas-size roundup of the Great Society.''
But the celebration, marking the 25th anniversary of the year Lyndon Baines Johnson was inaugurated, was shadowed by the recent publication of a highly critical biography of Johnson by Robert A. Caro.
Nearly 1,000 people, from former Cabinet officers to White House butlers, began a weekend reunion of parties and panel discussions that began with an afternoon reception at the White House for members of the Johnson family and influential figures in the Johnson Administration.
In a tribute to the 36th President, who died at his ranch in Texas in 1973, President Bush called Johnson ''a towering and passionate figure.'' 
 
'Lyndon Johnson Heard,' Bush Says
''He was endlessly in motion,'' Mr. Bush said at the East Room ceremony, in which he was joined by Mrs. Bush. ''He tried with all his heart to be the best President that this country ever had for the people who are pressed against the wall, whose cries are not heard. But he heard. Lyndon Johnson heard.''
At one point the President turned to Mrs. Johnson and said, ''The best thing he ever did was marrying Lady Bird Johnson.''
Thanking Mr. Bush for his tribute to her husband and his Presidency, Mrs. Johnson said, ''I will remember it always.''
Those who participated in the celebration today were mindful that the occasion followed by a few weeks the publication of Mr. Caro's book, ''Means of Ascent,'' the second installment of a projected four-volume biography of Johnson. The best-selling book, published by Alfred A. Knopf, presents a detailed account of how, in Mr. Caro's view, Johnson used political power to make a fortune in broadcasting and stole the 1948 Democratic primary for a seat in the United States Senate from his opponent, Coke Stevenson, a former Governor of Texas.
 
Some Personal Portraits Are Offered
Many who had worked for Johnson were eager to offer their own portraits of him at a dinner tonight in the Mayflower Hotel here.
''In truth, almost every fault you can think of, Lyndon Johnson had some of those,'' said Jack Valenti, who was a special assistant in the Johnson White House and is now president of the Motion Picture Association. ''But he also started a social, political and economic revolution in this country that can never be forgotton or ignored.''
Charles Guggenheim, a film producer who has spent 18 months researching and filming several movies about Johnson, said: ''He was so multifaceted. He could be kind, he could be abrupt, he could be mean, he could be loving, he could be compassionate, he could be devious. He was just bigger than life - that is what makes him so fascinating.''
Mr. Guggenheim added: ''He left the Presidency under a cloud, and I think it's fair to say he was an unpopular man because of Vietnam. But I think there is an obligation after 25 years to look back on the extraordinary contributions he made in his domestic programs that have been obscured by the tragedy of Vietnam.''
Clark M. Clifford, who served as Johnson's Secretary of Defense in 1968, seemed to stiffen when asked about the Caro book. ''I worked closely with Lyndon for many years, and I knew him better than Mr. Caro knows him,'' Mr. Clifford said. ''Caro had an opportunity to write a really outstanding book and it's too bad, even tragic, that his bias and prejudice against Lyndon Johnson was so pronounced.''
 
Portrayal of 1948 Opponent Is Assailed
Many of those who gathered here noted that some reviewers had faulted Mr. Caro for his portrayal of Stevenson as a paradigm of integrity.
''No one says Lyndon Johnson was a flawless man,'' said Liz Carpenter, former press secretary for Mrs. Johnson. ''But Caro tried to make a saint out of Coke Stevenson. He was just a goat-herding Governor - he had no vision for Texas.''
Mr. Valenti, who was master of ceremonies at the dinner, said: ''The Caro book's principle sin, for which there is no expiation, is the fact that he distorts reality. He set up a very mediocre Governor of Texas as a latter-day Jesus Christ so that he could portray Johnson as the slimiest creature that walked the earth.''
In recent interviews Mr. Caro has defended his book as accurate and indicated that later volumes, dealing with Johnson's Senate leadership in the 1950's and his White House years from 1963 to 1968, would be more sympathetic.
There was no comment on Mr. Caro's work from Mrs. Johnson, who was joined at the celebration by her daughters, Lynda and Luci, and six grandchildren. What was on her mind, she said, was that she would remember and recognize the array of former ambassadors, speech writers, military and political advisers and White House telephone operators, gardeners and carpenters who attended the dinner.
''I hope my friends will realize my eyesight and legs are not as good as they once were; I've asked them to make the namecards in big print,'' she said today. ''I feel such an overwhelming warmth at the outpouring of friends who have come from all the phases of work that we tried, and did, in those five crowded years. Lyndon would have had more fun than anyone at this gathering.'' Advance Publicationsd(Alfred A. Knopf) A reunion of former Johnson aides is shadowed by a critical biography.

HEADLINE: U.S. Jobless Rate Edges Down to 5.2%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 6

 BODY:
The unemployment rate edged down one-tenth of a point to 5.2 percent in March, but the number of payroll jobs in the private sector declined for the first time in four years, the Labor Department reported today.
The mixed pattern in the latest figures, which offer the first broad indication of economic performance last month, suggested to many analysts that business activity was markedly less robust than implied by big weather-related jumps in the number of payroll jobs in January and February.
Factory jobs skidded by 31,000 last month, resuming a prolonged decline that was interrupted in February by a return to work of idled automobile workers.
''This should cool the ardor of those who thought the economy was about to take off,'' said Samuel D. Kahan, chief economist for Fuji Securities, in Chicago. 
 
Job Growth of 299,000
On the other hand, number of Americans employed, as measured by the department's survey of households rather than of business payrolls, rose in March by 299,000. This, combined with a 199,000 increase in the labor force, brought the official civilian unemployment rate down one-tenth of a point from the 5.3 percent where it had stood for nine straight months.
Monthly changes of less than two-tenths of a point are regarded as statistically insignificant, however, and there has been no appreciable change in the unemployment rate for a year and a half.
The figure to which economists pay the closest attention is that of jobs as determined by the survey of business payrolls. Last month that number rose a skimpy 26,000 when the figures for the private sector and government are combined. That was considerably less than expected and far below the gains of more than 350,000 for the two preceding months, when exceptionally warm weather spurred construction and other outdoor work. When 58,000 temporary census-takers hired by the Government last month are subtracted from the March data, the number of jobs in the private sector declined 32,000.
The Government expects to add 200,000 more census workers in April, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, Janet L. Norwood, said at a briefing, adding that those temporary jobs are making assessment of the job market more difficult.
 
Lackluster Economy Seen
Despite the crosscurrents and special factors in the March report, most analysts agreed that it reflected a lackluster economy, one that Maury N. Harris of the Paine Webber Group Inc. and other analysts said was likely to result in a further easing of monetary policy by the Federal Reserve Board.
Deterioration in factory employment was widespread, Mr. Harris said, with only 46.1 percent of industries adding to their payrolls last month. It was the fifth straight month in which more manufacturing industries shed workers than added them.
Since November, about 100,000 factory jobs have been lost. The reduction in the 12 months is about 250,000, with heavy concentrations in metal and metal-using industries and in apparel industries.
Automobile employment held steady last month, but construction jobs fell 64,000 after seasonal adjustment because fewer-than-usual winter layoffs left a relatively large number of workers already on construction payrolls, providing little opportunity for new hiring.
Jobs in retail trade fell 25,000, the second straight monthly decline, while health services continued to post sizable gains in jobs. Over all, service jobs rose by 122,000 while goods-producing jobs fell 96,000, the report showed.
The length of the work week in the private sector and that in factories were unchanged last month, while factory overtime rose six minutes, to 3.7 hours.
 
Drop in Discouraged Workers
The Labor Department's quarterly survey of people who have given up looking for work because they think a search would be futile fell to 747,000 from 827,000, the lowest level since 1979. About two-thirds of those discouraged workers cited conditions in the job market as reasons for not looking; the rest cited personal factors like age or lack of education.
Unemployment among all the major groups of workers - whites, blacks, Hispanic-Americans, adult men, adult women and teen-agers - was virtually unchanged last month, as the ratio of employment to population edged up one-tenth of a point to tie the record of 63.1 percent reached last June.
Among the 11 largest states, the only notable changes in jobless rates were declines of eight-tenths of a point in Florida and Texas, to 5.2 percent and 5.6 percent, respectively. New York's rate was unchanged at 5 percent, though its employment-to-population ratio slipped below 60 percent to 59.6. In New Jersey, the unemployment rate rose slightly, to 4.7 from 4.5 percent.
By region, the South's jobless rate dropped to 5 percent from 5.8 percent, while the Northeast, Midwest and West recorded declines of one-tenth or two-tenths of a point. These figures are not adjusted for seasonally variation.
Nationally, 120,003,000 Americans had jobs last month - 118,334,000 civilians and 1,669,000 domestically stationed members of the armed forces.
The jobless rate that includes military personnel also fell one-tenth of a point, to 5.1 percent.
Average hourly earnings rose four-tenths of 1 percent in March after an increase of five-tenths of 1 percent in February, today's report showed.

HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Ari L. Goldman

 BODY:
One man, a President, topped the list of the Gallup poll's ''most admired men'' with the greatest frequency in the 1980's, but the names that followed his were almost all religious figures.
According to an analysis by the Princeton Religious Research Center, Ronald Reagan, the leading figure, was followed by Pope John Paul II, the Rev. Billy Graham and the Rev. Jesse Jackson. Next on the list was Jimmy Carter, who as well as being a President, proudly proclaimed he is a ''born again'' Christian. The research center said its list was compiled by combining the results of all 10 ''most admired'' polls by the Gallup Organization during the decade. 
In the final year of the 1980's, Mr. Reagan dropped a few notches, but the religious figures continued their strong showing. The 1989 Gallup poll placed President Bush first, followed by the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Mr. Reagan, the Pope, Mr. Graham, Lech Walesa, Donald J. Trump, Lee Iacocca, Mr. Jackson, and, in a tie for 10th, Mr. Carter and Bill Cosby.
For the first time since the National Conference of Christians and Jews was founded in 1927, a Muslim has been elected to the organization's national executive board.
The election of Aly Y. Massoud, announced this week, was another sign of the growth of the interfaith organization beyond its original roots. Founded to counter the campaigns of hatred that gripped the United States after World War I, the conference was initially a vehicle for better understanding between Christians and Jews.
In recent years, however, it has also initiated programs of education and dialogue for Muslims, Hindus, Buddhists and others, keeping to its vision of the United States as a nation where many faiths can co-exist without compromising their distinctiveness.
Mr. Massoud, a 54-year-old lawyer, was born in Cairo and immigrated to the United States with his wife and their two sons in 1970. The Massouds live in Rumson, N.J. For the last five years, Mr. Massoud has been an active member of the conference's ''trialogue,'' which each month brings together Christians, Jews and Muslims for interfaith discussions.
In an interview, Mr. Massoud said his election represented ''a big step toward the recognition of the Muslim community in North America.'' He said he was an advocate of expanding the title of the conference to the National Conference of Christians, Jews and Muslims. ''Islam is the completion of the Abrahamic religions,'' he said. ''This would bring it full circle.''
Harry A. Robinson, senior vice president for communications and development at the conference, said the group has been studying for two years the possibility of changing its name. ''While our committee has recognized the inherent limitations of the name, it has also taken into account its history and longevity,'' he said.
While some have advocated adding Muslim to the name, he said, others have argued that this would not solve the problem of other faiths that might feel excluded. Among the ideas offered have been to call the organizations the National Conference of Christians and Jews, Et Al. or to simply call it the Conference, founded by Christians and Jews. Mr. Robinson said the conference will continue to explore options.
For more than a decade, Jews at Passover seders have remembered the plight of Soviet Jews with a modern seder ritual, ''the matzoh of hope.'' The leader of the seder, the festival meal, would set aside a matzoh and say, ''We have not forgotten those who are not yet free.''
This year, with Jews leaving Moscow for Israel in record numbers, the ritual has been revised and renamed ''the matzoh of unity.'' The prayer is being distributed nationwide in mailings and newspaper advertisements by the United Jewish Appeal, which hopes to raise $400 million to resettle new emigres through its Operation Exodus Campaign.
The seders this year are held on Monday and Tuesday nights. The new prayer says, in part: ''As we observe this festival of freedom, we are heartened to be part of the largest exodus of Soviet Jews in recent Jewish history.''
The ritual ends with the words, ''am Yisrael hu am echad - the people of Israel are united.''
It took linguists and Bible scholars 20 years, but the people of Papua New Guinea finally have one Bible in one language, according to a report from Lutheran World Information. Translation was no small task, since the people on the island nation that occupies the eastern half of New Guinea speak 700 native languages.
The language used for the Bible, or Buk Baibel, was Tok Pisin, a hybrid tongue developed at the end of the last century as a common language of commerce. Words and grammar were taken from English, various Melanesian languages, German, Malay and Chinese.
English is the official language of the country, but it is spoken only by a small percentage of inhabitants. Although traditional religious practices and beliefs are still widely practiced, the majority of the population is Christian, with Catholics and Lutherans the largest denominatiions.
The Lutheran information service called the Bible translation an ''ecumenical and linguistic milestone.''

HEADLINE: A Plan to Save the Peabody

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 6

 BODY:
Leaders of the Maryland Legislature reached agreement today on a plan to provide $5.4 million in the next year to end the financial crisis that has threatened the Peabody Conservatory's existence.
Peabody, a leading music conservatory, is a division of the Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore. It has faced a growing deficit over the last four years, which the university said it would no longer be able to cover because it now faces its own financial pressures. This year the Peabody's deficit is $3.7 million. 
''For 60 years or more Peabody has not been able to equal its wealthier sister institutions,'' said Robert O. Pierce, Peabody's director for the last eight years.
 
A Plan Is Developed
Fearing that the financial problems would force the 132-year-old music school to shut down, Lieut. Gov. Melvin A. Steinberg spent the last year devising a plan that would rescue Peabody from its immediate financial problems while also increasing the school's endowment over the long run.
Mr. Steinberg's plan, which legislative leaders said would be approved tomorrow with slight modifications, requires the state to provide nearly $3 million to cover Peabody's current operating losses and to put $2.4 million in a special fund for the school.
Under the agreement, Peabody cannot keep the state's contributions unless it meets financial deadlines set by the legislators. The school, which graduates 70 students a year, must obtain pledges from private donors for $15 million by Sept. 15. By Jan. 1, 1991, the school must raise $5 million of that amount in cash, and the full total by 1995.
 
Optimism Expressed
If Peabody cannot meet these deadlines, the plan would die and all the money would revert to the state. Mr. Pierce said he was optimistic about meeting the deadlines.
''We do have friends out there and we have made our contacts,'' he said. ''I think they will rise to the occasion.''
Angela Revis, a sophomore at Peabody who plays the flute, said students there were willing to help with the fund raising.
''Nobody wants to see Peabody gone,'' she said. ''Life in Baltimore would be pretty bleak culturally without Peabody.''
Although Peabody is a private institution, it offers community music classes, which 4,000 Maryland residents take part in annually. It holds 400 recitals and performances in Baltimore each year as well.

HEADLINE: More Trade With Japan, Maybe

 BODY:
The new trade agreement between Japan and the United States is promising. Japan pledges to reduce its barriers to imports and foreign investment. America says it will become more competitive. Neither will happen overnight, and some undertakings won't be fulfilled. But the fact of a broad understanding may help calm the two nations' increasingly contentious relations. 
The agreement is an ''interim report'' on lengthy talks over deep-rooted practices that hamper trade, such as Japan's law that limits department stores and the U.S. law that won't let the Japanese buy Alaskan crude oil. A final report is due in July. The proof will be in the follow-up. Politically difficult legislation is required of both countries -and, even more difficult, new attitudes among bureaucrats and businesses.
Japan's commitments are substantially broader than any it has made before. Previous agreements have dealt with disputes over specific products or trade restrictions. Indeed, Washington proposed the broader talks in hopes of reducing item-by-item bickering.
Parts of the new agreement do relate directly to trade, such as speedier customs clearance for imports to Japan. New ground is broken by Japan's pledges to bear down on antitrust violations and price-fixing, speed approval for new department stores, stem the land price spiral with new taxes and spend more on public works. These measures should stimulate Japanese consumption and, it is hoped, boost imports. Likewise, in side agreements Japan said it would increase imports of U.S. supercomputers, telecommunications equipment and satellites.
The United States, for its part, has agreed to little more than existing Administration policy, including better education, increased private savings, reducing the cost of capital and putting out a welcome mat for foreign investment.
How likely is it that either Government will deliver? Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu admits that some Japanese interests will find the proposals ''painful.'' But he rightly points out that Japanese consumers would gain from such things as the wider variety offered by department stores, and moderated prices for land and thus housing. How much he can push through the Diet is unknown; his party controls only one chamber. Also, there's no telling what Congress will approve. In both capitals, some proposals will be rejected.
How much will America's trade deficit with Japan be reduced? That's impossible to quantify. The changes would help, but not right away. The important point is that the Japanese economy will be more open to foreign competition from all quarters. And the whole world benefits from expanded trade.

HEADLINE: Over All, Drug Trade Makes Colombia Poor

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The short reference to Colombia in your overview of Latin America (Week in Review, March 18) implies that earnings from illegal cocaine and marijuana exports are a major cause of the growth in per capita income in that country. Not so. 
My study of Colombian capital flight points to a net loss of capital since 1983 of some $500 million a year. The annual inflow of drug money has been more than offset by capital flight. From 1983 through 1985, this traditional capital flight reflected, at least in part, an inappropriate exchange rate policy. However, in recent years, the major cause of traditional capital flight appears to be the perception of rising violence in the war against the drug trade in Colombia.
Thus the growth of the drug trade, while having created an inflow of drug money into Colombia, has also fueled the violence that has led to a sharp rise in traditional capital flight. Viewed simply as an economic issue, the drug trade has caused a net deterioration in Colombia's international situation in recent years.
Colombia's success at achieving real growth while continuing to service its foreign debt depends on the policies of the Colombian Government and, ultimately, the efforts of the Colombian people. This success is despite, rather than because of the drug trade.
 
FRANK R. GUNTER
 Bethlehem, Pa., March 20, 1990
The writer is an assistant professor of economics at Lehigh University.

HEADLINE: In France, Day Care Is Every Child's Right

BYLINE: By Hillary Rodham Clinton; Hillary Rodham Clinton is chairman of the board of the Children's Defense Fund in Washington.

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.

 BODY:
Ten years after the U.S. started talking about ''family values,'' many wonder why we are still unable to provide decent education, health care and opportunity for all of our children.
The House and Senate are about to confer on child care legislation and review a range of options. At this pivotal moment, much can be learned by comparing America's child care system to France's. Of course, given the differences in political philosophies and tax structures between our nations we should not duplicate the French system here - wholesale. 
Recently, I joined a study team of child care professionals who spent two weeks in France, under the auspices of the French-American Foundation, which promotes various ties between the two nations.
Our group - including a pediatrician, a Senate aide, a state government official, academics, day care administrators and representatives from organized labor and business -visited schools and spoke with ministry officials, elected office-holders, educators, health professionals, business and labor representatives.
What we saw was a coordinated, comprehensive system, supported across the political spectrum, that links day care, early education and health care - and is accessible to virtually every child.
Much more significant, though, are the pervasive beliefs in France that children are a precious national resource for which society has collective responsibility, and that one goal of a child care system is to help children develop and thrive.
We found sharp contrasts between the French and U.S. child care systems.
In France, mandated paid parental leave for child birth and adoption acknowledges society's obligation to nurture strong parent-child ties.
In the U.S., where only a few states require employers to grant parental leave for child birth or adoption -usually without pay - the cost and disruption of child bearing is viewed as a private choice and responsibility.
France, where preventive health services are integrated with child care programs, ranks fourth lowest in infant mortality among industrial nations. The U.S., where child care and health care are largely separate, ranks 19th lowest.
French pre-school and elementary school teachers earn comparable salaries and receive subsidized training. As a result, pre-school teacher turnover is low.
In the U.S., where salaries and training levels are low, annual day care staff turnover is 40 percent or higher.
In France, virtually all home-based day care providers are licensed, receive benefits including social security, paid sick leave and vacations, and are visited periodically by specially trained pediatric nurses.
American parents use home-based day care twice as much as center care but have difficulty finding such arrangements. An estimated 90 percent of home-based day care operations in the U.S. are neither licensed nor monitored, and the turnover rate for care givers is 60 percent.
France's system has taken years to evolve, as has its emphasis on the needs and perspectives of children.
Today, the system goes far beyond our own in providing children with basic intellectual and social skills they'll need to succeed in grade school, high school and adult life.
Throughout the 1980's, debate over child care in the U.S. always seemed to focus on ''family values.'' This assumes that parents alone can always determine and then provide - personally or through the marketplace - what's best for their children and, hence, society.
But this view has allowed our Government and, to a much larger extent, business to ignore the needs of America's children and their parents. It also discounts the extent to which economic realities determine access to quality child care.
Child care is not just a family matter. To do our children and our country justice, we need to develop a nationwide consensus on how to best nurture our children, and, through that nurturing, prevent the personal and social costs we all pay when children's needs are not met.
Before we lock ourselves into a makeshift, inadequate child care policy, we ought to consider valuing children, French-style.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-ed

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (99%); FRANCE (95%); 

STATE: ARKANSAS, USA (79%);
