HEADLINE: About New York;
Odd Man Out: Helping Big Boys Feel Like Fathers

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
''I don't want her to call anybody else daddy, even if I despise the mother,'' Robert C. said. ''She's my kid.'' The teen-age father knows he will never have a future with his former girlfriend, but he wants to be a positive part of his daughter's life. He plans always to have a couch where the child, or even her mother, might sleep if things get rough.
So Robert C. spoke at a weekly counseling session for unwed fathers at John Dewey High School in Brooklyn. This is what his counselor answered: ''You're a heavy guy.'' 
The counselor, Leonard Mednick, began the sessions three years ago to give teen-age fathers some of the support that teen-age mothers increasingly get. His first task was finding fathers. Unlike mothers, they can run and hide. And often do. In part, that is because society gives them no real role, Mr. Mednick says. Teen-age mothers now receive day care and training in parenthood in schools. They benefit from ''female bonding'' with grandmothers and great-grandmothers, who often build a protective cocoon around new mothers. Socially, young women with cooing babies are now an accepted part of the scholastic landscape.
Mr. Mednick applauds all this, particularly since so many teen-age mothers don't get much help from teen-age fathers. But he worries that the men have been forgotten.
The reality is that they will always be fathers. If they abandon - or are excluded from - the role, something is lost to both generations.
Shirking the biggest responsibility of their young lives, the fathers can make a lame first step into adulthood. Their children lose a role model, a companion, a sense of order.
''They're not mistakes,'' Mr. Mednick declared. ''They're kids.''
The goal of the group, which has five members this academic year, is to deal with the feelings of the unwed father - of being a pariah, of being asked to share economic responsibility when they have no resources, of being eased out of a relationship.
A typical exercise: group members playing roles in the scene of a grandmother barring a father from seeing his child. Another is regular meetings with different teen-age mothers, none affiliated with any father in the group, to discuss their concerns.
Mr. Mednick emphasizes practical steps. He urges the fathers to pay some financial support, even if it's only $5 every two weeks. They should also bring presents. Books, he says, are good. He has given money from his own pocketbook to help poor fathers do this.
Mr. Mednick, who has long experience as a guidance counselor, was recently honored by the New York Alliance for the Public Schools as one of the city's best. His interest in teen-age fathers came through counseling one many years ago. ''I was really crazy about him,'' he said. ''A wonderful, wonderful potential parent.''
His understanding of the powerful emotions of parenthood came partly though a vicious and unsuccessful custody battle for his children. ''I saw how insidious I could become in trying to win them over,'' he said.
The other day, Mr. Mednick began by speaking of a student who told him he had seen his father do ''the lousiest thing he could have done to my baby brother.'' He let the members guess what that was. They judged the father must have hit or molested the child.
Nothing had really happened. Mr. Mednick's purpose was to ascertain what the young men deemed awful behavior. They set admirably high standards. ''You've got to understand they're little kids,'' David R. said. ''It you hit them, you can really hurt them.''
Mr. Mednick pressed the point. ''But you all must get really crazy hearing a baby cry,'' he said. ''What do you do?'' ''I just carry him,'' Luis L. answered quietly. Mr. Mednick then made up a situation: The father has been out late. At 7 on a Sunday morning, his child, now 10, starts bouncing a ball against his bedroom wall. The sound feels like nails being driven into his head.
Still, none of the fathers could imagine hitting his flesh and blood. One said he would promise to take the child to a ball game if he'd just stop. Another said he would wait until the child was sleeping and bounce a ball against his wall so he would know how it feels.
But the probability is that the more than 20 young men who have been through Mr. Mednick's program won't have much control over their children. They can aspire to only a tiny fraction of the joy of seeing them grow up. Mr. Mednick's message is that even this is worth striving for.
''You guys might not have one dime in your pocket,'' he said. ''But what it's all about is rocking a baby or reading a 3-year-old a story.''

HEADLINE: If It's Legal, City May Try Complex Bond Refinancing

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
New York City hopes to help plug an unexpected gap in its current budget with a highly technical financial maneuver intended to free up excess money that has accumulated since early in this century to pay off rapid transit bonds.
The proposal is so complicated, and Mayor David N. Dinkins's decision to try to use it so sudden, that neither the city's Budget Director, Philip R. Michael, nor its Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman, whose aides suggested it, was able to explain it fully or correctly when they announced it on Thursday.
City officials said yesterday that the plan would reshape a revenue source that dates from the era of green eyeshades by using the most modern computers. They recently decided it might work after discovering that the city itself owns the old bonds whose restrictive covenants had been thought to prevent such a move and, as a result, could waive those restrictions. 
Explaining the proposal in detail, officials said it was not fiscal chicanery but an especially complex example of a common technique, in which bonds are re-financed to take advantage of fluctuations in interest rates. They said it indicated the lengths to which the city was willing to go to make the most of existing assets in the face of a stagnant economy.
 
Freeing Up Assets
''We're supposed to be managing our balance sheet,'' said Darcy Bradbury, the Deputy Comptroller for Finance, who came into office with Ms. Holtzman in January after a career in investment banking. ''We had an underutilized asset that was just sitting there not doing anybody any good, and we're working very hard to free up those assets so they can be used by the people of the City of New York.''
Ms. Bradbury said the city was still studying possible legal impediments to the transaction, but believed it could work.
Here, in broad outline, is what the city proposes:
Beginning decades ago, the city issued bonds to support transit projects. Interest on the outstanding bonds - which are to mature at various times in the future and have varying interest rates - is paid from the city's treasury each year. But payments of the principal, due only when the bonds expire, is backed by a special fund, the Rapid Transit Sinking Fund of the City of New York.
Since perhaps the teens of this century, the city has made contributions to this fund, in amounts intended to provide just enough to pay off the principal on the bonds. But thanks to rising interest rates over the years, the fund, now valued at $172 million, has accumulated more money than will be needed.
 
May Be $85 Million
Just how much more is not yet clear, but Mr. Michael said the excess may amount to $85 million, enough to close most of a sudden $105 million gap in tax revenues for the fiscal year that ends June 30.
But because the covenants on all the bonds, some of which are only two or three years old, prohibit the city from touching the sinking fund as long as any bonds are outstanding, the city cannot use this money. So it is proposing a maneuver known as ''defeasance refunding'' to get access to it. This is how it would work: The city would issue new general obligation bonds, in an amount not yet determined but something under $200 million, Ms. Bradbury said. It would use the money from this sale to buy enough United States Treasury bonds to cover both interest and principal payments on the bonds now backed by the sinking fund. The Treasury bonds would be held in escrow to pay off sinking fund bonds as they mature.
''Then the old sinking fund bonds are backed by the new escrow fund and are off the books of New York City,'' Ms. Bradbury said. The amount of Treasury bonds needed to cover the cost would be figured using complex computer calculations, she said.
 
Date Back to 1960's
Until recently, the city believed it could not do this with the transit fund bonds because of restrictions on the oldest of the outstanding bonds that prohibit such re-financing. But in rummaging through the records of the city's Bureau of Accountancy, Ms. Bradbury said, officials found that the city itself owns these bonds, the oldest of which date from the early 1960's.
As both bondholder and bond-backer, the city would waive the restrictions for itself, she said. Then it could take the excess revenues from the sinking fund, and use them to pay interest on other outstanding bonds, freeing money to plug the budget gap.
She said it had not yet been determined what would be done with the rest of the money now in the sinking fund, but that it could be used to back the new general obligation bonds that would have to be issued to buy the Treasury bonds. Legally, it would have to be used to pay interest or principal on city debt.
Because the interest rates on the outstanding sinking fund bonds are roughly comparable to the prevailing interest rates needed for the planned new general obligation bonds, Ms. Bradbury said, the city should not lose money on the deal.
 
Cannot Legally Make Profit
Under Federal tax laws, the city could not make a profit on the issue of its bonds, which are tax exempt. Ms. Bradbury said that was one of the legal issues still being studied.
Harrison J. Goldin, the city's former Comptroller, said the maneuver would not amount to using bonds to pay for operating expenditures, a technique that helped lead to the fiscal crisis of the 1970's, but would instead use new bonds to re-fund old ones.
He said it was a way for the city to ''relieve itself of an obligation to a lender in order to take advantage of income opportunities that were not envisioned at the time the transaction was entered into.''
But Mr. Goldin said city lawyers would need to make sure the move did not violate tax laws or other restrictions.
Even if the transaction cannot be done, Mr. Michael said, the city still has a $75 million general reserve fund that could be used to help close the budget gap. He said other service cuts or an emergency year-end real-estate tax increase would also be possibilities, though not desirable.
He said he hoped the plan would work.
''This was a solution we discussed some weeks ago with the Comptroller's office, and there wasn't a use for it,'' he said. ''They renewed the suggestion Thursday, and I presented it to the Mayor and he thought it was a good idea. And consequently we incorporated it as a major piece of our solution.''

HEADLINE: Man in the News;
A Visionary as Planner: Richard Lance Schaffer

BYLINE: By LEONARD BUDER

 BODY:
As a member of the baseball team at West Orange High School in New Jersey, Richard L. Schaffer played third base, the acknowledged hot corner of the infield. Later, as a varsity player at the University of Pennsylvania, he became a pitcher.
But yesterday, with the announcement by Mayor David N. Dinkins that Mr. Schaffer, dean of the Graduate School of Management and Urban Policy at the New School for Social Research, would become the chairman of the New York City Planning Commission, the 43-year urban planner returned to the hot corner, in city government.
Mr. Schaffer, who clearly did not want to speak out on several controversial planning issues, sidestepped tough questions at yesterday's news conference at City Hall. When asked whether he thought the previous city administration had, as some critics have asserted, ''given the town away to developers,'' Mr. Schaffer said he prefered to look ahead, not back. 
He did, however, offer the view that good planning balances three things - economic efficiency, social justice and the participation of all concerned. A little later, he said he would ''move that balance more to social justice.''
 
A Critical Time
He will take charge just as land-use procedures change under the new city charter. The commission reviews zoning changes, sites for city projects and other land use - matters likely to turn into disputes. The commission will grow from 7 members to 13, though its duties will not change much.
But most of its decisions will be subject to final review by the City Council starting this summer, when the Board of Estimate goes out of existence. This means there will eventually be 51 people, rather than 8, looking over the commission's shoulder.
Mr. Schaffer, who will be paid $110,000 a year, will also head the City Department of Planning, which conducts long-range planning.
Those who have worked with Mr. Schaffer describe him as highly qualified for what he says will be ''the biggest professional challenge of my life.'' They speak of him as a planner of vision who is also a highly competent administrator with a wry sense of humor.
''He seems laid-back but he has a mind like a high-speed computer,'' said James Stewart Polshek, former dean of the School of Architecture, Planning and Preservation at Columbia University, where Mr. Schaffer was vice dean and acting dean.
Franklin A. Thomas, the president of the Ford Foundation, who met the new commissioner when Mr. Schaffer was a doctoral student and later hired him, said, ''He is smart, refreshing, insightful, a tireless worker, a caring person.'' He said Mr. Schaffer could also be ''wonderfully abrasive at times'' when it was necessary to ''take air out of balloons.''
Richard Lance Schaffer was born on March 6, 1947, in Newark and attended public schools in West Orange. He became became interested in urban issues and planning while attending the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, from which he obtained his bachelor's degree in 1969.
''There was a lot of unrest in the inner cities,'' he said. ''When I read about an area like Watts or Newark, I was intellectually interested in understanding how these areas developed and why.''
He received a doctorate in economics from New York University in 1972. His doctoral research on Bedford-Stuyvesant brought him into contact with the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation. Mr. Thomas, then president of the restoration corporation, said he was so impressed with Mr. Schaffer that he hired him. Mr. Schaffer spent nearly 10 years with the development corporation.
Working in the largely black Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn was ''a transforming experience,'' he said. ''There is a tendency to think that you have all the answers and can solve all the problems. But you go into an area and discover that there are a heck of a lot of bright people who have thought about a lot more things than you have.''
Mr. Schaffer's first marriage, to former Mayor John V. Lindsay's daughter, Katherine, ended in divorce and three years ago he married Cynthia Bielak, a casting director for an advertising agency. They live on West 82d Street.
Two years ago, Mr. Schaffer sought the position of Planning Commission chairman, but Mayor Edward I. Koch chose Sylvia Deutsch instead.
Before Mr. Dinkins selected him, Mr. Schafffer said he dreamed that if he did not get the post, ''I was on my way to becoming the Harold Stassen of New York City,'' a reference to the perpetual but always unsuccessful candidate for the Republican nomination for President.
''It was a funny dream,'' he said. ''But it was also terrifying.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard L. Schaffer, 43, was appointed chairman of the New York City Planning Commission yesterday by Mayor David N. Dinkins. (The New York Times/Don Hogan Charles)

HEADLINE: Cuomo Aides Say Budget Gap May Hit $1.8 Billion

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 6

 BODY:
Making a bad situation worse for weary negotiators, the $1.5 billion gap in the state's 1990-91 budget may grow to $300 million because of a continuing slump in tax revenues, state officials said today.
Tax collections in March, the last month of the 1989-90 fiscal year, were $528 million less than expected, largely because of shortfalls in business and personal income taxes, the officials said.
Because budget officials base their projections of tax revenues for the current fiscal year on revenue collections from the previous year, the shortfall last month is forcing the third reassessment of the size of the budget gap in as many months. 
The state found the shortfall about the same time Mayor David N. Dinkins learned that the New York City budget gap of more than $1 billion for this fiscal year had grown $105 million.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's Budget Office was still trying to determine the effect of the shortfall on the 1990-'91 budget. But his press secretary, Gary R. Fryer, said the gap could grow ''somewhere in the range of $300 million.'' He added that the estimate was ''only a guess'' and that an accurate number should be available in two days.
Until the analysis is complete, it is difficult to know whether the shortfall reflects a real downturn in the economy, which would mean lower tax revenues this year, or simply changes in the timing of tax collections.
 
Meeting of Negotiators
But Hyman Grossman, a managing director of Standard & Poor's, which lowered New York's credit rating two steps last week, said the tax collections last month were disastrous. A spokesman for Comptroller Edward V. Regan, Marvin G. Nailor, said there was no doubt the shortfall would ''negatively affect the 1990-'91 budget.''
That would add to the fiscal headaches of Mr. Cuomo, Assembly Speaker Mel Miller, and the State Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, who have been struggling to negotiate a compromise that would eliminate the gap in Mr. Cuomo's proposed $51 billion budget. Because of disagreements on an acceptable mix of tax increases and spending cuts, the fiscal year began on April 1 without a budget, the sixth year in a row that has happened.
Negotiators representing Mr. Cuomo, Mr. Miller and Mr. Marino continued to confer today on breaking the impasse. The leaders themselves did not meet.
The negotiators continued private discussions on a tentative agreement on the scheduled income-tax cut, which has proven to be the primary obstacle to a budget solution.
The broad outline of the plan, which was disclosed on Thursday, calls for the final stage of the cut to be postponed this year and then to be phased in over the next three years. To compensate for the revenue lost by maintaining the cut, a surcharge would be imposed on corporate taxes.
Legislative sources said the surcharge could be up to 15 percent. Each percentage point would mean $34 million for the state.
Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Miller, Democrats, favored suspending the last year of the four-year tax cut, a measure that would save $400 million this year. But Mr. Marino and his fellow Senate Republicans have pledged to protect the cut and have staked significant political capital on doing so.
Mr. Cuomo's budget officials were also pressing to save $100 million by further reducing contributions to some employees' large retirement funds. The Governor said this month that he expected the state to shave at least $200 million in payments to the State Teachers Retirement Fund by increasing the earnings assumptions on its $26 billion of investments.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, APRIL 7, 1990

 BODY:

 
 
The Economy
 The cost of the savings and loan bailout could grow to as much as $500 billion, roughly twice as high as previous official estimates, the General Accounting Office said. [Page 1.] The unemployment rate edged down one-tenth of a point, to 5.2 percent, in March, but the number of payroll jobs in the private sector declined for the first time in four years, the Labor Department said. The mixed pattern reflected in the latest figures suggested to many analysts that business activity was markedly less robust than implied by big weather-related jumps in the number of payroll jobs in January and February. 
Factory jobs skidded by 31,000 last month, resuming a prolonged decline that was interrupted in February by a return to work of idled automobile workers. The job growth as measured by the department's survey of households, rather than of business payrolls, picked up to 299,000. [9.]
 
 
 
Companies
 UAL's directors agreed to sell United Airlines to its employees for $4.38 billion, or $201 a share. If shareholders and the unions approve the bid, and if the investment bankers for the unions can raise the money, UAL would become the largest company in the world owned entirely by its employees. [1.] The buyout agreement may not bring an end to hard times at United Airlines, industry experts said. [33.] Lotus Development and Novell have tentatively agreed to a $1.5 billion merger that is intended to break Microsoft's dominance in the personal computer software business. [33.] Ford Motor is negotiating with Fiat about possible ''worldwide arrangements'' involving their tractor and farm equipment operations. [35.] In an important victory for Genentech, a jury ruled that the company's patents for tissue plasminogen activator, or T.P.A., its main product, were valid. [35.] A member of the family that controls Editions Gallimard is selling her 12.5 percent stake to Banque Nationale de Paris. [37.]
 
International
 Tokyo's Liberal Democratic Party may have to brace for enormous political losses if it passes legislation to carry out the revisions in trade barriers demanded by Washington and accepted by Tokyo on Thursday, members said. [33.] The U.S. concluded a trade agreement with Czechoslovakia that would cut tariffs and spur business ties and tourism between the two countries. An accord with the Soviets is also expected. [33.]
 
 
 
Markets
 Stock prices fell and the Dow declined by 4.05 points, to end the day at 2,717.12. For the week, the Dow was up 9.91 points. [36.]
 Treasury securities prices made a series of sharp moves on a mixture of conflicting economic news and rumors, but ended the day basically unchanged. [33.]
 The dollar ended the week slightly lower in subdued action as traders moved to the sidelines on the eve of a weekend meeting of world finance ministers. [42.]
 Copper futures rallied sharply on the Commodity Exchange in New York as traders worried about the continued strike at mines in Peru and declining supplies. [42.]
 
 
 
Today's Columns
 To free diabetes patients from the need to inject themselves with insulin daily, a surgeon in Texas has invented what amounts to a drug factory that could be inserted into a vein. Patents. [34.]
 For those who have not filed income taxes yet, a visit to the public library may be in order. Your Money. [34.]

HEADLINE: Czech-U.S. Trade Pact Set; Accord With Soviets Seen

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 6

 BODY:
The United States has concluded a trade agreement with Czechoslovakia's new democratic Government that would cut tariffs and increase business ties and tourism between the two countries, the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said today.
The accord, which is expected to be signed by the two Governments on Thursday, is the second economic pact the United States has reached with an Eastern European country since last year's political upheaval.
Last month the United States and Poland signed a more broadly based business and economic treaty, providing for investment safeguards, protection of patents, copyrights and other intellectual property and the resolution of trade disputes. 
Poland is further along in its process of economic change than Czechoslovakia and had already benefited from lower American tariffs.
Washington is also negotiating a trade agreement with the Soviet Union that Mrs. Hills said would be ready for signing when President Bush meets President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union from May 30 to June 3. ''We're making good progress,'' she told a group of reporters at her office today.
The aim of both the Soviet and Czechoslovak agreements is to confer ''most favored nation'' status on those countries - meaning that American tariffs would be lowered to the level charged against most other trading partners. Tariffs on Soviet and Czechoslovak goods now run as much as 10 times as high as for most other countries.
Both Moscow and Prague are eager to remove an international stigma arising from their failure to qualify for favorable tariff treatment under the Jackson-Vanik amendment to the Trade Act of 1974. To meet the terms of the amendment, which Congress passed in retaliation for the refusal of the Soviet Government to allow Jews and other dissidents to leave the country, the President has to certify that both countries have liberal emigration policies.
This is not expected to be a big hurdle for either country, although the Soviets still have to clear legislation that would codify their freer emigration policies. President Bush has said he will propose a waiver of the Jackson-Vanik amendment once the Soviet Parliament acts.
The trade agreement with Czechoslovakia, as well as the pact expected with the Soviets, is subject to Congressional approval. Congressional aides predicted easy sailing for the Czechoslovak pact.
 
Anxieties on Lithuania
 Approval of the Soviet agreement could be more complicated, the aides said, because of some anxieties over the Soviet handling of the dispute with Lithuania.
The arrangements with both countries cover issues like protection of intellectual property, establishment of a procedure for settling trade disputes, prevention of market disruptions from surging imports, allowances for trade promotion and business representation.
One achievement of the Czechoslovak agreement is that Americans will be treated as Czechoslovaks in establishing bank accounts and paying for goods within Czechoslovakia. Hard-currency earnings may be immediately repatriated.
Czechoslovakia already has in place an ''impressive'' array of intellectual property protections, Mrs. Hills said, and is committed to strengthening its system in various ways.
 
Trade Below $150 Million
 The United States and Czechoslovakia now do relatively little business with each other. Last year two-way trade was less than $150 million.
The principal export items were cow hides, cotton, synthetic yarns and tobacco. The principal imports were special tractors, glass beads, shoes and truck and bus tires.
American trade experts said there was little Czechoslovakia now had to sell that was of interest to American consumers. But with the incentive of lower tariffs, Czechoslovak entrepreneurs could find niche markets in the United States for crystal and other such specialty products, they added.

HEADLINE: Trade Pact Under Fire In Japan

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 6

 BODY:
Some members of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's Liberal Democratic Party said today that the party would have to brace for enormous political losses if it pushed through legislation to carry out the revisions in trade barriers sought by Washington and accepted by Tokyo on Thursday.
For example, politically powerful groups representing Japan's two million small retail stores came out strongly against the Government's agreement to revise the law that protects these stores from having big department store chains move into their neighborhoods.
''It's not going to be easy for the Government to get agreement from the vested interests,'' one Government official said. ''But the Prime Minister is obviously determined to carry out the terms. He is putting his leadership on the line.'' 
 
Popularity Ratings Are Up
 Aides to Mr. Kaifu note that he has gained in public approval ratings in recent weeks, in part because he seems to be getting results in his talks with the United States. After the new agreement was announced here early this morning, the Tokyo Stock Exchange advanced strongly all day, with the Nikkei index of 225 stocks showing a 3.6 percent gain at the close.
The Prime Minister is thus considered to be in a stronger position than he has been. Until now, he was seen as being dependent on the support of party barons, especially former Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita.
Top officials in Mr. Kaifu's Government warned that Washington should be careful not to push Japan further, because such pressure could undermine Mr. Kaifu's attempt to win approval for the new steps.
''I hope the U.S. will give due respect to our efforts,'' said Ichiro Ozawa, the party secretary general. Others said further pressure by President Bush could topple the Kaifu Government.
 
'Structural' Changes Sought
 The accord in the ''structural impediment'' talks was aimed at altering deeply ingrained business practices and public policies in both Japan and the United States that are deemed to be the underlying reason for the persistent trade imbalance that last year produced a $49 billion American deficit with Japan.
Japan agreed to several steps that fell far short of American requests but still went far enough to win the praise of the Bush Administration. Some Japanese officials said the changes could substantially alter the political landscape here.
For example, Tokyo says it will revise laws blocking big stores from coming into neighborhoods dominated by little stores and will toughen enforcement of laws against monopolies. The Government will also increase public investment in roads, bridges and similar projects, which will presumably increase demand for foreign goods and services.
The talks themselves are controversial, with many trade experts saying the changes demanded by Washington are too sweeping and impractical. Indeed, many in Japan, even those supporting the talks, say the new measures will have only a minimal effect on the trade deficit.
 
No Rise in Imports Expected
 ''We support these talks, but there isn't going to be a substantial increase in imports from them,'' said Hajime Ota, director of international economic affairs at Keidanren, the big business trade association. ''American businesses are not yet prepared to export products that Japan wants.''
There are enormous forces arrayed against making changes quickly. For example, the Finance Ministry - its political leadership and its powerful civil service bureaucracy -adamantly opposes increasing spending on public works projects. The idea is that more roads, public buildings, airports and such will lead to expansion of commercial and residential building. This, in turn, might bring in more foreign products. But the Finance Ministry is always nervous about increasing spending.
And many Japanese say privately that even if the anti-monopoly laws were changed, they would probably be weakly enforced because the ruling party is too beholden to big-business interests.

HEADLINE: U.S. Issues Steady After Early Moves

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities made a series of sharp moves early yesterday on a mixture of conflicting economic news and rumors, but ended the day basically unchanged.
The prices of fixed-income debt issues were initially bolstered by a less-than-expected rise of 26,000 nonfarm jobs in March, the smallest increase reported by the Government since June 1986.
A closer look at the data showed growing inflation pressure that is expected to discourage any move by the Federal Reserve to ease interest rates. This interpretation of the job data caused bond prices to relapse. 
 
Refunding Rumor Denied
 Among the day's assortment of rumors that briefly roiled the market was a report that the Resolution Funding Corporation, the financing unit of the Resolution Trust Corporation, would expand the size of Tuesday's $3.5 billion bond offering because of the worsening plight of the many savings and loan associations that the agency is trying to bail out. Officials at the agency emphatically denied this.
Dealers expect the new 40-year bonds to yield 8.85 percent, up from 8.60 percent at the last such sale on Jan. 23, when there was an offering of $5 billion in bonds.
One indication of the market's volatility was the price range of the Treasury's bellwether long bonds, the 8.5 percent issue maturing in 2020. Its price moved during the day from a high of 100 16/32 to a low of 99 13/32. Late in the session the long bonds were being offered at 99 27/32, unchanged on the day, with the yield at 8.51 percent. A week ago, the yield on the long bonds was 8.62 percent.
''The rumors were a nuisance compared with the impact of the March job data,'' said William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. ''While the small rise in nonfarm jobs was small and bullish, a breakdown of the numbers showed that wages are rising and that hourly earnings are rising at an annual rate of nearly 5 percent. This is not good for the fixed-income market.''
 
Reports on Japanese Selling
 What also drove bond investors and traders to the sidelines, Mr. Sullivan continued, were reports that Japanese investment houses were heavy sellers of long-term Treasury issues. ''It could be that they were selling the same paper they bought last week to dress up their accounts for the winding up of the Japanese fiscal year, which was March 31,'' he said, ''which is perhaps why the sales had relatively little impact on prices.''
The unwinding of the ''window dressing'' operations this week was also believed to be responsible for the unfounded rumors earlier in the week that a top Japanese financial institution was in trouble and was forced to sell some Treasury holdings.
Meanwhile, prices in the secondary market for Treasury debt showed few changes. The new 8.5 percent notes of 1992 rose 1/32, at par, for a yield of 8.50 percent; the new 8.5's of 1994 gained 1/32, at 99 25/32, for a yield of 8.56 percent.
On Wednesday, the Treasury plans to auction $7.5 billion of new seven-year notes. The notes traded on a when-issued basis to yield 8.58 percent.
 
Long Notes Rise
 The Treasury's long notes, the 8.5's of the year 2000, rose 2/32, to 99 23/32, to yield 8.54 percent, against 8.62 percent a week ago. By comparison, the yield on 10-year Japanese long bonds declined to 7.28 percent, from 7.36 percent during the week, while the yield on the same West German bond maturity climbed to 8.58 percent from 8.38 percent.
At the short end of the Treasury market, the discount rate on 90-day bills rose two basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.77 percent; six-month bills were unchanged at 7.75 percent, and the one-year bills eased two basis points, to 7.68 percent.
The Federal Reserve added another $1 billion of reserves to the banking system, following an influsion of $1.5 billion the day before. But the moves were linked to holiday credit demands. Federal funds, which banks charge each other for temporary credit, traded at 8 1/4 percent most of the day before easing to 8 3/ 16 percent.

HEADLINE: Debt Seen as Negating Gains in United Deal

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
United Airlines has been looking for a way to recapture the No. 1 position in the domestic airline industry from American Airlines. But industry experts think the tentative agreement reached yesterday for an employee buyout will not by itself be the answer.
The tax advantages, wage concessions and improved morale associated with an employee buyout may have turned the $4.38 billion offer for the UAL Corporation, the airline's parent, into the company's best available option. The $201-a-share bid came after speculative investors had accumulated large holdings of stock and demanded the company's sale. 
 
Higher Interest Costs
 But the deal will mean taking on more debt, and the resulting higher interest costs may cancel out most if not all of the advantages. American Airlines, which in November 1988 replaced United as the nation's leading carrier, has a light debt load.
''There seems to be a misunderstanding that United becomes a low-cost carrier because of these wage concessions,'' said Kevin C. Murphy, an analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company. ''That's simple-minded.''
Daniel M. Kasper, a transportation consultant in Boston, said: ''The positive feature is you get for some time a calm labor situation, with people pulling in the same direction. The price you pay is a heavily leveraged airline.''
The proposed buyout comes at a crucial time for United. United's share of all traffic carried by United States airlines has stagnated for the last four years at about 16 percent, while American's share has grown to 17 percent from 13 percent in 1986.
American, a subsidiary of the AMR Corporation, is pouring its extra revenues into buying new aircraft, with plans to spend $21 billion over the next five years, and half of its 8,300 pilots have been hired at entry-level wages in its rapid expansion since late 1983.
United's top management has expressed fears that the airline may be locked in a vicious circle, with slower growth leading to lower investment spending and less hiring of younger and less expensive pilots, in turn leading to even slower growth.
United has hired a quarter of its more than 6,500 pilots since introducing low entry-level wages four years ago, and has made commitments to invest $9.1 billion, principally for aircraft, over the next four years, said Sara Darnecker, a spokeswoman for the company.
Wall Street analysts estimated that yesterday's agreement would probably require UAL to make extra annual interest payments ranging from $400 million to $500 million. To defray this expense, United's unions have agreed to wage concessions of $300 million in the first year after the deal, rising to $500 million in five years.
 
Tax Deductibility Cited
 In addition, repayments of the principal borrowed to finance the transaction will be tax deductible, a person familiar with the deal said. This benefit would exceed $150 million a year and make up the difference between the interest payments and the wage concessions, this person said.
Even if the promised concessions do add up to the promised amounts, the opportunity for further concessions may be limited in any future economic downturn, said Edward J. Starkman, an airline analyst at Paine Webber. ''What happens when things get really tight and there aren't any more concessions to give?'' he asked, pointing out that airlines have traditionally responded to recessions by seeking to reduce their wage bills.
United could reduce the debt load and the accompanying interest burden by selling and then leasing back more of its aircraft. United owns 279 of its 429 planes and leases the rest.
But sale and leaseback agreements may be difficult to conclude quickly. The used jetliner market has softened considerably in recent months while potential lenders for equipment deals have begun demanding special and costly legal protections against sudden changes in United's financial position, airline industry and bank officials said.
Yesterday's agreement also calls for the unions to raise $240 million from the sale of securities related to UAL's 50 percent interest in the Covia computer reservation system, at a time when Government and private studies have repeatedly shown that control over such a system is vital to a worldwide airline.
Spokesmen and participants in the deal declined to discuss whether the securities would consist of debt or equity. They insisted that UAL would keep the benefits of its position as the dominant partner.
A Justice Department study estimated in May 1988 that the extra business for United generated by UAL's control over Covia resulted in profits of up to $300 million a year. Since then UAL has redesigned the system in part to accommodate criticism by the Justice Department that it favored UAL too much.
UAL sold half of Covia for $493 million in August 1988 to affiliates of Alitalia-Linee Aeree S.p.A., British Airways P.L.C., KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, the Swiss Air Transport Company Ltd. and USAir Group Inc.
 
'One of the Crown Jewels'
 But Covia remains ''one of the crown jewels'' of UAL, one industry expert said, and the company has fought hard to maintain its control. UAL insisted that when a Covia stake of a fraction of 1 percent was sold last September to Air Canada, all of the stock transferred come from the minority partners in Covia to avoid putting UAL's stake below 50 percent.
The terms of the Covia partnership also require until 1993 the unanimous consent of all partners before any partner may sell any of its stake. United has not sought such consent, although it has been reportedly negotiating for months and with limited success to sell part of its stake in Covia to any of several Asian and European carriers.
Selling even part of Covia may be difficult because all other major American carriers except Pan American World Airways are already affiliated with various computer reservation systems and the Justice Department has objected to their consolidation.
Most large European carriers have already joined one of two major computer reservation systems, and Covia is a large stakeholder and equipment supplier to one of these systems, known as Galileo. That may result in legal complications for any effort to sell Covia stock in Europe

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Copper Rallies Before Prices Ease a Bit on Profit Taking

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Copper futures rallied sharply yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York as traders worried about the continued strike at mines in Peru and declining supplies, but profit taking trimmed prices near the close of trading.
On other markets, precious metals were higher, grain and soybeans declined, livestock surged, pork fell and oil prices were mixed.
Copper settled 1.60 cents to 2.55 cents higher, with the contract for delivery in April at $1.245 a pound. 
Copper prices surged 4.20 cents in early trading on the Comex before gains were trimmed by half.
Jim Steel, an analyst with Refco Inc. in New York, said the rally stemmed from short covering - the buying of contracts to fulfill obligations made by earlier short sales, which are the sales of borrowed contracts - by traders after Thursday's selloff. He said the selloff was prompted by reports saying the strike was over, but the fresh indications that the mines were still shut alarmed the market.
Mr. Steel said the belief that the strike was winding down caused prices to retreat near the close of trading.
Mr. Steel added that the price surge had also been helped by feelings that copper stocks in London Metal Exchange warehouses had declined.
Precious metals futures rose in trading on the Comex.
Gold prices surged after the release of employment figures by the Bureau of Labor Statistics that showed a small increase in the number of jobs created and a decline of jobs in the manufacturing sector.
Mr. Steel called the employment figures disappointing and said they could result in lower interest rates and weakening of the dollar, which he says would be good for gold.
Gold was $5.90 higher, with April at $380.75 an ounce; silver was 2.1 cents to 2.1 cents higher, with May at $5.19 an ounce.
Grain and soybean futures closed lower on the Chicago Board of Trade as profit taking set in after a strong opening on rumors of a large grain purchase by the Soviet Union.
The rumors of a Soviet grain purchase were never confirmed during the day and traders took the opportunity to cash in.
After the close of trading, the United States Agriculture Department reported the sale of 750,000 metric tons of corn to the Soviet Union.
Wheat prices was getting support from expectations of a weekend freeze in winter wheat crop areas. That concern eased as forecasts indicated the drop in temperatures would not be as severe as previously expected.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;
Banks and the Elderly

 BODY:

Many banks are trying to lure older Americans' deposits by offering a variety of benefits that are not available to the other customers. Such depositors are viewed as a source of stable funds and a ready market for estate planning services. Some banks require fairly large balances for these accounts; others set no minimum, but depositors have to pay monthly fees. And some banks may require depositors to sign up for direct deposit of Social Security, payroll or pension checks. There is no national listing of banks that offer these special accounts; the American Association of Retired Perosns generally recommends using banks that are close to home and suggests phoning them for information. Here are some of the requirements, charges and services to consider in deciding on one of these accounts:
 
Minimun Age: Most banks have lowered it to 50 years, from 65.
 
Benefits and Serivces: Free checking; bonus rates on certificates of deposits, sometimes as much as a quarter of a percentage point higher; free credit cards and discounts on retail purchases and travel.
 
Minimum Balances or Fees: Some banks require account balances ranging from $2,000 to $5,000. Others charge monthly fees of $7 to $10.
 
 
 
Source: Bank Rate Monitor, North Palm Beach, Fla.

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
How the Schools' Failure Is a Business Crisis, Too

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
If good intentions could do the job, ''Our Future at Risk: The Education Crisis'' would be exemplary television; but, then, if good intentions could do the job, there would be no crisis. The nine educators and corporation executives gathered Monday night at 8 o'clock on Channel 9 concentrate on the failure of America's schools to teach young people to read, spell, add and speak English well enough to staff America's businesses. They agree that cooperation between workplace and schoolplace is essential. ''A'' for good intentions.
The hour, sponsored by I.B.M. and moderated by Hodding Carter. It begins with a familiarly depressing 10-minute report on the inability of millions of youngsters who have made their way through the school system to do any sort of job more demanding than handing out hamburgers at McDonald's. 
Although the panelists tend to talk in sound bites, what they say is realistic. All recognize that the schools are staggering under an assault of social and economic problems, from single-parent households to the decline of jobs for the unskilled, that cannot be remedied in the classroom.
Seasoned observers like Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, Dr. Ernest Boyer, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, and Dr. Joseph A. Fernandez, New York's Schools Chancellor, emphasize the dimensions of the problems. ''Is the school to become a social agency?'' asks Dr. Boyer. A teacher on the panel reminds viewers of the many elementary school children who graduate not into intermediate school but ''into motherhood or prison.''
The solutions offered are less compelling. Chancellor Fernandez calls for a Marshall Plan for the schools but does not tell how the money would be spent. Mr. Shanker calls for ''a new kind of school,'' but is given little opportunity to elaborate. The businessmen are agreed that corporations have to provide more in the way of day care, time off for workers to study and on-the-job training, and Peter McWalters, the superintendent of schools in Rochester, tells, in the jargon of his trade, of cooperation between businesses and schools in his jurisdiction. But in sum, the positives seem overwhelmed by the negatives. (From the applause for every proposal to raise teachers' pay, you may deduce that the profession was well represented in the audience at Pace University, where the program was taped in March during a Business Week symposium. There is something odd in having teachers applaud the news that for years the brightest graduates haven't been going into teaching.) It is a dutiful hour rather than a stimulating one. The best that can be said for ''Our Future at Risk'' (one of those all-purpose titles available for everything from acid rain to the brain drain) is that it drives home the inability of the schools as traditionally financed and operated to address the problems that have been imposed on them. Not a new message, but a necessary one that, alas, demands repeating. There's that much to be said for good intentions. (Details of the cooperative effort in Rochester can be found in ''Crisis: Urban Education,'' a four-part series that will be shown on Channel 13 at 11 P.M. from April 16 through 19. The series also reports on a troubled high school in Trenton, a well-reputed high school in East Harlem and three inner city youths with different attitudes toward education.)

HEADLINE: Peru Votes for President Today; Polls See a Runoff

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 7

 BODY:
Mario Vargas Llosa, the internationally known novelist, has long enjoyed a commanding lead in the campaign for elections on Sunday in Peru, where voters are to select a new president and Congress to guide their fragile democracy.
But in a measure of Peruvians' deep political alienation from the established parties, Alberto Fujimori, an agricultural engineer who was a virtual unknown six weeks ago, has vaulted from the pack of eight candidates chasing Mr. Vargas Llosa for the presidency. On Friday, poll takers indicated that Mr. Fujimori, an independent, would win enough votes to force Mr. Vargas Llosa into a runoff next month.
Mr. Vargas Llosa, an admirer of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, has drawn up a blueprint for a free-market revolution in Peru. Mr. Fujimori, whose campaign literature shows him dressed in a kimono and brandishing a samurai sword, has loosely sketched out a program based on attracting more investment from Japan, his parents' homeland. 
Last year, Peru's gross national product contracted by 12.2 percent, the sharpest drop on the continent. At the same time, prices rose by 2,775 percent. Peru's currency, the inti, has lost 70 percent of its value against the dollar since February, trading last week at 30,000. The United Nations reports that 5 million of Peru's 22 million inhabitants live in extreme poverty.
This economic disaster is believed to have undermined the campaign of Luis Alva Castro, the candidate of the governing Popular Revolutionary American Alliance.
 
Terror of the Shining Path
Competing for the attention of Peru's 10 million voters is terrorist violence, which has claimed 700 lives since the beginning of the year and 18,000 since the rebellion by the Shining Path guerrilla group began in 1980. Most of the Pacific coast nation is under a state of emergency. On the eve of the election, the police and soldiers conducted intensive patrols in the hope of thwarting any attacks.
Voting Sunday is expected to be light in most areas of the Andean highlands, the Shining Path's primary zone of influence. The guerrilla group, which abhors elections and seeks a worker-peasant state along Maoist lines. has threatened to cut off voters' fingers. In a response to the threats, election officials in the highlands have been instructed to suspend a traditional practice of guarding against voter fraud: dipping voters' forefingers in indelible ink.
This weekend, the rebel group brought most interstate traffic to a halt by threatening to mine roads and by declaring ''armed strikes'' in two departments, Ayacucho and Junin.
 
Killings and Explosions
Ten days ago, the threat of an armed strike disrupted life in Lima, the Peruvian capital, as 80 percent of the city's private bus drivers stayed home. Drivers said that the Government of President Alan Garcia never reimbursed the owners of buses burned during an armed strike before municipal elections last November.
In the last two weeks, terrorists killed four congressional candidates, occupied radio stations to broadcast warnings against voting, and, in at least 200 attacks, dynamited power pylons, party offices, bank branches, police posts, hotels, Government offices, empty movie theaters and factories. At least two dozen people were killed, including at least one Shining Path guerrilla in an explosion of land mines placed around a power pylon.
With terrorism and the economy preoccupying voters, candidates rarely mentioned the Peruvian issue that most concerns Washington: the cultivation of coca leaves, the raw material for cocaine.
Peru probably grows half of the world's coca leaves, a major source of hard currency there. Most candidates, including Mr. Vargas Llosa, oppose aerial eradication programs. Instead, they call for increased aid from the United States to help peasants switch to a legal crop. #37 Percent for Vargas Llosa With the campaigning ended, representatives of Peru's top three polling organizations, Apoyo, Datum, and the Peruvian Company for Market Research, met in Lima on Friday with foreign correspondents. By law, the results of new opinion surveys cannot be reported in the local press less than 15 days before the election.
The pollsters agreed that support for Mr. Vargas Llosa had declined in the last two months from a near majority of voters to around 37 percent.
In contrast, Mr. Fujimori, referred to as the ''Japanese torpedo'' by Lima's press, has jumped from less than 1 percent of voter support in February to about 25 percent.
If no candidate wins more than 50 percent of the votes cast on Sunday, two candidates will face a runoff, probably in May. The ballot for Congress, in which voters are to elect 60 senators and 180 deputies, requires no runoff.
Several polling experts and political analysts here describe part of the decline in support for Mr. Vargas Llosa as a cross-border reaction to the radical economic program that is provoking a recession in neighboring Brazil.
 
Fallout From Brazilian Austerity
Three weeks ago, Mr. Vargas Llosa hailed the anti-inflationary program imposed by Brazil's new President, Fernando Collor de Mello.
The 54-year-old candidate of Peru's center-right Democratic Front coalition has vowed for months to bring inflation down to 10 percent a year through an economic ''shock'' program: cutting the state payroll, abolishing subsidies and selling state companies to private investors.
But Mr. Fujimori, a 51-year-old independent who campaigns under the slogan ''Work, Technology and Honesty,'' has said that drastic economic measures are not needed to straighten out Peru's economy.
Mr. Fujimori, who has campaigned with evangelical Christian support, is a former rector of the Agrarian University of La Molina, a Lima suburb. After Brazil, Peru has South America's second-largest colony of descendants of Japanese immigrants, and polls indicate that Peruvians hold the Japanese community in high regard.
 
Disillusionment With Parties
The pollsters said the lack of a party network is not a major handicap in Peru, where many voters are disillusioned with the track record of politicians from established parties.
In an upset victory in November, Ricardo Belmont, a radio and television announcer without any party affiliation, won the mayoralty of Lima, Peru's second-most important elected post after the presidency.
''Sunday's election will be one of big surprises,'' Manuel Dornellas, editor of the center-right newspaper Expreso, wrote last week. ''From the consolidation of Vargas Llosa, to the appearance of Fujimori, passing through the collapse of the Marxist leftists, no one can deny that new winds are blowing in national politics.''

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
Commission Urges Hungary to Overhaul Economy

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUDAPEST, April 7

 BODY:
A task force of international economic experts has called for a swift and decisive attack on the centrally planned economy in Hungary, saying economic change must occur in ''quantum leaps'' if the country is to move successfully from its socialist past toward a free-market system.
Reporting just before elections on Sunday that will produce Hungary's first democratic government in more than 40 years, the Blue Ribbon Commission, a privately financed committee of Hungarian and foreign experts, laid out a program for the new government.
The report, issued on Friday, calls for drastic cuts in state subsidies for housing, food and enterprises; an overhaul of the banking system, including greater discipline in the collection of bad debts and a greater role for investment banks in the privatization of state companies; a lowering of Hungary's personal income tax rate; the raising of the retirement age to 65 from 60 for men and 55 for women; the convertibility of the Hungarian forint to other currencies within three years, and a review of tax breaks for foreign businesses so that local investors are not put at a disadvantage. 
 
Early Actions Proposed
The report calls on the new government, while it is still in its ''honeymoon period,'' to adopt incentives for private entrepreneurs, the creation of an investment agency, enforcement of the bankruptcy law and abolition of some import restrictions.
Most importantly, the report said, Hungary should adopt a comprehensive program for economic reform, set a timetable and keep the public informed of all its decisions, so that people are not surprised by the shocks caused by the transition.
''Policies cannot be implemented if the public does not understand the consequences,'' said Sylvia Ostry, a Canadian economist and co-chairwoman of the commission. ''The more the public understands, the better the policies are likely to be.''
The report also proposed changes in the West's response to Hungary's economic problems, including an easing of import restrictions and Western government guarantees for commercial loans and tax concessions for companies investing in Hungary. But it concluded that help should be made conditional on a decision by the new government to take necessary, if painful, steps on its own.
 
The Commission's Background
The 20-member commission, financed by private sponsors in the West and by Hungarian business and academic institutes, has been meeting for six months to map out how Hungary should reach its goal of a free-market economy.
Among its members are prominent figures from Hungary's rival political parties, as well as leading economists. The foreign experts include several Hungarian emigres living in the West as well as financial and management experts from the United States, Canada, Europe and Japan. Among the American sponsors are the Hudson Institute, a private research organization in Indianapolis; Indiana University, and the East-West Forum, a nonprofit research group.
At a news conference here on Friday, members of the commission said the report would serve as a reference for the government that emerges from Sunday's elections, and perhaps as a detailed guide.
The timetable for converting the forint, the Hungarian currency, was the most contentious issue debated by the commission, because letting the forint float to its true market value is bound to jolt the economy.

LENGTH: 1304 words

HEADLINE: U.S. and Allies Concerned by Yen's Fall

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, April 7

 BODY:
The top economic policy makers from the United States and its six main industrial allies expressed concern today about the fall of the Japanese yen. While leaving open the possibility of steps to bolster the yen's value, the officials announced no specific plans.
After a daylong meeting here, the finance ministers and chief central bankers of the seven nations, known as the Group of Seven, issued a brief communique stating that the decline of the yen had ''undesirable consequences.'' The statement said the officials had ''agreed to keep these developments under review.''
That could mean that the policy makers will wait to do something about the yen until their next meeting, in Washington next month. Or it could mean they will take joint action sooner. 
 
Concern About Trade Deficits
The yen's value has fallen by more than 10 percent against the dollar this year, and some officials believe that could have an eventual effect on the international trade balance. A less valuable yen makes Japanese goods less expensive abroad and the goods of other countries more expensive in Japan, making it harder for other nations to reduce trade deficits with Japan. The yen closed trading Friday at 157.50 to the dollar.
But the prevailing view seemed to be that internal Japanese economic and political conditions, particularly the sharp drop in the Japanese stock market, had caused the yen to decline and that international intervention would not be effective.
At a news conference after the meeting, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said the value of the yen was ''about where it was three years ago'' and was thus not outside the bounds of stability.
Neither Mr. Brady nor the officials from other countries would state specifically what had been decided on at the meeting.
 
Waiting for Market Action
If the ministers did decide to bolster the yen, even with modest purchases of the Japanese currency, such action would not be known for certain until the financial markets around the world open on Monday morning.
In addition to the United States and Japan, the Group of Seven consists of West Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada. The group usually meets three times a year to review international economic conditions, with the goal of keeping international markets on a steady course.
Today's meeting was held in the new Finance Ministry building in a neighborhood called Bercy, on the Right Bank of the Seine.
Monumental changes have occurred in the world since the group met in September, including the first steps toward free markets in Eastern Europe and the movement toward German unification. But the decline of the yen was seen as the only significant issue on which joint action was possible today.
Yasushi Mieno, the governor of the Bank of Japan, said after the meeting that he hoped the group's communique would bolster the yen when trading resumes Monday. The Japanese have been urging their allies to give them some help in supporting the yen.
 
Overall Outlook Is Optimistic
The morning session today was devoted to a review of international conditions led by Michel Camdessus, director of the International Monetary Fund. The Group of Seven concluded in its communique that ''overall growth prospects remain good, inflation remains contained and external imbalances have been reduced, although unevenly.''
In the afternoon, the officials discussed not only the value of the yen but such issues as the developments in Eastern Europe, the formation of an international bank to lend to the new democracies there and an impending increase in payments to the International Monetary Fund.
According to sketchy accounts of today's meeting, the argument against strong market intervention to increase the value of the yen was led by Mr. Brady and the Finance Minister of West Germany, Theo Waigel.
Mr. Waigel said afterward only that ''coordination and cooperation will continue'' in regards to the yen.
The American view is that the conditions that caused the yen to drop are beyond international repair and that steps now would probably not succeed in raising its value.
''If you fail, you have wasted a tool that can only be used occasionally,'' one United States official said.
 
Japanese Stocks a Factor
The decline of the Japanese stock market by about 25 percent this year has not been reflected in other stock markets, and some American policy makers worry about actions that might tie United States markets to those in Japan.
A West German finance official told reporters that a large part of the problem with the yen resulted from the delay by Japanese officials in raising their interest rates. After public squabbling between the Finance Ministry and the Bank of Japan, the central bank finally raised its key discount rate on March 20 by one percentage point, to 5.25 percent. But that did not stop the yen's slide.
''They should have raised interest rates earlier to avoid a lack of confidence,'' the German official said.
The Finance Minister of France, Pierre Beregovoy, added evidence to support the view that the policy makers had agreed not to act decisively on the yen for the time being. ''It's up to Japan to keep these developments under close review,'' he said at a news conference.
 
German Issues Discussed
Officials said that during the discussion of the monetary union of West and East Germany, Mr. Waigel reassured his counterparts that they would be consulted before an official exchange rate was set for converting East German currency into West German marks. In any event, Mr. Waigel said at a news conference, no decision would be made before the leaders of Western Europe meet in Dublin on April 27.
Last weekend, Mr. Waigel said his Government intended to allow one West German mark for each East German mark. But a political furor arose in both Germanys, and the Government backed off that plan.
Officials in other countries fear that granting equal value to East German marks could produce serious inflation and lead to higher interest rates, but Mr. Waigel said at his news conference that he did not anticipate interest rates rising.
 
A New International Bank
After the Finance Ministers leave on Sunday, their deputies will stay behind to continue negotiations over the formation of a European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
The bank is being created to lend money to the emerging free-market economies in Eastern Europe. United States officials say they hope it will be in operation by a year from now.
Many important issues have been resolved, at least in principle. The United States is to hold a 10 percent share in the bank, the largest single stake. No other country's share will be larger than 8.5 percent, but a 51 percent majority of the shares are to be held by the Western European countries that make up the European Community.
Of particular importance to the Americans, up to 60 percent of the money lent by the bank will go to new private ventures or to state-run enterprises like telephone companies that are becoming private.
 
Disagreement on Soviet Loans
The most significant unresolved issue involves loans to the Soviet Union. The United States insists that the Soviets should be allowed to borrow no more than the amount of capital they put into the bank. Some European countries favor a more generous policy toward Moscow.
Another matter that must be settled is the location of the headquarters. The United States wants the headquarters in Prague, but it will probably lose, and the offices are likely to be somewhere in Western Europe.
In addition, a competition has developed over the presidency of the new bank. The leading candidates are Onno Ruding, a former Dutch Finance Minister, and Jacques Atalli, an adviser to President Francois Mitterrand of France.

HEADLINE: Wisconsin Spring: New Fishing Season, Old Strife

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINOCQUA, Wis., April 4

 BODY:
The ice is beginning to give way on the lakes of northern Wisconsin, and soon the Chippewa will renew a ritual as old as their ancestors' memories. They will take to the water in boats to spear the fat walleyed pike that come to spawn each spring in the cold shallows.
But among the small towns and lakeside resorts in this part of the state, the Indians' annual spearfishing has become the occasion for an uglier seasonal rite. On spring nights, for the last two years, hundreds of whites have gathered at boat landings to hurl taunts, racial slurs and sometimes stones at Indian fishermen.
With the spearfishing season expected to begin soon, state, local, Federal and tribal officials are girding for another round of protests in which whites will accuse Indians of exploiting tribal fishing rights to strip some lakes of valuable sporting fish. 
''I am hoping the silent majority on both sides will prevail and we will have a calm spring,'' said Michael W. Allen, the chairman of the Lac du Flambeau Reservation, home of the largest of six Chippewa tribes in northern Wisconsin. ''But in the meantime, our main concern is that our tribal spearers are protected.''
 
When the Ice Breaks Up
Law-enforcement officials have dispatched hundreds of police officers and sheriff's deputies to standby duty around the state. Last spring more than 200 whites were arrested.
Nearly all the conflicts in Wisconsin have involved the Lac du Flambeau, whose spearers have been the most aggressive and whose reservation, near here, is at the center of one of the most popular tourist areas. Indian and non-Indian leaders alike have issued public appeals to stay away from the boat landings, and this week Gov. Tommy G. Thompson said he was encouraged by the efforts of local groups to reduce strife. But both sides say their supporters will turn out later this month when the lake ice breaks up.
In Washington, Senator Daniel K. Inouye, the Hawaii Democrat who is chairman of the Senate's Indian Affairs Committee, has asked President Bush to name a representative to start new negotiations with tribal, state and local officials in Wisconsin in which the tribe would exchange some fishing rights for economic aid.
Since last May, efforts to reduce the tensions have resulted in thousands of hours of talk but have achieved little. Although the Indians say they will voluntarily reduce their harvest, Lac du Flambeau members narrowly rejected a proposed financial settlement that was worked out last fall between Governor Thompson and the tribal leadership headed by Mr. Allen.
 
What Might Have Been
Under the settlement, the tribe would have agreed to take fewer fish in exchange for $49.7 million in state aid and services over 10 years - roughly $600 a year for each of the nearly 8,400 walleyed pike that the Lac du Flambeau took in the 12-day season last spring. The six Chippewa tribes together took 16,400.
The dispute grew out of a 1983 Federal court decision affirming Chippewa rights to take walleye and other fish from the lakes of the densely wooded northern third of Wisconsin. The Chippewa ceded the territory, including the lakes, to the Federal Government in the 19th century. In return, they were guaranteed the right to hunt, fish and gather timber.
But most of those lakes are now surrounded by cottages, resorts and businesses owned by non-Indians whose livelihoods depend on the tourist economy. Beginning with spring weather, the region becomes a popular vacation spot, particularly for sport fishers who prize the walleye and muskellunge that populate the northern lakes.
 
Damage to Economy Charged
Such disputes underscore the problems that many state and local governments have faced in recent years as a result of Federal court decisions affirming century-old Indian treaty rights and protecting tribal governments. Those decisions have brought local governments and tribes into conflict over matters like taxes, law enforcement, mining, and water, hunting and fishing rights.
Opponents say the Chippewa spearfishing damages the local economy because the Indians are now taking thousands of walleye that could be available to non-Indian fishermen when the regular season opens later this spring.
 
What the Indians Have Taken
On some of the lakes most popular among white anglers, for example, state game wardens last year had to reduce the limit for non-Indian anglers to one or two fish per day as a result of spearing activity by the Chippewa. In the past, a limit of five fish a day used to be common.
This year, the Indians say they will reduce fishing activity on most lakes to allow state wardens to assure sports anlgers a limit of three fish a day.
Under the Federal court ruling, the Indians are entitled to harvest up to 100 percent of what biolgists calculate to be the safe allowable catch on a lake. Such a harvest would leave enough adult fish to assure future reproduction, but not enough for sports anglers.
But the tribes have agreed voluntarily never to take more than 60 percent of the allowable catch in any one lake, and this year agreed to reduce that limit to 54 percent.
The Indians argue that they have never taken more than a small part of the total allowable safe catch. If they had taken 60 percent of the walleyed pike in every lake, they would have removed more than 40,000 fish last year. Because there are not enough Indian spearers to harvest all the lakes, and because the season is so short, a total of 271 tribal spearers last year took only about 16,400 walleyed pike from 101 lakes.
 
From an Opponent's View
Dean Crist, who owns a pizza restaurant in Minocqua, is the leader of Stop Treaty Abuse-Wisconsin, a group that opposes the spearfishing. He says the Federal courts have granted the Chippewa special privileges.
''I can't fish out of season - I can't go out and take thousands of walleye at one time,'' said Mr. Crist, who was recently acquitted of charges that he endangered Indian fishermen and state game wardens in a confrontation.
''If they want to spearfish as a ceremonial thing, great, we're with them,'' he said. ''But what they are doing is ravaging the lakes, and that hurts a lot of innocent people.''
Mr. Crist says he has wide support among the 50,000 residents of Vilas and Oneida Counties here, though his organization mustered only feeble support when it recently tried to win the recall from office of a state legislator who had backed the tribal negotiations.
 
New Recall Effort Is Begun
The legislator, Assemblyman James Holperin, was returned to office here Tuesday after defeating a Republican challenger with a wide margin. Last month, Mr. Holperin rolled up a similar margin in the Democratic primary, when he was challenged by an ally of Mr. Crist.
Now opponents of treaty rights are seeking the recall of Representative David R. Obey, the Democratic Congressman, because he backed talks with tribes.
Jeff Long, the Town Chairman in nearby Boulder Junction, a leader of a local group seeking to ease tensions with Indians, said he believed most people in the region were eager to work with the Indians.
''It's a question of finding comon ground,'' he said. ''We see the walleye as a resource to attract tourists. The Indians see it as a commodity, something to be taken for food. But it can benefit both of us.''
Some Chippewa argue that racism, not economic concern, motivates many treaty opponents. ''For a long time, we said nothing,'' said Tom Maulson, who organized opposition among tribal members to the settlement proposed by Governor Thompson. ''We knew our place. Now there is frustration from some of those on the outside who don't like the idea that we are now exercising our rights.''
