HEADLINE: Deficits Imperil Northeast Governors

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, April 6

 BODY:
The economic slowdown in the Northeast has rattled the region's politics, putting incumbent governors of both parties on the defensive and injecting a powerful element of uncertainty into this year's elections.
In the last month two Democrats, William A. O'Neill of Connecticut and Madeleine M. Kunin of Vermont, announced that they would not run again, citing a number of personal reasons. But their states' fiscal difficulties and the hard political choices those difficulties forced were widely seen as factors in both decisions and as likely to drive the campaigns to succeed them.
In Massachusetts, where Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, a Democrat, announced a year ago that he would not seek re-election, analysts in both parties say the state's fiscal troubles have so soured the public's mood that Republicans stand a good chance of winning the governorship in November, even though only 14 percent of the registered voters are Republican. 
 
People Feel 'Lied To'
''People feel they were lied to about the budget process,'' said Linda DiVall, a Republican poll taker working for Steven Pierce, a Republican candidate for governor in Massachusetts.
In New York, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has so far escaped a serious challenge in this year's race, but many analysts say the state's fiscal problems will dog him if he seeks the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1992. And in New Jersey a newly elected Democrat, Jim Florio, was quickly confronted by what he estimated as a $580 million deficit and has proposed a huge tax plan to deal with it.
Nor are Republicans immune to the political fallout. In Maine and Rhode Island and even in the Republican stronghold of New Hampshire, Democrats are planning tough campaigns against Republican incumbents, sensing new opportunities based on the incumbents' handling of the states' fiscal troubles.
''I don't think it's a Democratic or Republican issue,'' said Mark Gearan, executive director of the Democratic Governors Association. ''It's a result of eight very good years in a regional economy that is now slowing down.''
The severity of fiscal difficulties in these states varies widely, but a study made public on Friday by the National Association of State Budget Officers in Washington showed the regional sweep of the problem. ''Twenty states in all have had to cut fiscal year 1990 budgets already, and that includes every state in the Northeast - all of New England plus New York and New Jersey,'' said Marcia Howard, the group's research director. The region has also seen a round of tax increases, she added.
 
Follows a Decade of Boom
The adjustment is particularly difficult in the Northeast because it follows a decade of boom, when many of these state governments expanded services and programs while growth in revenue enabled them to depict themselves as fiscally responsible.
''Their tax bases were growing very rapidly,'' said William Galston, a political scientist at the University of Maryland. ''They could initiate new programs and beef up old ones at zero political cost, and they all looked like geniuses.''
That image was particularly seductive to the Democrats, who in the late 1980's showcased these governors as a new breed of Democrat, with both a heart and an adding machine. Mr. Dukakis, who rose the highest and fell the farthest, built his 1988 Presidential campaign around what he called ''the Massachusetts miracle,'' although even during the race signs of fiscal difficulties were emerging.
There is a widespread belief that the Dukakis administration did not heed the early signs of trouble because it was preoccupied with Mr. Dukakis's Presidential campaign.
Now many Republicans say the next potential Democratic Presidential candidate from the region, Governor Cuomo, will be vulnerable to the old charges of ''taxing and spending'' as the state struggles to deal with a $1.5 billion gap in the 1990-91 budget.
''You could always criticize his record,'' said Charles Black, a Republican consultant. ''Now, he's had to do more on the tax front, and fiscal problems will be more of a vulnerability.''
 
The Electorate Was Lulled
Behind the volatility of this year's gubernatorial elections is an electorate that felt unprepared for a grim round of revised revenue estimates, budget cuts and tax increases, according to analysts in both parties. Politicians note that the region's economic slowdown cannot compare to what the Midwest endured in the early 1980's, but it looms large to people who heard talk of ''a miracle'' a few years ago.
''Voters don't understand how you can be in a $100 million surplus one year and scraping and cutting back to balance out the next year,'' said Rhode Island's Governor, Edward D. DiPrete, a Republican.
Tom Kiley, a Democratic poll taker working for Representative Joseph E. Brennan, who is challenging Gov. John R. McKernan Jr. of Maine, said: ''If you're driving along at 80 miles per hour on the Massachusetts Turnpike and you slow down to 55, it feels like you're not going anywhere. That's the kind of reflex New England voters are feeling.''
Moreover, some Demcorats say the resolute ''no-new-tax'' stand of the Bush Administration has led to unrealistic expectations among the voters. ''I think they've gotten accustomed to the message that they can have it all without pain and sacrifice,'' said Governor Kunin. ''And when local and state governments offer a different message, you really don't like it.''
Mingled with the politics is a deeper debate over whether some of these states should have better prepared for the slowdown, an argument that varies widely from state to state but is acute in Massachusetts. ''I would blame it on the political system,'' said Richard A. Manley, president of the Massachusetts Taxpayers Foundation, a public policy group that is heavily financed by business.
 
From Growth to Groans
''During the so-called Massachusetts miracle years, the money was coming in over the transom, from both dramatic economic growth and a rejuvenated revenue department,'' Mr. Manley said.
In short, he and other analysts argue, some states became accustomed to a level of revenue growth that could not be sustained. ''Part of what haunts the Northeast is they had such a phenomenal economic growth and revenue growth that everything else looks pitiful in comparison,'' Ms. Howard said.
Political experts in the region indicate that this year's campaigns could revolve around what the governors should have known and when they should have known it. In New Hampshire, for instance, where Gov. Judd Gregg succeeded John H. Sununu, a fellow Republican who is now the White House chief of staff, Democrats are homing in on the timing of the state's fiscal troubles.
''John Sununu supposedly left the state with a surplus, then the next thing we're told is Judd Gregg has a deficit,'' said Ramsay McLauchlan, executive director of the New Hampshire Demcoratic Party. ''He's not blaming John Sununu; he's just saying it's here, somehow.''
New Hampshire Republican leaders say the state is confronting its fiscal problem and expect Mr. Gregg to be re-elected.

HEADLINE: Everglades Sentinel on Watch at 100

BYLINE: By JAMES LeMOYNE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, April 7

 BODY:
She lives in a region that has often symbolized glitz and the American dream of endless growth. But on her 100th birthday today, Marjory Stoneman Douglas is more than ever a living testament to a different ethic.
As one of the nation's best-known and one of its oldest living environmentalists, Mrs. Douglas is spryly celebrating the rare completion of an unbowed century of life.
If that weren't bounty enough, she is enjoying the even rarer experience of being an environmental prophet who has lived to see her prophecy proved true and acted upon. 
Mrs. Douglas has guaranteed her place as a leading naturalist by spending most of her life fighting to preserve the Everglades, the vast, slow-moving stream of water and saw grass that covers much of the final 100 miles of South Florida, providing a home to some of the most exotic and beautiful animals in North America.
 
Just Common Sense
She herself seems utterly unimpressed with her achievement, treating it as an act of plain common sense.
''Eighty percent of our rainfall depends on evaporation from the Everglades,'' Mrs. Douglas said in an interview at the English-style cottage she built on a leafy street here in 1926. ''If you don't have rain and water, South Florida will become a desert - it's as simple as that.''
But government officials, local citizens and environmentalists are far more generous in their assessment of Mrs. Douglas. They applaud her for her early understanding that the survival of the Everglades was the precondition to the survival of much of the rest of South Florida.
''The Everglades wouldn't be there for us to try and continue to save if not for her work through the years,'' said Roderick J. Jude, an official of the Florida chapter of the Sierra Club.
 
Fired the First Shot
That recognition has prompted local officials to name a new high school for Mrs. Douglas and to christen a new nature center, on Key Biscayne in Miami, after her in a celebration today commemorating her 100th birthday.
It was not always so easy for her to get her views across.
Forty-three years ago, Mrs. Douglas fired the first shot, more like a cannon blast, in what became a near-ceaseless campaign to persuade Florida to change the way it thinks about itself. In so doing, she used arguments that have had impact across the country.
At a time when Floridians commonly acted as if their state was a boundless font of natural riches, Mrs. Douglas wrote a 1947 book, ''The Everglades: River of Grass,'' that argued exactly the opposite.
''There are no other Everglades in the world,'' her book began, going on to tell in clean language why the Everglades is an especially fragile vessel of life threatened by drainage canals, commercial farming and suburbs. That is almost common wisdom today, but four decades ago it was an astonishingly original and independent insight.
 
Right, but Not Popular
It was not, however, a popular message. State officials saw unfettered development as a boon to economic growth. Big farmers wanted more swamp drained. The Army Corps of Engineers went to work cutting canals that in effect choked the natural wetland of its one utterly essential requirement: water.
It took an uncommon eye to gaze on a vast swamp filled mainly with mosquitoes, alligators and mud and see it as the key for creating, filtering and retaining most of the fresh water available on the thin limestone shelf that separates South Florida from the sea.
But that is exactly what Mrs. Douglas saw. She used a potent pen to share that vision and also formed Friends of the Everglades.
After decades of effort, the central core of the once extensive Everglades today is preserved as a national park. The Government has announced plans to buy more land from private owners and to restore some original streams to permit the Everglades to gradually regain more of its function as the filtration system for the region.
 
Life Like No Other
The entire 4,000-square-mile swamp is a slowly moving river, carrying a sheet of water from Lake Okeechobee to the Gulf of Mexico. In the islands and wet byways along the way live ibises, roseate spoonbills, wood storks, manatees, the threatened Florida panther and saltwater crocodile, as well as hundreds of other animals, fish and plants.
There is particular concern for the Everglades this year, during one of the worst droughts ever recorded. Wading birds are not nesting because they lack food and water. A winter freeze killed thousands of fish, as well as several manatees.
But if the river of grass has anything like the staying power of Mrs. Douglas, its future may be more secure than some fear. The author of several books, she is now at work on a biography of the Anglo-American naturalist W. H. Hudson, the author of ''Green Mansions.''
Though her eyes are poor, she prefers to stand up and walk on her own as she steps out to her sunlit porch. Asked if she is hopeful for the Everglades' survival, she answers: ''I am neither an optimist nor a pessimist. I say it's got to be done.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Marjory Stoneman Douglas, one of the nation's best-known environmentalists, has spent the better part of a century fighting to preserve the Everglades. She celebrated her 100th birthday yesterday. (The New York Times/Susan Greenwood)

HEADLINE: Owner of Fire Site Is Being Sued by Brother and Sister

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
The landlord of the Happy Land Social Club is being sued by his brother and sister, who claim that he is running one of New York City's biggest real-estate fortunes into the ground with bad investments, borrowing huge amounts of money to speculate in commodities and deliberately squandering his father's billion-dollar estate before his younger brother can gain control of a portion of it.
The accusations of mismanagement against Alexander DiLorenzo 3d by his brother, Marc, and sister, Lisa, echo comments about Mr. DiLorenzo's operating style from other New York City real-estate developers.
Others in the business say Mr. DiLorenzo is a loner in a gregarious world and a man who has shunned the blue-chip properties that other heirs to big real-estate fortunes usually favor. Instead, he has spent recent years mortgaging his company's properties to buy land and buildings on the very fringes of what his fellow operators would consider respectable New York.
Happy Land, the illegal Bronx social club at 1961 Southern Boulevard in which 87 people died in an arson fire on March 25, was part of such an assemblage - a nondescript commercial strip that he bought in 1985. So are block after block of fading apartment houses on Riverside Drive in the 140's and 150's, on the edge of Harlem, and blocks in Manhattan and the Bronx with eight other social clubs. 
 
'Alex Buys Funny Things'
His brother and sister sued in October 1988 to wrest control of the two family partnerships, which have roughly 250 holdings valued in court papers at as much as $1.2 billion, before they are broken up into three equal shares.
In his response to the suit, Mr. DiLorenzo claimed that such aquisitions were part of a strategy of long-term growth, although he conceded that they have not performed well as investments in the current economy.
Five brokers who have worked with the DiLorenzo family said that he had departed from the pattern his father had followed of buying established, expensive properties. None would be quoted by name for fear of jeopardizing future business dealing with him.
''Alex buys funny things,'' said a broker who had done business with Mr. DiLorenzo's late father, ''You look at other big dealers - after they had made a little money, they forgot about the junk, they wanted to assemble good portfolios. But Alex was still buying town houses up to last year, one after the other, whole strings of them, just like he played the commodities market.''
On Friday, Mr. DiLorenzo was released without bail on 42 separate arrest warrants charging him with serious building violations at a dozen Manhattan locations. some of which are the sites of social clubs. On Tuesday, he surrendered on a warrant issued a year ago after he had failed to respond to complaints of safety violations at the Happy Land building.
 
No Public Relations Firm
Mr. DiLorenzo was known for his public reticence before the fire and the lawsuit, and since then he has refused all comment. Neither his company officers nor his lawyers would return telephone calls asking for comment.
In a city in which real-estate operators can achieve a degree of fame that other towns reserve for movie stars, Mr. DiLorenzo has not taken even the first step toward a acquiring a public persona - retaining a public relations firm.
But the DiLorenzo empire holds far more valuable properties purchased by Mr. DiLorenzo's father.
It owns what amounts to several acres of land under prominent buildings, and the land is often sold or leased separately from the building above it.
 
Other 'Fee Positions'
Easily the best property is the land that the St. Moritz hotel rests upon on Central Park South. Mr. DiLorenzo once turned down an offer reported to be in the tens of millions for the property by Donald J. Trump who, like Mr. DiLorenzo, is the son of a successful real-estate operator.
Other prime ''fee positions,'' as ownership of such land is known, are at 63 Wall Street; 200 Madison Avenue, at 35th Street, and 1001 Fifth Avenue, at 82d Street. The DiLorenzos also own or control impressive corner assemblages on Lexington Avenue on the Upper East Side and the entire block of Greek Revival brick houses and the adjoining apartment building facing Washington Square Park between Fifth Avenue and University Place.
The DiLorenzos' St. Moritz land lease, now worth $210,000 a year, expires in two years, and the renewal lease has already been set at 7 percent of the land's market value, which is undoubtedly far higher than the $21 million the city has assessed it at for tax purposes.
The DiLorenzo partnerships were left in trust to the three children at the death of their father, and Alex 3d administered the trust. Several years ago, Marc DiLorenzo, requested, as was his right under the terms of the trust, that his brother break it into three equal parts and distribute it. His brother apparently refused, and Marc and Lisa sued. The American Arbitration Association was appointed to divide the estate into three shares, to be divided by lot, but Alex did not accept the division.
And Marc DiLorenzo told Justice Harold Baer Jr. that his brother was ''squandering'' the family's holdings.
 
Details in a Ruling
The fortune was assembled by Alexander DiLorenzo Jr. before his death in 1975, in partnership with another shrewd real-estate developer, the late Sol Goldman. Now Mr. Goldman's children are also in court, trying to keep their mother, Lillian, from claiming the family fortune.
Details of the DiLorenzo case were made public in a ruling on a motion by Marc DiLorenzo to remove his brother as head of the partnership pending the breakup. The decision was printed in full in the Dec. 21 edition of the New York Law Journal, and the DiLorenzos have since had the record sealed by the court.
Justice Baer rejected Marc DiLorenzo's demand to remove his older brother as head of DiLorenzo Properties Company and DiLorenzo Associates.
But he ordered the older DiLorenzo not to take any major steps without consulting his younger brother and set in motion the process that will eventually lead to the breakup.
 
Losses in '88 and '89
In affidavits before the court, Marc DiLorenzo charged that his brother had lost $14 million in commodities speculation in two and a half years; that tens of millions of dollars were ''wasted'' in the purchase of two old-line brokerage houses, which have yet to return a profit, and that Alex had absented himself from the business for months on end, allowing it to decline.
Justice Baer also reported that preliminary financial statements submitted to the court showed cash losses of $21.5 million in 1988 and the potential for a $21 million additional shortfall for 1989.
''Marc goes so far as to claim that Alex is pursuing a 'scorched-earth policy' and is 'embarked on a program of ruining the partnerships from a distance,' '' Justice Baer wrote.
The judge ordered the DiLorenzo siblings to try to work out a settlement among themselves, and that in the meantime Alex DiLorenzo should avoid taking steps to diminish or encumber his brother's and sister's share of the family fortune.
The older brother also pledged to return to daily supervision of the family business.

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Haverford;
Rockwell's Son Shuns Americana For Gargoyles

DATELINE: HAVERFORD, Pa.

 BODY:
If you expected that pug nose, freckle-faced boy on The Saturday Evening Post covers to grow up to produce the same art as his father, you'd be wrong. While Norman Rockwell, the illustrator, created familiar scenes from hometown America, his son, Peter, currently artist-in-residence at Haverford College, goes beyond the familiar.
Mr. Rockwell has been pulling monsters out of his imagination and carving them in stone all semester.
The sculptor's unfinished limestone block of monsters was moved last week from the college's foundry and installed near the library, just out of the grasp of the Climbing Tree, a long, tentacled Osage Orange tree for children, students and professors to play on. Mr. Rockwell, 53 years old, chose the site himself and said his climb-on sculpture is a gift to his alma mater, from which he was graduated in 1958. 
''Most universities have a need for more nonsense,'' said Mr. Rockwell. The sculptor, who has been intrigued by monsters since he was asked to design some gargoyles for the National Cathedral in Washington, in the early 1970's, created gargoyle-like creatures out of a block of white stone that can be clambered over and slithered through.
 
'Children Enjoy Monsters'
''I associate monsters with playfulness,'' said Mr. Rockwell while examining his work in outdoor light for the first time ''and I think children enjoy monsters.''
Fretting a bit, he looked at one hollow-eyed monster with its mouth agape, and said: ''I hope it isn't frightening. I have been told I am incapable of creating a frightening monster. I take it as a compliment.'' He immediately drew a parallel to his father. ''He used to complain that he couldn't paint a sexy woman; they always looked too homey,'' Mr. Rockwell said.
Matthew Zobian, a senior economics major from Reading, Pa., who has taken sculpture classes at Haverford, said, ''It's sort of eerie looking. The gargoyles have almost a comical, scary look to them. They have big, wide-open mouths, so kids can crawl through them. They're more grotesque than scary, so that's what makes them funny.''
Hanging above the sculptor's work table in the foundry is a picture torn from an Acme supermarket advertisement of what is believed to be Mr. Rockwell's angelic 13-year-old face munching on a turkey drumstick. Below are the tools of his profession - sundry chisels, plaster-dusted rags and a rusty Chock Full o' Nuts coffee can for brushes.
There are the inevitable comparisons between famous father and son, and the son explains them this way: ''My father was conscious of what the American people would want on a Post cover,'' Mr. Rockwell said. ''Those would be constraints I might find extremely difficult. He felt everything he did was for an audience and he was willing to allow his work to be affected by the taste of that audience. I don't think that way. I don't work for a popular audience. Sculpture is not done for a mass audience.''
Mr. Rockwell lives in Rome with his wife, Cinny, and four children. He has been there since he won a fellowship at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia.
But Mr. Rockwell entered sculpture by way of fencing. He nearly died his freshman year in a fencing accident when he was stabbed in the heart and lungs by a Princeton man. He beat the odds and lived. ''I haven't liked Princeton since,'' he joked.
Next month, when Mr. Rockwell expects to complete the monster piece, he will dedicate it to Wallace Kelly, a faculty member who encouraged him to take a sculpture class to replace fencing. ''I flinched every time someone lunged at me,'' said Mr. Rockwell. ''It was love at first sight with sculpture.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Peter Rockwell with his sculpture of gargoyle-like creatures. He is donating the work to his alma mater, Haverford College, near Philadelphia. Mr. Rockwell, who is the son of Norman Rockwell, is currently an artist-in-residence at the school. (The New York Times/Arthur W. Wilkerson)

HEADLINE: Lifestyle;
The Summer Renter Now Prefers A Swing Set to the Swinging Set

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS

 BODY:
The summer folk are often familiar these days, if perhaps a bit more mature. In the 1970's, they summered with friends and significant others in popular resort areas like Fire Island, Ocean City and Old Saybrook. Now they arrive with children in tow.
The ''groupers'' still flock to the beaches and wildwoods. But unlike the swinging singles of an earlier generation, they are fewer in number and are seekers not just of good times but of times better spent. More often than not, they are accompanied by relatives, rather than strangers acquired through classified advertisements. 
''It's interesting because now there are different requirements,'' said Frank Newbold, a partner in the real-estate firm of Braverman, Newbold & Newman in East Hampton, L.I. ''They used to want to know where the singles bars in the neighborhood were located. Now they want to know where the day-care center is.''
Summer rentals in the New York region are off to their best start in years, said brokers like Mr. Newbold, who has already leased 75 houses in the Hamptons. They said the surge has been fueled by factors that include a growing confidence that beachfront pollution of recent sumnmers in places like New Jersey has been corrected and the settling down of the generation born in the late 1940's and the 50's, which has become more conservative in its spending and mores.
Brokers, who suffered through one of their worst summer seasons last year because of concern about Lyme disease, beach waste and an unstable economy, are rhapsodic about the early indicators.
''If only the real-estate sales market were as good as the rental market,'' said Patricia Swaun, a broker at Lively Real Estate in Clinton, Conn., a town overlooking Long Island Sound. ''I think people are taking their vacations differently. They're coming out to the suburbs. We have cottages that are rented by the month by families, married siblings, who split the time. We're seeing much more of that kind of sharing, rather than groups of strangers.''
Mary Randazzo, who owns Randazzo Realty in Westhampton, L.I., said: ''Last year was not as good a rental season as we expected, but that was because of the general economy. We saw fewer groups or singles renting, because they started to buy property.'' Now those who cannot afford to buy are renting. ''We are seeing a marked increase in the family rental market,'' said John Williams, the president of the Greater Wildwood-Cape May County Board of Realtors in New Jersey. ''In my own office, our rentals are up 20 percent over this time last year.''
Mr. Williams said last year's weak rental season was caused by the ''pollution paranoia'' that resulted from reports of medical waste on beaches along the Jersey Shore and garbage slicks floating offshore. He said there are accommodations to fit most budgets, from a $250-a-week studio apartment to a $2,000-a-week three-bedroom town house.
And vacationers are discovering that renting a bungalow, cottage or condominium for the summer brings some added advantages that a hotel stay does not.
''People often want to know if they can install a second telephone in order to use their fax machines,'' said Mr. Newbold, the East Hampton agent. ''That way, they can spend an extra day or two in the country and not lose touch with the office.''
 
'Child Proof' Houses
Houses with pools, tennis courts or high decks overlooking the water are still in great demand, but brokers are just as likely to get requests from prospective renters for houses that are ''child proof'': safe for children.
''That's the phrase that keeps coming up,'' Mr. Newbold said. ''In the 70's a high deck overlooking the pool was sexy for people planning to have a lot of parties. But if there is a child around, it can be dangerous. Those who ask for homes with pools want to know if the pools are enclosed or can be benched off.''
A three-bedroom house in the Hamptons has been leased from May through September by Erica Koenig, a translator, and her husband, Ovak Arslanian, a freelance photographer, who live in Greenwich Village. This is the first summer they will spend in the continental United States since their 3-year-old daughter, Kayla, was 3 months old.
''I'm from Holland, so every summer we went there,'' Ms. Koenig said. ''Rather than hauling her around Europe, we wanted to stay in the States, but not necessarily spend the summer in the city.'' With the help of Mr. Newbold, they found the house in the Hamptons. ''It's perfect,'' Ms. Koenig said. ''It's on the bay. Kayla can do her biking and venture out to the sea and play with the gulls.''
The family leased the house for $11,000. They spent half that last year in a hotel in Hawaii, where they spent a month of their vacation in addition to going to Europe.
Ms. Koenig summed up their plans for this year: ''With the house, we can come and go as we please, invite guests over, since we have the extra bedroom, and not have to be worried about nannies, since we have several friends in the Hamptons with daughters who can baby-sit. I think this is really going to work out.''

''Now they want to know where the day-care center is,'' he said. (NYT/Michael Shavel)

LENGTH: 1504 words

HEADLINE: FILM;
She's Filming Her Movie, Twice

BYLINE: By STEPHEN FARBER

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD

 BODY:
Catchy, compelling, topical ideas for movies - what Hollywood calls ''high concepts'' - are a precious commodity. That is one reason why Coline Serreau, the French writer-director, is in demand. Her 1985 French hit ''Three Men and a Cradle,'' the story of three swinging bachelors forced to raise a baby girl, was bought by Disney Studios and turned into an Americanized version, ''Three Men and a Baby,'' that grossed more than $200 million. Disney has been equally enraptured by Ms. Serreau's latest French film, ''Mama, There's a Man in Your Bed,'' and they hired Ms. Serreau to write and direct the American remake even before she had finished shooting the French film.
The original ''Mama'' - which was titled ''Romuald et Juliette'' in France - will be released by Miramax Films Friday. It stars Daniel Auteuil as the chief executive of a successful yogurt company who is in danger of being deposed by several treacherous underlings. A cleaning woman (played by a newcomer, Firmine Richard) working in the office happens to discover the plot and warns her boss of the sabotage. She helps him to foil the takeover attempt, and in the course of this most unlikely alliance, the two fall in love. 
While awaiting the American release of ''Mama,'' Ms. Serreau is living in Santa Monica, Calif., making revisions in the script for the remake, which she plans to shoot this summer with Richard Dreyfuss in the lead. (The role of the cleaning woman has not yet been cast.) Many other film makers have attempted American remakes of French hits; among the recent cultural transplants have been ''Cousins,''
''Three Fugitives,'' ''The Man With One Red Shoe,'' and ''Breathless.'' Most of these American remakes, however, have seemed faintly unconvincing when transposed from Paris to Seattle or Baltimore. As Vincent Canby observed in decrying the trend last year, French and American films ''reflect a different reality. In a French movie, a man who moves easily between his wife and his mistress can be taken for granted. The French accept the situation without surprise. An American movie would insist on analyzing the guy.''
While Ms. Serreau is reluctant to criticize other French remakes, she does suggest one reason why a story may seem entrancing in French and leaden in English. ''We have another system of writing in France,'' she says. ''Most directors are writers, and they are completely free. They write a story that is meaningful to them. Here in Hollywood people write a story that they hope will make money.''
What makes Ms. Serreau's films stand out from the pack of French films recycled for America is that they have universal stories that transcend national boundaries. She points out that ''Three Men and a Cradle'' was successful all over the world even before Hollywood cast Tom Selleck, Ted Danson and Steve Guttenberg in the remake. (Despite their success at the box office, both films got mixed reviews from the critics.) ''The script and the theme of the movie were very up to date,'' she suggests. ''It burst out at just the right moment. It caught something in the air. I think men are changing in their attitudes toward raising children, and I took notice of that.''
Similarly, ''Mama, There's a Man in Your Bed'' tells a story of economic, racial - the cleaning woman is black - and sexual barriers that is at least as pertinent in America as in France. In fact, Ms. Serreau thought of the story for her French film while she was living in Los Angeles working on ''Three Men and a Baby.'' ''I had the feeling that there were very separate worlds in America,'' she says. ''There's a whole mixture - third-world people, Latinos, blacks, whites - and I think things are ready to blow up because the difference in the quality of these people's lives is amazing.''
Ms. Serreau reports that France has its own distinct but troubling racial problems. ''Race is a big issue in France,'' she says. ''It's not so much with black people but with Arabians, Islamic people who have emigrated from North Africa. It's more a cultural problem and a religious problem than a racial problem, but it's huge.''
Ms. Serreau suggests that it was not simply the racial and economic gap between Romuald and Juliette that tantalized her but the gender gap as well. ''It is not only a story of class and racist issues,'' she says. ''It's also about sexism. Romuald has been very unaware of his wife, and he is very insensitive to this black woman, too. He is a man in a man's world, and then he is exposed to another side of life, a whole other way of seeing things.''
The ending in which Romuald and Juliette overcome their differences to get married was never intended by Ms. Serreau to be realistic. ''This movie's not about reality,'' she asserts. ''It's about dreams and desire. If by any chance anybody is happy to see this story happen, that is already an achievement, because it means people wish that it might be true.''
That potent, whimsical fantasy is clearly what attracted Disney to the idea of doing an American remake. ''The human idea transcends cultural barriers,'' says Ricardo Mestres, president of Hollywood Pictures, a new Disney division that will produce the American film. ''It's a unique love story. Choosing to focus on a white man and black woman is surprising and gutsy. I think it may have an even greater appeal to an American audience because the stakes of the racial conflict are greater here than they are in France.''
But if the film speaks to American audiences in its French version, why do it again in English? ''The American market is closed to foreign movies,'' Ms. Serreau says in reply. ''It is absolutely closed. If you have a big hit here of a foreign movie, you'll have about 7 percent of the audience. That's the best you can ever hope for.''
Ms. Serreau sees another reason for remaking a French film. ''I like the idea of redoing something,'' she says, ''because I have the opportunity to improve it. In theater, people do that all the time. You can direct a play three, four, five, six times in your life.''
Ms. Serreau was originally scheduled to direct the American version of ''Three Men and a Baby'' as well, but she became ill and had to return to France. Leonard Nimoy was enlisted to direct, and he brought in American writers to make changes in Ms. Serreau's script. ''I'm not a movie critic,'' Ms. Serreau says with a laugh when asked her opinion of Mr. Nimoy's movie.
Her contract for the American remake of ''Mama'' stipulates that she cannot be replaced, and Mr. Mestres says he is confident that Ms. Serreau can oversee an expensive American movie. ''Coline is an extremely visual film maker,'' he declares. ''She does not rely as much on words as many American movie makers.'' Ms. Serreau acknowledges that she needs help in writing idiomatic American dialogue, but she thinks that good actors can help her with the lines. Otherwise she feels quite capable of taking charge of an American film.
But she has had to adjust her methods of working to the American studio system, which frequently can be intrusive. ''In France,'' she says, ''the director decides everything. Whatever you say, that's the way it's going to be. If you make a mistake, it's your mistake. Here in Hollywood everything is discussed between many people. All of these discussions are very exhausting and sometimes very productive. The executives at Disney have a lot of suggestions. Some of their suggestions are good and some are bad. If they have a bad idea, I tell them, and then we try to convince each other.''
Ms. Serreau, who is in her late 30's, notes that Hollywood's obsession with commercial success is not so pronounced in France. But she has always been aware of the need to connect with an audience, and this may grow out of her background. Her parents were both show business people; her father, Jean-Marie, had a theater company in Paris and her mother, Genevieve, was a novelist and playwright. Growing up, Ms. Serreau knew Beckett, Ionesco and Brecht. ''Around our house,'' she recalls, ''were always actors, writers, producers, set decorators, everyone without one dollar. All I had ever heard when I was a kid was talk about writing, directing, actors, lights, sets. I knew nothing else.''
Soon she began acting, and she thinks that her performing experience was invaluable. ''Acting shows you how things work in front of an audience,'' Ms. Serreau says. ''Where can you learn that except on stage?''
Ms. Serreau's first films as director received little exposure outside France. With the release of ''Three Men and a Cradle,'' she suddenly found herself not only in demand but also very wealthy for the first time in her life. ''Sure it's made a difference in my life,'' she says with a shrug, ''but I don't know how. I still dress the same way because I hate shopping. As a film maker it's so important to watch and learn from the world around you, and that means staying in touch with ordinary people. That's the source for everything we do.''

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
At Last, Small Stocks May Be Ready to Party

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
As Wall Street kept its cool and Tokyo's market fought one rumor-driven panic after another, the United States last week added a few percentage points to its thin lead in the worldwide game of stock-market supremacy.
The Dow Jones industrial average stumbled slightly on Tokyo rumors early in the week, but steadied itself and closed the week at 2717.12, up about 10 points from the week before. The Nikkei 225 zigzagged through a tumultuous week to close at 29,278.78, down 701.67 points since the previous Friday. 
The result was that United States market capitalization - the estimated value of all its publicly traded shares - is now 4.4 percent larger than the Tokyo market's value, according to Morgan Stanley Capital International.
Does that matter? Yes, a little, said Mark Sladkus, a principal at Morgan Stanley. ''It is an interesting measure of the strength of the two countries,'' Mr. Sladkus said. ''And those who invest strictly on a passive basis are likely to contribute more, on a percentage basis, to the larger market.''
Of potentially more importance to American investors is a market-capitalization issue closer to home. Ever since the bull market began in 1982, the small-capitalization stocks in the United States have lagged behind the blue chips by almost every measure - stock price, earnings, you name it. But some analysts think they see signs of a turnaround.
Mutual funds specializing in smaller companies did better than most other fund categories in recent months. And Claudia Mott, an analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities, pointed out last week that the Russell 2000 index, a good proxy for her ''small-cap'' universe, outperformed the Standard & Poor 500 in both Februrary and March. That suggests to her that small-cap stocks are poised for a comeback.
Binkley Shorts, the manager of the Over-the-Counter Securities Fund, said that market psychology, not economic fundamentals, is the major influence on how small stocks perform. ''Small stocks seem to come in and out of favor like a pendulum,'' he said. They've been out of favor so long, he added, that they're bound to rebound sooner or later.
Is now a good time? Ms. Mott thinks so. With the market worried about earnings and debt, her research shows that small-cap companies may compare favorably with the blue chips on both counts in the months ahead. ''The leveraging of corporate America appears to be more of a large-cap story than a small-cap one,'' she noted. ''And small-cap profits have been better than large-cap profits for two quarters running.''
By now, small-cap investors are understandably skeptical of anyone who promises that their bull market is just over the next ridge. But this time, that pounding they hear might actually be hoofbeats - unless, of course, it is just a bunch of tipsy traders at some Wall Street bar watching the late market reports from Tokyo, stomping their feet and chanting ''We're No. 1. We're No. 1.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
UAL: The Employees Have It
The UAL Corporation has found a way to win concessions from its unions: Sell them the company. The airline announced on Friday an estimated $4.38 billion deal with its machinists, pilots and flight attendants. For each UAL share, the unions would put up $155 in cash, a bond with a face value of $35 and a stake in the company's computer reservation subsidiary - about $201 a share altogether. But will the banks that refused to finance a $6.8 billion deal last October back the lower offer? Analysts say the unions will have their work cut out for them. ''If interest rates are going up and the economy is chilling out, then nothing gets done,'' said Kevin Murphy, an analyst at Morgan Stanley. Reflecting Wall Street's pessimism, UAL closed at $163 1/2 on Friday, down $2.
 
 
Shearson Sinks, Salomon Soars
 
Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. said on Monday that it will suffer a first-quarter loss as deep as $917 million, a Wall Street record. About $630 million covers the cost of reorganizing the firm, which is retreating from several businesses as furiously as it entered them a few years ago. ''We were trying too much to be all things to all people in the 1980's,'' Howard Clark Jr., Shearson's new chairman and chief executive, said. ''The 1990's are going to be more focused.'' 
 
*
 
Salomon Brothers, on the other hand, is showing a new flair for making money. The firm said on Thursday that it had earned at least $200 million during the first quarter, far more than analysts had expected. Tokyo's woe became Salomon's win, as the company profited from issuing securities that allowed investors to bet that the Japanese market would tumble. Good bet.
 
 
Bonwit in Bankruptcy
 
The woman on the phone at Bonwit Teller in Manhattan's Trump Tower sounded downcast. ''We're closed, sir,'' she said Thursday afternoon. ''We're going out of business.'' And so, under arrangements announced in bankruptcy court the day before, the high-fashion Bonwit Teller department stores are being liquidated. Its Australian parent company, the Hooker Corporation, had already shut its B. Altman chain. The Manhattan Bonwit Teller planned to reopen to sell off its stock. New York, and several other cities, might continue to have Bonwit Teller stores, though possibly at different locations. The Pyramid Companies, a Syracuse, N.Y., mall developer, bought the Bonwit name, with the aim of opening a new flagship store on Fifth Avenue.
 
 
The Time Warner Factoid
 
Early in this century, Tristan Tzara composed a poem by randomly pulling words from a hat. In 1990, Time Warner Inc. seems to have done about the same to compose an annual report. Fragments of text - ''factoids,'' the designers call them - run in arcs and circles, sideways and upside down, in Day-Glo colors and bizarre collages. The company's aim was to stress that Time Warner is much more than the sum of the corporate parts that merged to form the world's largest media company last year. ''One of our goals was to make the report a reflection of the creativity that is a key to our business,'' said a company executive. Imagine what Wolcott Gibbs, that deft parodist, would say if he could update his essay on the company: ''Sideward ran factoids until reeled the mind.''
 
 
Insurers at Sea
 
Finding the billion-dollar treasure took $10 million and three frustrating years. Now the salvagers of the 132-year-old wreck of the S.S. Central America off the Carolinas have to chase away the insurers. Lawyers for about a dozen insurance companies crowded a Norfolk, Va., courtroom on Tuesday to say that their clients, or the companies' predecessors, had paid off claims on the wreck, back before the Civil War. Now, the lawyers said, the companies have a right to some gold.
 
 
G.M.'s Nuts and Bolts Chief
 
The General Motors Corporation must hope that Robert C. Stempel, the next chairman and chief executive, proves more popular than Roger B. Smith, whom he will succeed this August. Mr. Smith and his many plant closings were the target of ''Roger and Me,'' a bitter documentary released last year. Analysts praised Mr. Stempel's promotion, announced on Tuesday, as a sign that the company was ready to concentrate on quality and production. Mr. Smith was the latest in a line of chief executives from the financial side; Mr. Stempel is an engineer. ''What everyone's looking for,'' said Harvey Heimbach, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, ''is whether the person who's running an auto company has gasoline in his blood. To the extent that he's excited about products, this is a positive for G.M.''
 
 
In Brief
 
The Lotus Development Corporation, whose personal computer spreadsheets dominate the market, announced on Friday that it would acquire Novell Inc., a maker of network software, for $1.4 billion worth of Lotus stock.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Wandering Waterford?
 
Somehow, Waterford Czechoslovakian crystal doesn't sound as appealing as the products from Ireland. But Waterford Wedgewood P.L.C. management is threatening to move the crystal operations to Eastern Europe unless the Irish workers help to cut costs. The company stopped bonus payments for 500 workers on Thursday, and all 2,300 at Waterford's three plants reacted by going on their first full strike. Waterford's attempts to apply modern industrial management to the traditional crystal-making craft have backfired, with losses mounting and sales to the United States slumping. The company's managers say Eastern Europe could provide cheaper labor. ''Investors, in my view, are not too concerned where the glass is manufactured as long as they get a dividend from their investment,'' an executive said.
 
 
Japan and the Trade Issue
 
The United States emerges as the friend of the oppressed Japanese consumer in a broad trade agreemeent reached on Thursday. The Japanese agreed to lower restrictions on large new stores, help make more land available for homes and businesses, stiffen antitrust penalties, increase public spending on housing and roads and ease imports, especially of items like communications equipment and satellites. Japanese officials warned that entrenched interest groups - businesses large and small - would fight to block these measures in the Japanese Parliament.
 
*
 
Immediate improvement in the trade deficit with Japan is unlikely, longer-term improvement in doubt, American economists say. ''We're talking about things that are supposed to go into effect over a very long time,'' said Kevin Logan, who follows trade matters as chief economist at the Swiss Bank Corporation. ''I don't think they're going to open Toys 'R' Us stores in 15 cities next year.'' So far, the toy chain has been unable to open any outlets there. But Mr. Logan said that Japanese consumers might rally behind the trade agreement. ''They're waking up to what's going on in the world,'' he said. ''They're getting shortchanged.''
 
 
 
ECONOMY
 
S.&L.'s Get Their Man
 
It cost $89,000 a year to hire him, $29 million a day not to. The Senate decided on Wednesday that confirming T. Timothy Ryan Jr., 62-to-37, as the nation's top savings and loan regulator was the better option. Senators who doubted that Mr. Ryan's experience as a labor lawyer qualified him to supervise the savings and loan bailout had predicted that his nomination would fail. Then came Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady to remind them that a court battle had brought the bailout process to a halt (costing taxpayers at least $29 million a day) until the Senate could confirm a new Office of Thrift Supervision director. As the Labor Department's solicitor in the early 1980's, Mr. Ryan cleaned up the Teamsters' Central States Pension Fund. Maybe he's ready to attack a much bigger mess - one that, according to the General Accounting Office on Friday, will cost at least $325 billion.
 
 
Pollution: Who's to Pay?
 
In Washington, pollution-control cost and benefit estimates are floating as thick as the smog in Los Angeles. The Senate passed clean-air legislation on Tuesday that, the Administration says, would add at least $20 billion annually to the $33 billion cost of meeting current pollution laws. Businesses say that the costs could go much higher, and that consumers will pay. Environmentalists say that stronger standards, especially for fuel economy in automobiles, would yield benefits far greater than the costs. Next: The House of Representatives, expected to be tougher on polluters, takes up the bill.
 
 
Reading the Indicators. . .
 
News last week that the Government's index of leading economic indicators fell 1 percent in February caused economists to say that industry is weak but not staggering. Without a record 25 percent drop in building permits, after a sharp gain during a warm January, the index would have dropped just two-tenths of 1 percent, they said.
 
 
. . .And the Jobless Rate
 
Friday's unemployment figures are likely to persuade the Federal Reserve Board to stay its course. Unemployment declined to 5.2 percent in March after nine months at 5.3 percent. But the nation added only 26,000 jobs, the lowest gain in four years. The message is that the Fed is avoiding either a recession or higher inflation, said Neal M. Soss, chief economist at First Boston. ''The current policy stance is the correct one,'' he said.
 
 
Boesky's Back Out
 
Ivan Boesky is free, but he is going to help the Government try to send others to prison. Mr. Boesky signed himself out from a halfway house in Brooklyn on Wednesday. He began a three-year prison term for securities fraud in 1988, winning a parole for good behavior. Boesky is barred for life from acting as an investment advisor in the United States. But he will be heard from some more if the Government's case against Michael R. Milken, once the star financier at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., goes to trial.

HEADLINE: Currency;
April in Paris for the Yen

 BODY:
The weak yen gained a little ground last week as traders waited for the results of the Saturday meeting in Paris of the finance ministers from the United States and its economic allies in the Group of Seven. The dollar was little changed against other major currencies. The impact of the meeting - the group's other members are Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada - will be tested as foreign exchange markets open today in New Zealand (in the early afternoon hours, New York time) and then in Tokyo. The yen is likely to fall further without some statement of support and central bank intervention. Meanwhile, the mark could be buffeted this week if the dispute continues over what exchange rate to use in merging the economies of the two Germanys.

HEADLINE: All About/Hotel Marketing;
After a Decade of Growth, Far Too Much Room at the Inn

BYLINE: By PHILIP S. GUTIS

 BODY:
With development costs rising, buildings aging and the room glut worsening, the troubled hotel industry has hit on a new set of responses: ''It's gotten gimmicky,'' said Darryl Hartley-Leonard, president of the Hyatt Hotels Corporation. ''Suites, frequent-traveler programs, discounting, free food, free breakfast, free liquor.''
After a decade of fast growth and large profits, the $57.1 billion American hotel industry is likely to need every gimmick at its disposal to prosper during the next five years. Industry executives are predicting a shakeout, with ownership and management changes becoming more likely. Analysts say that some companies are too highly leveraged to survive an extended downturn.
The statistics are already discouraging. Average occupancy rates for the major full-service hotel chains have dropped to about 63 percent, below the 65-to-68 percent range that was the average in the 1980's. To remain profitable, hotels generally need to fill 70 percent of their rooms - a level they haven't reached since 1979. Even resorts, an especially profitable category for many chains, appear to be in excess supply. 
Hotels were generally profitable during the 1980's only because of real estate tax incentives that were eliminated late in the decade. Analysts have estimated that as much as 65 percent of the 774,000 hotel rooms added in the 80's were built to create losses that could be deducted from investors' income.
And yet, Mr. Hartley-Leonard said, the hotel industry hasn't overcome a serious case of ''blind optimism'': ''The headlines scream of more units, new product lines and the creation of new hotel chains within hotel chains every day,'' he said.
During the last few years, hotel companies tried to sidestep the crowded middle market by adding rooms in the economy or luxury classes. Now, these ends of the market are becoming overbuilt too. Budget and luxury accommodations each account for 18 percent of the nation's hotels, with the remaining 64 percent falling in between the two categories.
Some companies are trying to save on labor by turning more tasks over to computers. Others are trying to slice the market finer, developing new niches, like hotels for nonsmokers and all-suite hotels. ''The industry is trying to provide a hotel room for every price and every pocketbook,'' said Melinda Bush, the publisher of the Hotel & Travel Index, an industry publication.

 
No-Frills Gospel
 
Middle-Market Chains Convert to Economy
The economy hotel market may be crowded, but the middle market remains much worse. So some leading middle-market hotel chains are scaling down as fast as they can, stripping frills and slashing room rates in older properties.
The demand for economy lodging grew during the 80's as business travel costs rose 94 percent, according to the Runzheimer International Business Travel Price Index. Corporate travel planners often ordered employers to use cheaper hotels. Several major chains reached down to build budget properties that promise clean hotel rooms with little more in amenities than a telephone and a television. The Marriott Corporation started the Fairfield Inns chain and Ramada Inc. introduced Rodeway Inns.
Analysts say that the 90's are likely to be a time of conversion instead of construction. ''There is a tremendous amount of conversion activity going on,'' said Daniel W. Daniele, a general partner at Laventhol & Horwath, the accounting and consulting firm. ''New developments of budget hotels have slowed to a snail's pace as a result of lenders already having too much in their portfolios.''
Last year, 42 percent of the 91,300 new economy-class rooms came from conversions of either full-service or independent hotels (those not part of a chain) that could no longer survive, Laventhol & Horwath reported. At Ramada's Rodeway Inns, a budget chain of 150 hotels, all but three of the 27 new properties added last year represented conversions rather than new construction.
 
 
Wall-to-Wall Paradises
 
Resorts Still Court the Business Traveler
 A veritable Shangri-La can be difficult to market when its beaches, palm trees and dolphin-filled pool are no different from the Shangri-La's down the street. Even in Hawaii, analysts say, the resorts will have to begin chopping rates to fill rooms - though hotel managers there say they aren't lowering rates yet.
Several luxury chains - including Four Seasons Hotels Inc. and Ritz-Carlton - built resorts during the 1980's so that business travelers who stayed at their downtown urban properties could rely on them for vacation havens as well. For Four Seasons, which is opening six resorts over the next four years, resort development is ''a line extension - another brand within the family,'' said Mr. Richards. ''We needed to grow our business and capture more of our customers' time.''
Analysts and hotel executives said more resorts will be built, even though occupancy in 1988 dropped 4 percent and average room rates 3 percent. Resorts used to hosting conventions and week-long stays are now going after harried professionals who can only take three- or four-day weekends. ''It is harder for many couples to get away as regularly as they used to,'' said Gary B. Hedges, the national director for resort real estate with Laventhol & Horwath. ''Couples deciding to get away for a long weekend often automatically go to a resort.''
 
Labor Shortages
 
Accentuating The Automated
 Guests who might never mind eating bread from an automated bakery or driving a car from an automated plant find their tolerance for labor-saving technology ends at check-out time. Hotels trying to cut costs discover that most guests prefer settling bills in person to viewing them on televisions or paying by phone. ''Much of the new technology had lost the personal touch, and that was bad for business,'' said Larry Chervenak, president of the Chervenak, Keane and Company hotel consultants.
Hotel managers have strong motives for relying more and more on computers and machines. The profusion of hotels has aggravated a labor shortage and raised costs.
So far, hotel guests seem most comfortable with the computers they can't see: equipment that keeps inventories and other business records and prepares reports. New front-desk systems call up a guest's records with one pass of a credit card. Some luxury hotels, like the Four Seasons, keep guest preferences on computer, so a room can be supplied with, say, nonfeather pillows before a guest even has to ask. And like the airlines, the hotels are using computers to refine the art of ''yield management,'' determining when to discount and when to hold the line to fill the most rooms at the highest rates.
Hotel executives say that letting computers do more of the work can actually make service more personal. Robert M. Foster, the general manager of the huge Sheraton New Orleans Hotel, resorts to theatrical terms to describe his aim of leaving his aides with time to help the staff (his ''cast'') improve service.
''What we have found,'' Mr. Foster said, ''is that the better the technology is - especially for the core of middle-management people - the more time they have to be out with cast members to improve the moment of truth.'' Mr. Foster has found some simpler ways to unburden his managers. For several months, he encouraged them to shoot unneeded internal reports back to those who sent them.
 
 
 
WANTED: THE WEALTHY
Whil economy hotels slash amenities, luxury hotels are seeking new ways to heap services onto their wealthy guests. The latest gadget offered is the fax machine, so executives can send confidential documents without going through the front desk.
Four Seasons Hotels Inc. is going to even further lengths to pamper its most frequent guests, treating them as if they truly lived at the hotels full-time. The chain has introduced an embellished frequent-stayer plan called Private Reserve. Those who have stayed at least 42 nights in a year can use hotel concierge services even when they are not staying at the hotels.
John B. Richards, the chain's senior vice president of marketing, is quick to point out the program's advantages. ''Let's say, for example, that you are a D.C. lawyer with a client in Seattle and you want to acknowledge the client in some way,'' he said. ''You could just call the hotel in Seattle, and they will send a gift for you.'' Four Seasons says that executives of 4,500 companies are eligible for the program.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Modest Luster for High Tech

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
Investing in high technology paid off for mutual fund investors last quarter. The 23 science and technology funds returned an average of 2.7 percent, while all other stock fund categories combined lost 2.8 percent, according to Lipper Analytical Services, which tracks mutual funds. In fact, the science and technology funds were the only ones in the 26 major groups tracked by Lipper - beside the European regional funds - that made money in the quarter.
This performance represents a turnaround for the funds, which, investing mainly in computer and telecommunications stocks, lagged all stock funds in 1989 by about two percentage points. The group took a particular beating during last year's fourth quarter, dropping 1.3 percent against a 0.1 percent rise in stock funds. 
Fund managers say several factors are driving the high-tech rebound.
Overall, the stocks have underperformed the market for seven years. But at some point, some analysts believe, the market flip-flops and the group becomes undervalued enough to become a good buy.
The managers also point to the changing nature of technology. The year began with expectations of an economic slowdown, and high-tech companies - many of them producing big-ticket items like mainframe computers - have been sensitive to downturns. But the evolving computer industry now sells a broader range of products, many at lower prices, so demand remained strong.
''You don't need the board of directors to approve a purchase of 10 personal computers,'' said Larry Bowman, portfolio manager of Fidelity's Select Computers Portfolio.
New corporate attitudes, emphasizing faster, cheaper ways to send and receive data, mean that more corporate decision makers are using desktop computers to manage the growing flow of information, and companies are investing heavily in computers and communications networks.
Then there were revises in earnings forecasts early in the year, with estimates of earnings gains for the personal computer market repegged at 10 percent to 12 percent, still only half of last year's 25 percent-plus gains, but better than originally expected. ''The entire sector began to pick up steam, led by personal computers and new software,'' said Jack Geraghty, a vice president with the First Boston Corporation.
Harris Leviton, who manages the past quarter's top performer, the $33 million Fidelity Select Portfolios Electronics, is betting heavily on companies that distribute electronic components. The industry has undergone painful restructuring over the past two years and consolidation has improved company margins, he said. Two favorites: Long Island-based Avnet, the leader in the field, and Pioneer Standard Electronics, in Cleveland, Ohio, a distributor with a strong foothold in the Middle West. Mr. Leviton also likes Applied Materials Inc., based in Santa Clara, Calif., the nation's leading manufacturer of capital equipment for the semiconductor industry.
The largest holding of the $30 million Fidelity Select Computers is Sun Microsystems Inc. of Mountainview, Calif. Sun manufactures work stations, powerful computers used by engineers, scientists and others who need a lot of individual computer power. Mr. Bowman, the fund's manager, says Sun's revenues are growing 30 percent a year, although management is still grappling with growing pains.
Another favorite: the Compaq Computer Corporation, based in Houston, a leading maker of personal computers. The stock trades at less than 11 times earnings, versus the 14 or 15 that Mr. Bowman says would more fairly reflect the company's potential.
Daniel Leonard, manager of the $35 million Financial Strategic Portfolios-Technology Fund, based in Denver, thinks computer software is the market niche with the biggest growth potential. He likes General Motors Class E, the stock of a Dallas-based computer services company bought by G.M. about six years ago. The company custom-designs software, a service Mr. Leonard expects more and more executives to snap up.
A favorite holding of Richard A. Spillane, who manages the $95 million Fidelity Select Technology Fund, is the Policy Management Systems Corporation, a Columbia, S.C., software company that services insurance companies. Mr. Spillane says management has repositioned the company from software products, which have widely variable earnings, to computer services where earnings are steady and growing.
At the $150 million Alliance Technology Fund, which didn't make the top five, the biggest holding is is Autodesk Inc., of Sausalito, Calif., a leading supplier of computer-aided design, or CAD, software. Roger W. Honour, the fund's manager, also favors the Weitek Corporation, a Sunnyvale, Calif., manufacturer of math co-processors, computer chips that can be installed inside personal computers to speed up laborious mathematical calculations.
But despite the first-quarter performance, analysts are uncertain about how the science and technology funds will fare during the rest of the year. Mr. Geraghty says most stocks will probably do well through Memorial Day and maybe June, ''but the rest of the year is a question mark.''
 
 
 
MONEY FUNDS: PLAYING MATURITIES
Many people think money market funds are all alike, but that's not true. The average fund's portfolio matures in 31 to 40 days. Some fund managers do not go out longer than 10 days; others stretch maturities beyond 70 days.
The longer the maturity, of course, the less flexibility a fund has to keep up with changing interest rates. So when rates rose in January and February, managers of the longer-term money funds were locked into lower rates. Knowing the maturities of a portfolio helps investors bet on where rates are headed. If you don't want to do that, stick with funds whose maturities stay close to the average.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
The Interest-Rate Forecast Is Wrong

BYLINE: By MADIS SENNER; Madis Senner is president of SunRay Securities Inc., an international money management firm, and author of ''Japanese Euroderivatives.''

 BODY:
A number of economists are now betting that interest rates will come down. They cite the weakening of the domestic economy and the possibility of a recession later in the year. But companies and investors that heed this advice are in for a shock. The 1990's will see global interest rates climb for reasons that most economists have ignored.
During the 1980's, as inflation abated, aggressive overseas financial investment by capital-surplus countries, like Japan, prevented capital from becoming scarce - and expensive - holding interest rates down. During the 1980's, the Japanese bought almost 15 percent of Canadian Government bond issues and between 25 and 40 percent of new United States Treasury bonds. 
But with the 28 percent drop in Tokyo's Nekkei 225 stock index since last December, the end has come for cheap capital exports from Japan. Other capital-surplus countries, like West Germany, will also be constrained in their capital exports, but for other reasons.
One immediate consequence of the fall in the Tokyo stock market has been the one-month moratorium recently imposed on the issuance of new equity derivatives by Japanese corporations. These instruments are powerful tools that Japanese companies used to raise capital for their overseas investments.
Equity derivatives are financial instruments - like bonds - that companies can issue to raise money. But what made them attractive was that they are convertible, at the purchaser's request, into common stock. This allowed bond investors to participate in the rise of share prices on the Japanese stock market. In 1988 and 1989, Japanese companies raised a total of 20 trillion yen - about $180 billion - using these instruments.
During the 1980's, the use of equity derivative instruments by Japanese companies coincided with an increase in the purchase of foreign securities by Japanese investment institutions. Throughout the 1980's, otherwise conservative Japanese companies grew adept at using these new financial instruments to participate in investment opportunities abroad. In the 1980's, it was not uncommon for Japanese manufacturers to earn 20 percent - or more - of their profits from financial investments.
Another reason why those predicting lower interest rates are wrong concerns the east-bloc countries. They will be competing for a greater share of the world's supply of capital - especially West Germany's. The economies of the East bloc, excluding the Soviet Union, have an aggregate gross national product of about $750 billion. These countries could absorb about 10 percent of that amount in foreign capital investment. This would put further pressure on the world's supply of investment funds.
A final reason rates will not come down is that most major governmentsare planning to issue more bonds over the next few years, which will add to demand. To compete for capital, they will have to increase the interest rates they offer.
In West Germany, estimates are that the Government will issue 30 to 60 billion marks - $17 billion to $35 billion - in German bonds in the next few years to pay for reunification. The Japanese Government has agreed to the American proposal to increase its public works expenditures, and will do so by issuing new bonds. In the United States, the estimates are that it will take from $100 billion to $200 billion in new bond issues by the Resolution Trust Corporation to complete the bailout of the savings and loan industry.
The disinflation that drove down interest rates in the 1980's has been replaced by a new phenomenon: less capital available from Japan and the other surplus countries, and increasing demand. Because of this, interest rates will rise around the world during the early 1990's. But even if a recession should come, it will only dampen the rise in interest rates; it will not alter the upward direction.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Trading Away the Trade Deficit

BYLINE: By WILLARD C. BUTCHER; Willard C. Butcher is chairman and chief executive of the Chase Manhattan Corporation.

 BODY:
Last month's announcement by the Commerce Department that the trade deficit narrowed to $113 billion for 1989 sparked a sense of euphoria. It is true that the deficit was 11 percent less than the $127 billion recorded in 1988, but even with this modest improvement, the current account deficit is still running in excess of $100 billion. Since 1980, the United States has run up a cumulative trade deficit of more than $850 billion, with almost 80 percent of it from the last five years. Add this year's deficit, and that figure could reach $1 trillion. What must we do? There is an approach I call the United States trade certificate program. It would directly link the value of goods exported from the United States to the value of goods imported. 
Anyone in any other country who imported American-made goods would receive a trade certificate with a face value corresponding to the value of the purchased goods. Anyone shipping foreign-made goods to the United States would be required to supply trade certificates equal to the value of those goods.
Trade certificates could be used at any time to ship any goods to the United States from any country. They would neither favor, nor discriminate against any industry, shipper, product or country. They would not protect our markets. In fact, they would end up promoting trade, since the more goods that are shipped from the United States, the more that could be shipped to the United States.
Because the certificates would be so valuable to those who export to the United States, it is likely that an active trading market would develop. Although the certificates would carry a fixed dollar amount, the market would fluctuate freely. Through a highly liquid global market, those who wish to sell to the United States would buy certificates from those overseas who had purchased American goods.
Such a multilateral program would hold the added benefit of eliminating the need for existing protectionist measures. If any country wished both to keep its markets closed to United States exports and to continue selling to it, its exporters would be perfectly free to do so. They would simply go to a third country with surplus certificates.
If in due course, with improved economic fundamentals, a suitable trade balance could be maintained, there would no longer be a market for trade certificates. They would become valueless and self-destruct. But until that time, such a program makes irrefutable sense. It is not, however, an economic cure-all. We do need to work hard to reduce the budget deficit, boost the rate of savings and investment, improve educational standards, recapture our lead in technology and further improve product quality. But our ability to achieve those vital national objectives is severely handicapped while we continue to incur huge trade deficits.
The time has come to stop dealing in empty pledges, idle hopes and unrealistic dreams. We need decisive action that provides, not promises, a real trade improvement.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
A Paradoxical Anti-Takeover Bill

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
How should investors in Pennsylvania's public companies react to the anti-takeover bill that is about to be signed into law in the Keystone State?
''The same way you'd react to a rattlesnake curled up on your pillow,'' said Ronald Gilson, a professor at the Stanford Law School and an outspoken critic of the proposed legislation, which is intended to curb hostile acquisitions. The law would severely restrict the shareholder's ability to initiate proxy contests.
Roland Machold, the director of the New Jersey State Investment Division, who manages the state's huge public-employee pension funds, is less pointed but equally unenthusiastic. ''I can't see myself buying the stock of any Pennsylvania company coming to market now,'' Mr. Machold said. ''All that company could sell would be a sort of 'zero-coupon, non-maturing, junior subordinated something-or-other.' But it wouldn't be a common stock with accountability to shareholders.'' 
The fundamental paradox of the Pennsylvania proposal is that it is being sponsored in the name of protecting jobs and long-term economic growth, but it is likely to hit hardest at exactly those companies that contribute such an important share of any region's jobs and economic growth: young companies that need new equity capital to grow.
The provenance of the legislation is the Belzberg family's protracted raid on Armstrong World Industries, a home-products company based in Lancaster, Pa. Although some Wall Street firms have already told their clients that the Belzbergs are running out of steam, state legislators are undeterred.
They have approved, and Gov. Robert P. Casey has said he will sign, a bill that restricts the voting rights of any group or investor who buys 20 percent or more of a company's stock; the bill also allows for the seizure of all profits made by short-term investors who sell their stock within 18 months of an unsuccessful hostile-takeover bid. And it assures labor contracts and severance pay to employees in the unlikely event that a takeover occurs in spite of the bill's other provisions.
Defenders of the measure say they are simply making into law what is a simple fact of life: that shareholders are not the only people with a stake in what a public company does. Workers and communities and suppliers - and, of course, managers - have an interest as well. And, in the future, raiders like the Belzbergs will ignore those interests at their peril, at least in Pennsylvania.
Some of the bill's critics see it as the financial equivalent of the Maginot line, a defense against the strategies of the earlier war against ''junk-bonded'' raiders, which will be worse than useless in the current battle for new jobs and global market share. Richard Breeden, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has waded into the fight, condemning the bill as a measure that would disenfranchise shareholders and leave incompetent managers ''free to run a company into the ground.''
But unless Mr. Breeden is willing to put the S.E.C.'s muscle where his mouth is, the measure is likely to affect investors in a host of companies.
Which ones? There are the frequently cited giants: Allegheny International, Consolidated Rail, H. J. Heinz, Mellon Bank, PPG Industries, Scott Paper, the Sun Company and Westinghouse Electric, all listed on the New York Stock Exchange.
There are some lesser-known exchange-listed stocks, too, including Dravo, Equitable Resources, Hunt Manufacturing, Quaker Chemical, Publicker Industries, Tasty Banking, UGI, Weis Markets and Zurn Industries.
But only 22 percent of the companies incorporated in Pennsylvania are grand enough to qualify for the New York Stock Exchange or the American Stock Exchange. The rest trade over the counter. Some are tiny companies whose highly speculative shares trade for a few pennies apiece. But others are enterprises of much more substance.
The latter group includes the mighty Corestates Financial Corporation, the parent of both Philadelphia National Bank and First Pennsylvania Bank, and a host of smaller regional bank holding companies, such as Susquehanna Bancshares, the Bryn Mawr Bank Corporation and the York Financial Corporation. Also on the roster is the C-TEC Corporation, a burgeoning independent telephone company that is frequently the subject of takeover speculation, and such retailers as the Deb Shops, Charming Shoppes and Strawbridge & Clothier.
Some studies show that the adoption of anti-takeover legislation can drag down such share prices by as much as 4 percent; others say the damage is fleeting, a one-time drop that evaporates quickly. However, Professor Gilson of Stanford points out that none of these earlier studies involved a law quite as sweeping as Pennsylvania's.
Several major institutional players, including Fidelity Investments and several large pension fund managers, have said that they will be wary of investing in companies based in Pennsylvania if the bill becomes law. ''This won't be instantaneous,'' said Mr. Gilson, ''because it takes time for institutions to decide to sell. But watch the volume; that's where it will show up first - with an increase in volume for Pennsylvania companies.''
Mr. Machold of New Jersey, however, notes that the new law would fall heaviest on smaller companies trying to raise fresh capital. ''It is those companies who need to raise money in the marketplace who will be hurt the most,'' he said.
As for the future, critics of the bill note that there is only one other standard organizational model that comes close to offering incumbent directors the protections they will have under this bill, protections that make it impossible to replace them without their consent. That model, said Mr. Gilson, is the nonprofit corporation.
