HEADLINE: Searching for the Survivors in Tokyo World Markets

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
In the rubble of the Tokyo stock market - now down 24.8 percent for the year - there are stocks that are doing well. They resisted the downturn and some of them, especially electronics stocks, are now recommended by analysts in Tokyo and elsewhere as the way to beat an otherwise miserable market.
In addition, the wave of selling has brought some other stocks far enough down in price to make them attractive again.
The survivors include the favorites of speculators, like Meiji Shipping, which is rising although its price is at almost 1,000 times earnings; the good small companies, like Konami Industry, which makes arcade-game software, and Keiyo, a do-it-yourself home-improvement store, and those companies riding on renewed demand, like Shimano Industrial, the bicycle-parts maker. 
But the list also includes many household names - like Sony, Nintendo, Canon, Hitachi, Panasonic, Pioneer and NEC - that have been lifted by the rush to healthy electronics and communications companies with good export prospects.
NEC, which makes communications equipment and personal computers, is up 20 percent this year. Hitachi, which has introduced a new mainframe computer, is up 15 percent; Pioneer, the radio and television manufacturer, is up 11 percent. But outdoing them all is Kyocera, which is up more than 44 percent, partly on the profit potential from its 25.5-percent holding in D.D.I., the chief challenger to Japan's telephone company, N.T.T. The others, including Sony, Canon and Panasonic, the American arm of Matsushita, are down only slightly, and renewed investor interest should push them back up very soon.
''It just goes to show that there is someplace to hide,'' said David Warren, executive vice president of Rowe Price Fleming in London, which manages a fund that has just started buying the electronics stocks.
One reason these stocks survived is that they were generally unpopular for several years, ignored in the wave of buying that left the Tokyo market at a record high on the last trading day of 1989. In that frenzy, which sent some companies to price-earnings ratios as high as 200, the most popular companies, from real estate to railroads, owned land, especially in Tokyo, that was rising in value at phenomenal rates. Financial companies, which were buoyed by the low interest rates in Japan, also were in on the ride up.
While the Nikkei 225 stock index rose 236.7 percent from 1985 to the end of 1989, Canon was up 49 percent and Hitachi 78.8 percent. Kyocera was down almost 17 percent. Sony and Pioneer did rise more than 150 percent - still well below the Nikkei.
But now this asset-focused buying binge is over. Interest rates are at their highest levels in years and the Bank of Japan is doing all it can to halt the boom in land prices. All these factors make electronics companies, including makers of microchips, attractive again. The have good, consistent earnings potential; many of them have price-earnings ratios in the 20's and 30's, below current averages in the 40's and 50's. And the weakness of the yen means that these export-oriented companies will be very competitive abroad, adding to their earnings outlook. ''Investors will pay more attention to technology than assets,'' said Yuichi Kohashi, executive vice president of Daiwa Securities America Inc.
The relative unpopularity of these stocks in the past helps in another way, said Yoshiro Katsuya, senior vice president at the Nikko Securities Company International in New York. Because they are not a major factor in portfolios of insurance companies or trust funds and were not bought in large amounts by individuals on margin, there will be little downward pressure on them even if the Tokyo market, which bounced back with a 1,029.72 point rise Friday, declines further.
Other stocks did not weather the downturn but look attractive now because their sharp decline - by as much as 60 percent - has transformed them from overpriced to fairly priced. Their price-to-cash-flow ratio is down to 20 or less, well below the market average of 35. Ron Napier of Salomon Brothers in London has identified 136 of these companies, including well-known names like Nippon Steel, Bridgestone and N.T.T.

HEADLINE: The Response From Philadelphia On Penny-Stock Questions

 BODY:
To the Editor:
We read with confusion and considerable dismay your article reproaching the Philadelphia Stock Exchange for its practice of listing emerging companies that trade at low prices (''The Latest Penny-Stock Shuffle,'' April 1). Rather than a brilliant unearthing of facts, the article reflects your point of view that listing such companies is dangerous and the Philadelphia Stock Exchange is derelict in doing so.
Curiously, none of these listings is now under investigation, a point that your story takes a long time to make and does so parenthetically. Further, these and all other primary listings together account for a tiny percentage of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange's volume. Which leaves us baffled as to why the story was so compelling and needed to be illustrated and packaged in such a histrionic way. 
There are obvious advantages to being listed on an exchange, among them a stronger standard of regulation. More than 50 companies began the process of listing on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange last year, not 20 as your story said. Among those, fewer than 1 in 5 were approved for listing and trading was subsequently halted in another instance when the exchange's own regulators identified failures to fulfill obligations in the listing agreement each company must sign.
The Philadelphia Stock Exchange is not a loophole for penny stocks to jump through, nor by any means the only exchange to list small companies with low prices. Here are a few facts. Of all primary issues traded on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange, 27 are priced at or below $2 per share, compared with 71 such issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange (12 of which have filed bankruptcy proceedings) and 102 similarly priced issues on the American Stock Exchange.
The Securities and Exchange Commission's concerns on the subject of penny stock rule circumvention are not news to the Philadelphia Stock Exchange. We share them. In the final analysis, boiler rooms and other unscrupulous sales tactics destroy public confidence in our market. For this reason, we began a review of our listing standards several months ago. However, these are guidelines that the exchange is fully within its rights to apply judiciously in the entrepreneurial interests of companies for which it believes there may be a promising future.
The Philadelphia Stock Exchange recognizes the important role these companies play in our economy. Our listing policy has given starts in public life to many successful companies which might otherwise have gone without recognition. Your concern about our reputation is especially curious. Your story, which unfairly characterizes the exchange's listing activities, does much greater harm to our reputation than the listing of a few small companies. In our 200 years as the nation's oldest exchange, we have learned a lesson that others apparently have yet to: only by putting its reputation on the line can an enterprise hope to grow.
 
NICHOLAS A. GIORDANO
President and Chief Executive
Philadelphia Stock Exchange, April 4

HEADLINE: THE STATE OF THE CHURCH;
Has Catholicism Lost A Chance to Be Our Moral Clearinghouse?

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS

 BODY:
NOT long ago, thinkers of various religious and political persuasions were hailing the coming of a ''Catholic moment,'' in which the church would help fill the moral vacuum left by the decline of mainline Protestantism and the rise of a secular liberalism that many Americans found arid and ineffectual.
Possessed of a sophisticated style of moral reasoning that is rooted in religion but philosophical enough to engage non-Catholics and perhaps even agnostics and atheists, the Catholic church, the religious home for one of every four Americans, seemed poised to make a unique contribution to the country's public life.
Today talk of the Catholic moment is fading; and with it, the hope that the church could bring its history of reasoned discussion to bear on a range of baffling issues that include nuclear deterrence, medical ethics and biotechnology.
For some the church's image has been badly damaged by the political hardball of the abortion debate. Serious moral reasoning on the beginning of life has been eclipsed by headlines about bishops banning Catholic politicians from the communion rail or warning them of eternal damnation. 
At the same time, the church is being shaken by internal problems. Men and women who have often been the mainstay of their parishes feel that, for all the discussion about the laity's participation in the life of the church, their deepest concerns and insights about marital sex, childrearing and other moral issues are still not being heard. In February, a liberal lay group opened a campaign for greater democracy in the church with an ad in The New York Times. Both conservatives and liberals seem to be registering their dissatisfaction by giving less generously in the collection plate.
 
Narrowing the Debate
Adding to the pressure is the fact that the Catholic leadership that will have to meet these challenges is growing steadily more cautious. Pressed by the Vatican and increasingly led by Pope John Paul II's chosen men, the American hierarchy has felt duty-bound in recent months to tighten the limits of debate, a strategy that is meant to rally the faithful but seems at least as likely to leave them resentful and rebellious.
American Catholicism is not in danger of collapse; in many places it is flourishing at the grass roots. But 25 years after the Second Vatican Council released energies that remade a once-conservative institution into a force for worldwide change, the leadership of the American church has grown shy of innovation. While some maintain that this newly imposed doctrinal discipline is the very soul of sound churchmanship, to others it is a recipe for calamity.
There remain a number of reasons to think that the church, the country's largest denomination, could still reach beyond its walls and serve a larger social role for Catholics and non-Catholics alike. Sociologically, the church spans the gap between the center of society and the edges. Throughout the country, Catholic descendents of earlier immigrants are now ensconced in the middle and higher ranks of government, business and the professions. But the church's parishes, priests and various agencies also extend a hand in the other direction, ministering to inner-city blacks and Hispanic and Asian groups still striving to escape poverty and enter the American mainstream.
Liberal proponents of the Catholic moment like the sociologist Robert Bellah saw intimations of a wider reach for the church in the Catholic bishops' 1983 pastoral letter on nuclear defense and disarmament and in their 1986 letter on the American economy and poverty. Conservative proponents of a greater Catholic role like the Lutheran theologian Richard J. Neuhaus saw opportunities in the dynamic traditionalism of Pope John Paul II.
But the church now seems to be having a hard time living up to those expectations. When Joseph Cardinal Bernardin alluded to the Catholic moment three weeks ago, it was in a speech about politics and abortion. He did not back away from the bishops' belief that public figures who profess to be personally opposed to abortion are obliged to translate that conviction somehow into public policy. But the church, he said, should respect honest disagreement over political strategies and should make its case against abortion primarily through ''moral persuasion, not punitive measures.''
To bolster their persuasive powers in the anti-abortion struggle, the bishops, it was announced last week, are hiring two prominent public relations and polling companies. Although it may make sense for the bishops to avail themselves of the kind of expertise used by their opponents, the step was an implicit acknowledgement of the church's difficulty in defining important moral questions even for its own members, let alone for wider society.
The publicists and pollsters will have their work cut out for them. American Catholics are probably the best-educated, most independent-minded laity in the church's history. It is no wonder that many of them chafe at a church leadership that is undergoing a fundamental transformation as Pope John Paul II gradually replaces retiring or dying bishops with leaders of his own stamp - men determined to uphold centralized Vatican authority and to resist pressures for any further revisions in Catholic doctrine and practice.
Of 302 American bishops, this pope has named more than half. And the appointments are having an effect on theological debate. A 1986 draft statement on women's concerns, for example, called for further discussions of the church's stands on contraception and on ordaining women; but a revised version, released last week, underlined the prohibitions and dropped the call for discussion.
The same pattern was seen last November when a blanket condemnation of ''safe sex'' campaigns for AIDS prevention was written into a sequel to a less stringent 1987 statement. In both cases, the bishops showed themselves more concerned with avoiding ambiguity about official church positions than with seeking grounds for cooperation with those of divergent views.
Some believe this uncompromising leadership promises to consolidate the Second Vatican Council's work, to shake down and shore up an institution whose distinct identity they believe is endangered. It is the uncertain trumpet of previous leaders, they believe, that has fostered the laity's new independence.
But the new mood may demoralize many of the church's most creative clergy and alienate many of the laity. The new, blander draft of the pastoral on women's concerns, for example, will frustrate the many Catholic women increasingly impatient, even bitter, about the church's restriction of the priesthood and crucial decision making to men.
But in spite of considerable dissension, even anger, the church continues to grow in numbers, although not as fast as the American population. Catholics leave the church at rates no higher than in the past. Sunday church attendance, after dropping in the early 1970's, has held steady and remains well above the rates for non-Catholics.
The disagreement of many Catholics with official church positions on questions like birth control, divorce, the ordination of women and papal authority has been well documented and well publicized. But on questions like God's existence, the divinity of Jesus, the supernatural meaning of the Eucharist and other sacraments, traditional beliefs appear to remain strong.
In a few decades, Catholicism has had to negotiate its way through the minefields of 150 years of biblical and theological scholarship. It has come through, to this point anyway, with its central doctrines surprisingly intact.
At the parish level, where statements by bishops or even popes may have only a faint impact, observers insist that there is tremendous resilience and vitality. The Rev. Philip J. Murnion, director of the National Pastoral Life Center, said that he found Catholic parishes around the country leading the way in running shelters and soup lines, caring for the elderly, animating community groups.
Still, this grass-roots strength coexists with a daunting list of institutional problems. Many dioceses, as well as the national conference of bishops, are strapped for funds, and Catholics in several cities have witnessed the painful closing of older parishes.
In the last 15 years, almost a million Hispanic Americans have abandoned the church for Protestant denominations. There is a growing feeling that religious education programs have left younger Catholics with a diluted sense of Catholic identity. Most threatening of all, the next decade will see a drastic reduction in the number of priests.
The Rev. Andrew M. Greeley, whose studies of Catholicism earned him a reputation as a sociologist long before he became an author of popular fiction, recently summed up the contrast between such imposing problems and the apparent continuity of Catholic life. ''As an institution the Catholic Church is in terrible condition,'' he wrote, but ''the Catholic community prospers.''
Another widely traveled priest, although deeply impressed with the vigor of grass-roots Catholicism, warns that this vitality is being ''unhooked'' from the institution. ''The muscle,'' he says, ''is coming away from the skeleton.''
What does this mean for the future? Father Greeley, a harsh critic of Catholic leadership, has argued in recent writings that loyalty to the church is largely conveyed in family relationships and that, almost regardless of institutional failings, a distinctly Catholic outlook - what he calls ''the sacramental imagination'' - will perpetuate itself.
Others cannot imagine that the institutional problems, left unresolved, won't eventually undermine Catholic allegiance, belief and practice. And for problems like the shortage of priests, the loss of credibility in sexual matters or the alienation from the church of a sizable number of women, there are no ready solutions that don't fall outside the realm of what Rome considers thinkable.
For some time, the important forces in the American church - its hierarchy, its post-immigrant laity, its angry women, its new immigrants, its diminishing clergy and swelling corps of lay workers - will continue to grind against one another below the surface of Catholic life. Pressures mounting along these fault lines will regularly produce tremors. The American church is unlikely to experience the Big One. But whether the shock waves result in salutary rebuilding or whether they simply prove periodically destructive, the church will remain an earthquake zone.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Day Care Bill Marks a Turn Toward Help For the Poor

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A SWEEPING child care bill has nearly made it through Congress, and it is tempting to see in this some impulses from the Great Society. The House's 265-to-145 vote last week at least marked a sharp departure from the trends in domestic spending during the 1980's.
At a price of $27 billion over five years, the House bill would be the most expensive piece of social legislation since the 1960's. Moreover, it channels the vast bulk of benefits to low-income families. This follows a long and serious contraction of Government spending on the poor, which accompanied an expansion of entitlement programs like Social Security and Medicare that primarily benefited the middle class. 
''What we've seen is a decade of starvation of domestic social programs,'' said John L. Palmer, dean of the Maxwell School of Citizenship and Public Affairs at Syracuse University. ''The passage of the child care bill is a recognition that there are some fundamental needs that ought to be met.''
Even the criticisms by President Bush, who has threatened a veto, are largely based on disagreements over Federal regulation of state programs and the creation of a small day care program in the public schools. Mr. Bush is not questioning the need for child care. The last child care bill, passed in 1971, was vetoed by President Nixon, who said it ''threatened the sanctity'' of the American family. But between Richard Nixon and George Bush there was a big demographic change. In 1970, the Department of Labor reported that 29 percent of children under age 6 had working mothers. That figure has grown to 51 percent. The National Research Council, an arm of the National Academy of Sciences, projects that in 10 years 70 percent of preschool children will have mothers either working or looking for a job.
Currently, the largest Federal program to help working parents is the Child and Dependent Care Tax Credit, which allows families to deduct from their taxes up to 30 percent of child care costs up to $2,400 for one child and $4,800 for two or more. But if a working family does not make enough money to pay taxes it gets no benefit at all. In 1988, 77 percent of the $3.6 billion in credits went to families with annual incomes above $30,000, and 43 percent went to families making more than $50,000.
At the same time, inflation and budget cuts have shrunk the Federal Government's second-biggest child care effort, a $2.7 billion-a-year program of grants to the states for a variety of social programs, including child care, mainly for the poor.
The House's new bill, the Early Childhood and Education Act of 1990, must be reconciled in conference with the child care measure that the Senate passed by a 63-to-37 vote last June. Both provide $1.75 billion a year to the states, but the House would give them more specific marching orders: 35 percent for Head Start, for example, 35 percent to set up a new program to look after children in the public schools before and after classes. The Senate bill allows states wider discretion, so long as the money is spent on child care.
The big difference is in tax policy. The House bill relies much more heavily on an expansion of the Earned Income Tax Credit, a tax break designed for the working poor that is a particular favorite of Republicans.
Under current law, families with at least one worker but earning less than $20,270 this year can receive a maximum credit of $930. The credit is refundable, meaning that families with no tax liability get money from the Government. Under the House bill, an eligible family with three children would receive a credit of $2,218.
The Senate bill creates a refundable tax credit for health insurance costs and makes the Child and Dependent Care Tax Credit refundable for low-income families.
The theory behind expanding the earned income tax credit is that if poor parents have more money they will spend it on their children. But nothing stops them from spending it on anything else, of course, from rent to beer. ''The earned income tax credit is one of the most important anti-poverty measure today,'' said Ellen Nissenbaum, legislative director for the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities. ''It is not child care, however.''
It is also expensive. The tax credits in the House bill would cost $18.5 billion over five years. About half would be paid for by making permanent the 3 percent telephone excise tax, which is due to expire at the end of the year, and reducing the amount of the Child and Dependent Care Tax Credit and other benefits that could be claimed by families with incomes over $70,000 and eliminating these benefits for familes making more than $90,000.
Not everyone feels that asking middle- and upper-income families with children to foot much of the bill for child care for the poor is equitable. ''The question is who's going to pay for the problems of low-income people with children?'' said Eugene Steuerle, a senior fellow at the Urban Institute. ''Should it be higher-income families with children? Or should it be all higher-income families, including those who don't have children?''
The Census Bureau found that in 1986, the latest year for which complete figures are available, families making more than $45,000 a year paid on average 4 percent of their income for child care. Among poverty-level families, 22 percent of the income went to child care.
''I don't think direct help in purchasing the child care itself ought to be going to middle- and upper-income families,'' said Mr. Palmer. ''They have gotten most of the benefits during the 1980's, so they shouldn't expect to go to the front of the line now.''

HEADLINE: HEADLINERS;
Threats of Arms Jolt a City

BYLINE: By CARLYLE C. DOUGLAS

 BODY:
JUST when the term ''black militant'' was beginning to seem quaint comes Alderman Michael McGee of Milwaukee. In a stunning reminder of the country's continuing racial and economic divisions, Mr. McGee announced last week that he was forming an armed black militia that would take unspecified violent action unless the city committed $100 million to improve the lot of poor blacks.
''The only way to get respect is to be willing to use violence,'' said the Alderman, a 40-year-old former member of the Black Panther Party. ''We either stand there with our backs to the wall or we fight our way out.'' 
In a city whose recent prosperity has not extended to most black neighborhoods - 40 percent of blacks in Milwaukee live below the poverty level - Mr. McGee's words inspired some and alarmed others. ''He scares people,'' said Thomas P. Donegan, the president of the City Council, who is white.
But Mr. McGee's message was welcomed by more than 600 young blacks who packed a school auditorium meeting at which prospective militia members were signed up. Walter Farrell, a professor of educational policy and community relations at the University of Milwaukee, said blacks in poor Milwaukee neighborhoods, where unemployment runs at 25 percent, were heartened. ''What he has done is restore their dignity,'' he said.
Mr. McGee, who has established a reputation as a maverick during his six years on the City Council, represents a district with some of the poorest of the poor. Anger and resentment in the deteriorating neighborhood has heightened in recent years as the city has committed tens of millions of dollars for new professional sports facilities.
If some whites in Milwaukee were shaken, it was clear that Mr. McGee was posing no immediate threat of armed rebellion. He said he would give the city five years to come up with the sort of programs he demanded. In the meantime, he said, his militia would provide anti-crime patrols.
Though some whites in city government called for Mr. McGee's resignation, others seemed less troubled by the man and the issues he raised. Alderman John R. Kalwitz said Mr. McGee was causing ''divisiveness and dissension,'' but he also allowed as how the black Alderman had raised ''a legitimate question'' - ''Where are our priorities when you spend millions for downtown and dribbles for the neighborhood?''

HEADLINE: Social Security Still Beats Privatized Schemes

 BODY:
To the Editor:
David Boaz of the Cato Institute suggests replacing the Social Security program with private individual retirement account-type savings accounts (''Privatize Social Security,'' Op-Ed, March 21). At the heart of this proposal is the notion that workers can do much better financially by investing their payroll-tax money in the private sector.
The comparisons of retirement benefits between Social Security and private replacement plans are misleading in several ways. They depend on high real rates of return that are not sustainable over the long term that must be considered. With the 2 percent real rate of return that Social Security's board of trustees has used for intermediate estimates for years, some workers would come out ahead under a private plan - particularly those with steady work at high earnings. Others would fall behind and need to rely for retirement income on other sources. 
The benefit comparisons also assume steady lifetime earnings - and contributions - for very long periods. Mr. Boaz, for example, assumes continuous earnings from age 18 to age 67! But real workers often have periods of unemployment or reduced earnings for other reasons, like child raising and early retirement.
In those cases, Social Security protects the retirement benefit by providing ''dropout'' years; with privatization schemes, future benefits would be lost.
Another very important difference is that Social Security benefits are indexed to the cost of living. The benefits from private accounts are not and cannot be so indexed. Thus, while initial benefit amounts may be comparable, the private benefit can be expected to fall further and further behind Social Security with time.
Privatization schemes may provide advantages to high-income, steady workers who are never unemployed and do not become disabled or die young. For the majority of workers, however, Social Security is often better. Moreover, workers simply cannot know in advance whether they will be winners or losers. A 25-year-old cannot know whether he or she will be a lifetime maximum earner or become disabled at age 30 and never work again.
If Social Security were privatized, the demands on the Government to provide supplemental benefits would in many cases be irresistible, and these benefits would be expensive.
I have proposed supplementing Social Security with private savings accounts. But replacing Social Security with such accounts is neither practical nor desirable. As you said in a Feb. 22 editorial, ''schemes that sound too good to be true invariably are.'' The proposal by Mr. Boaz is no exception.
 
BRUCE D. SCHOBEL
 Louisville, Ky., March 23, 1990
 
The writer, an actuary, is principal of the Social Security division of William M. Mercer Meidinger Hansen.

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
Nobody Is Perfect

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In offices all through George Bush's Administration are men and women totally committed to him, affectionate and admiring, but who yearn for him to take the one step that national leaders find most difficult of all.
That is to do at least once in public life what every intelligent human being must do throughout his private life: concede an error and change course.
At this moment, there are at least three leaders who are entwined in mistakes that they refuse to correct.
Day by day, Mikhail Gorbachev's policy of pressuring Lithuania by using force and threatening more force diminishes confidence that he will ever deal fairly with those nationalities that feel trapped in the Soviet Union and want to get out. 
In London, Margaret Thatcher clings to a weird head tax that allows the poorest person in town the right of paying the same amount for public services as the richest. It has caused the worst British riots in decades and threatens her achievements and her party's hold on office.
In Washington, Mr. Bush cannot admit what so many of his friends in Congress and the Administration have been saying for months: appeasement of Communist China has failed and should be abandoned. So the damage continues - to his own reputation and the future of a people for whom he says he has a strong attachment.
The Bush policy of trying to placate the top leadership of the Chinese Communist Party is almost a year old - almost as old as the massacre that ended student demonstrations in Beijing.
From the beginning that policy was despised in Congress, which he knows. As time goes on it is opposed by more people within his own Administration, which, given the tendency of officials not to upset any President too much, perhaps he does not know.
The reasons he gave in the beginning are history. He promised us that being nice to the Communist leaders, dealing with them at high level, promising economic goodies, would persuade them to ease off on their own people, persuade them to try decent discourse with dissenters.
It has not happened. The decision to ''lift'' martial law was a farce. Under martial law, in a tyranny, lies just more martial law. Americans find that difficult to get through their heads.
The Chinese leaders did not react to kindness with kindness. They reacted with a kick in the American shin.
The speeches of people like Prime Minister Li Peng get nastier and nastier about the intention to eliminate remnants of freedom, and about foreigners who might object.
Everything that appeasement was supposed to accomplish has been disdainfully rejected. No, Beijing will not stop selling missiles to the Middle East.
No, Beijing will not let Fang Lizhi, the dissident who took refuge in the American Embassy, leave the country. No, Beijing will not cease persecution of intellectual dissent. The opposite: Some students found out that they will be sent to work on the farms before being allowed to open college textbooks.
This will be a hard spring for the Chinese people as the anniversary of the June massacre approaches. Beijing is nervous. Nobody is as mean as a nervous bully.
In Washington, members of Congress will resume the fight against the appeasement policy. There will be hearings on whether the Chinese Communists are illegally selling convict-made goods to this country. The Chinese Communist privilege of receiving most-favored-nation export tariffs will be questioned.
It seems to be fearfully difficult for an American President to concede that a policy is wrong and change it. Apparently whatever makes a man President prevents him from saying he is ever wrong - not a comforting thought. Historians who were consulted could not give an example of that happening.
The reasons probably are fear of repercussion and loss of pride and face. But the Chinese leadership cannot do much more to its people without bringing on another rebellion, or be more rude and rejecting to the United States.
As for loss of face, Mr. Bush can find out how false that fear is. All he has to do is invite everybody in his Administration who opposes his Chinese policy to come forward and speak frankly. He will need a bigger office.
I think they might convince him that if he says the era of appeasement is over, and speaks and acts in opposition to Beijing's repression, his face will shine brighter than ever. And there he will be in the history books, the President who knew a mistake when he saw one, even if it was his own.
